And the fact that Mycenae was a small place, or if any one of the former towns appears now to be insignificant, one must not take this as sure evidence and so rejuse to believe that the expedition against Troy was as great as the poets have asserted and the legend represents. The two clauses o(/ti . . . h)=n and ei)/ ti . . . ei)=nai must be conceived as repeated together in an understood tou/tw| to which a)kribei= shmei/w| is a pred. (Cl. gets out of ei)/ ti . . . ei)=nai a second subj. to mikro\n h)=n.) The particle me/n has no exact correlative, but the opposed statement occurs in a different form in 16. With mikro/n neut. pred. to *mukh=nai, cf. c. 138. 26; iv.76.15. G. 138, N. 2 c; H. 617. The impf. h)=n is used because Mycenae was destroyed by the Argives, B.C. 468 (Diod. xi.65.5). Strabo, viii.6.10, with exaggeration says of the site: w(/ste nu=n mhd' i)/xnos eu(ri/skesqai th=s *mukhnai/wn po/lews, whereas the ruins of Mycenae have always in modern times been regarded of archaeological importance (Curtius, Pelop. II. p. 400 ff.), and have recently awakened fresh interest from the researches of Schliemann.
mh\ gene/sqai: mh/ with inf. after a verb of denial. GMT. 95, 2, N. 1; H. 1029.
kate/xei: obtains, prevails; abs., as in c. 11. 19; with acc. c. 6. 13.

*lakedaimoni/wn ga\r kte(.: an instance to prove the fallaciousness of such reasoning. The two opt. verbs are
placed together for contrast.
th=s kataskeuh=s ta\ e)da/fh: the groundwork of the buildings. As applied to a city kataskeuh/ (see on c. 2. 12) means the public and private edifices with their internal arrangements.
pollh\n a)\n...au)tw=n ei)=nai : after the lapse of a long time great incredulity, methinks, would reign among posterity as to their power, considering their fame.

tw=n pe/nte ta\s du/o moi/ras: two fifths. See Cobet, Mnemosyne, 8, p. 68. In the expression of fractions, when the denominator exceeds the numerator by 1, the gen. is omitted; ta\ tri/a me/rh = 3/4. Cf. c. 104. 9. Otherwise the denominator stands first in the gen. as here. Hom. K 252, parw/|xwken de\ ple/wn nu\c | tw=n du/o moira/wn, trita/th d' e)/ti moi=ra le/leiptai. H. 293; Kühn. 135, 6. Cl., v. H., and B., after the Schol., think the pe/nte moi=rai the traditional five divisions of Peloponnesus, Elis with either Arcadia or Achaea being reckoned as one. Then ta\s du/o moi/ras will be Laconia and Messenia.

th=s te cumpa/shs kte(.: a general expression for the political importance of Sparta at the time of the writer; not, however, to be pressed, since Argolis and a large part of Arcadia were not under the hegemony of Sparta. pollw=n is pred., = pollw=n u)/ntwn.
po/lews : pred., since it has never been brought together into a compact city, as Athens has been. Cf. ii.15.14.

u(podeeste/ra: (not with Kr. u(podee/stera) with the subj. h( du/namis understood from th=s duna/mews in 7. So St., B., v. H., and Herbst, Philol. 16, p. 306. But Cl. supplies *lakedaimoni/wn h( po/lis, though the same subj. has just been supplied in gen. with the abs. partics. This adj. means weaker, not ‘smaller.’ Cf. c. 11. 18; ii.89.22; iii.11.15; 45. 26. The parenthesis beginning at kai/toi, 9, should be closed after u(podeeste/ra (with Bekk., St., v. H., B., Sh.), not after pollw=n, that ei)ka/zesqai, 15, may depend on oi)=mai.

paqo/ntwn : = ei) pa/qoien. GMT. 52, 1 and 110, 1; H. 902.— 16. h)\ e)/stin: as it really is, not ‘as it now is.’ The writer has in view the general importance of Athens at his time, not its condition at the end of
the whole war, or of the first ten years, as Ullrich assumes, Beitr. p. 124.
stratei/an: see App.—tw=n pro\ au)th=s: see on c. 1. 4.
leipome/nhn: remaining behind, falling below, with gen. of separation. G. 174; H. 749.—au)=: refers to c. 9. 24.

h(/n: i.e. stratei/an (not referring to poih/sei, though nearer; cf. c. 68. 15; 140. 28; 144. 25), which it is natural to suppose that he as a poet embellished to excess, but which even with this exaggeration evidently falls short. But Cobet reads o(/n, i.e. *(/omhron, referring to c. 21. 3. The subj. of fai/netai would naturally be h(/; but in Greek, when the rel. would appear in successive clauses in different cases, it is usually omitted in the second, often being represented by a dem. or pers. pron. Cf. c. 36. 2; ii.41.15. G. 156; H. 1005; Kühn. 561, 1.

pepoi/hke kte(.: for tense, see on c. 3. 17. The exact number is 1186. new=n is part. gen.; a)ndrw=n is gen. of material (G. 167. 4; H. 729) or of quality, which in Greek is nearly confined to designations of quantity or age with a numeral. Cf. Kr. Spr. 47, 8, 3, 4. For the facts, see Hom. B 510, 719.
ta/s: cf. c. 6. 1. Since the two adjs. cannot be referred to the same subj., there is no risk of confusion. Sh. compares Aesch. Ag. 314, nika=| d) o( prw=tos kai\ teleutai=os dramw/n.
gou=n : see on c. 2. 18; at any rate, i.e. whether this inference is correct or not.—pe/ri: with mnhsqh=nai, for the simple gen. Cf. c. 37. 4; v.41.9; viii.47.11.
au)tere/tai: fighting men who served also at the oar. Cf. iii.18.16; vi.91.15; here defined further by ma/ximoi.
e)n tai=s *filokth/tou : when he mentions the ships of Philoctetes. See on c. 9. 25. Cf. Hom. B 719.
proskw/pous: Schol. tou\s pro\s tai=s kw/pais nau/tas.

peri/news : Schol. tou\s perittou\s e)n th=| nhi+\ e)piba/tas, the supernumeraries who were not needed to work the ships. Boeckh, Urkunden über das Seewesen, p. 121. The word seems not to occur again before Dio Cass. (xlix.1.5).

tw=n ma/lista e)n te/lei: so ii.10.10, those highest in rank. Elsewhere simply oi( e)n te/lei, c. 90. 29; iii.36.20; iv. 65.
6; v.27.6, etc.: and in the same sense ta\ te/lh, c. 58. 8; iv.15.2; 86. 3; 88. 6. Xen. Hell. vi.5.3 has ta\ me/gista te/lh.

me/llontas : this and e)/xontas, 32, though formally agreeing with peri/news, refer really to the crews in general. The anacoluthon is rendered less striking by a)/llws te kai/, which often introduces partics. abs. or approximately so. Cf. c. 70. 2; 85. 8; ii.8.14; 16. 6; 85. 5; iii.20.18; 40. 27; 43. 14; iv.104.5; 106. 3; vii.1.10; viii.1.18.—pe/lagos: the open sea. Cf. iii.33.5; iv.24.19; vi.13.12; 34. 27; vii.49.13.
au)=: again, i.e. to use another argument bearing on this point.—kata/frakta: decked, opp. to a)/frakta.

lh|stikw/teron : rather in a piratical fashion, than in that of ships of war; the comp. expressing the existence of one quality rather than that of another. Cf. c. 49. 4; ii.83.11; vi.104.22. Kühn. 542, note 7.

pro/s: cf. 8; c. 6. 15.—d' ou)=n: the correction of Bekk. for gou=n of most Mss., adopted by St., B., Sh., v. H., serves after a digression to resume a previous statement; here that of 21. See on c. 3. 19, and cf. c. 63. 4; ii.5.28; 34. 21; vi.56.1.

to\ me/son: the mean or average; viz. 85.—skopou=nti: a dat. partic. often thus used to indicate the person who from his position, attention, or other circumstance, is likely to form a correct opinion. ‘Dat. of the observer.’ Cf. c. 21. 12; 24. 1; ii.49.17; 51. 1. G. 184, 5; H. 771 a; Kühn. 423, 25 e.— w(s...pempo/menoi : considering that they were sent; partic. impf. The impf. tenses of pe/mpein regularly combine the notion of ‘continued action’ with that of ‘outset.’ “pe/mpein has not the same notion of ‘detachment’ as our ‘send.’” Gildersleeve, Pind. Ol. 11. 23.
For there was still a great lack of means and appliances for war.
a)pori/a|: the preceding gen. serves for the art. See on c. 1. 11.
kai\ o(/son kte(.: “and only so large as they expected would find its support in the country while carrying on the war.”

e)peidh\ de/: see App.—e)kra/thsan: Cobet, Mnem. 8, p. 69, adopts the conjecture of Thiersch, e)krath/qh-
san. But the fact of one victory at least is necessary to support the general statement of 11, o)/ntes a)qro/oi . . . kratou=ntes ei(=lon. See a discussion of this question in Am. J. of Ph., V. p. 235 ff.—dh=lon de/: sc. to\ ma/xh| krath=sai au)tou/s.

to\ ga\r kte(.: for otherwise (i.e. ei) mh\ ma/xh| e)kra/thsan, cf. c. 68. 18; 102. 7; Dem. XVIII. 47, 197) they could not have raised the rampart for the camp. For ga/r, cf. c. 2. 22; 3. 2. Kr. Spr. 57, 10, 14. The rampart here spoken of cannot be that of Hom. H 337, 443. Thuc. must have found the notice of this as well as of the gewrgi/a th=s *xersonh/sou, 7, in some other poem than our Iliad. See Eustath. on Hom. E 4, and the Schol., who says, pro\s gewrgi/an, w(=n h(gei=to *)aka/mas kat' *)anti/maxon. On the necessity of a victory as a preliminary to occupation of a country, cf. vi.23.6, ou(\s pre/pei th=| prw/th| h(me/ra|, h(=| a)\n kata/sxwsin, eu)qu\s kratei=n th=s gh=s. On the aor. with a)/n to express a past potential, see Aken, Tempus und Modus, § 73; Bäumlein, Modi, p. 148; Kühn. 392 a, 4.

fai/nontai de/: de/ in apod. after a parenthesis, as in c. 18. 11; vii.33.7; viii.29.10. G. 227, 2; H. 1046 c.— ou)d' e)ntau=qa: not even then, i.e. not even after their first and promising success were they able from lack of supplies to keep their army together and prosecute the siege with vigor. Cf. Aesch. Pr. 204.
lh|stei/an: cf. Hom. A 366; 1 328.—h(=| kai/: used before a comp. adv. emphasizes an inference. Cf. c. 25. 22; ii.2.21; iii.13.13; iv.1.14.

au)tw=n: by its position = ipsorum, implies that the dispersion was due to their own needs.— ta\ de/ka e)/th: the famous ten years.— bi/a|: in the field, used by Thuc. in dat. only, as adv. to express any sort of violent effort, opp. to o(mologi/a| or cumba/sei (agreement), v.17.14; vi.47.6; to dikai/w| (judicial decision), iv.62.11; to a)pa/th| (deception), iv.86.5.

die/feron: we might have expected the aor. dih/negkon. But in unreal conditional clauses the impf. is used in Greek in opp. not only to a present state of things but to a past, if it is continued. Cf. Hdt. viii.30.5. GMT. 49, 2; H. 895 a.—r(a|di/ws a)\n ma/xh| kratou=ntes ei)=lon: this clause states that the Greeks might have successfully maintained themselves in the field, as the indispensable condition of their prosecuting the siege; the second stage being expressed in 14, poliorki/a| de\ kte(. These two clauses do not state, as Jowett says, alternative means of taking the city (cf. c. 116. 12, where proved superiority on land is merely preliminary to a siege),
but the two natural stages of the expedition. To answer poliorki/a| de/, we might have expected r(a|di/ws me/n. But there are many cases in which a de/ clause has no expressed correlative particle. Cf. c. 12. 7 (where me/n is omitted by P., B., v. H. with best Mss.); 19. 2; 56. 6; 64. 2; 86. 5; iv.7.2; Dem. XIX. 80 (*fwke/wn de/); Plat. Rep. 340 d (to\ d' oi)=mai); 398 a (ei)/poimen d' a)/n). Kühn. 531, 3. kratou=ntes includes the victory of 4, and others which would have ensued on the assumed condition. ei(=lon may be explained with Herbst, Philol. 16, 288, with ellipse of tou\s *trw=as, “would have defeated the Trojans.” Cf. for this meaning, c. 110. 6; Xen. Hell. iii.5.1; Hipparch. 5. 14. Or perhaps the verb may be used intr., “would have proved superior,” after the analogy of o( lo/gos ai(rei=. St. and v. H. omit ei(=lon, but give no satisfactory explanation of de/. The above explanation differs materially from that of Cl.

di) a)xrhmati/an kte(.: this gives the conclusion of the inquiry announced in c. 9. 29, since ta\ pro\ tou/twn (i.e. tw=n *trwikw=n) are disparaged in proportion as au)ta/ ge tau=ta (i.e. ta\ *trwika/) are shown to be of less importance than fame would lead us to expect.
tw=n pri/n: see on c. 1. 4.
toi=s e)/rgois: by the facts, i.e. by an unprejudiced inquiry into the truth of things.

katesxhko/tos: Thuc. often places an attrib. partic. after a noun which is attended by other modifiers. Cf. c. 90. 7; 96. 8; iii.54.18; 56. 5; 67. 11. So Dem. xx. 76, tau=ta e)la/ttw fanh=nai th=s e)n e(ka/stw| nu=n peri\ au)tou= do/chs u(parxou/shs. XVIII. 126.
Even the Trojan war was followed by movements of population in Greece, and then by systematic colonization.

e)pei/: since, for. The causes which impeded the development of Hellenic power continued, in some respects, in operation even after the Trojan war; and this fact is a further indication of the truth of the inference in c. 11. § 3.—h( *(ella\s...au)chqh=nai : Greece was still subject to changes and the establishment of new states, so that it did not get rest (aor. as in c. 3. 8) and so increase. See App.

xroni/a: (elsewhere in Thuc. of two terminations) pred. adj. used adv., after a long time. Cf. c. 4. 1; 141. 30; ii.49.29; vi.31.16. G. 138, N. 7; H.
619.

kai\ sta/seis...e)gi/gnonto : the kai/ in correlation with the previous te shows that the sta/seis here spoken of are not, with the Schol., to be regarded as results of the Trojan war, but are the movements, presently mentioned, which were caused by the pressure of the Thessalians. w(s e)pi\ polu/, as a rule, in many instances. See App.

a)f) w(=n...e)/ktizon : a)po/, in consequence of, of the remote, not the immediate, cause. Cf. c. 17. 4; 24. 10. Since e)kpi/ptein is regularly used as the pass. to e)kba/llein, to express the forced departure of a defeated faction, Cobet wishes to read u(f) for a)f). An indef. subj., men, must be supplied. ta/s with po/leis implies those of which current tradition makes report. But Madvig conjectures ne/as, and v. H. a)/llas.
oi( nu=n: i.e. those occupying the present land of Boeotia.—e(chkostw=| e)/tei: acc. to the common date of the fall of Troy, B.C. 1124.

*)/arnhs: the old home of the Aeolian Boeotians near the Gulf of Pagasae. The Boeotian Arne mentioned Hom. B 507, of doubtful position, probably near Coronea, was named from it.—a)nasta/ntes: the regular term for forcible removal. The act. in ii.27.1.

w)/|kisan: St. reads w)/|khsan (also B., Kr., v. H.) on the ground that oi)ki/sai de regionum vel urbium aut primis aut novis incolis dicitur—oi)kh=sai quod in universum sedes collocare significat, de condendis urbibus dicinequit. Cl. admits this distinction, but retains w)/|kisan, because, though Thuc. conceived some Boeotians to have settled earlier in Boeotia, the ones now spoken of must be regarded as novi incolae.—h)=n de\...e)stra/teusan : an attempt to reconcile Hom. B 494 ff., which mentions Boeotians who went to the Trojan war, with the tradition that the Aeolic migration into Boeotia took place sixty years after it. But an a)podasmo/s could not fill all the places mentioned in the catalogue as Boeotian; and this so far confirms the judgment of recent criticism, that the new=n kata/logos is one of the latest additions to the Iliad. In a)f' w(=n the reference is to the collective a)podasmo/s.
*dwrih=s te : the particles te . . . te unite *boiwtoi\ kte(. and *dwrih=s kte(. on an equal footing (c. 8. 14), as illustrations of the want of stability in Hellas.
e)/sxon: aor. as in c. 3. 8. This is the only second aor. which appears to be used ingressively, “the pres. which is ‘process’ of holding connoting ‘state.’ See note on Pind. Ol. 11. 10.” B. L. G.
ou)ke/ti a)nistame/nh: partic. impf., being no longer subject to these violent changes of inhabitants.

w)/|kisan: with acc. of persons, here and in vi.4.8; rare in prose. Cf. Pind. Is. VIII. 22; Soph. O. C. 785; Eur. Hec. 1022; I. A. 1293.—*)itali/as: used by Thuc. only of the peninsula south of the river Laus and Metapontum; cf. vi.2.19; vii.33.21; whereas Campania belongs to *)opiki/a, vi.4.25; and therefore to\ plei=ston may be taken in its proper sense.

th=s te a)/llhs *(ella/dos kte(.: see on c. 1. 6. Notice the rare use of te to connect two single notions. See on c. 60. 8. Kühn. 519, 2. The many settlements of the Corinthians in the islands and on the coast of the Ionian gulf are referred to.
pa/nta de\ tau=ta kte(.: these words refer to the settlements made after the migrations above mentioned had ceased.
Advance is now made in maritime skill, particularly by Corinth, and, among the Ionians, by Samos and Phocuea.

e)/ti ma=llon h)\ pro/teron: the reference is to c. 8. 11, where a similar statement is made as to the time before the Trojan war. e)/ti is therefore significant, and not to be changed to ti or h)/dh, as Kr. proposes.

ta\ polla/: adv. often. Cf. c. 78. 5; 122. 5; ii.11.17; 87. 26; iii.37.22.—turanni/des: the despotisms here spoken of differed in their origin from those of which that of Pisistratus was a type; as a government, legal in its origin, might be converted into a turanni/s by an illegal and forcible extension of its powers. This is stated by Arist. Pol. viii.10.5, when, after describing the usual growth of despotisms (oi( plei=stoi tw=n tura/nnwn gego/nasin e)k dhmagwgw=n), he says: ai( de\ pro\ tou/twn e)k tw=n basile/wn parekbaino/ntwn ta\ pa/tria kai\ despotikwte/ras a)rxh=s o)regome/nwn.

e)pi\ r(htoi=s ge/rasi : with defined prerogatives; e)pi/ with dat. of the condition and basis of established order. Cf. Arist. Pol. iii.14.14, h( peri\ tou\s h(rwi+kou\s xro/nous [basilei/a] . . . h)=n e(ko/ntwn me\n e)pi/ tisi d) w(risme/nois: strathgo\s ga\r h)=n kai\ dikasth\s o( basileu/s, kai\ tw=n pro\s tou\s qeou\s ku/rios.

patrikai\ basilei=ai : hereditary monarchies (cf. vii.69.12; viii.6.17, of ties of friendship, etc.), passing from father to son.—e)chrtu/eto: of naval preparations; usually mid. Cf. c. 14. 4; 25. 23; 121. 7; ii.13.19; 85. 11, etc.
Act. with e)pi/ploun, ii.17.21.
a)ntei/xonto: applied themselves. For pl. following sing., cf. iii.72.8. Kühn. 359, 2.

prw=toi de\ *kori/nqioi kte(.: the view which Thuc. now gives of the development of Greek maritime power (to the end of c. 14) comprises the period from 700 to 500 B.C., including the advances made by the Corinthians, the Ionians, the tyrants in Sicily, and the Corcyraeans, to the development of the Athenian navy under Themistocles. See App.

tou= nu=n tro/pou: opp. to the palaio\s tro/pos of c. 10. 31. —metaxeiri/sai: used only act. by Thuc. Cf. iv.18.14; vi.12.17; 16. 31; vii.87.2. Later chiefly mid.— 8. kai\ trih/reis...nauphghqh=nai : and it is said that Corinth was the first place in Greece where triremes were built. Part. gen. with a sup. adv. G. 168; H. 755 b; Kr. Spr. 47, 28, 8. This probably represents a further advance on the previous statement, prw=toi . . . ta\s nau=s.

fai/netai de\ kte(.: since it was a Corinthian shipwright who constructed ships of war (nau=s, probably not triremes; cf. c. 14. 4) for the Samians, we have a second indication of the early prominence of the Corinthians. The third is introduced by te, 12. See on c. 2. 6.

ma/lista: used with statements of quantity to imply that the account given is the best practicable approximation, though the reality may be either more or less.—tou=de tou= pole/mou: on the import of this expression, see Introd., p. 24. The two events dated must have occurred respectively in B.C. 704 and 664.

o(/te: since the time when = e)c or a)f' ou(=, as in c. 18. 9. So to express the terminus a quo we have w(s in iv.90.14, and in v.20.4, where h)/ is perhaps to be omitted; e)peidh/, iii.68.31 (cf. c. 6. 9); e)pei/, Eur. Med. 26; Hipp. 34; I. T. 258. Kr. Dial. 69, 56, 2. In iii.29.9, o(/te gives the terminus ad quem, till.—h)=lqe: with dat. Cf. c. 27. 1; 61. 1; 107. 27; iii.70.2; vi.46.12; vii.73.5; viii.96.1; Plat. Prot. 321 c.
palaita/th: see on c. 1. 11.
gi/gnetai: here and in 24 the pres. is not hist., but represents the vision of the historical inquirer.

e)sti : here
and in 11 represents the result of a calculation. So h)=san in iii.29.9.

a)ei\ dh/ pote: from the very earliest times. The indef. pote extends the notion of a)ei/ over an unlimited past (cf. c. 47. 10; 60. 9; iv.103.11, etc.; Hdt. ix.26.5), and receives additional emphasis from dh/, as in viii.73.26.— 17. ta\ plei/w: usually in comp. sense without the art., as in c. 3. 23. Cf. with this Soph. Ant. 313; Eur. Hipp. 471. Kr. Spr. 50, 4, 13. Commonly the phrase has a sup. meaning. Cf. c. 69. 27; 81. 8; ii.39.14; 89. 8; iii.37.26; 83. 8.
tw=n te...e)/cw : appos. to tw=n *(ellh/nwn. See on c. 2. 24.— 19. par' a)llh/lous: see on c. 2. 5.— xrh/masi/ te: with e)peidh/ te, 21, of the successive stages of progress. See on c. 12. 10.

a)fneio/n: cf. Hom. B 570. So Pind. Ol. XIII. 4 calls Corinth o)lbi/a, and Hdt. iii.52.14, eu)dai/mwn.— 22. e)/plw|zon : poetic verb (cf. Hes. Op. 634); i.e. ploi+mw/tera e)gi/gneto, c. 8. 8.— tas nau=s: i.e. those above mentioned. —kaqh/|roun: sc. oi( *kori/nqioi, as the following words show.

a)mfo/tera: not now, as in 17, kata\ gh=n ta\ plei/w, but on both elements, = kata\ gh=n kai\ kata\ qa/lassan. Cf. c. 100. 4; 112. 11, etc.—dunath\n e)/sxon kte(.: the aor. sums up the results of their efforts, = h( po/lis au)tw=n dunath\ e)ge/neto.

*)/iwsin u(/steron kte(.: cf. Hdt. i. 161 ff. This statement refers chiefly to Miletus and Chios, since Samos and Phocaea are specially mentioned afterwards. As Thuc. does not elsewhere date by the Persian kings, Köhler, Archae. d. Th. p. 7 (see App.) justly infers that he is here using Hdt. as his authority. The dates are, Cyrus, B.C. 559-529; Cambyses, B.C. 529-522.

ui(e/os: this form of the gen. also c. 137. 2; ii.100.14; iii.26.8; but ui(ou=, v.16.24. The nom. and acc. sing. are of the second decl. only, as c. 111. 1; ii.29.24; 67. 15, etc., and the pl. cases, acc. and gen., only of the third, as c. 20. 7; vi.30.12.
e)kra/thsan: the aor. is not ingressive (cf. c. 3. 8; 4. 2) but complexive, they maintained their power.

turannw=n: not tu-
rannh/sas, for his despotism began under Cyrus, about B.C. 532, and he was killed in the year of Cambyses's death, B.C. 522. Cf. Hdt. iii. 120 ff.
*(rh/neian kte(.: cf. iii.104.8.

*fwkah=s te...naumaxou=ntes : Massalia (Marseilles) was founded by the Phocaeans, B.C. 600. The city of Phocaea was itself taken by Harpagus, the Persian commander, cir. B.C. 543, at which time half the population abandoned the place, and sailing westward to Corsica, fought a successful but ruinous battle against the combined fleets of the Carthaginians and the Tyrrhenians (Hdt. i. 166). Thuc. is probably not referring to this battle, but to repeated successes (e)ni/kwn) over the Carthaginians, who would be likely to resist any attempt to found a settlement on the Gallic coast. Antiochus of Syracuse may have been his authority for this statement. Even if the dates did not conflict, the tense e)ni/kwn, which denotes the victory and its enduring results (cf. c. 49. 24; 100. 3; 116. 10; iii.108.10, etc.) could hardly be used to denote the *kadmei/h ni/kh of the Phocaeans. See App.
Still it was only slowly and by degrees that progress was made.
dunatw/tata ga\r kte(.: not the reason of the preceding thought, but of the mention of the particular states named in last chap.
fai/netai: to be joined with xrw/mena and e)chrtume/na.

pollai=s...*trwikw=n : though these naval powers arose many generations after the Trojan war.— 5. ploi/ois makroi=s: ploi=a usually opp. to war-ships, particularly to triremes, which are often called nh=es simply. Cf. ii.84.7; iv.116.5; vi.65.14. Here the epithet makroi=s marks them as ships of war, though except in size they probably differed little from trading vessels. Kr. refers to Hdt. vii.21.9, where he speaks of makra\s ne/as as furnished for Xerxes's bridge, to show that the epithet does not always have this force; but ibid. 36. 3 the same vessels are spoken of as penthkonte/rous kai\ trih/reas.
w(/sper e)kei=na : i.e. ta\ kata\ ta\ *trwika\ nautika/.
o)li/gon te: see on c. 2. 6.
tou= *darei/ou qana/tou: B.C. 485.

e)basi/leuse: see on c. 3. 8.—peri\ *sikeli/an: see on c. 5. 17. Reference is made to Gelo, Hiero, and probably also to Anaxilas of Rhegium.—toi=s tura/nnois...e)ge/nonto : cf. c. 13. 24. e)s plh=qos, in numbers, = pollai/; usually plh/qei, as in ii.11.12; viii.22.3. Cf.
Ar. Ach. 688, e)s ta/xos pai/ei.
tau=ta : the Sicilian and Corcyraean navies. The subj. is conformed to the pred. nautika\ a)cio/loga. teleutai=a is adv. See on c. 12. 3.

braxe/a: of trifling importance. Cf. c. 74. 22; 117. 12; 130. 9; 141. 4, etc.—ta\ polla/: agrees formally with the preceding whole (ta\ nautika/), but really refers only to a part to which penthkonto/rous is pred. The penthko/ntoros had on each side 25 oarsmen arranged horizontally.

o)ye/ te a)f' ou(=: the event spoken of (e)/peise *qemistoklh=s) stands at a point between the Trojan war and the time of the historian. Looking from the former one might say o)ye\ e)/peisen; looking from the latter, ou) polu\s xro/nos a)f' ou(= e)/peisen. Cl. considers the expression in the text as a mixture of the two. Such a su/gxusis might easily occur in a long and complex period, but is hardly credible when the words stand close together. Kr. and v. H. bracket a)f' ou(=, and Sh. suggests that e)ke/kthnto may be repeated after o)ye/.— 13. *ai)ginh/tais polemou=ntas : no doubt the war mentioned in c. 41. 6; Hdt. vi. 87 ff., which was perhaps before the battle of Marathon (B.C. 490), though the invasion of Xerxes (B.C. 480) is referred to in the following lines. Hdt., vii. 144, himself says that the advice of Themistocles was given before the alarm caused by Xerxes' invasion. See Grote, IV. c. 39, p. 399, on the importance to Athens of this interval and its causes.—kai\ a(/ma: with o)/ntos. See on c. 2. 8; 9. 20.

ta\s nau=s: the well-known fleet; 100 triremes, acc. to Plut. Them. 4. 2; 200 acc. to Hdt. vii.144.8.—ai(=sper kai\ e)nauma/xhsan: with which they actually fought as he intended. Cf. c. 137. 2; ii.86.7.

kai\ au(=tai kte(.: referring to c. 10. 31, ou)de\ ta\ ploi=a kata/frakta e)/xontas, and showing an advance since the Trojan times, though not an entire change. The completion of the deck was due to Cimon. Cf. Plut. Cim. 12. 3: e)kei=nos to/te platute/ras e)poi/hse ta\s trih/reis kai\ dia/basin toi=s katastrw/masin e)/dwken, w(s a)\n u(po\ pollw=n o(plitw=n maximw/terai prosfe/rointo toi=s polemi/ois. With dia\ pa/shs, throughout, no definite word is to be supplied. Cf. a)po\ th=s i)/shs, c. 15. 11; e)pi\ th=| i)/sh| kai\ o(moi/a|, c. 27. 3; a)po\ prw/ths, c. 77. 11; with art., vii.43.35; dia\ kenh=s, iv.126.22.
Of still less importance were the wars waged in early times on land.
toiau=ta: i.e. of small importance as compared with those of later times.

i)sxu\n de\ kte(.: i.e. though they were on a small scale, still those who paid attention to them gained greatly in wealth and power. Cf. c. 8. 11; 13. 1. On the spelling of prossxo/ntes, see App.; and for the meaning, cf. vii.4.22. au)toi=s = toi=s nautikoi=s.— 5. o(/soi mh\...xw/ran : refers chiefly, perhaps exclusively, to the Athenians. Cf. c. 2. 26.

kata\ gh=n de\ po/lemos kte(.: the remainder of the chapter states the natural inference to which the discussion in c. 4-14 leads, that only the sea could be the adequate scene of Hellenic development.—o(/qen tis kai\ du/namis parege/neto: from which any considerable amount of power resulted. Cl. and Kr. consider the meaning to be, “in consequence of which any large force was placed in the field,” the latter saying that prosege/neto would have been used for the meaning given above. But cf. Xen. Mem. iv.2.2, to\ proesta/nai po/lews . . . paragi/gnesqai toi=s a)nqrw/pois. Plat. Theaet. 197 c. du/namin au)tw=| peri\ au)ta\s paragegone/nai. Men. 99 e; Legg. 732 d. Besides for the latter meaning we should expect e)s o(n rather than o(/qen. Under the influence of the neg. ou)dei\s cune/sth there is no need of a)/n with parege/neto, as potential of the past, though v. H. reads ka)/n. Cf. Xen. Hell. vii.5.17, ou)de\n ou(/tw braxu\ o(/plon e(ka/teroi ei)=xon w(=| ou)k e)ciknou=nto a)llh/lwn. Isae. VI. 11.

cune/sth: implies the meeting of the parties engaged more forcibly than kate/sth. Cf. iv.78.29; vi.85.15.— o(/soi kai\ e)ge/nonto: as many as did occur; the ‘emphasis-giving’ kai/, as in 6, often implies that a thing, the reality of which might be doubted, did take place. Cf. c. 97. 11; 105. 17; ii.51.21; iii.67.4.
tou\s sfete/rous: on the position, see on c. 1. 6. The refl. refers to a subj. implied in e(ka/stois.
stratei/as...e)ch=|san : see App. on c. 3. 22.
th=s e(autw=n: sc. gh=s. Cf. c. 44. 8; 142. 11.— 10. cuneisth/kesan...u(ph/kooi : cf. c. 1. 6.

ou)d) au)=...e)poiou=nto : here the second mode of combining a large force is referred to, through a free
alliance resting on equal rights, au)toi\ a)po\ th=s i)/shs. Cf. iii.40.31.
kat' a)llh/lous: connected with the distributive w(s e(/kastoi (sc. e)pole/moun), “their wars were only the wars of the several neighbouring tribes, one with another.” Jowett.

ma/lista: i.e. within the time preceding the Peloponnesian war.— e)s to\n pa/lai kte(.: the war for the possession of the *lh/lanton pedi/on between Chalcis and Eretria. Cf. Hdt. v. 99; Strab. x.1.11; Grote, III. c. 12, p. 170. Curtius, Herm. 10, p. 220 ff., gives good reason for placing this in the eighth rather than in the seventh century.
*)eretriw=n: on the spelling, see App.
The Ionians especially were hindered in their progress by the extension of the Persian power.

e)pege/neto: came upon, happened, from the outside. This verb is often used of what is unexpected and disastrous, as in ii.58.8; vii.87.14; viii.96.8; and therefore of destructive natural phenomena, as in ii.4.8; 77. 20; iv.3.7; viii.34.4.
a)/lloqi: not here local, but of circumstances, relations, aliis rerum condicionibus. Cf. Plat. Symp. 184 e, monaxou= e)ntau=qa sumpi/ptei . . . a)/lloqi de\ ou)damou=.

mh\ au)chqh=nai : the Vat. Ms. has tou=, other Mss. tou= mh/, before the inf. We might have had the simple inf. as in iv.67.24. GMT. 92, 1, N. 2; 95, 2; H. 1029.—kai\ *)/iwsi: should after a)/llois te depend on e)pege/neto, but is dat. of interest with the partic. clause, and is felt again with e)pestra/teuse. For similar irregularity from apparent displacement of te, cf. c. 53. 7; 77. 24; 129. 5; iii.94.17; iv.28.19; 52. 5; 85. 11; 127. 12; Hom. *w 632. e)pistrateu/ein has dat. in c. 107. 25; iii.54.8; but acc. in iv.60.10; 92. 26.—proxwrhsa/ntwn...pragma/twn : refers to the Ionians, not, as the Schol. says, to the Persians.— 3. h( *persikh\ basilei/a: in a concrete sense, the Persian empire, as in ii.97.25, of the Odrysian kingdom. The reading e)cousi/a of inferior Mss., adopted by St., P., B., v. H., is not a suitable word for an absolute monarchy.

kaqelou=sa: (see on c. 4. 6) has the double obj. *kroi=son (B.C. 549) and o(/sa . . . qa/lassan (sc. e)sti/, as ei)si/ in ii.97.25). Cf. Hdt. i. 71 ff.—e)nto\s *(/aluos potamou=: on the west side of the Halys, from the point of view of the Greeks; pro\s qa/lassan from that of the Persians. The generic name is often thus joined with the special, which takes the attrib. position. Cf.
ii.97.3; iv.102.3; vi.4.2.

*darei=os de\ kte(.: acc. to Hdt. i. 169, the Ionians, oi( ta\s nh/sous e)/xontes, i.e. the Chians and Samians (c. 142), had surrendered to Cyrus. But Thuc. is probably right in placing their subjugation after the battle of Lade (B.C. 494?). Cf. Hdt. vi. 7-17.
The tyrants also in the Greek states employed their power in no important wars.

tu/rannoi de\ kte(.: we have here the last of the tekmh/ria for the time before the Persian war. See note at end of c. 2. The position of tu/rannoi (without art. before the attrib. rel. sentence, nearly = o(/soi e)tura/nneuon) reminds us of the previous mention of turanni/des in c. 13. 3.

proorw/menoi: the Attic prose writers often use the mid. of compounds of o(ra=n, chiefly of intellectual perception. Kühn. 374, 3.—e)/s te...au)/cein : the two aspects of to\ e)f' e(autw=n (their own interest), their personal security (cf. vi.9.8) and the aggrandizement of their families.— 3. di) a)sfalei/as...w)/|koun : administered their states (cf. iii.37.18; viii.67.6) in the way of the greatest attainable security. For dia/, cf. c. 40. 16; 73. 13; ii.64.2.

a)p' au)tw=n: as the result of their rule. The execution might be by others. So a)po/ is frequently used with pra/ssesqai, cf. iv.76.4; vi.61.6; viii.48.46; 68. 24; with le/gesqai, iii.36.24; 82. 41; vi.32.18, in all of which Cobet (V. L. p. 276) would read u(po/. But see Herbst gegen Cobet, p. 49, who says, u(po/ dicitur de ipso actore, a)po/ de auctore. Sh. asks: “Why should copyists constantly change u(po/ into a)po/ after such verbs, and very rarely after others?”

ei) mh/ ti: with the Vat. and other good Mss. for ei) mh\ ei)/ ti, which is not found elsewhere in Thuc.—pro\s perioi/kous...e(ka/stois : on the order, see on c. 1. 6. e(ka/stois is not to be connected with e)pra/xqh, but with perioi/kous tou\s au(tw=n (though the gen. would be more regular), emphasizing the separate instances.
oi( ga\r kte(.: see App.

ou(/tw pantaxo/qen kte(.: refers generally to the causes which hindered the rapid growth of Greek power, enumerated in c. 2 ff., before the Persian war, to which we pass in c. 18. katei/xeto, was
held back, checked. Cf. ii.65.33; iii.62.13. With w(/ste mh/, iv.130.27; Hdt. viii.57.9. With simple inf. probably here only. On the neg., see GMT. 95, 2; H. 1029. The second clause, kata\ po/leis . . . ei)=nai, contains the neg. in a)tolmote/ra, = mh/te kata\ po/leis tolmhro/tero/n ti pra/ssein. fanero/n here = e)pifane/s, a)cio/logon. Cf. Xen. Cyr. vii.5.58.
Soon after came the Persian wars. Athens and Sparta, after a brief alliance, fell into hostility, and each strove to augment her own power.
Chaps. 18 and 19 show that even the recent occurrences (ta\ pro\ au)tw=n, c. 1. 10) were important chiefly as preparations for the Peloponnesian war.

oi( e)k th=s *(ella/dos: followed by the supplementary description plei=stoi kai\ teleutai=oi with repeated art. Cf. c. 2. 24; 23. 17; 108. 12; iii.23.8. e)k th=s *(ella/dos is a proleptic attrib., caused by katelu/qhsan. See on c. 8. 9.

e)pi\ polu\...turanneuqei/shs : for the order, see on c. 11. 19. e)pi\ polu/, generally, in local sense. Cf. ii.34.24. kai\ pri/n, even earlier than Athens. Before pri/n or pro/teron, kai/ = h)/dh. Cf. v.14.19; vi.88.23; vii.15.16; 68. 16.

plh\n tw=n e)n *sikeli/a|: an exception to teleutai=oi. In Sicily they maintained themselves to a later time. Besides the expulsion of the Pisistratidae (B.C. 510; cf. Hdt. v. 65) by Spartan help, we know only that after the death of Periander in Corinth (B.C. 585), of Clisthenes in Sicyon (B.C. 570), and of Theagenes in Megara (about B.C. 510), the Lacedaemonians favoured the restoration of the older order of things, and made an unsuccessful attack on Polycrates of Samos, about B.C. 525 (Hdt. iii. 39, 56). Therefore the words oi( tu/rannoi . . . katelu/qhsan are to be understood generally in the sense of the words in 10, ta\ e)n tai=s a)/llais po/lesi kaqi/stasan. Cf. Arist. Pol. viii.10.30 (1312 b 7), *lakedaimo/nioi plei/stas kate/lusan turanni/das. See Curtius, Hist. of Greece, I. p. 422.

e)pi\ plei=ston xro/non: i.e. down to the legislation of Lycurgus, which Thuc. places about B.C. 820 (Eratosthenes, 884); and so the unsettled period must have lasted two or three hundred years. Hdt. i. 65 agrees as to the fact. See Grote, II. c. 6, p. 340.

w(=n i)/smen: common in the historians with sup. or mo/nos (cf. Hdt. i.142.3; 178. 12; ii.68.7; iii.60.15; iv.152.13; 197. 5, etc.); assimilated to an antec., usually obvious; as in c. 4. 1; 13. 13; here probably pasw=n po/lewn is to be supplied.—e)k palaiota/tou: after the longest period of disturbance Sparta was the earliest to reach a settled state; implied by the aor. hu)nomh/qh, to which is attached, as a natural result, a)tura/nneutos h)=n. On this eu)nomi/a see C. Wachsmuth, Jahrbb. 14, p. 9.
ma/lista: see on c. 13. 11.
tou=de tou= pole/mou: see Introd. p. 24.
di) au)to/: the condition described in 7. The subj. of the rel. clause is to be repeated with kaqi/stasan.
duna/menoi : = me/ga duna/menoi. Cf. c. 33. 20.

kaqi/stasan: act., implying ‘among and for others.’ The mid., ‘at home’ or ‘for their own interest.’ Cf. c. 76. 2; 118. 8; ii.6.3; iii.18.6; 28. 17; 35. 7.—meta\ de\ th\n...kata/lusin : a brief repetition of 1, e)peidh\ kte(. On the repeated de/, see on c. 11. 6.
e)k th=s *(ella/dos: for position, see on c. 11. 19.
e)n *maraqw=ni: see App.
tw=| mega/lw| sto/lw|: as the current designation of the expedition of Xerxes.
doulwso/menos: in c. 16. 6 the act. e)dou/lwse has in view rather the sufferings of the conquered than the interests of the conqueror.

cumpolemhsa/ntwn...h(gh/santo : aor., as in c. 3. 8; 4. 2; 14. 6 (joined in the war . . . took the lead). But h(gou=nto in c. 19. 2, they held the hegemony. The gen. implies that their control was normal or rightful.

duna/mei prou/xontes: by the same natural law that had placed Agamemnon at the head of the Trojan expedition, c. 9. 1. It was on a similar basis of superior force already existing (c. 14. 12) that the Athenians after the second Persian war established their claim to leadership.

dianohqe/ntes: this partic. and e)sba/ntes stand on a par as conditions of nautikoi\ e)ge/nonto, but a)naskeuasa/menoi(ta\ skeu/h a)nalabo/ntes, Schol.) is subordinate to e)sba/ntes as the necessary preliminary. dianohqh=nai, resolve (c. 141. 2; iv.13.16; vii.40.17), dianoei=sqai, have a mind.
e)sba/ntes: for e)mba/ntes. See App.
koinh=| te: and so by joint effort. Cf. c. 4. 5.

diekri/qhsan: = die/-
sthsan. Cf. 28; c. 15. 16. The subj. to a)pwsa/menoi must be oi(/ te *lakedaimo/nioi kai\ oi( *)aqhnai=oi with their allies; but the allies alone form the subj. of diekri/qhsan, and there are included also those who were set free from the Persian yoke by the battle of Salamis; and so to the subj. thus extended oi(/ te a)posta/ntes . . . cumpolemh/santes is an explanatory appos. (cf. c. 2. 24; 13. 18), while the Athenians and Lacedaemonians now stand in obj. relation. Cf. ii.16.4; iii.10.17; 23. 8; 53. 17, for a similar change of subj.
tau=ta: these states. Cf. tw=n nautikw=n, c. 14. 2.—diefa/nh: had shown themselves among all. Cf. ii.51.9; iv.108.20; vi.17.20.

cune/meinen, e)pole/mhsan : complexive aors., as in c. 6. 3. The latter refers to the struggle in B.C. 458-440, recorded in c. 107-115.—o(maixmi/a: here only in Thuc. In Hdt. vii.145.11; viii.140.23. But o(/maixmos is used by the Plataean speaker in iii.58.19.

diastai=en: the iterative opt. after ei)(o(po/te, e)peidh/), followed as usual by the impf. GMT. 51; H. 894, 2. Cf. c. 49. 14; ii.10.5; vii.71.11. —h)/dh: now, by this time, the conditions described in c. 15. § 2 being now changed.

w(/ste kte(.: from hence to the end of the next chapter it is shown that the rivalry of the Athenians and Lacedaemonians after the Persian war caused the full development of their powers; and from this, with the increase of means of war, follows the preponderant importance of the Peloponnesian war.— a)ei/: belongs in effect to the following partics. as well as the finite verbs pareskeua/santo and e)ge/nonto.
spendo/menoi : by concluding truces, polemou=ntes, by waging war. For ta\ me\n . . . ta\ de/, cf. ii.46.2.
a)fistame/nois: = o(po/te a)fistai=nto. GMT. 109, 6; H. 902. Cf. c. 99. 13, and the whole of c. 89-118, where are the proofs of the brief statements here made.
The hegemony of the Lacedaemonians differed from that of the Athenians.

u(potelei=s fo/rou: so c. 56. 7; 66. 6; 80. 14; vii.57.13. Without fo/rou,
ii.9.15; v.111.20; vii.57.23, but just before fo/rw| u(ph/kooi in the same sense.

h(gou=nto: abs., maintained their hegemony. Cf. c. 77. 23; iii.10.13.—kat) o)ligarxi/an...qerapeu/ontes : see App. kat' o)ligarxi/an belongs to politeu/sousi (cf. iii.62.8); the intervening words show that the object was to further the interests of the Lacedaemonians only, not those of the smaller states. Cf. c. 144. 13; iv.76.28; v.81.6; Lys. XIII 51. Elsewhere Thuc. joins qerapeu/ein with inf. (cf. vi.61.25; vii.70.20), here with o(/pws, like skopei=n, e)pimelei=sqai, after which verbs the fut. indic. seems preferable to the aor. subjv., though the Mss. vary greatly. Cf. c. 56. 3; 57. 21; 82. 24. GMT. 45; H. 885.

paralabo/ntes: i.e. causing to be delivered to them (paradou=nai is used of the allies themselves in c. 101. 13), while they increased their own fleet by the tribute exacted subsequently. Cf. c. 99. § 3. —*lesbi/wn: these lost their independence after their revolt, B.C. 427. Cf. iii.50.5, where the same phrase is used.

kai\ e)ge/neto au)toi=s kte(.: Cl. follows Grote, V. c. 44. p. 117, in understanding Thuc. to say that the power both of Sparta and of Athens was greater at the beginning of the Peloponnesian war than that of both together during the short time that the o(maixmi/a lasted. See App. ta\ kra/tista is adv. with h)/nqhsan. Cf. c. 31. 4; ta\ pro/tera, c. 2. 2; ta\ plei/w, c. 13. 17; ta\ teleutai=a, c. 24. 12. The position of a)kraifnou=s gives it the effect of a temporal sentence. The word occurs in c. 52. 8; not elsewhere in Att. prose.
But men often judge of past events without thorough inquiry.

hu(=ron: see on c. 1. 11.—xalepa\...pisteu=sai : Sh. renders, albeit difficult for one, hardly allowing one, to give credit to every link in the chain of argument; the const. being that by which in Greek an adj. is used pers. when the impers. is more natural to us (H. 944; Kühn. 477 d) = kai/per xalepo\n o)\n e)moi\ pisteu=sai au)ta\ panti\ e(ch=s tekmhri/w| (cf. Eur. Hel. 710, lo/gois d' e)moi=si pi/steuson ta/de). It is probable that pa=n e(ch=s tekmh/rion means the series of tekmh/ria actually alleged by Thuc.; but Cl. thinks it means every point of evidence, without exception, which presents itself. We find e(ch=s with pa=s in the sing. only in Dem. IX. 69, to/te xrh\ kai\
nau/thn . . . kai\ pa/nt' a)/ndra e(ch=s proqu/mous ei)=nai; in pl. in vii.29.21 and Dem. xxiv. 70.

a)koa/s: here in objective sense, the things heard. So ii.41.8 (cf. Tac. Ann. iv. 11, ut falsas auditiones depellerem); elsewhere in Thuc. subjective, ‘hearing,’ ‘apprehension.’ Cf. c. 4. 1; 23. 10; iii.38.31; iv.126.15, 33; vi.17.23.— sfi/sin: in a dependent sentence refers to the subj. of the primary. Cf. c. 115. 23; iii.108.14; vi.32.9.— 4. o(moi/ws: i.e. as much as if the events had taken place among strangers, when a failure to examine would be more excusable. Cf. vii.68.14.

gou=n: see on c. 2. 18; so for instance.—to\ plh=qos...a)poqanei=n : the popular belief which Thuc. opposes here, and more fully in vi. 55, was probably founded on ballads and erroneous views about the statues in honour of Harmodius and Aristogeiton. Hdt. v. 55; vi. 123 agrees with Thuc. The principal stress lies on tu/rannon o)/nta, just as in 7 presbu/tatos w)/n gives the reason for h)=rxe. So in 9, u(potoph/santes stands at the head of its clause, since the failure was due to this mistaken suspicion.

u(potoph/santes: a rare verb, used by Thuc. only in aor., and only in partic., except in iii.24.4 inf. (for in v.35.14; viii.76.6, u(pw/pteuon is the true reading). Hdt. vi.70.4; ix.116.15 has aor. pass. with act. meaning. The mid. occurs in Ar. Ran. 958; Thesm. 496; and in Lys. IX 4.—kai\ paraxrh=ma: at the very moment of execution (precisely para\ to\ xrh=ma), a more exact definition than e)kei/nh| th=| h(me/ra|, on that (famous) day.— 10. e)k tw=n...memhnu=sqai : Sh. renders, that information had been conveyed from the body of their fellow-conspirators. e)k would not have been joined with the sing. Cf. iii.69.3; vi.36.9. e)k is found often in Hdt. and the Att. poets for u(po/ with pass. H. 798 c; Kühn. 430, 2.
dra/santa/s ti kai\ kinduneu=sai: to do something if they must risk their lives. Sh. Cf. iii.53.14; iv.11.20. Tac. Hist. i. 21, acrioris viri esse merito perire.

perituxo/ntes: peritugxa/nein dicitur, qui non quaerens, e)pitugxa/nein, qui quaerens in aliquid cecidit. Herm.—*lewko/rion: the sanctuary of the daughters of Leos, an
old Attic king, who in a famine were sacrificed for the state. It was in the inner Ceramicus near the temple of Appollo Patrous.
th\n *panaqhnai+kh\n pomph/n: on the 24-29 Hecatombaeon (July).
kai\ oi( a)/lloi: i.e. not the Athenians only.

oi)/ontai: used only here with obj. acc. Elsewhere with inf. or abs. Cf. ii.54.10; iv.64.13.— w(/sper...pw/pote : the statements here denied by Thuc. are apparently made by Hdt. vi.57.30, on the double vote of the Lacedaemonian kings, and ix.53.9, on the *pitana/ths lo/xos; and we can hardly doubt that Thuc. has those passages in view. Cobet, Mnem. 12, p. 158, explains that Hdt. means that the one nearest kinsman of the kings cast two votes for the kings, if both absent, and a third for himself, and that the pl. tou\s ma/lista prosh/kontas is used because this kinsman would not always be the same. Paus. iii.16.9, speaks of a kw/mh *pita/nh, as Hdt. iii. 55 calls it dh=mos. On this question see Kirchhoff, Monatsb. d. Berl. Ak., Jan., 1878. The unusual expression yh/fw| prosti/qesqai (quite unlike c. 40. 18, yh=fon prostiqe/meqa) probably means that the kings voted last. See Schömann, Antiquities of Greece, I. p. 233. The neg. mh/, because this clause is appos. to polla\ a)/lla. See Am. J. of. Ph. I. p. 49.
ta\ e(toi=ma: what lies nearest at hand, taken without scrutiny, and therefore having no guarantee of accuracy.
An unprejudiced examination of the proofs adduced must result in a conviction of the superior importance of the Peloponnesian war.
o(/mws: i.e. although xalepa\ o)/nta kte(., c. 20. 1.

a(\ dih=lqon: obj. of nomi/zwn, with toiau=ta ma/lista (see on c. 13. 11) as pred., pretty nearly such as I have described them. The same obj. must be supplied with pisteu/wn, 4, and h(ghsa/menos, 7. Cl. regards these partics. as cond. prot. to a(marta/noi a)/n, but he has not observed that the neg. with the second is ou)/te—ou)/te, not mh/te—mh/te. The last two really express the cause of the writer's conviction of the correctness of his result, and only the first is cond., = ei)/ tis nomi/zoi, where tis may be regarded as a disguised e)gw/ (Kühn. 470, 1). What he feels to have been the cause of his own escape from error must be the condition of a similar escape on the part of any one
who may pursue the same investigation.

w(s logogra/foi cune/qesan: see App.—cune/qesan: aor., refers to records of facts recently compiled by writers of prose, and probably points to Herodotus. It implies merely the collection and recording of a mass of facts, not, like cuggra/fein and the Lat. res componere, an elaborate inquiry and systematic treatment. Cf. c. 97. 10.—e)pi\ to\...a)lhqe/steron : rather to tickle the ear in public recitation than to reach the truth. The repeated comp., as in Lat., expresses that of two qualities in the same object, one exists in larger measure. Cf. Hom. a 164; Hdt. iii.65.11; Plat. Theaet. 144 b. H. 645; Kühn. 543, 5. The adv. periphrasis with e)pi/ as in c. 3. 6, and 9. 20. a)kro/asis here and in c. 22. 14 of public recitations at festivals.

o)/nta a)nece/legkta...e)knenikhko/ta : these words are in formal agreement with a(/ dih=lqon, though referring specially to the misstatements of poets and chroniclers; stories which cannot be tested, and most of which have from lapse of time passed into the region of romance destitute of all credibility. For e)knika=n, cf. c. 3. 11.
hu(rh=sqai: as expressing the result of diligent inquiry (cf. c. 1. 11; 20. 1; 22. 12) stands first in its clause in contrast with kosmou=ntes and cune/qesan.

w(s...a)poxrw/ntws : sufficiently considering their antiquity. w(s suggests a natural limit to what it is fair to expect. Cf. c. 10. 34; iv.84.9; Kühn. 581, 5. Not usually, as here and Hdt. iv.81.4, with the restrictive inf. of iv.28.5 (to\ e)pi\ sfa=s ei)=nai); Plat. Prot. 317 a (kata\ tou=to ei)=nai). GMT. 100, N. 2; H. 956; Kühn. 479, 4.

kai\ o( po/lemos kte(.: “and so, though men are apt, while they are engaged in war, to judge the present one always most important, but when it is over to look with greater wonder on those ancient events, still this war, which I am going to narrate, will show to persons who form their opinions on the basis of facts, that it proved really more important than they.” au)tw=n = tw=n palaiw=n. In this chapter the importance of the Peloponnesian war is compared with that of ta\ palaia/ (see on c. 1. 10), and the next chapter is not, as Kr. thinks, out of place, but comes in quite properly to contrast the modern critical methods with the uncertified traditions of early poets and logographers. With
e)n w(=| a)\n polemw=si cf. Plat. Phaed. 67 a, e)n w(=| a)\n zw=men. GMT. 62; H. 914. For dhlw/sei = dh=los e)/stai, cf. ii.50.4; Soph. Ant. 20, 471. Kr. Spr. 56, 7, 5; Kühn. 482, 2.
The writer has taken pains to set forth a true account of what was said as well as of what was done during the war, without aiming at mere entertainment.

kai\ o(/sa me\n kte(.: the distinction between the two chief elements of the narration, the speeches and the facts, is enforced by the pleonasm of o(/sa lo/gw| ei)=pon followed by tw=n lexqe/ntwn, and of ta\ e)/rga tw=n praxqe/ntwn in 8. These aors. as well as diamnhmoneu=sai and h)/kousa are complexive. See on c. 6. 3.
diamnhmoneu=sai: (Xen. Mem. i.3.1; but not elsewhere in Thuc.) refers to the mass of material as well as to the length of time. With a)pagge/llousin must be supplied w(=n h)/kousan.

w(s d) a)\n...ei)pei=n : the a)/n belongs to ei)pei=n, and ma/lista to the whole phrase, as in c. 21. 2, expressing the greatest practicable probability. For a)ei/, sce on c. 2. 4. ta\ de/onta, the sentiments proper to the occasion (Jowett), from the point of view of the historian; all that was necessary to bring out the inner connexion of events. See Herbst, Philol. 38, p. 565.
e)xome/nw|...lexqe/ntwn : adhering as closely as possible to the general sense of what was actually said.

ou(/tws ei)/rhtai: sc. e)moi/, so have I represented them as speaking; ou(/tws sums up his method. Cf. c. 37. 4; vi.2.25. The pf. ei)/rhtai is most naturally explained on the assumption that when Thuc. wrote this Introduction, he had already completed a large part of his work.
tw=n praxqe/ntwn: includes all the incidents of the war, plans, negotiations, etc., as well as military operations, in reference to all of which e)/rga stands in opposition to lo/goi.
tou= paratuxo/ntos : the first chance comer. This verb is used of persons or things which present themselves by accident. Cf. iv.19.6; 103. 12; and the impers. paratuxo/n, c. 76. 14; v.60.11.
h)ci/wsa: I thought it my duty as an historian. a)ciou=n with inf. properly ‘to regard as worthy of one's self.’

e)pecelqw/n: to be under
stood, not of statement, as in iii.67.1, but of inquiry, as antecedent to h)ci/wsa gra/fein. The fundamental meaning ‘pursue to the end’ admits both senses. Cf. Plat. Parm. 128 d, ei)/ tis i(kanw=s e)peci/oi; Tim. 38 d, ai)ti/as pa/sas e)pecie/nai. The object of the inquiry is expressed by (1) oi(=s au)to\s parh=n, (2) peri\ tw=n a)/llwn, in regard to other matters of which I was not a witness. See App. To both belongs o(/son . . . e(ka/stou, with the utmost possible accuracy in detail.

hu(ri/sketo: see on c. 1. 11; impf. to denote the continuous effort. The subj. is ta\ e)/rga tw=n praxqe/ntwn.— 13. eu)noi/as h)\ mnh/mhs : dependent on w(/s tis e)/xoi, as in w(s ta/xous tis ei)=xe. Cf. ii.90.19; vi.97.14; vii.2.2; viii.102.5. G. 168, N. 3; H. 757; Kühn. 419, 5. Cf. Tac. Ann. xv. 53, ut quisque audentiae habuisset. See on c. 36. 11. e(kate/rwn, a certain correction of e(kate/rw| of most Mss., depends on eu)noi/as. Cf. vii.57.56, and kreisso/nwn, c. 8. 15. e)/xoi is iterative opt. Authorities varied in their reports according as they were inclined to favour one or the other party.

kai\ e)s me\n a)kro/asin kte(.: having described his mode of composition, Thuc. here characterizes his work as regards the two aspects of entertainment and utility, employing the particles kai/ . . . me/n . . . de/, as in c. 19. 1, 3, to mark the contrast. “And it may well be that the absence of fabulous narration from my history will make it seem less attractive to the ear; but for such as shall desire to gain a true picture both of the past and of what is likely at some time hereafter, in accordance with the course of human nature, to prove either just the same or very like it—for such persons to judge that my history is profitable will be enough for me. And so it has been composed rather as a treasure for all time than as a prize composition to please the ear for the moment.” a)kro/asin, as in c. 21. 5, and a)gw/nisma, in 19, refers to public recitation at festivals.
au)tw=n: as au)ta/ in 18, refers to the subject of discussion, i.e. his work. See on c. 1. 10.— boulh/sontai: anticipates readers in the distant future.

to\ safe/s: limited as well by tw=n genome/nwn (the past) as by tw=n mello/ntwn . . . e)/sesqai (the probable future). Thuc. gives in ii.48.14 an example of his meaning in describing the symptoms of the plague, ei)/ pote kai\ au)=qis e)pipe/soi.— 18. kri/nein : tou/tous must be supplied as subj., the antec. of o(/soi boulh/sontai. For the const. of kri/nein with obj. and
pred., cf. c. 21. 10; ii.34.15; 43. 23; iv.61.22.

te: and so, inferential, as in c. 4. 5. Pliny, Ep. v.8.11, refers to this passage: plurimum refert, ut Thucydides ait, kth=ma sit an a)gw/nisma, quorum alterum oratio (i.e. a work of rhetorical art), alterum historia est. Cf. also Polyb. iii.31.12.—a)gw/nisma: means a special feat at an a)gw/n; here, like a)kro/asis in 14, referring to the delivery of a show-piece at a public gathering, like that reported of Herodotus (Lucian, Herod. i.)—e)s to\ paraxrh=ma a)kou/ein: cf. ii.11.29, e)n tw=| parauti/ka o(ra=n. This whole phrase is opp. to e)s a)ei/, not the adv. part merely, as Cl. says.
cu/gkeitai: = the pf. pass. of cuntiqe/nai.
The Peloponnesian war surpassed the Persian war in duration and in the many calamities by which it was attended. A general statement of its cause.

tw=n de\ pro/teron kte(.: connected with the close of c. 21, where this war is compared with ta\ palaia/, by de/ (cf. c. 33. 1) rather than by ga/r, because of the interposed account of his method in c. 22.

duoi=n...pezomaxi/ain : since Thuc. has in view the expedition of Xerxes (o( me/gas sto/los of c. 18. 14), the Schol. is probably right in saying that these battles were the sea-fights of Artemisium and Salamis and the land-battles of Thermopylae and Plataea, which brought a decisive kri/sis. Cf. c. 89. 3. duoi=n is to be supplied with the second noun; in such cases Thuc. usually employs i)/sos. Cf. tessa/rwn h(merw=n kai\ i)/swn nuktw=n, ii.97.5; i.115.13; iii.75.12; v.20.12; 57. 12. But v. H. thinks that with the dual nothing need be supplied.

tou/tou de\ tou= pole/mou kte(.: the importance which Thuc. here attributes to the war is grounded not on the serious interests involved nor on the character of the military operations, but on its unusual duration and the great number of disastrous occurrences which attended it. So must we understand the words paqh/mata cunhne/xqh gene/sqai e)n au)tw=| th=| *(ella/di, as well as those in 17, tau=ta ga\r pa/nta meta\ tou=de tou= pole/mou a(/ma cunepe/qeto. The preceding gen. serves as an art. to mh=kos. Cf. c. 1. 11; 3. 1.
me/ga: pred. to prou/bh, indicating the result. Cf. c. 90. 21; 93. 6.—cunhne/xqh: = cune/bh. Cf. vii.44.3; viii 83. 4; 84. 1, and often in Hdt.

oi(=a ou)x e(/tera kte(: a common formula for what is extraordinary. Cf. vii.70.15; viii.1.12; and similarly iii.113.21. No inference can be drawn as to a definite duration from the words e)n i)/sw| xro/nw|.

u(po\ barba/rwn: as Mycalessus,
vii. 29; perhaps also Colophon, iii. 34.

u(po\ sfw=n au)tw=n: = u(p' a)llh/lwn, the Athenians and Peloponnesians being the virtual subj.; opp. to tw=n barba/rwn. Examples are, Plataea, iii. 68. § 3; Mitylene, iii. 50; Thyrea, iv. 57. § 3.—ei)si\ de\ ai(/: sunt quae. G. 152, N. 2; H. 998. ei)si/n is more common than e)/stin when the rel. is nom. (cf. 15). Kühn. 554, 5.

oi)kh/toras mete/balon: e.g. Aegina, ii. 27; Potidaea, ii. 70; Anactorium, iv. 49; Scione, v. 32; Melos, v. 116.—a(lisko/menai: partic. impf.—fugai\ kte(.: sc. e)ge/nonto, e.g. in Plataea, ii.5.30; of the Plataeans, iii. 68. § 2; of the Melians, v. 116. kat' au)to\n to\n po/lemon, i.e. directly in consequence of the war.

dia\ to\ stasia/zein: in Corcyra, iii. 81. ff.; iv. 47; Megara, iv. 66. ff.; Samos, viii. 21. There may well have been other instances which the narrative omits, as having no direct connexion with the war. This remark applies particularly to the seismoi/, 12 (cf. ii.8.9; iii.87.9; 89. 4, 17; iv.52.3; v.45.20; 50. 26; vi.95.2; viii.6.29; 41. 9), and to the h(li/ou e)klei/yeis, 13 (ii.28.2; iv.52.1), of which many others must have been observed in Greece in 27 years; also to the au)xmoi/ and limoi/, 15, of which no particular instance is mentioned; for it is clear that he means here (15, a)p' au)tw=n), and in ii.54.7, famine as the result of failure of crops.
ta/ te pro/teron...kate/sth : and so stories of former times reported on hearsay, but too scantily confirmed by fact, ceased to be incredible.

seismw=n te pe/ri: both as to earthquakes = earthquakes for instance. Cf. c. 52. 9, where the clause with peri/ is parallel to an acc. Though this clause strictly belongs to the preceding subj. ta\ pro/teron kte(., the following rel. sentence, oi(\ . . . e)pe/sxon, refers only to occurrences of this war; and, as if explanatory of ta\ pro/teron, nom. cases (as e)klei/yeis) follow, for which a verb like e)ge/nonto must be supplied out of ou)k a)/pista kate/sth. The two sup. expressions are closely united by a(/ma . . . oi( au)toi/.

e)pe/sxon : prevailed, intr., with e)pi\ plei=ston me/ros gh=s as adv. definition. Cf. c. 50. 7, where, however, e)pi\ polu/ is obj. of e)pe/sxen, as we find neut. objs., c. 48. 7; ii.77.13; iii.107.24; vii.62.18. Cf. also iii.89.6, tw=n seismw=n katexo/ntwn.
para\ ta\ kte(.: “running beyond those recorded of former times,” and so pleonastic (cf. the Lat. prae) with a comp. Cf. iv.6.6. G. 191, VI. 4; H. 802, 3; Kr. Spr. 49, 2, 8.

au)xmoi/: pl. as siccitates, Caes. B. G.
v. 24.—e)/sti par' oi(=s: = par' e)ni/ois. Cf. e)/stin e)n oi(=s, v.25.9; viii.65.3. See on 7.

h(...no/sos : the repetition of the art. lays stress on the partic. Cf. c. 126. 10; viii.64.6; 90. 27; Hdt. viii. 92, th\n profula/ssousan e)pi\ *skia/qw| th\n *ai)ginai/hn(ne/a); Plat. Gorg. 502 b; Dem. XIX. 26. me/ros ti is adv., to a (considerable) degree, not obj.; so that fqei/rasa is a stronger bla/yasa. Cf. ii.64.7; iv.30.2.
cunepe/qeto: complexive, as in c. 6. 3. e)piqe/sqai, as of hostile forces.
h)/rcanto de\ au)tou= kte(.: the narrative of the beginning of the war is carried on in ii. 1. The following words dio/ti d' e)/lusan kte(. announce the contents of the rest of this book.
triakontou/teis: cf. c. 115. § 1. B.C. 445. In such words we find the forms -ou/teis (c. 115. 3; ii.2.2) and -ou/tides (c. 87. 19; v.32.19; Ar. Ach. 194; Eq. 1388).
prw=ton: for a similar pleonasm, cf. ii.36.1; iii.53.9; vi.57.10; viii.66.6.
tou=...zhth=sai : see on c. 4. 6.

pro/fasin: here of the actual reason or occasion. Cf. c. 118, 3; 133. 7; 141. 4; ii.49.4; vi.6.3; Dem. XVIII. 156, th\n a)lhqh= pro/fasin. If we take tou\s *)aqhnai/ous mega/lous . . . e)s to\ polemei=n as obj. of h(gou=mai and th\n a)lhqesta/thn . . . lo/gw| (the truest cause of this war, though least voiced, Bacon) as pred. (the art. being required by the sup.), we need not, with most commentators, assume an irregularity or mixture of consts.

tou\s *)aqhnai/ous...polemei=n : the stress of the sentence lies on the partic. clauses (see on c. 100. 16) rather than on a)nagka/sai. Cf. c. 82. 10; ii.61.3. For a)nagka/sai e)s, cf. ii.75.14; vii.62.15.
e)s to\ fanero/n: = fanerw=s, but with the notion of coming forward in public. Cf. c. 6. 17.

ai)ti/ai e(kate/rwn, a)f' w(=n: proleptic for ai)ti/ai a)f' w(=n e(ka/teroi. Kühn. 600, 5. For a)po/, cf. c. 12. 5. The e)s to\ fanero\n lego/menai ai)ti/ai include c. 24-55 the *kerkurai+ka/, and c. 56-66 the *poteidaiatika/. And then, after the negotiations at
Sparta and the decision there arrived at, we reach in c. 88-118 the narrative of the a)lhqesta/th pro/fasis of the war, viz. the alarming growth of the Athenian power, which is thus, in Greek fashion, placed after ostensible ones. The remaining chapters, 119145, contain the concluding consultations and decisions at Sparta and Athens.

div2.head: The dispute between Corinth and Corcyra. Chaps. 24-55.
div2.p: Origin and early history of Epidamnus. The commons appeal in vain to Corcyra for help against the attacks of the banished aristocrats.

*)epi/damnos: Dyrrhachium of the Romans, now Durazzo, on the Illyrian coast of the Adriatic. A name thus placed is a common mode of beginning a narrative. Cf. Hom. t 172; or with preceding e)/sti, g 293; d 844. So c. 126. 6; Cic. Verr. Act. II. iv. 33; Virg. Aen. i. 12.— e)sple/onti: see on c. 10. 34. This verb only here in prose with simple acc.; with prep., ii.86.19; 89. 30; 92. 22; 94. 4; iv.75.5; viii.99.17. So also e)sa/gein, e)sba/llein, e)sbai/nein, e)skomi/zein, e)sfe/rein always with prep. in prose.
prosoikou=si: with acc. Arist. Pol. i.8.7. In. iv.103.10; v.51.3 it is abs.
a)pw/|kisan: Ol. 38. 2; B.C. 627.

*fali/os: so accentuated in distinction from the adj. fa/lios or falio/s. See Lehrs, de Aristarcho, p. 279; Chandler, Greek Accentuation, § 249.—*)eratoklei/dou: the gen. of the father's name without the art., as in ii.67.13; 99. 25.— 5. tw=n a)f' *(hrakle/ous: as vi.3.6, *)arxi/as tw=n *(hrakleidw=n, probably one of the Bacchiadae. The gen. of the whole depends directly on the personal name.—dh/: naturally; often used in explanatory clauses. Cf. ii.102.28; iii.104.2. On the custom itself, see vi. 4. § 2; and on the connexion between a colony and the mother city, cf. c. 25. § 4; 34. § 1; 38. § 2.
kataklhqei/s: only here in Thuc.; found again in Polyb., Strab., and Plut.
ge/nous: = e)/qnous. So in iv.61.14; vii.27.2; 29. 23.
[h( tw=n *)epidamni/wn po/lis]: the Mss. vary between po/lis and du/namis, thus betraying that the words are a gloss, as Stahl rightly judged.

stasia/santes: agreeing kata\ su/nesin with po/lis. Cf. iii.2.2, *le/sbos . . . boulhqe/ntes; 79. 9, po/lin . . . o)/ntas.— 10. w(s le/getai : belongs to e)/th polla/,
as this formula always stands immediately after or within the words it qualifies, never before them. Cf. c. 118. 21; iii.79.10; vi.2.20; vii.86.17; viii.50.16. It indicates not doubt, but only vagueness in the tradition. —a)po\ pole/mou: see on c. 12. 5. The real cause of this war lay in their internal divisions.—tw=n barba/rwn: gen. as in 19 and c. 32. 14.
e)fqa/rhsan: they became crippled. Cf. c. 2. 17.
ta\ teleutai=a: see on c. 2. 2.— 13. e)cedi/wce: a rare compound, only here in Thuc. In Dem. XXXII. 6, where the vulgate has this compound, the best Ms. *s has diwko/menos.

tou\s dunatou/s : so the o)li/goi, the party opposed to the dh=mos, are often called. Cf. ii.65.8; iii.27.8; v.4.8; viii.21.4.—e)pelqo/ntes: Haase's conjecture for a)pelqo/ntes of Mass.; for the aor. partic., related as it is to e)lh/|zonto, must express the notion of attack, not of moving off. But Sh. and B. take oi( a)pelqo/ntes together = ‘the exiles,’ opp. to tou\s e)n th=| po/lei.

periora=n: the pres. inf. as including all subsequent times; the following aor. infs. with special reference to immediate necessities. GMT. 23, 1. The same distinction in c. 25. 6 and 10. “periora=n with pres. partic. implies inactive perception = ‘look on with indifference’; with aor. partic. (ii.18.22) implies non-perception = ‘shut one's eyes to.’ Both these occur in Dinarch. 11. 8. With inf. (ii.20.6) it has lost its notion of perception, and becomes simply = e)a=n, ‘permit.’ B.L.G.

i(ke/tai kaqezo/menoi: aor. (not impf., cf. c. 26, 19; vii.77.22) of i(ke/thn kaqi/zein, which forms a simple notion, ‘to seek for protection.’ Cf. c. 136. 10; iii.70.19; 75. 22. Cf. the Homeric a)/ggelon e)lqei=n, Hom. B 786; *g 121; E 804, etc.
*(/hraion: rather than *(hrai=on, acc. to Vat. Ms. and Arcadius. See Chandler, § 357 and 360.
The Corinthians are ready to lend the Epidamnians the aid they ask for.

timwri/an: in Hdt. (iii.148.14;
vii.169.11) and Thuc. (c. 38. 15; 58. 5; 69. 30, etc.), help; later, ‘vengeance.’ —ou)=san: = u(pa/rxousan. See on c. 2. 5. —e)n a)po/rw| ei)/xonto: this expression occurs here only; in iii.22.31, e)n a)po/rw| h)=san, also with inf. In Hdt. iv.131.2, e)n a)pori/h|si (ix.98.3, e)n a)pori/h|)e)/xesqai. Plat. Phaed. 108 c; Gorg. 522 a, e)n pa/sh| a)pori/a| e)/xesqai.

qe/sqai : to arrange, manage, in a general sense (cf. c. 41. 15; 75. 16; iv.17.12; 18. 11; 59. 14; 61. 23; v.80.3; vi.11.26); then settle, as here to\ paro/n, their present difficulty. Cf. c. 31. 15; 82. 27; viii.84.19 (to\n po/lemon); iv.120.22; v.80.3 (ta\ pra/gmata). In the latter sense there is no need, as there is in the former, of an adverbial qualification.—to\ paro/n: nearly as freq. sing. as pl., without important difference of meaning; cf. c. 77. 19; 133. 13; ii.22.1, pro\s to\ paro\n (59. 10, pro\s ta\ paro/nta)xalepai/nein; 36. 18; 54. 8; iii.40.35, etc.; it varies with peri/ pro/s, a)po/, but always e)n tw=| paro/nti, e)k tw=n paro/ntwn.
e)ph/ronto : here and iii.92.19; viii.29.6 aor. to the pres. e)perwta=n, ii.54.13; v.45.15, and the impf. e)phrw/twn, i.118.20.

paradoi=en: opt. of the deliberative subj. paradw=men. GMT. 21, 2 b; 71. Cf. Hom. A 191, mermh/ricen h)\ o(/ ge . . . a)nasth/seien; c. 63. 3.—timwri/an poiei=sqai: if correct, = auxilium sibi conciliare. See App. The regular sense of opem ferre in c. 124. 4.— 8. sfw=n: as possessive gen. with to\n oi)kisth/n. So often in Thuc.; rare in other Attic writers. Cf. c. 30. 14; 50. 19; 136. 10; ii.5.20; iv.55.3. Here a direct refl., as the more emphatic e(autw=n in 12.

kata/ te to\ di/kaion: followed in 13 by a(/ma de\ kai/. This irregularity in the use of the particles is probably due to the number of intervening words. Cf. c. 11. 4. Kühn. 520, note 3.—u(pede/canto: polliciti sunt: used with acc. (ii.95.9) as well as with fut. inf. (ii.29.25; viii.81.21).
parhme/loun: here only in Thuc. Cf. Hdt. i.85.14; Xen. Mem. ii.2.14.

ou)/te ga\r kte(.: Cl. and B. follow Stahl (Jahrb. 1863, p. 465, 466; 1868, p. 176) in removing the period at the end of the chapter, in order that
the sentence introduced by ga/r may find a verb in the e)/pempon of c. 26. 2; though, owing to the intervention of several partics. and the parenthesis at 22, h(=| kai\ ma=llon . . . polemei=n, the structure is changed from oi( *kerkurai=oi [e)gklh/mata parei=xon toi=s *korinqi/ois] to oi( *kori/nqioi e)gklh/mata e)/xontes e)/pempon. v. H., however, follows Badham in omitting ga/r, that the partics. may be connected with the subj. of parhme/loun; and Sh. produces the same result by understanding ga/r (=ge a)/r) in its primitive meaning ‘in fact,’ ‘in sooth,’ Germ. nämlich. See his note; and on this use of ga/r, Heller, Philol. 13, p. 114; Bäumlein, Partikeln, p. 68 ff.; Bursian's Jahrb. 15, p. 272. A good example is Hom. K 127, i(/na ga/r sfin e)pe/fradon h)gere/qesqai. So Sh. explains vii.28.13.

ge/ra ta\ nomizo/mena: for the order, see on c. 1. 6. Acc. to Diod. xii.30.4 these were the offerings which should be sent to the chief festivals of the mother city, called koinai\ panhgu/reis, because the colonies had part in them. On these offerings, see the decree about Brea, C. I. A. I. 31, l. 11; Hicks, Inscr. p. 37, and Schol. on Ar. Nub. 386; and on the whole subject, Am. J. of Ph., V. p. 479 ff.

prokatarxo/menoi tw=n i(erw=n: refers to the sacred usages at the beginning of the sacrifice (see Buttm. Lexilogus, I. 103, and cf. Hom. g 445; Hdt. ii.45.6; iv.60.9; 103. 4; Ar. Av. 959; Eur. I. T. 40), as the cutting off hair from the forehead of the victim and distributing it to those present. Cf. Hom. *g 273, a)rnw=n e)k kefale/wn ta/mne tri/xas: au)ta\r e)/peita kh/rukes *trw/wn kai\ *)axaiw=n nei=man a)ri/stois. So we must understand prokatarxo/menoi (which occurs only here in a religious sense) with the Schol., dido/ntes pro/teron (sc. h)\ toi=s a)/llois)ta\s katarxa/s, and that in the normal state of things citizens of a mother city who were present at a sacrifice in a colony received the katarxai/ of the victims first. The two clauses joined by ou)/te—ou)/te refer, therefore, to the fulfilment of such dutiful obligations in the mother city as well as in the colony.

perifronou=ntes: like u(perfronei=n (iii.39.30; vi.68.10) in meaning and const., but in this sense only here in Attic. Cf. Ar. Nub. 225, *s*w*k*r. a)erobatw= kai\ perifronw= to\n h(/lion. *s*t*r*e*y. e)/peit) a)po\ tarrou= tou\s qeou\s u(perfronei=s;

e)n duna/mei o)/ntes : = dunatoi/; used with the gen., as in iii.93.6; Plat. Rep. 328 c. With this is joined o(moi=a in adv. sense; cf. vii.29.24; Hdt. iii.8.1; 57. 9; vii.118.7; 141. 4. dunatw/teroi in 19 is its comp. Thus the partic. u)/ntes with its two preds. is subord. to perifronou=ntes, giving a double reason for their pride. See App.

nautikw=| de\ kte(.: to the two real grounds of arrogance (xrh/mata and paraskeuh/) is added a third, based on the mythical
fame for naval skill of the Phaeacian inhabitants of their island. Thuc. disparages this reason by the use of e)pairo/menoi, which generally has an unfavourable sense (c. 84. 9; 120. 20, 24; iii.37.28; vi.11.23), and by e)/stin o(/te with kai\ kata\ th\n kte(., “and boasting their great superiority also in naval power sometimes actually (kai/) on the ground of the former occupation of the island by the Phaeacians, whose glory lay in their ships.” —proe/xein: after e)pairo/menoi = gloriantes, as au)xei=n with inf. in ii.39.18.
th\n tw=n...*kerku/ras : note the position of the governing noun between the subjective and the objective gen., as in ii.49.37; 89. 46; iii.12.10; vii.34.25.
e)xo/ntwn: for the position, see on c. 11. 19.—h(=| kai\ ma=llon: see on c. 11. 8.
kai\ h)=san: et erant, and they actually were.
The Corinthians send a garrison to Epidamnus. After fruitless negotiations, the Corcyraeans besiege the place with forty ships.

e)/pempon: the impf. of this verb used as aor., since the activity of the sender is regarded as going along with the person sent. So a)poste/llein (ii.85.10; iii.49.5). Cf. keleu/ein, 11, dei=sqai, 14. See on c. 10. 34.
oi)kh/tora: = e)/poikon, ii.27.5.
frourou/s: formally construed with i)e/nai keleu/ontes, but in sense rather dependent on e)/pempon.
*)apollwni/an : a Corinthian colony, south of Epidamnus, also in the country of the Taulantii.
de/ei...u(p) au)tw=n : a proleptic const., the pass. form of which makes u(p' au)tw=n necessary. In the act. it would be mh\ sfa=s kwlu/wsi.

tou/s te oi)kh/toras kai\ frourou\s...th/n te a)poiki/an : by te . . . te the two members are united on the same level (see on c. 8. 14), while tou\s oi)kh/toras kai\ frourou/s are joined together as one whole, as in 15, and, with stronger discrimination of the two parts, in c. 28. 4, tou\s frourou/s te kai\ oi)kh/toras.

h(/kontas...dedome/nhn : these pf. partics. indicate that all was finished when they learned it. Cf.
ii.3.2.
kai\ u(/steron e(te/rw| sto/lw|: inserted here in anticipation of 18, where the fleet of 25 ships, which was despatched immediately, is augmented by 15.

kat' e)ph/reian: e)phreasmo/s is defined by Arist. Rhet. ii.2.4, e)mpodismo\s tai=s boulh/sesin(tou= plhsi/on)ou)x i(/na ti au(tw=|(ge/nhtai)a)ll' i(/na mh\ e)kei/nw|. It implies, therefore, wanton malice. The Corcyraeans had no interest in the restoration of the nobles.
ta/fous: i.e. tou\s patrw/|ous (iii.59.13), of their common ancestors, who had founded Epidamnus.
kata/gein: regularly used of the restoration of exiles. Cf. 18; c. 111. 3; ii.33.4; 95. 9; v.16.31; viii.53.4.

oi( de\ *)epida/mnioi...oi( *kerkurai=oi kte(.: instead of this parataxis of clauses, we should have looked for e)pei\ . . . u(ph/kousan, strateu/ousin. The decisive matters are thus placed in strong contrast. Though the subj. is changed, after the neg. a)lla/ is used. Cf. c. 58. 6; ii.70.2; iii.45.16. Otherwise kai/ is employed. Cf. c. 48. 3; 61. 2; 105. 29. The aor. u(ph/kousan stands in the sense of our plpf. in a protasis. Cf. c. 62. 6; 63. 11; ii.2.12; iv.3.9, etc. Before strateu/ousin, as St. rightly remarks, we must understand ou) pei/santes, for ou)de\n u(ph/kousan = ou)k e)pei/sqhsan. See App. In tessara/konta nausi/ the reinforcement spoken of in 11 is silently assumed. For the acc. ou)de/n, cf. c. 139. 9; v.114.2: au)tw=n is neut. and part., since with u(pakou/ein Thuc. uses a pers. gen. always without acc. Cf. ii.62.22; iii.50.14; iv.56.16; v.84.11; vi.71.15; 82. 8; 87. 5; viii.5.19 (abs., i.143.33; with dat., iv.63.12; v.98.3). We have here au)tw=n with aor. (not as in c. 29. 1, tou/twn with impf.) in reference to the demand made by the first squadron, 10, which had not been regarded. See Herbst, Philol. 16, p. 274.
proskaqezo/menoi: with acc. Cf. c. 61. 8; v.61.16, where, however, the acc. may be governed by poliorkei=n. But cf. c. 24. 2 and Kühn. 409, 8.

proei=pon kte(.: announced publicly. See on c. 29. 3. Note the change of subj. with the following
infs. (as in Hdt. ii.115.29), and that the former represents the imv., the latter the indic., of dir. disc.
i)sqmo/s: a remark inserted to show the ease of the operation.—e)polio/rkoun: obsidere coeperunt.
The Corinthians make preparations to support the Epidamnians and appeal to their allies.
au)toi=s: see on c. 13. 12.

e)pi\ th=| i)/sh|...i)e/nai : defines more exactly the obj. a)poiki/an. Both are dependent on e)kh/russon. On the phrase, see on c. 14. 15. As a)po\ th=s i)/shs (cf. c.15. 11) marks a starting point, so e)pi\ th=| i)/sh| refers to conditions. The two adjs. together, without distinction of meaning, constitute a formula (aequo et pari iure, Cic. Off. i. § 124). Cf. c. 145. 6; iv.105.12; v.27.12; 59. 24: and with similar meaning e)pi\ toi=s i)/sois kai\ o(moi/ois, v.79.2; Xen. Hell. vii.1.1, 13, 45. See Curtius, Herm. 10, 234 f.

ei) de/ tis...a)poiki/as : when a case is supposed with ei), in order that a further supposition may be then made about it, the indic. is used in the former and the opt. in the latter; and what seems to us the natural order is often inverted in Greek. Here: “a man, suppose, is desirous (bou/letai) to take part in the scheme; should such a one be unwilling (mh/ e)qe/loi) to sail at once.” The same moods and order in Xen. Mem. ii.6.4 (e)/xoi . . . a)ne/xetai); indic. in first place, Plat. Phaed. 67 e (diabe/blhtai . . . foboi=nto); Xen. Cyr. iv.6.7 (de/xh| . . . la/boimi). The opt. here, therefore, is not due to the indir. disc. Cf. c. 5. 14.

draxma\s *korinqi/as: the Corinthian standard being like the Aeginetan (see Boeckh, Publ. Ec. p. 28), the Corinthian drachma (paxei=a): the Attic (lepth/) :: 10 : 6 (obols). So Cl. But this ratio is disputed by Hultsch, Griech. und Röm. Metrologie, p. 540. —kataqe/nta: and kataba/llontes, 8, of depositing as security, to be forfeited if the pledge should not be fulfilled. Cf. Plat. Prot. 314 b; 328 c.
polloi/: pred. to the two partic. subjs. united on the same level by kai/ —kai/. See on c. 8. 14.
e)deh/qhsan de\ kte(.: the main points of the action of the Corinthians, expressed by aors., 8, 11, 14, are separated by short notices of the results.

cumprope/myein: only inferior Mss. have cumprope/myai, which has, however, been adopted by St., B., and v. H. So the fut. inf. is found in the best Mss. after bou/lesqai, vi.57.10; e)fi/esqai, vi.6.4; dunato\n ei)=nai, iii.28.2. See on ii.29.26 and vi.6.4. GMT. 27, N. 2 a; Kühn. 389, note 8; Stahl, Quaestiones grammaticae, p. 8. —ei) a)/ra: if, as might be expected. See Heller, Philol. 13, p. 118.
*kefallh/nwn: part. gen., as in c. 24. 5; 29. 10; 30. 15; v.67.7.

*qhbai/ous: ai)tei=n is used by Thuc. with acc. of person only in connexion with xrh/mata. Cf. viii.44.6; 85. 20. Elsewhere the person, if expressed, is governed by para/. The fulfilment of the last request is mentioned in c. 30. 9.

kena/s: inanes, the hulls only; opp. to plh/reis, c. 29. 2.—*korinqi/wn: prop. names often without art. when joined with au)to/s (cf. ii.31.10; iii.98.19; vi.30.6; 31. 12), by which the absence of alien elements is indicated. Kr. Spr. 50, 11, 14.
The Corcyraeans once more require the Corinthians to abstain from protecting the Epidamnians.
pare/labon: usually of support in war; here and viii.92.40, of additional advocates of a proposal. The Lacedaemonians would naturally be chosen, as being in favour at Corinth.

frourou/s te kai\ oi)kh/toras: with a single art. See on c. 6. 1.—w(s ou) meto/n : the subjective w(s with the abs. partic. and the neg. ou) of fact (connected with e)ke/leuon, not with a)pa/gein) indicate the confidence of the assumption. In dependence on the imv. idea of keleu/ein we should have mh/. Cf. vii.77.35; Ar. Ran. 128.
a)ntipoiou=ntai: sc. *)epida/mnou. Cf. iv.122.15.

di/kas dou=nai: cf. c. 85. 9; 144. 15; iv.118.35; one side, and here the most important, of the full di/kas dido/nai kai\ de/xesqai (cf. di/kaia, c. 37. 21, and di/kas i)/sas kai\ o(moi/as, v.27.12; 59. 24), “to submit the quarrel to a fair discussion and arbitration.” —para\ po/lesin ai(=s: = par' ai(=s. See
on c. 1. 12; 6. 21.
cumbw=sin: sc. di/kas dou=nai.
h)/qelon de/ : this emphatic repetition (epanaphora) of the verb, the clause o(pote/rwn . . . kratei=n being parentheic, indicates their willingness to accede to any friendly adjustment.

po/lemon de\ ou)k ei)/wn poiei=n: (not poiei=sqai) “against causing war they strongly protested.” ou)k e)a=n as c. 127. 10; vi.72.7. Cf. Hdt. v.36.7, ou)k e)/a po/lemon a)naire/esqai. The aor. inf. used for the positive recommendations, dou=nai, e)pitre/yai, the pres. for the dissuasive, poiei=n.

ei) de\ mh/ : introduces the alternative, whether a positive clause, or, as here, a neg., precedes. GMT. 52, 1, N. 2; H. 906. After this transition e)/fasan, which Kr. suspects, can hardly be dispensed with. See the similar case in ii.5.22.

ou(\s ou) bou/lontai: a covert allusion to the alliance with the Athenians, which, as ou) shows, was already contemplated, with whom they would naturally not desire to unite themselves, as being of a different race.

tw=n nu=n o)/ntwn: the gen. depending on e(te/rous. G. 175, 1, N. 1; H. 753 g. This refers rather to the Lacedaemonians and Sicyonians, who were with them, than to the Illyrians (c. 26. 19), whom they would hardly call fi/loi.
w)feli/as e(/neka : placed at the end, implying that if their claim of right is rejected, interest alone must guide their action. See App.

a)paga/gwsi: the best Mss. give a)pa/gwsi, and the pres. partic. in c. 29. 18; but the connexion of thought requires the aor. here, as in the precisely similar case in 17: the withdrawal must take place first, and then only can negotiations be entertained. —pro/teron: before this takes place, belongs not to kalw=s e)/xein but to dika/zesqai, to which poliorkei=sqai, though in parataxis, is in sense subord.: “it was not proper that, while the Epidamnians were undergoing siege, they (the Corinthians and Corcyraeans) should dispute about their rights.”
au)tou/s: acc., although inclusive of the speakers, from the contrast with tou\s me/n. Kühn. 476, 1.

e)n *)epida/mnw|: directly opp. to tou\s . . . a)po\ *)epida/mnou of 14. The
Corinthians had troops actually in Epidamnus, who, as not really Epidamnians, could not be described by the proleptic tou\s e)c *)epida/mnou.

e(toi=moi d) ei)=nai kte(.: supply dika/zesqai from 16, they were ready for a judicial settlement. Cf. v.41.10. w(/ste, on condition that (cf. c. 29. 22; iii.28.4; iv.65.3; vii.83.8), introduces both me/nein and poih/sasqai, the latter being aor. to mark the new step which would then be taken. kata\ xw/ran, as they were. See App.
The Corinthians are defeated in a sea-fight off Actium, and Epidamnus surrenders to the Corcyraeans.
plh/reis h)=san and 17, e)peplh/rwnto: the regular terms for the manning of ships. Cf. c. 35. 5; 47. 2; 141. 14; vi.32.1; vii.37.17.
