prope/myantes: sending forward, proerou=nta(proagoreu/ein), to announce publicly. Cf. c. 140. 22; ii.13.9; iv.97.18. In neither word is pro/ temporal, and therefore pro/teron is not pleonastic, as prw=ton is in c. 23. 21.

e(bdomh/konta kai\ pe/nte: therefore in addition to the 68 mentioned in c. 27. § 2, there must have been others, probably those of the Eleans. There is no reason for preferring the number 70, given by Diod. xii. 31. In c. 27. 16, we have trisxi/lioi o(pli=tai; but 1000 may have been elsewhere employed; and 2000 corresponds well with the 75 ships, since in early times there were 30 e)piba/tai (later 20) in a trireme. Boeckh, Publ. Econ. p. 383.— 5. e)pi\ th\n *)epi/damnon: in the direction of, to succour, Epidamnus.
e)nanti/a: acc. of inner obj. as adv. Kühn. 410, note 5. So o(moio/tropa, c. 6. 24; o(moi=a, c. 25. 18; a)gxw/mala, vii.71.21.— e)strath/gei: sing. preceding several subjs. G. 135, N. 1; H. 607.
*tima/nwr kte(.: other instances of names of father and son formed from the same roots are *nausi/filos *nausini/kou, *swsige/nhs *swsia/dou, *)epige/nhs *metage/nous, etc.

*)akti/w|: at that time only a sanctuary of Apollo, where games were celebrated every second year. Augustus founded to the north of it the town of Nicopolis, to commemorate his victory over Antonius, B.C.
31.
e)plh/roun: in parataxis with proe/pemyan. Cf. c. 26. 17; impf. to indicate that they began then to man the ships.
zeu/cantes: applied to the strengthening of ships by new cross-planks; zugw/mata au)tai=s e)nqe/ntes, Schol. Cartault, La trière Athénienne, p. 42.
e)piskeua/santes: of other kinds of repair which ships might need on putting to sea. The completion of all these preparations is expressed by the plpf., 17, which is unusual in a prot.
tessara/konta ga/r: referring to c. 25. 24, trih/reis ei)/kosi kai\ e(kato\n u(ph=rxon au)toi=s.— 18. a)ntanagago/menoi : see App.

e)ni/khsan: the aor. of the fact simply: usually the resulting consequences are included by the use of the impf. See on c. 13. 31.—para\ polu/: decisively. Cf. ii.8.13; 89. 16; iii.36.27; viii.6.16. Kühn. 440, p. 445.
au)toi=s: i.e. to the Corcyraeans in general.

parasth/sasqai: in Thuc. only in aor. (cf. c. 98. 8; 124. 18; iii.35.2; iv.79.12), to reduce, serving as causative to prosxwrei=n tini, ‘to submit.’ Cf. c. 74. 24; 103. 10; 117. 13, etc. th\n *)epi/damnon must be repeated as obj.—w(/ste: on condition that; see on c. 28. 18.—tou\s e)ph/ludas: i.e. the oi)kh/toras of c. 26. 8.— 23. *korinqi/ous: probably the larger part of the frouroi/, c. 26. 4.—dh/santas e)/xein: = e)n desmoi=s e)/xein. Cf. c. 30. 4; 52. 9; ii.5.23; 6. 8; iii.32.11; 34. 16; iv.21.5; v.42.10, etc. See on c. 38. 15.
Further hostilities on the part of the Corcyraeans; new preparations of the Corinthians.
*leuki/mmh|: (not *leuki/mnh|) the S. E. promontory of Corcyra, now Leukimo.

ou(\s...ai)xmalw/tous :
i.e. those taken in the sea-fight, as to whom no agreement had been made; not those taken in Epidamnus.
h(sshme/noi: chiefly used in pf. of defeat sustained. Cf. c. 63. 2; v.73.7; vi.72.8; vii.40.5.
e)kra/toun: the impf. denotes their continued superiority. Cf. iii.32.14; vii.57.34. The following aors. e)/temon, e)ne/prhsan express the particular facts which ensued.
e)pi/neion : in ii.84.33 again, of the Elean naval station at Cyllene.— nau=s kai\ xrh/mata: cf. c. 27. 15.

te: and so. See on c. 4. 5.— tou= xro/nou to\n plei=ston: see on c. 2. 12. The meaning of these words is doubtful. It is probable that they denote the remainder of the year available for war after the sea-fight, and that periio/nti tw=| qe/rei in 13 means when the first summer was drawing to a close. But some suppose that these expressions include besides the earlier portion of the succeeding summer. See App.
sfw=n: the pron. gen. thus placed has almost the effect of a dat. of interest. Cf. c. 35. 15; 71. 15; 82. 14; ii.27.9.
*xeime/rion: see on c. 46. 9.
a)ntestratopedeu/onto: after the verb in 14 a kind of epanaphora: see on c. 28. 8. Cf. c. 128. 1, 6.

to\ qe/ros tou=to: the summer succeeding the battle; and so the xeimw/n next spoken of is the first winter after the
same event.

h)/dh: to be taken closely with xeimw=nos, when it was now winter. Cf. nukto\s h)/dh, iii.106.12; pro\s to\ e)/ar h)/dh, v.17.7; h(me/ras h)/dh, v.59.2; similarly, e)/ti nu/kta, ii.3.16; e)/ti e)n th=| ei)rh/nh|, iii.13.5. Cf. c. 103. 8.
The Corcyraeans and the Corinthians betake themselves to Athens.

to\n d) e)niauto\n...u(/steron : the two years of preparation here spoken of include the period mentioned in c. 30. 13-20, i.e. from spring of 434 to spring of 432. The embassy of the Corcyraeans to Athens may have been sent at the beginning of 432, when the preparations of the Corinthians were nearing completion. Krüger, Stud. I. p. 218 ff.
o)rgh=| fe/rontes: pressing on with the zeal of anger. Cf. v.80.7, qumw=| e)/feron. iv.121.4, to\n po/lemon proqu/mws oi)/sein.

ta\ kra/tista : adv., as in c. 19. 8.—e)/k te au)th=s kte(.: the prep. is to be repeated before th=s a)/llhs *(ella/dos. See on c. 6. 21. If e)k governed both gens., it should have run, e)c au)th=s te . . . kai\ th=s a)/llhs. Kr. Spr. 69, 59, 2; Kühn. 520, note 5.
misqw=| pei/qontes: subord. to a)gei/rontes. Cf. c. 18. 19; 25. 18.

kai\ (h)=san ga\r . . .) e)/docen: a causal sentence, thus placed in parataxis before the main one, is common in Hdt., and not rare in Thuc. Cf. c. 57. 16; 87. 2; iii.70.11; 107. 16; vii.48.12; viii.109.3. Since here kai/ belongs to the principal sentence, and the const. is not confused as in c. 72. 1, the causal should be separated by a parenthesis. Here e)/nstondoi is a subst., allies, with gen.; in c. 40. 15; iii.65.19, it is adj. with dat. G. 181; H. 754; Kühn. 423, note 24.

e)segra/yanto e(autou/s: had had themselves enrolled, in the list of allies who were parties on one side or the other to the spondai\ triakontou/teis. c. 115. § 1.— 10. cumma/xous: attracted by the understood subj. of inf. G. 136, N. 3; H. 941; Kühn. 475, 2 a. Cf. c. 12. 2. The inf. gene/sqai does not depend on peira=sqai, for they were seeking only what the terms of the treaty allowed. See c. 35. § 2.
eu(ri/skesqai: to procure for themselves (by effort). Cf. c. 58. 6; v.32.25.

presbeuso/menoi: in v.39.7 the pres. partic. in same sense; both are equally permissible. Cobet rejects the word in both places, since, elsewhere, Thuc. always uses the mid. presbeu/esqai = legatos mittere (c. 126. 1; ii.7.16; iv.41.14; vi.104.14), whereas legatum esse is presbeu/ein (not in Thuc.; but in vi.55.11, it = maiorem esse natu).— 14. e)mpo/dion ge/nhtai: = kwlu/sh|, and so followed by inf. GMT. 95, 2; H. 963.
qe/sqai: see on c. 25. 2.— katasta/shs: cf. iii.36.23, of an assembly convened for a special purpose, i.e. su/gklhtos. Schömann, Ant. of Greece, I. 380.
h)=lqon: sc. e(ka/teroi, to which here oi( *kerkurai=oi, and in c. 36. 22 oi( *kori/nqioi, are in part. appos. On these speeches see Grote, V. c. 47, p. 321.

div2.head: Speech of the Corcyraean ambassadors at Athens. Chaps. 32-36.
div2.p: § 1, 2. Whoever asks for aid without being able to appeal to obligation, should show that the granting of his request will be attended with advantage and not injury to those who help him.

mh/te eu)ergesi/as...proufeilome/nhs : without having any claim on the score of important service rendered or of alliance. Cf. Hdt. v. 82, h( e)/xqrh h( proofeilome/nh. The pres. partic. expresses the standing obligation, mh/te, the hypothetical generality of the thought.
tou\s pe/las: has no local meaning, but simply = others, his neighbours. Cf. 16; c. 37. 13, 20; 69. 13; 70. 2, etc.

a)nadida/cai: show on the contrary or rather; for the absence of previous claim would be likely to give rise to an unfavourable judgment. Cf. iii.97.2; viii.86.4.—prw=ton: has its correlative in e)/peita de/. Cf. v.31.3; 61. 15; vi.2.18; vii.23.5. Its position gives it prominence enough without me/n, which before ma/lista me/n, if possible, would have been objectionable.—kai\ cu/mfora: implies ‘not only help for himself.’ dei=sqai properly takes gen. of person or of thing, but not often together as in 23. Kühn. 417, 2. But a neut. acc. of inner obj. is freq. found. Cf. Xen. An. vii.2.34, tau=t' e)sti\n a(\ e)gw\ u(mw=n de/omai. Here it = cu/mforon de/hsin de/ontai.

o(/ti ge :
with conjs. and preps. ge is often placed before what it really emphasizes; here ou)k e)pizh/mia.
*kerkurai=oi de/: and now the Corcyraeans. de/ brings their case under the general rule. Cf. c. 121. 1; ii.64.28; iii.10.7.
pare/cesqai: mid., as in ii.62.32, implying that the powers of the subject are exerted. ‘Dynamic mid.’ Kr. Spr. 52, 8, 2.

§ 3-5. We must indeed admit that our former rule, of keeping aloof from all entangling alliances, does not justify itself in view of the danger which now threatens us from the Corinthians; and we now renounce it.

tetu/xhke de\ kte(.: before they proceed to give the promised justification of their petition (which comes in c. 33), the de/, and in truth, introduces a recognition of the perilous mistake of their previous behaviour. The pred. adjs. a)/logon, a)cu/mforon after tetu/xhke without a partic. Cf. c. 106. 4; ii.87.23; Soph. Aj. 9; El. 46, 313; Ar. Av. 760; Kühn. 483 c. Herbst, Philol. 24, p. 652. tetu/xhke, it has turned out, indicates the unusual coincidence of two bad results of the same cause (to\ au)to/).

e)pith/deuma: a course of conduct based on principles; of individuals, vi.15.18; 28. 13; of states and peoples, c. 71. 9; 138. 4; ii.37.11; vi.18.19. The consistent carrying out of the same is e)pith/deusis, ii.36.15; vii.86.26.— pro\s u(ma=s: in your eyes; e)s th\n xrei/an: in respect of the request we make; e)s ta\ h(me/tera au)tw=n e)n tw=| paro/nti: as regards our position at the present time.—h(mi=n: belongs to tetu/xhke a)/logon kai\ a)cu/mforon. The a)/logon, “involving a contradiction,” is explained by 12, cu/mmaxoi/ te . . . h(/komen, the a)cu/mforon by 13, kai\ a(/ma . . . kaqe/stamen.
e)n tw=| pro\ tou=: with xro/nw|, ii.58.12; 73. 10; without xro/nw|, iv.72.13, including all past time up to the present. Note the behaviour of the Corcyraeans recorded in Hdt. vii. 168.
*korinqi/wn: to be joined with po/lemon. Cf. Xen. An. ii.5.7, to\n qew=n po/lemon.
kaqe/stamen : here we stand; an emphatic e)sme/n, with pred. adj. Cf. c. 70. 3; ii.59.9; iii.40.10; 102. 26; iv.26.25; vi.15.17; vii.28.31.

perie/sthken kte(.: the verb
expresses the change and its result. Cf. c. 78. 5; 120. 27; iv.12.12; vi.24.6; 61. 18; vii.18.26; viii.1.9. The partic. fainome/nh of actual manifestation, opposed to dokou=sa of fallacious appearance. And so (kai/, introducing the final consequence) what was formerly regarded as our wise discretion, in that we took no share in the risks of the policy of others by joining in a foreign alliance, has now at last (peri-) shown itself to be sheer want of foresight and weakness. The inf. clause to\ mh\ . . . cugkinduneu/ein is in appos. to h( . . . swfrosu/nh. Cf. c. 41. 8; vii.36.26. a)bouli/a and a)sqe/neia, the result of the a)/logon and a)cu/mforon.

th\n me\n ou)=n...naumaxi/an : though grammatically construed with a)pewsa/meqa after the analogy of nika=n tina ma/xhn, has at the head of the sentence an almost abs. position; as regards the victory, however. This effect must be often noted where the construction offers no difficulty. Cf. 33. 16; 73. 10; 86. 7; 142. 6; ii.62.1; iii.15.4.
kata\ mo/nas: singlehanded. Cf. c. 37. 17. An elliptical phrase with no certain supplement. See on c. 14. 15.
w(/rmhntai: have made themselves ready for war. Cf. ii.9.1; vi.33.6.

kai\ a(/ma: adds a new reason; not here temporal. See on c. 2. 9.—22, 24. ki/ndunos, a)na/gkh, cuggnw/mh: usually without e)sti/. Kühn. 354 b. Cf. iv.61.17; v.88.1. Here for ki/ndunos we must supply e)/stai or a)\n ei)/h.
u(mw=n...panto/s : dependent on dei=sqai, to which here is joined also the gen. of the thing. Cf. Hdt. v.40.7; Xen. Cyr. viii.3.19.
mh/: belongs only to meta\ kaki/as, not to the verb. Cf. c. 37. 6; iii.14.7.
tolmw=men: we venture, decide. The thing to be encountered is not a danger but an unfavourable judgment.

The proof we offer consists in the fact that, in return for your support which will bind us to eternal gratitude, we bring you our fleet, second only to your own, and that too at a time when the Peloponnesians have already resolved upon war with you, and wish only to get us out of the way first.

genh/setai de\ kte(.: recurs to the promise of c. 32. § 2, with de/ as in c. 23. 1.—kalh/: not in a moral sense,
but an enhanced cu/mforos. Cf. c. 93. 11; ii.84.12; and e)n kalw=|, v.59.17; 60. 11.—h( cuntuxi/a th=s...xrei/as : the present occurrence of our request; the fact that we now come before you with our prayer. Cf. iii.45.18; 82. 14; 112. 26; v.11.17; vi.54.2; vii.57.5.

kata\ polla\ kte(.: the points are introduced by prw=ton me/n, e)/peita, and te in 6 (the postscript te: B. L. G. on Just. Mart. Apol. i.22.10. Cf. c. 2. 6). Since the three clauses depend alike on o(/ti, we must read kataqh/sesqe for kata/qhsqe(kataqh=sqe) of the Mss.; and with w(s a)/n must be supplied du/nhsqe kataqe/sqai (cf. Isae. 111. 21; Lys. XXIV 4; Dem. XVIII. 256, 280), not kataqei=sqe, as Cl. says, referring to vi.57.13, where the main verb is past, not fut. as here. “You will lay up for yourselves in the highest possible degree a store of well-deserved (th/n) gratitude, with an ever-abiding record, in the fact that the maintenance of our independence will be due to your support.”

ske/yasqe kte(.: after luphrote/ra, where the sentence might close with the easy supplement of h)\ au(/th, the eu)praci/a is enforced by the enumeration of its favourable features in the sentence ei) h(
 . . . i)sxu/n. The insertion of h)/ before ei) h(/n would only weaken the effect. Cf. Lys. XIII 77, pw=s a)
 ge/noito a)/nqrwpos miarw/teros, o(/stis—e)to/lmhsen e)lqei=n w(s tou/tous; Eur. Alc. 879, ti/ ga a)ndri\ kako
 mei=zon, a(martei=n pisth=s a)lo/xou; In such cases the inf. or rel. sentence is explanatory of a tou/tou or tau/ths which is sometimes expressed, as in Aesch. Ag. 601, ti/ ga gunaiki\ tou/tou fe/ggos h(/dion drakei=n, . . . a)ndri\ . . . pu/las a)noi=cai; Plat. Gorg. 519 d; sometimes, as here, omitted. Kühn. 542, note 6.— 8. ei) h(
...au)tepa/ggeltos : ei) with indic. presents the actual case more vividly to the mind than the causal e)pei/ would do. Cf. c. 76. 8; 86. 4; iv.10.20. The rel. clause with the antec. incorporated in it (G. 154; H. 995), h(
 du/namin u(mi=n prosgene/sqai, which is the obj. of u(mei=s a)
 . . . e)timh/sasqe (cf. iii.40.33; vi.10.17), is placed first for effect, and then resumed by the emphatic au(/th. Cf. c. 83. 8. au)tepa/ggeltos, offering itself, from the mid. e)pagge/llesqai. So in iv.120.18.
e)s tou\s pollou/s: in the eyes of the world.

a)reth/n: gen
erosity, which is ready to succour the needy. Cf. c. 69. 7; ii.40.22; iii.56.27. Here = do/can a)reth=s, the repute of magnanimity. Kühn. 346, 6. B. L. G. on Pind. Py. IV. 173. Cf. Soph. Ant. 924, th\n dusse/beian eu)sebou=s) e)kthsa/mhn.
oi(=s d) e)pamunei=te...i)sxu/n : and gratitude in the hearts of those whom you shall help, and increase of strength for yourselves.

kai\ o)li/goi...paragi/gnontai : few, when they beg for an alliance, come and offer to those whom they call upon (c. 101. 3) security and honour in no less degree than they expect to receive them. Here ko/smos (see on c. 5. 11) corresponds to a)reth/, and a)sfa/leia to xa/ris and i)sxu/s.
to\n de\ po/lemon: though subj. of e)/sesqai, has almost the effect of an abs. acc. See on c. 32. 17. See App.
gnw/mhs a(marta/nei: he fails to form a right opinion. Cf. c. 92. 6; iii.98.13. But with gnw/mh| in vi.78.16.

polemhsei/ontas: partic. depending on ai)sqa/netai. G. 279, 2; H. 982. This desiderative here only; others in c. 95. 24; iii.84.4; iv.28.7; viii.56.11; 79. 13. In c. 118. 10, Thuc. denies this eagerness for war. But the statement is here justified, as one of ta\ de/onta, c. 22. 5, by the actual outbreak of the war. See also c. 88. Herbst.—kai\ tou\s *korinqi/ous...e)pixei/rhsin : St. is right in making prokatalamba/nontas alone depend on ai)sqa/netai, showing by commas that duname/nous and u)/ntas are subord. to it, and in rejecting kai/. duname/nous, of great weight. Cf. c. 18. 10. prokatalamba/nontas (c. 36. 18) kte(., are assailing us now in preparation for an attack on you.

kat) au)tou\s...stw=men : stand together against them, as it were on the battle-field. Cf. c. 48. 12; 62. 24; v.71.22; 73. 10.—mhde\...a(ma/rtwsin : the order is, mhde\ duoi=n a(ma/rtwsi (cf. iii.53.6; 69. 9; vii.50.2; viii.71.14) fqa/sai, so that the inf. is epexegetic; and that they may not be disappointed in their two objects, to gain them before our alliance is effected. duoi=n is explained in the two inf. clauses, h)\ kakw=sai . . . bebaiw/sasqai, which after the neg. are not mutually exclusive but are placed co-ord. = mh/te kakw=sai mh/te bebaiw/sasqai. Since each of these is indispensable to the Corinthians, the Schol. is wrong in
saying that duoi=n is for duoi=n tou= e(te/rou, as in iv.28.25, in a positive sent., not neg., as here.
h(me/teron: i.e. tw=n te *kerkurai/wn kai\ tw=n *)aqhnai/wn. To avoid confusion after this use of h(me/teron, the Corcyraeans are next referred to not by h(mw=n but by tw=n me/n.
dido/ntwn : offering (cf. c. 35. 22), and therefore pres. partic., whereas the decisive decame/nwn is in the aor.
Note the paronomasia, as often in Thuc. Cf. c. 37. 16; ii.62.27; iii.39.10; 82. 31; iv.62.10; vi.76.7.

You need feel no scruple on the ground of interference with the traditional relations of colony and mothercity; for the Corinthians have already trespassed on these. And you will do well to be on your guard against their hostile purposes.
maqe/twsan: we would have them know, with a touch of irony. Such turns are common in the tragic poets. See App.
e)kpe/mpontai: the subject is by synesis oi( a)/poikoi implied in pa=sa a)poiki/a. Cf. c. 13. 6.
proklhqe/ntes: prokalei=sqai/ tina (always mid.) e)s kri/sin, as e)s sponda\s kai\ dia/lusin, iv.19.1; e)s di/kas, vii.18.16, 23.

tw=| i)/sw|: i.e. di/kas dido/ntes kai\ lamba/nontes. Cf. ii.37.5; iii.53.5.—metelqei=n: metie/nai is used with acc. either of the charge to be maintained or of the person to be punished. Cf. iv.62.13.

e)/stw ti...drw=sin : “let their behaviour to us be a warning for you.” For ti, bringing out the significance of the tekmh/rion, cf. ii.11.14; iii.13.4.— 9. a)pa/th| te...deome/nois te : these words placed at the head of their clauses to emphasize the two means of seduction which may be employed; and therefore not the usual mh/te . . . mh/te.— 10. e)ktou= eu)qe/os : belongs to deome/nois, in an open way, opp. to a)pa/th|, which resorts to crooked ways. Cf. a)po\ tou= profanou=s, c. 35. 17; a)po\ tou= eu)qe/os, iii.43.5; a)po\ poi/ou a)\n ta/xous a)pofu/goi,
Xen. An. ii.5.7.

lamba/nwn: this verb with substs. of moral meaning forms a periphrasis of verbs expressing disposition, feeling, etc. (metame/leian lamba/nein = metamelei=sqai), as poiei=sqai does with expressions of activity. See on c. 6. 3. Cf. eu)/noian, c. 77. 21; swfrosu/nhn, viii.64.21; fro/nhsin, Soph. Phil. 1078. Then the place of an adv. is supplied by a pred. adj., as e)laxi/stas here.
diateloi/h: with adj. without w)/n, as vi.89.6. See on c. 32. 9.
§ 1-4. Your admitting us will be no violation of your obligations to the Lacedaemonians: we claim no more than is permitted by the treaty.
ou)de/: i.e. just as little as you will violate colonial obligations.
mhdete/rwn: not ou)dete/rwn, because, though expressing a fact, it is under the influence of the cond. partic. dexo/menoi.
ei)/rhtai : it is expressly stipulated. Cf. c. 40. 4; 139. 7; 140. 14; iv.23.6; v.21.6; 25. 10; vii.18.14.

h(/tis...cummaxei= : rel. sent. = logical cond. GMT. 61, 1; H. 914.— 4. par)...e)lqei=n : to join whichever side it may feel itself inclined. The verb is used pers. with dat., c. 129. 14; ii. 68.7; viii.84.16; without obj., v.4.11; 37. 19. Cf. Hdt. vi.128.11; ix.79.10. In c. 40. 5, we have bou/letai for it.—kai\ deino\n...a(\ deo/meqa : the period has its two members, the coexistence of which is said to be deino/n, arranged in parataxis, though we should naturally make the former subord. with ‘while’ (see on c. 121. 19); and each member comprises the ascending steps of indignity (a) a)po/ te kte(., kai\ prose/ti kte(., kai\ ou)x h(/kista kte(.; (b) a)po\ th=s kte(., kai\ a)po/ kte(., ei)=ta kte(. The use of ei)=ta, actually, expresses lively indignation; without a conj. also in Ar. Pl. 79; Plat. Apol. 23 c; Theaet. 151 c; Dem. 1. 12. This arrogance is strongly protested against in the simple words polu\ de\ . . . e(/comen, as in iii.63.13. See App.
a(\ deo/meqa: see on c. 32. 4.

e)n ai)ti/a| (or di) ai)ti/as) e)/xein: is used by Thuc. for ai)tia=sqai; the former in ii.59.4; v.60.10; 65. 24; vii.81.3; the latter in ii.60.16. On the position of polu/ before the prep., see
Kühn. 452, note 3. Cf. c. 63. 5.

ou)k e)xqrou/s: as the Corinthians are, c. 33. 20.—ou)x o(/pws: = non modo non. When the ou)x o(/pws clause precedes, it always contains the weaker of the two contrasted notions. But since here there is no relation of climax between ‘hindering’ and ‘promoting,’ the required meaning forces us to take the notion of ‘hindering’ negatively. Aken, T. u. M. § 119 ff.; Kühn. 525, 3 b.—kwlutai\ genh/sesqe: will plant yourselves as opponents: not a simple periphrasis for kwlu/sete. On iii.2.11, Cl. refers, among other examples, to iii.23.13; v.9.38; viii.86.23. Cf. c. 4. 3; ii.43.8.
proslabei=n: see on c. 24. 17.

h(/n: grammatically in same const. as du/namin, but referring in adversative relation to the whole preceding sentence, = “this, however, is not right, but it is right—.” For this force of the rel., cf. c. 10. 20; 39. 2, 10; 69. 20; 95. 20.—ka)xei/nwn: see on c. 30. 14. Instead of misqou=sqai, we have strangely tou\s misqofo/rous. We should say rather, “you should prevent them from raising mercenaries in places under your control.” The reading of Codex Monacensis, ta\s . . . misqofori/as, though suiting the sense, must be regarded as a gloss. The use of kai/ before e)kei/nwn and h(mi=n implies that impartiality requires perfect equality of treatment: “If you will not help us, stop them also; if you allow them to enlist men among your subjects, send help to us also.”
kaq' o(/ ti a)\n peisqh=te: in so far as we may succeed in persuading you. Cf. c. 69. 10; iv.118.54.
a)po\ tou= profanou=s: adv., see on c. 34. 10.
§ 5. By receiving us you will gain allies who are perfectly trustworthy and very powerful on the sea.

u(pei/pomen: we premised, we alleged as the basis of our proposal, in c. 32. § 1. Cf. Dem. XVIII. 60. In the two other passages in Thuc. where this verb occurs, c. 90. 25; ii.102.30, it means ‘say besides.’

kai\ me/giston: see on c. 142. 1; and, what is most important.—oi(/ te au)toi/: the correlative of this is not kai\ ou(=toi, which means iique, and these too, but kai\ nautikh=s kte(., which in consequence of the parenthetical insertions takes the form of a new sentence. The force of a)podei/knumen is felt in what follows only generally as a verb of exhortation.—h(mi=n: both of us. Cf. h(me/teron, c. 33. 24.

h)=san: they are as we saw, c. 33. § 3. Kr. Spr.
53, 2, 5, calls this the didactic impf. GMT. 11, N. 6; H. 833; Kühn. 383, 5. But Cl. thinks that the tense is used as if the desired alliance were already realized.—o(/per...pi/stis : and this is the surest guarantee of fidelity. On o(/per (for which Cobet reads h(/per, comparing Eur. Med. 14; Thuc. iii. 116.4), see Kühn. 369, 2.

tou\s metasta/ntas: i.e. the Corcyraeans themselves, since they have fully abandoned their mother-city. Cf. c. 107. 27; ii.67.8; v.29.12; viii.53.19. The fact that those whom they had deserted were able to punish them if they stood alone, would induce them to hold fast to their new allies.—nautikh=s...didome/nhs : i.e. nautikh=s ou)/shs th=s cummaxi/as h(\n di/domen (see on c. 33. 25).
ou)x o(moi/a: i.e. u(mi=n blaberwte/ra h)\ ei) h)peirw=tis h( cummaxi/a e)di/doto.
h( a)llotri/wsis : the rejection; only here in classic writers.

ma/lista me/n: best of all. Cf. c. 32. 4; 40. 13. On ei) de\ mh/, see on c. 28. 10.—e)a=n and e)/xein: may be taken as imv. infs., as in v.9.26. Or, as Kr. thinks, they may depend on kra/tisto/n e)sti implied in ma/lista me/n. Cl. seems to govern them by a)podei/knumen, 19.
tou=ton fi/lon e)/xein : cf. iv.86.5. e)/xein expresses a fixed relation better than xrh=sqai would do.

§ 1-3. Do not, therefore, allow any timidity to delay you; but, in view of the great advantages of our position, attach us to yourselves, and so gain the preponderance over the Peloponnesians, instead of letting us fall into the hands of the Corinthians, only to increase the strength of your enemies.
ta/de cumfe/ronta le/gesqai: for cumfe/ronta ta/de ei)=nai a(\ le/getai.

fobei=tai : the subj. to be supplied from the preceding o(/tw|. See on c. 10. 21.—mh\...ta\s sponda\s lu/sh| : i.e. if the argument of the preceding chap. has not succeeded in removing your misgiving, that the reception of a state which is engaged in open hostility with another may be regarded as an act of hostility against the latter. This anxiety is not confuted; but they are advised to have a full apprehension of the danger (to\ dedio/s), and to realize all the consequences of taking the step; for this only will inspire respect in their opponents. Inactivity may indeed secure a certain sort of confidence (to\ qarsou=n), but can only betray weakness in the eyes of their enemies.

to\ dedio/s and to\ qarsou=n: this use of neut. partics. and adjs. for abstract nouns (GMT. 108, 2, N. 4; H. 966 b; Kühn. 403 g) is a favourite one with Thuc. It presents to the mind the abstract quality in operation, standing between e.g. to\ dedie/nai and o(/ti de/die. to\ dedio\s au)tou=: i.e. the fear which sees in himself no adequate strength. Opp. to this is to\ qarsou=n mh\ decame/nou, i.e. the
confidence that he has nothing to fear, which has led him to reject allies. The gen. decame/nou, like au)tou=, properly depends on the partic., but has the effect of an abs. gen.—i)sxu\n e)/xon: if it is backed by strength, i.e. if it leads him to secure the means of effective action.
fobh=son: this and e)so/menon, bouleuo/menos, pronow=n are supplementary partics. to gnw/tw. GMT. 113; H. 982.
a)dee/steron: here in the rare pass. sense, less formidable. Cf. Plat. Symp. 198 a, a)dee\s de/os dedie/nai. In ii.59.13; iii.37.4, ‘without fear.’
ou) to\ ple/on h)/: see on c. 9. 21.—h)\ kai/: cf. c. 140. 10; ii.38.7. Kühn. 524, 2; Kr. Spr. 69, 32, 13.—tw=n *)aqhnw=n: without repeated prep. See on c. 6. 21.
kai\ ou)...pronow=n : and that he is not taking the best thought for her.
e)s to\n...po/lemon : in view of the coming and all but present war.—to\ au)ti/ka periskopw=n: from regard for the moment. Cf. v.16.12; vii.42.8; viii.27.25.

e)ndoia/zh|: he hesitates. Cf. c. 122. 15; vi.91.20. Not elsewhere in Attic.— o(\ meta\ megi/stwn...polemou=tai : which is with the most momentous consequences made either friend or foe. polemou=tai, “placed in a hostile attitude,” as in c. 57. 5, 6. The kairoi/ are regarded as themselves friends or enemies.

th=s te...*sikeli/as : depending on para/plou (as c. 44. 16), which is governed by kalw=s kei=tai. See on c. 22. 13. Cf. c. 75. 3; iii.92.14, 17.— 11. para/plou: not dia/plou, because the ancient mariners hugged the coast. The art. omitted as in c. 1. 11.

e)pelqei=n: to come to join. Cf. iii.69.8; Hdt. vi.95.5, e)ntau=qa stratopedeuome/noisi e)ph=lqe o( nautiko\s pa=s strato/s. Usually in hostile sense. See on c. 70. 16.—to/ te e)nqe/nde: the art. merely to give a subst. character to e)nqe/nde, a fleet from this side. Herbst notes that this passage could be regarded as one of ta\ de/onta (c. 22. 5) only by a writer who was acquainted with the latter part of the war.

braxuta/tw| kefalai/w| kte(.: for kefa/laion to/de braxu/tato/n e)stin w(=| a)\n ma/qoite. For a)/n repeated in emphatic positions, cf. 77. 21; 136. 18. GMT. 42, 3; H. 862.—toi=s te cu/mpasi kai\ kaq' e(/kaston: to be taken adv., on the whole as well as in detail, without any grammatical relation to kefalai/w|, to which Kr. and B. make it appos., like c. 145. 4, kaq' e(/kasta/ te
kai\ to\ cu/mpan. In viii.91.3, toi=s cu/mpasi is perhaps to be taken so, and not personally. O. Ribbeck (Rhein. Mus. 23, 211) proposes to place these words before cumforw/taton, as v. H. places them after e)sti, saying “intelligo: cum universis tum singulis (hominibus).”

ma/qoite: with inf. implies reaching not merely a correct view, but a decision.—tri/a me\n...nautika/ : sc. e)sti/, o)/nta being joined with lo/gou a)/cia, as w)/n is often placed before important attributes. Cf. c. 21. 5; 118. 10; 124. 4; ii.97.20; iv.13.19. But Sh. perhaps better makes o)/nta depend on ma/qoite taken now in the sense of ‘learn that,’ not of ‘learn to.’ Cf. vi.40.2. The two clauses tri/a me\n . . . *korinqi/wn, and tou/twn de\ . . . a)gwni/zesqai are formally co-ord. by me/n, de/, but in effect the former is subord. to the latter.

tw=n *korinqi/wn: the omission of to/ is surprising, yet established by the best Mss., so that the omission of the art. is similar to that of the prep. in 6. It is inserted, however, by St., B., and most editors.—tou/twn d) ei) kte(.: notice the “minatory and monitory” form of the condition, ei) with fut. indic. B. L. G. Trans. of Am. Phil. Assoc. 1876, p. 9.
tai=s h(mete/rais: the dat. of measure of difference with plei/osi, with a naval force augmented by our fleet.

div2.head: Speech of the Corinthian ambassadors. Chaps. 37-43.
div2.p: The Corcyraeans have misrepresented their position as well as ours. They have hitherto maintained their isolation that they might have no check on their wrong-doing.

a)ll' w(s kai/: instead of the usual a)lla\ kai\ w(s. The trajection is due to a desire to emphasize strongly the perversion of truth attributed to the Corcyraeans. kai/, actually, covers the two following clauses, which are again united in peri\ a)mfote/rwn, neut. (not e(kate/rwn). See App.
polemou=ntai: pass. of polemei=n tini, as c. 68. 18; iv.68.12. See on c. 2. 18.

ou(/tw: in reference to mnhsqe/ntas: “we must
first make our statement on both these points; when that is done.” Kühn. 486, note 5. Cf. c. 22. 7; iii.96.8; iv.88.8; vi.24.3.

th\n a)f' h(mw=n a)ci/wsin: implies that the Corinthians are making a well-grounded claim, as opposed to the pressing entreaty (xrei/a) of the Corcyraeans. The emphatic a)f' h(mw=n is for the same reason preferred to the simple gen. Cf. c. 39. 14; ii.39.6; iv.108.36; vi.40.15; vii.77.17.

a)sfale/steron proeidh=te: i.e. that you may the better protect yourselves against their deceptive persuasion by knowing the facts in time, before you take the decisive step.—mh\ a)logi/stws: not without reasonable grounds; litotes for ‘with mature consideration.’ mh/ here is to be closely connected with the adv., as ou)k with ei)ko/tws in 3. See on c. 32. 24.
fasi\ de/: now they assert; de/ marks the transition from the general statement to the details, and should not be altered with Kr. to dh/. See on c. 32. 7. Cf. iii.61.9.—to\ sw=fron: see on c. 2. 19.

to\ de/: de/ expresses a vigorous opposition, but on the contrary, like cum tamen and to/ retains its old dem. sense. Cf. Dem. XVIII. 140, to\ d' ou) toiou=to/n e)sti; Stallbaum on Plat. Apol. 23 a. Kühn. 459 c.—a)reth=|: from magnanimity. The repetition of the prep. is not necessary. Cf. iv.19.12.

cu/mmaxo/n te ou)de/na: for ou)/te cu/mmaxo/n tina, to lay more stress on the noun. Cf. c. 34. 9. Since the connexion of ou)/te—ou)/te depends on the repeated te, so here te—ou)/te, though not occurring elsewhere in Thuc., is not less justifiable than ou)/te —te. So Herbst, Philol. 10, p. 333.
parakalou=ntes: gives the occasion of ai)sxu/nesqai, “they are not inclined to expose themselves to shame by inviting others to join them in their base undertakings.” See App.

qe/sin: since kei=sqai is the pf. pass. of tiqe/nai, qe/sis is its verbal noun, and so this expression is like e(/dran kaqh=sqai, Eur. Heracl. 55; prosqakei=n, Soph. O. C. 1166. G. 159; H. 715; Kühn. 410, 1 b.

pare/xei: copiam facit, here with acc. and inf.; with inf. alone, iii.63.10; with dat. and inf., viii.50.26.—au)tou\s dikasta\s...gi/gnesqai : Cl. explains this, with a zeugma of gi/gnesqai, “to constitute themselves judges of the wrongs they do rather than enter into any covenant which would hamper them.” He thinks that this sense of kata\ cunqh/kas gi/gnesqai is justified by gi/gnesqai with kata\ custa/seis, ii.21.15; kata\ cullo/gous, iii.27.7; di) a)nokwxh=s, c. 40. 16; e)p' a)mfo/tera, c. 139. 20; e)k tou= i)/sou, ii.3.18; e)n dikastai=s,
iii.53.4; di) e)/xqras, Ar. Ran. 1412. Another explanation seems simpler: “They can in consequence of their independent position make themselves judges of the wrongs they do to a greater extent than would be possible if commercial treaties bound them,” where gi/gnesqai is taken impers., = rem agi. Sh. and Jowett understand dikasta/s as subj. of gi/gnesqai, “than that judges should be appointed by covenant.”

e)kple/ontas: sc. tou\s *kerkurai/ous, while the other partic. agrees with tou\s a)/llous, i.e. the citizens of other cities who a)na/gkh| katai/rousi by reason of the position of the island (c. 36. 10).

ka)n tou/tw|: and in this state of things, described in § 2, 3. Cf. c. 81. 9.—to\ eu)prepe\s a)/spondon: cf. c. 32, § 3, 4. An adj. used as subst. qualified by an epithet, as to\ a)nqrw/peion kompw=des, v.68.6; to\ cu/nhqes h(/suxon, vi.34.17; to\ pro/teron cu/nhqes fobero/n, vi.55.15.

probe/blhntai: they have put forward as a cloak. Cf. ii.87.14; iii.63.9. Their designs expressed by final sentences; cunadikh/swsin, the aor., of single cases, a)dikw=si, pres., of long opportunity. There is a paronomasia (c. 33. 26) here, since kata\ mo/nas (cf. c. 32. 18) answers to the cun-. St. after Cobet omits the second o(/pws, since the following clauses are merely an epexegesis of a)dikw=si.

ple/on e)/xwsi : this phrase is regularly employed to designate unrighteous gain. Cf. c. 76. 15; iii.43.12; iv.62.16; viii.99.12; and so the noun pleone/kths, c. 40. 2. —h)\n de/ pou/...a)naisxuntw=si : this does not, as Cl. says, imply that there is a third method, opposed to the force or fraud of the two preceding clauses; but that, if by either of these means they have made some (pou) gain, they may be able to brazen it out in the absence of witnesses. Cf. iv.86.5, where bi/a and a)pa/th are named as the two means by which men proslamba/nousi what they want. See App.
ei) h)=san: if they really were. Cf. c. 25. 23.

o(/sw|...h)=san : though this clause expresses the actual state of things, “in proportion as they are less assailable by others” (cf. c. 143. 21), the impf. is used by assimilation to the unreal cond. GMT. 64, 2; H. 919 b; Kühn. 399, 6.—to/sw| de/: so we should probably read with Hertlein for tosw=|de, which occurs only in reference to real relations of magnitude (cf. c. 23. 6; 122. 16; ii.72.7, etc.). The simple to/sw| for tosou/tw| is found in iv.28.13; viii.24.22. The use of de/ in apodosi after a dem. pron. or emphatic art. (ii.46.6; 65. 19; iii.
98. 2) is as early as Homer. Cf. Hom. A 58; I 167; g 10. G. 227, 2; H. 1046, 1 c; Kühn. 533, 1. Cf. also w(\s de/, Plat. Prot. 326 d, and ou(/tw de/, 328 a.
e)ch=n: like other imperss. of power, manner, etc., regularly in the impf. without a)/n. GMT. 49, 2, N. 3; H. 897.

ta\ di/kaia: more usually di/kas. Cf. c. 140. 14; v.59.24. See on c. 28. 6. The Corinthians did not regard the offers of the Corcyraeans, c. 28. § 2 ff., as di/kaia, as is stated in c. 39; and probably the art. is used with di/kaia to denote the behaviour which is actually required by justice.
They have behaved to us, their mother-city, in the most reckless way in many former instances, and recently in the case of Epidamnus.

ou)/te pro\s tou\s a)/llous: with no special reference, but to put stress on h(ma=s. pro/s = in their attitude towards. As e)s is the favourite prep. with a(marta/nein, 13, Thuc. may have shifted to it here to indicate the hostile relation of the Corcyraeans to the Corinthians. Cf. c. 55. 13; 130. 12; ii.60.1; 68. 25; iii.37.4, 5; vi.18.30; 86. 15. —toioi/de: = a)/ndres a)gaqoi/, as just defined.

a)festa=si: = h)llotri/wntai (c. 34. 3), the pf. denoting the fact as now manifested: they have separated themselves from us, and are in the unfriendly relation depicted in c. 25. § 4.—dia\ panto/s: as usual of time, constantly. Cf. c. 76. 3; 84. 4; 85. 2; ii.16.9; 49. 26; iii.58.14; 93. 8; iv.61.20; 119. 12; v.69.8; 105. 5; vii.6.6; 61. 8. The open hostility is introduced by kai\ nu=n.— 3. e)pi\ tw=| kakw=s pa/sxein : cf. c. 34. § 1.

e)kpemfqei=en: as Heraclides ap. Eustath. Hom. f 195, says: h( a)rxai/a *)atqi\s ta\ eu)ktika\ sugko/ptei kat' e)cai/resin mia=s sullabh=s (cf. Stahl, Qu. gr. p. 18); the shorter form of the opt. is everywhere adopted, even against the Mss. The opt. = e)cepe/mfqhmen of the dir. disc.

a)re/skontes: cf. iii.34.14; v.41.23; Soph. O. T. 274; Eur. I. T. 581. The partic. expresses an adj. notion always in readiness to
exert itself. See Am. J. of Ph., IV. p. 297.—ou)k o)rqw=s a)\n a)pare/skoimen: = ou)k o)rqw=s a)\n e)/xoi, ei) a)pare/skoimen.— 9. e)pestrateu/omen : so we should read with Ullrich (Beitr. z. Krit. I. 1), for e)pistrateu/omen, repeating the a)/n from toi=sd' a)/n. See App.—e)kprepw=s: in a way so unusual, considering the ordinary relation of a mother-city to its colonies. Cf. e)kprepe/steron, iii.55.6. —mh\...a)dikou/menoi : = ei) mh\ . . . h)dikou/meqa.

kalo
 h)=n: see on c. 37. 21.— 11. toi=sde me
...h(mi=n de\ ai)sxro/n : the second member of the sentence would naturally have been h(mi=n de\(kalo
)th=s o)rgh=s u(fi/esqai. But the suggestion of a willing submission on the part of the Corcyraeans occasions the vivid change, thus it would be a shame for us.

bia/sasqai: to use violence to, with acc. as in viii.53.9.—e)cousi/a| plou/tou: from the license which wealth occasions. The two words are used together in dat. in c. 123. 5. The position of te shows that polla/ is not to be taken directly with a)/lla, but rather covers the action of both the following clauses.
kakoume/nhn (= e)n w(=| e)kakou=to)kte(.: a similar parataxis to that in c. 28. 15. Cf. 35. § 3.—prosepoiou=nto: cf. c. 8. 16; 57. 10; ii.30.6; 33. 9; iv.77.13.

e(lo/ntes bi/a| e)/xousi: they have taken by force and now hold. Cf. c. 29. 23. From this use of e)/xein it comes to be employed with the partic. aor. or pf. as a periphrasis for those tenses, but expressing strongly the maintenance of the result attained; in Thuc. only in vi.39.10; 76. 11; frequent in the tragic poets, particularly Soph.; as Aj. 22; O. T. 577, 699; Antig. 1058, 1068. GMT. 112, 2, N. 7; H. 981 a.
For it was not till after they had begun their wrong-doing that they professed to be ready to submit to arbitration; and they allege this to entangle you in their guilt.

h(/n ge kte(.: the rel. has the effect of a strong adversative conj., as in c. 35. 15. So below, 10, ou(\s xrh=n. h(/n depends on to\n—prokalou/menon (cf. iv.20.4; v.37.24), which is defined by prou/xonta as well as e)k tou= a)sfalou=s: but surely not he who from a commanding and safe position challenges such a decision ought to be considered as saying anything worth listening to. For a similar combination of a partic. and adv. expression, cf. ii.89.22; iii.34.17; 42. 23.

le/gein ti: opp. to ou)de\n
le/gein. Cf. Plat. Crit. 46 d; Men. 92 d; Eur. H. F. 279; Ar. Eq. 334.—e)s i)/son...kaqista/nta : places on the same level with his opponent. Cf. c. 121. 15. The stress lies on e)/rga, which therefore attracts o(moi/ws. Cf. c. 58. 7; 70. 25; iii.47.13. Their offer to submit to arbitration should be accompanied by the evacuation of Epidamnus.

pri\n diagwni/zesqai: before proceeding to appeal to arms. Cl. gives a rendering which covers alike Poppo's armis discernere and Reiske's iudicio disceptare. But this is not necessary. Note the force of pri/n with pres. inf. In the next line it occurs again apparently in a neg. sentence. But here, as in c. 68. 9, the following clause with a)ll' e)peidh/ shows that ou) pri/n is used only as a note of time to bring out rhetorically the contrast of before and after. Sturm, *p*r*i*n, p. 89. GMT. 106, 2, N. 2; H. 924; Kr. Dial. 54, 17, 11. Cf. also the use of ou) in 8 after a)ciou=ntes with the regular mh/ in c. 43. 4.
to\ eu)prepe\s th=s di/khs: more striking than th\n eu)preph= di/khn. Cf. c. 68. 1; 69. 14.
pare/sxonto: they proffered. Cf. iii.36.3; 54. 1; 90. 18; 112. 15; iv.108.15.—ou) ta)kei=...a(marto/ntes : not satisfied with the wrongs they have committed yonder by themselves.

cummaxei=n kte(.: note the adv. force of cu/n (cf. c. 37. 16), to be, not their allies, but their accomplices in crime. Jowett. It is this parenthetical antithesis which justifies ou) with inf. after a verb of will. Kr. Spr. 67, 7, 3.

diafo/rous: qualifies sfa=s, though placed first for emphasis: to receive them now that they are at variance with us, and therefore in danger. The opposite to this follows, 10, o(/te a)sfale/statoi h)=san.

prosie/nai: i.e. for the purpose of seeking alliance. Cf. c. 40. 23; 71. 22; 75. 6; iv.76.27.—mh/: a pres. inf. depending on xrh/ regularly takes mh/. mh\ poi/ei is expressed by xrh\ mh\ poiei=n, but usually mh\ poih/sh|s by ou) xrh\ poih=sai. See Gildersleeve on Pind. Ol. IX. 40. Cf. Eur. Heracl. 969, xrh=n to/nde mh\ zh=n mhde\ fw=s o(ra=n e)/ti. Isocr. IV. 176, a(\ xrh=n a)nairei=n kai\ mhde\ mi/an e)a=n h(me/ran.

metadw/sete: and in 15 e(/cete, express categorically the cer
tainty of the disastrous results.

a)pogeno/menoi: though having had nothing to do with. a)po/ = ‘far from.’ Cf. Hdt. ix.69.4, a)pogenome/noisi th=s ma/xhs. Plut. Them. 2. 1, a)po\ tw=n maqhma/twn geno/menos. Elsewhere in Thuc. ‘be destroyed, lost.’ Cf. ii.34.4; 98. 10; v.74.12.—th=s a)f' h(mw=n ai)ti/as: cf. c. 37. 5, ai)ti/a being = ai)ti/asis. Cf. c. 83. 8; ii.18.9. Schol. ai)tiaso/meqa ga\r tou\s summaxh/santas toi=s *kerkurai/ois w(s e)xqrou/s.— 15. pa/lai de\ koinwnh/santas : this reading of the best Mss. requires for its subj. not tou\s *kerkurai/ous implied in ou(/s (10), but, following the intermediate clauses, e)kei/nous te kai\ u(ma=s. See on c. 18. 21. And since koinwnei=n is really = koino\n e)/xein, it here has the acc. obj. du/namin in contrast with ta\ a)pobai/nonta (cf. c. 83. 7; ii.11.37; viii.89.26); and only if both parties had before shared their power, ought they now to have the results of their policy in common. See App.
By receiving them you will break your obligations under the treaty, since you will be plainly acting to the prejudice of us, to whom you are bound by it.
ei)/rhtai: see on c. 35. 2.

a)gra/fwn: i.e. mh\ e)ggegramme/nwn. Cf. c. 31. 7.—ou) toi=s...e)sti/n : is not for, does not refer to, those who join one side to the prejudice of the other. With i)ou=sin supply para\ tou\s e(te/rous.
h( cunqh/kh : i.e. the whole treaty as well as each article of it.

mh\ a)/llou au(to\n a)posterw=n: not withdrawing himself from another who has a claim on him. Cf. Ar. Nub. 1305, o( ge/rwn a)tosterh=sai bou/letai ta\ xrh/maq' a(danei/sato; Arist. Rhet. ii.6.3, to\ a)posterh=sai parakataqh/khn. Usually the const. is reversed, as in c. 69. 4. Kühn. 411, note 10 d.

ei) swfronou=si: this condition applies to the whole clause, and not to toi=s decame/nois only; and the force of it will be felt if, instead of “who will not cause war instead of peace to his new friends” (toi=s decame/nois), we substitute its positive equivalent: “who will permit peace to be maintained by his new friends” if they exercise ordinary discretion (cf. c. 120. 16); i.e. no new allies should be received who will render ordinary discretion unavailing to prevent war, as the Corcyraeans are sure to do. See App.—
9. o(/: i.e. po/lemon e)/xein a)nt) ei)rh/nhs.— 12. kai\ a)mu/nesqai...tou/tous : to revenge ourselves on them not without you, i.e. you will necessarily be involved in the vengeance we must take on them. The suppression of h(mi=n or h(ma=s after a)na/gkh, and the use of mh\ a)/neu u(mw=n for the downright meq' u(mw=n, are due, perhaps, to a desire to show how unwelcome the contingency would be.

di/kaioi/ g' e)ste/: = di/kaio/n g' e)sti
 u(ma=s, according to the tendency of the Greek language to construct such adj. in agreement with the principal subject. H. 944; Kr. Spr. 55, 3, 10. See on c. 20. 1.—e)kpodw
 sth=nai a)mfote/rois: cf. c. 53. 5, h(mi=n e)mpodw
 i(/stasqe. Cf. c. 35. 16 of the corresponding speech.
me/n ge: ge belongs to *korinqi/ois. This combination occurs in c. 70. 6; iii.39.11; vi.86.8; Dem. XIV. 29, 40, etc.
di) a)nokwxh=s e)ge/nesqe: see on c. 37. 13. Cf. also di) u)/xlou, dia\ ma/xhs, dia\ di/khs i)e/nai and ei)=nai, c. 73. 13; ii.11.13; vi.60.18.
w(/ste: superfluous, as viii.45.5, e)pistolh=s . . . w(/st' a)poktei=nai. GMT. 98, 2, N. 2; Kühn. 473, note 9.
*sami/wn a)posta/ntwn: B.C. 440. In c. 115. The service which the Corinthians here claim to have rendered is mentioned only here and in c. 41. 8.— yh=fon: dat. in c. 20. 18.

di/xa e)yhfisme/nwn: (Schol. distazo/ntwn) i.e. when there was a division of opinion as to lending them aid, we joined the party in your favour. di/xa, as in c. 64. 6; iv.61.11; vi.100.4: not, with Bétant, in contrariam partem.
au)to/n tina: each for himself; tis as in c. 37. 12; 43. 2. Cf. vi.31.27. —kola/zein: dependent on a)ntei/pomen = a)ntekeleu/sauen.

timwrh/sete : sc. au)toi=s, to be supplied from the preceding acc.—fanei=tai a(/: connected closely, like e)/stin a(/, and so followed by an adj.; it will turn out that no fewer of your allies will join us.
pro/seisi: cf. c. 39. 11.
e)f' u(mi=n: in a hostile sense. Cf. c. 102. 19; 124. 16.
On the contrary, we have a claim on your gratitude for services rendered you in former times.

dikaiw/mata: claims on ground of right. Cf. v.97.1.—ta/de: refers to the foregoing, which is rare. Cf. c. 43. 9. So tosoi/de, vi.2.40; toia/de, vii.78.1, the only instance after a speech.— 2. parai/nesin kte(.: in same const. as dikaiw/mata, though it would have been more natural to use verbs: parainou=men kai\ a)ciou=men u(ma=s xa/rin h(mi=n a)ntidou=nai.

h(/n kte(.: the antec. is xa/ritos. The meaning is: this repayment you ought not to refuse on the ground either that we are your enemies, who are seeking to injure you, or friends so intimate as not to care for recompense. The rare verb e)pixrh=sqai (see on c. 2. 5) occurs in Plat. Legg. 953 a, where it is recommended that intercourse with strangers be restricted, di/kas au)toi=s o)rqw=s diane/montas, a)nagkai=a me\n w(s o)li/gista d' e)pixrwme/nous; and in Hdt. iii.99.9, ai( e)pixrew/menai ma/lista gunai=kes, of a woman's intimate friends.

to\n...po/lemon : see on c. 14. 12. Cf. Hdt. vi.89.6, didou=si de\ pentadra/xmous a)podo/menoi: dwti/nhn ga\r e)n tw=| no/mw| ou)k e)ch=n dou=nai. Here u(pe/r = pro/, a rare use. Cf. Plat. Tim. 23 c, u(pe\r th\n megi/sthn fqora/n.
to\...bohqh=sai : appos. as in c. 32. 16.
pare/sxen: rendered possible. Cf. c. 37. 12.

tw=n pa/ntwn...nika=n : indifferent to everything in comparison with victory. Cf. c. 23. 14. The same thought is expressed more strongly in 15, kai\ ta\ oi)kei=a . . . th=s au)ti/ka, “they mismanage (see on c. 25. 2) even their real interests if they can only gain
their present end.”
h)=|: in connexion with pro/teron = fuerit, not sit. (Cf. Ar. Vesp. 1074, r(a|di/ws e)gw\ dida/cw, ka)\n a)/mousos h)=| to\ pri/n. B. L. G.).
th=s au)ti/ka: on the order, cf. 11, tou\s sfete/rous, and see on c. 1. 6.
And you will thus at the same time best consult your own interests.

w(=n: on the rel. in this position, see on c. 9. 19.—e)nqumhqe/ntes: with gen. of neut. rel. here and vi.60.1, like fronti/zein. Elsewhere either without case, c. 120. 27; 122. 8; ii.43.9; 60. 20; iii.40.26, etc.; or with acc. of noun, ii.40.9; v.32.5; vii.18.17; 63. 11. In v.32.6 the gen. is abs. The appeal in this pl. partic. to all present passes to a part through new/tero/s tis (see on c. 40. 21), which controls the sing. a)ciou/tw, nomi/sh|. See on c. 18. 21.

au)ta/: might have been omitted after w(=n, and is bracketed by Cobet. See on c. 10. 21; 36. 2. But often the second of two really rel. clauses assumes an independent form, and takes for the rel. the corresponding case of au)to/s. Cf. ii.4.25; 34. 13; 72. 7; 74. 13. Kr. Spr. 60, 6, 2.—a)ciou/tw: implies the recognition of something as a duty. Cf. c. 22. 9; 74. 12.—a)mu/nesqai: has the general meaning of ‘requital,’ not simply of ‘repelling evil,’ also in ii.67.28; iv.63.11.
di/kaia: not adv., but for di/kaia me\n ta/de ei)=nai a(\ le/getai.
e)n w(=| : as in c. 39. 11; and so e(/petai is abs., arises, is present. Cf. Hom. *q 140.
to\ me/llon tou= pole/mou: cf. c. 39. 6. “That war will come is still uncertain”; a reply to c. 33. § 3. To this is opposed fanera\ e)/xqra kai\ ou) me/llousa.

th=s de\ u(parxou/shs...u(poyi/as : P., B., Kr. explain this by c. 103. § 4; the Megarians join the Athenian alliance, in consequence of border disputes with the Corinthians, cir. B.C. 462. So Herbst, Philol. 38, p. 568. The u(poyi/a is then felt by the Corinthians. But Cl. refers to c. 114. § 1; the Megarians by Peloponnesian aid expel the Athenian garrison, B.C. 446. This would create u(poyi/a in the minds of the Athenians. Of the two, the former reference is no doubt to be preferred. Then u(felei=n will mean
reduce, render less intense, with part. gen., as Xen. An. vii.4.5, a)fi/hsi tw=n ai)xmalw/twn. Cf. c. 30. 8, th=s gh=s e)/temon. But a reference to to\ peri\ *megare/wn yh/fisma, c. 67. 14; 139. 6, would be still more likely, if it were certain that it had been enacted at this time.— 10. sw=fron ma=llon: would rather show wisdom and discretion. Cf. c. 120. 16; vi.6.22.

h( ga\r teleutai/a...lu=sai : this xa/ris is the service the Athenians will render in not interfering; this will be highly opportune (kairo\n e)/xousa) though involving a trifling sacrifice (e)la/sswn). But Cl. refers xa/ris to the services of the Corinthians in the Samian affair, c. 40. § 5.
o(/ti nautikou=...dido/asi : cf. c. 35. 21; 36. 20. mega/lhn has an ironical tone.

to\ ple/on e)/xein: it is better to connect to/ with e)/xein, answering to to\ a)dikei=n of 13, than, with Cl., to join to\ ple/on, though, as Thuc. uniformly omits the art. in this phrase (cf. c. 37. 18; 76. 15; iii.43.12; viii.99.12), he proposes to read ti ple/on, as in iv.59.7; vii.36.6; viii.99.12. This v. H. adopts.
Do not then take up their cause, since it has no basis of justice.

peripeptwko/tes: chiefly used of unfortunate circumstances. Cf. ii.54.1; 59. 6; v.14.15; 111. 16; viii.27.14; 33. 13.—oi(=s: Cl. follows St., Jahrb. 1863, p. 471, in governing this (= tou/tois oi(=s) by peripeptwko/ta understood with au)to/n tina. But it is hardly credible that this could have been felt; and it seems better, with P. and Cl.'s earlier opinion, to resolve oi(=s into tou/tois a(/, the rel. being governed by proei/pomen (cf. c. 26. 20; ii.8.15) and kola/zein being governed by the continued force of ei)/pomen now = e)keleu/samen. “Finding ourselves fallen under the operation of the rule which we proclaimed in Sparta (c. 40. 20), (when we recommended) that each power should discipline its own allies.” But the words tou\s sfete/rous . . . kola/zein are bracketed by v. H. after Cobet, as a gloss introduced from c. 40. 20; and the use of sfete/rous as a poss. pron. of the sing. seems very dubious in prose. Kühn. 170, p. 463. See Naber, Mnem. 12, p. 33.
komi/zesqai: usually of good things. Cf. iii.58.6; iv.98.25; Dem. XXI. 171, keko/mistai xa/rin par) u(mw=n.

kai\ mh\...bla/yai : sc. u(ma=s (inserted by v. H.), with abrupt change of subject. mh/ with inf. after a)ciou=n = ou)k with a)ciou=n itself (as with
e)a=n, c. 133. 13). Cf. c. 136. 12; ii.89.2; iii.44.12.
gno/ntes: having determined, i.e., as Sh. says, “showing by your vote.”
bi/a| h(mw=n: see on c. 11. 9; in defiance of us, a forcible a)ko/ntwn h(mw=n. Cf. c. 68. 19; iv.99.6; v.21.9.
bouleu/sesqe: with acc. of a neut. pron. or adj. only. Cf. c. 85. 11; vi.23.9.
The Athenians conclude a defensive alliance with the Corcyraeans.
toiau=ta de/: resumptive from c. 36. 22, as in c. 18. 11. So also iii.49.1 after iii.41.1.
kai\ di/s: (not once but) even twice, indicating the seriousness of the matter in hand. Cf. iii.87.5, kai\ du/o e)/th.

th=| me\n prote/ra|...u(sterai/a| : notice the omission of e)n with prote/ra|, as in c. 128. 17; ii.20.3; though with words which are not properly designations of time e)n is usually inserted. G. 189; H. 782; Kr. Spr. 48, 2, 9. Here e)kklhsi/a| is to be understood with both expressions. The adj. u(sterai/a, only fem. in Thuc., is used most frequently of the following day, though h(me/ra is never expressed; yet here, iii.91.16; v.46.1; vii.11.8, it is joined with other nouns (ma/xh, e)kklhsi/a) of what takes place on the next day. But proterai/a is applied only to the preceding day itself, also without h(me/ra. With other nouns pro/teros is used of occurrences on the preceding day, as here; iii.36.25; 41. 2; vii.36.5. (Herbst, Gegen Cobet, p. 33 ff.)— 4. mete/gnwsan: = th\n gnw/mhn metabalo/ntes e)/gnwsan.

e)lu/ont' a)/n: not, of course, by the demand (e)ke/leuon), but by the assumed compliance with it, i.e. ei) keleuo/ntwn tw=n *kerkurai/wn e)pi\ *ko/rinqon cune/pleon. sfi/sin, depending on cumplei=n, refers to the Corcyraeans;
au)toi=s, depending on the pass. e)lu/onto, to the Athenians.

e)pimaxi/an: a defensive alliance. So v.48.8.— e)poih/santo: after the parenthesis the government of mete/gnwsan is lost sight of, and the fact is stated independently.—th=| a)llh/lwn: cf. c. 15. 9; 142. 11; 143. 9, etc.

kai\ w(/s: even under these circumstances, in any case. Cf. iii.33.9; vii.74.2; viii.51.10; 56. 10; 87. 18. —kai\ e)bou/lonto: though in parataxis, this expresses the consequence of the preceding, and accordingly they wished.
cugkrou/ein: trans. bring into hostility. Dem. XVIII. 19, 163; Arist. Pol. v.11.8 (1313 b. 17), diaba/llein a)llh/lois kai\ sugkrou/ein. In vii.36.26, intr. in a literal sense.

a)sqeneste/rois ou)=sin: placed first for emphasis. Cf. c. 36. 5.—toi=s a)/llois...e)/xousin : = toi=s a)/llois nautikoi=s, particularly the places named in c. 27. § 2. The insertion of a second toi=s before nautiko/n, with Bekk., P., v. H., Kr., is unnecessary, if nautiko\n e)/xousin is taken as a compound word, which the frequent use of this expression rendered easy. Cf. iii.13.31; vii.55.8; and similarly c. 56. 11, tou\s a)/llous e)pi\ *qra/|khs cumma/xous. But there also Bekk. and Kr. insert tou/s.
th=s te *)itali/as kte(.: depending on e)n para/plw|. Cf. c. 36. 10.
And send them ten ships to protect them against attack on the part of the Corinthians.
ou) polu\ u(/steron: so c. 136. 11; and often u(/steron ou) pollw=|, c. 137. 3; ii.27.6; 30. 10; 65. 12.

*lakedaimo/nios: son of the great Cimon, who gave him this name because he was proxenus of Sparta. Curtius, Hist. of Greece, III. p. 12. Plutarch, Per. 29. 2, attributes the small number of ships to Pericles's desire to humiliate the family of Cimon. This rests, no doubt, on statements coloured by party feeling. See Grote, V. c. 47, p. 325. Diotimus is not elsewhere mentioned; Proteas was strathgo/s also in 431, ii.23.8. The names of these
generals are mentioned in the inscription providing for the expenses of the expedition, C.I.A.I. 179; Hicks, Inscr. No. 41. If it is rightly referred to the archonship of Apseudes, Ol. 86. 4, we may suppose that the debate just recounted took place early in B.C. 432, and the despatch of the 10 ships a little later. See App. on c. 51. 12.
proei=pon: of a distinctly expressed order. Cf. c. 26. 20; 29. 3. On the repraesontatio by which the moods of the original are retained in the following conditions, see GMT. 77, 1 a; H. 933.

e)s tw=n e)kei/nwn ti xwri/wn: so in c. 53. 17, and similarly v.82.25, tw=n e)n *peloponnh/sw| tine\s po/lewn. Observe that in Attic tis is interposed between art. and noun only when the art. is followed immediately by some other modifier of the noun; here by e)kei/nwn, masc. In Hdt., however, often without this restriction. Kühn. 463, 1; Kr. Spr. 47, 9, 20. Cf. the position of tis in c. 106. 3; vi.4.3.—ou(/tw de/: but in that case,=e)a\n de\ tou=to poih/swsi, just as ei) de\ mh/, c. 32. 5, means “in the opposite case.”

ai( me)n dh) nh=es kte(.: a usual parataxis in narration in passing from one side to the other, the particles me\n dh/, me\n ou)=n (c. 46. 17), and me/n alone (c. 54. 19; 58. 17) serving to sum up what precedes, while de/ introduces the new statement.
The Corinthians with a fleet of 150 ships anchor in the harbour of Chimerium on the Thesprotian coast.

pareskeu/asto: the impers. pass. is much rarer in Greek than in Latin. But cf. c. 49. 30; 73. 15; 78. 6; 91. 15; iii.22.1; iv.14.14; 67. 2; vi.64.25; vii.75.2; Plat. Gorg. 453 d; Phaedr. 230 c; 232 a. G. 198; H. 602; Kühn. 378, 7, note 2; Kr. Spr. 61, 5, 6.—e)/pleon: impf. of the beginning of the undertaking. See on c. 26. 24.
*)hlei/wn kte(.: Elis and Megara were allies, the other places colonies, of Corinth.

strathgoi\ de\ kte(.: h)=san has the pregnant meaning were present, with strathgoi/ as pred. The officers of the separate allied contingents are not named, but by me\n kai/ are put in contrast with the Corinthian commanders who doubtless had charge of the whole.—
7. pe/mptos au)to/s: with four others; the usual mode of indicating at once the whole number and the chief person. Cf. the German selbander, selbdritter.

prose/mican: used of approach to (cf. iii.31.13; vi.104.19), o(rmi/zesqai, of putting in to, the coast (cf. iii.76.6; viii.11.3; 92. 18). Here the aor., of the collective fleet, with dat., which as it were personifies the coast; the pres. with prep., of the several portions of it. Cf. iii.22.5, 12. —kata/: over against. Cf. c. 48. 11; ii.30.8. Leucas had no doubt been the rendezvous for the fleet.
*xeime/rion: name both of roadstead and promontory, 16.
e)/sti de\ limh/n: sc. to\ *xeime/rion. Cf. c. 30. 15. Strabo, vii.7.5, calls it *gluku\s limh/n; now, acc. to Leake, Northern Greece, III. p. 4, Splantza. See App.—a)po/: see on c. 7. 6.

*)elaia/tidi: the strip of coast on each side of the mouth of the Acheron, so called from the town Elaea.—*)efu/rh: all Mss. give this name in the Ionic form, which was preferred in Attic. Herodian, Bekk. Aneed. p. 1173.—e)ci/hsi: though found only in inferior Mss., to be preferred to e)/ceisi. Cf. ii.102.15; iv.103.4; Hdt. i.6.4; 180. 5; ii. 17.20. e)sba/llei in 13 in the same sense occurs here only in Thuc. Cf. Hdt. iv.48.13; 49. 4; 57. 5.— 12. *)axerousi/a: on this and the river Acheron, now the river of Suli or the Gurla, see Leake, N. G. I. p. 232, IV. p. 51-53, 94 ff.
*qu/amis: now the Calamar, further to the north; between it and the Acheron (w(=n e)nto/s) is the promontory Chimerium, now Varlás. — 16. a)ne/xei: rises. So iv.53.13; vii.34.10, proanexou/sais.
The Corcyraeans with 110 ships take their station at one of the Sybota islands, and the 10 Attic ships with them.

*mikia/dhs: to be preferred to *mei-
kia/dhs of the better Mss., as connected with *mi/ka, *mi/kwn. Wecklein, Curae Epigraphicae, p. 56.

*su/bota: name of islands, promontory, and harbour on the Thesprotian coast, c. 50. 14; 54. 4; still existing in S. Nicolo di Sivota.—kai\...parh=san : closely connected with preceding sent.; and the Attic ships too arrived immediately. parh=san=parege/nonto. Cf. iii.6.3.

*leuki/mmh|: c. 30. 2. Strab. vii.7.5, ei)si\ de\ nhsi=des ta\ *su/bota th=s me
 *)hpei/rou mikro
 a)pe/xousai, kata\ de\ to\ e(w=|on a)/kron th=s *kerkurai/as th
 *leuki/mmhn kei/menai.

o( pezo/s : subst. as in ii.86.13; vii.62.18; adj. with strato/s, iv.8.10.—*zakunqi/wn: though no alliance has been mentioned, they appear here from the similarity of their interests on the side of the Corcyraeans, as later (ii.7.17; iii.94.7; vii.57.33) with the Athenians. For xi/lioi supply h)=san from h)=n, but not, as Cl. says, here forming a periphrastic plpf. with the partic., as the local phrase is one of rest. Cf. c. 50. 14, oi(= . . . prosebebohqh/kei. The partic. is inserted as an afterthought.

parabebohqhko/tes: para- implies the drawing up along the coast. Cf. ii.90.15; iv.14.12; vii.37.18; 53. 5; 70. 5. The repetition of the word has an effect like that in c. 28. 8; 30. 17; and e)n th=| h)pei/rw|, which has been without reason suspected, is in natural opposition to e)pi\ th=| *leuki/mmh|.— 9. a)ei/ pote : expresses forcibly the continual existence of a state of things. See on c. 13. 16; ii.102.10.
The putting to sea and arrangement of the two fleets.

triw=n h(merw=n: gen. of description, which in Greek is nearly confined to numerical definitions of magnitude and age. Cf. ii.23.11; iii.1.8; ii.13.50 (space); ii.13.33 (value). G. 167, 5; H. 729 d.—a)nh/gonto: impf. as in c. 46. 2.—w(s e)pi\ naumaxi/an: so ii.83.10; iv.13.13. In iii.4.6; vi.34.34 the dat. is used with e)pi/ in same sense. Placed thus before the prep. w(s implies the ‘purpose,’ ‘intention’ of the subj. Cf. c. 50. 21; 62. 20.
kai\...kaqorw=si : lively transition by parataxis. See on c. 26. 16.— 4. metew/rous: out at sea. Cf. ii.91.12; iii.33.15; iv.14.3; etc. Not in this sense in Hdt. or Xen.

a)ntipareta/ssonto: so placed to include both sides and all their divisions; but in the details this connexion is at once given up. The Attic ships are named first, because such enumerations usually begin with the right wing. Cf. ii.90.6; iii.107.23; iv.43.8.
to\ a)/llo: includes the remainder of the right wing, the centre, and the left. So e)pei=xon, as in iii.107.25, indicates the extent of this portion.

tri/a te/lh poih/santes: they formed three divisions Cf. ii.81.8; iii.50.6; vi.62.2. te/los applied to a fleet, vi.42.8; to cavalry, ii.22.10; iv.96.20; to land forces in general, ii.81.8.—w(=n...ei(=s : an involved order of words, w(=n depending on e(ka/stou and srtathgw=n on ei(=s. v. H. after Cobet inserts tw=n before triw=n.

*korinqi/ois: dat. as in c. 6. 8.— 10. ei)=xon: the regular verb in such tactical statements. Cf. iii.107.23; iv.31.10; 93. 17; vi.67.3; 101. 20; vii.34.11; 52. 6; viii.104.9. In ii.81.11 and vii.70.9 we have e)/xein to\ me/son, for which here kata\ to\ me/son, sc. e)ta/canto, perhaps because e)/xein could hardly be said of the small number of 21 ships, c. 46. 3, 4.
kata\ to\ me/son: at the centre, but 12, kata\ tou\s *)aqhnai/ous, over against (c. 46. 8). Cf. iii.108.6 with 107. 29; 108. 10.
w(s e(/kastoi: singuli deinceps, there being no need of a precise statement of order. See on c. 3. 19; 67. 13.

e)peidh\...h)/rqh : gives the time of cummi/cantes, not of e)nauma/xoun (impf. as c. 26. 23). To h)/rqh, which implies the raising a flag or some such signal (Schol. su/mbola/ tina peri\ to\n kairo\n th=s ma/xhs deiknu/mena) is opposed katespa/sqh, c. 63. 14.

tw=| palaiw=| kte(.: cf. c. 10. 32. This want of naval skill is shown in the large number of variously armed soldiers
on board (e)piba/tai). “The number of combatants assigned to a ship was diminished in the same degree in which the art of fighting at sea was improved.” Böckh, Publ. Econ. p. 383. While in early times the number was probably 30 (see on c. 29. 4), “in the Peloponnesian war only 10 heavy-armed epibatae used to be put on board of a trireme.” Ibid. p. 384.
h)=n te: and so (c. 4. 5) it actually was, as might be expected from the large fighting force. h)=n placed first, as in c. 25. 23.

th=| me\n te/xnh|...ou)=sa : the reason of the fight being kartera/ is expressed in varied form (cf. 8); “the battle was hotly contested, not so much from the skill displayed, as because it was more like a battle on land.” ou)x o(moi/ws=h(=sson. Cf. ii.60.21; v.11.13. to\ ple/on= ma=llon. Cf. 12; c. 69. 32; 74. 20; 81. 6; ii.89.21, etc.

e)peidh\ prosba/loien: this is to be preferred to prosba/lloien of most Mss., as expressing the repetition of rapid shocks. So in vii.70.31. On the other hand, 15, pie/zointo, of longer enduring pressure.

a)pelu/onto: see on c. 18. 28. Cf. vii.70.31.— u(po/ te plh/qous...pisteu/ontes : the reasons expressed first by a subst., then by a partic., as in 6. “They did not readily get clear of one another, partly from the number and throng of the ships, and still more because they trusted for victory to the hoplites on the decks.”
katasta/ntes: when they had got into position. Cf. c. 59. 7; ii.1.3; iii.92.24; v.4.15; more literally in iii.86.19; iv.14.23; 75. 8.

die/kploi: the favourite Attic manœuvre of breaking through an enemy's line, and so taking the separated portions at a disadvantage to attack them on flank or rear; first mentioned by Hdt. vi.12.3; viii.9.9. —ou)k h)=san: see on c. 2. 5. Cf. ii.89.35; vii.36.22; 70. 26.

paragigno/menai: “the durative tense of vision: ‘rallying to the Corcyraeans if they saw them pressed at any point.’” B. L. G. The subj. ai( *)attikai\ nh=es is narrowed in the second clause to oi( strathgoi/, by whom the order to attack would be given.
See App. th\n pro/rrhsin: see c. 45. 6; the subst. of proeipei=n, only here in this sense.
spora/das: in disorder, pred. to katadiw/cantes.

e)pekba/ntes : landing in pursuit. Cf. viii.105.3.— 21. e)rh/mous:=e)rh/mous katalabo/ntes. e)rh=mos is of two terminations also in ii.4.19; iii.22.13; 67. 14; 106. 4; of three, in ii.32.3; 81. 7; iv.26.13; vi.61.37.—ta\ xrh/mata: in the general sense of property. Cf. iii.74.10; vi.97.27.

oi( *kori/nqioi kai\ oi( cu/mmaxoi: an expression adapted to the diverse fortunes of the allied forces (though in c. 48. 9 and c. 49. 17 oi( *kori/nqioi is given alone, as the leading power) which is subj. of e)ni/kwn, 24, as well as of h(ssw=nto, 23, but restricted in each case by the local phrases tau/th| me/n and h(=| de\ kte(. The particles te kai/ have the effect of combining complements or opposites into an exhaustive whole; the second clause is here added (as Cl. says, almost as if it were parenthetical) to give the reverse side of the action expressed in the first. It is not necessary to bracket te, or with St. to read to/te.
a)po\ e)la/ssonos plh/qous : from a smaller number to begin with, i.e. 110 against 150. Cf. ii.65.7; viii.87.33.

ma=llon a)profasi/stws: i.e. than as in 15. But there are still two stages: (1) a)pexo/menoi . . . tini/, “so far as not actually to attack”; (2) e)pei\ de\ . . . oi( *kori/nqioi, “as soon as the Corcyraeans began decidedly (lamprw=s, see on vii.55.1) to turn their backs.”

e)gi/gneto: though found in only one Ms., the impf. is necessary here to represent the beginning of the flight, while the Corinthians e)ne/keinto. So too P. and St. Cf. the impf. with kata\ ta/xos, iii.106.3; with qa=sson, iii.111.5; with dia\ ta/xous, iii.109.20. Not till the rout is complete do we find c. 50. 1, th=s troph=s genome/nhs.

to/te dh/ : introduces the decisive moment with reference to the serious consequences of it. Cf. c. 58. 10; so ou(/tw dh/, c. 131. 8; ii. 12.
16.—e)/rgou ei)/xeto: put his hand to the work. Cf. c. 78. 8; ii.2.23; Hdt. viii.11.4.—h)/dh: emphasizes the critical instant. Cf. c. 18. 28.—kai\ dieke/krito ou)de\n e)/ti: and no longer was any distinction maintained between the Corcyraeans who were declared enemies, and the Athenians who were nominal allies, of the Corinthians. See on c. 46. 1.

cune/pesen: impers., like a stronger cune/bh. Cf. iv.68.8.—e)s tou=to a)na/gkhs: see on c. 5. 10. Cf. e)s tou=to cumfora=s, iii.57.12; e)s tou=to dustuxi/as, vii.86.25; e)n tou/tw| paraskeuh=s, ii.18.1; e)s tou=to a)na/gkhs, Plat. Theaet. 170 d; ei)s tou=q' u(/brews, Dem. IV. 37; XXII. 16.—e)pixeirh=sai: with dat. in proper sense; cf. iii.94.23; vi.48.12;=e)s xei=ras e)lqei=n, c. 52. 13.
The Corinthians improve their victory, but abstain from a second engagement, since 20 additional Attic ships come up.

th=s troph=s genome/nhs: see on c. 49. 29.—ta\ ska/fh: hulls. Schol. ta\ koilw/mata tw=n new=n a(\ h(mei=s ga/stras kalou=men. The contrast between what was usually done and the action of the Corinthians is brought out by the position of ta\ ska/fh me\n kte/. and pro\s de\ tou\s a)nqrw/pous kte(. Cf. c. 44. 5, 8.

ei(=lkon a)nadou/menoi: took in tow and hauled off: the regular expression. Cf. ii.90.26; iv.14.9; vii.74.16.— a(/s: unassimilated for w(=n. Cf. c. 52. 9; 99. 13; ii.61.12; 92. 19.—a(\s katadu/seian: iterative opt., whatever ships they disabled.

foneu/ein...zwgrei=n : dependent upon e)tra/ponto. Cf. ii.65.43, e)tra/ponto kaq' h(dona\s tw=| dh/mw| ta\ pra/gmata e)ndido/nai. This relation is not prevented by the position of pro\s tou\s a)nqrw/pous, which is required by the contrast. The partic. diekple/ontes describes the way in which they did it.
tou/s te au(tw=n fi/lous: the Megarians and Ambraciots of the defeated right wing. Cf. c. 49. 22. te adds a third member. See on c. 2. 6; 33. 6.
e)pi\ deciw=|: the Vat. Ms. omits the art. Cf. c. 48. 11; iv.93.17; vi.67.2. Kr. Spr. 50, 2, 13.
e)pi\ polu\ th=s qala/sshs: taken together as the object of e)pexousw=n,= me/ga me/ros th=s qala/sshs. Cf. ii.76.20; iv.3.11; 12. 16; vii.65.7; as nom., iv.100.12. Kühn. 351, 3.
e)peidh\ cune/mican: as soon as they had joined battle: quite different from the opt. in c. 49. 7.

th\n dia/gnwsin e)poiou=nto:=diegi/gnwskon: with Thuc. a
favourite periphrasis for a simple verb. Cf. c. 6. 3; 8. 12; 51. 8; 68. 7; 72. 9.—o(poi=oi: Cl. explains what sort of men, whether friend or foe, since probably difference of dress or arms would be little observed. But Sh. reads o(po/teroi after Cobet, who, however, now brackets the whole clause.

naumaxi/a ga\r...gege/nhtai : on the order, see on c. 1. 8. The pf. takes this sentence out of the course of the narrative and presents the statement as it would be made by an observer who witnessed the result.
tw=n pro\ au)th=s: see on c. 1. 4.
ta\ naua/gia: i.e. the wrecks, and the men that were on them, the saving of whom was their chief care. See L. Herbst, Die Schlacht bei den Arginusen, p. 37, note 51.

oi(= au)toi=s kte(.: cf. c. 47. 7; ii.86.13.— 15. e)/sti de\ ta\ *su/bota: (see on c. 47. 5) the same turn as in c. 46. 10; here, however, the repetition of the name is necessitated by the parenthesis.— 16. tou=to poih/santes: i.e. proskomi/santes tou\s nekrou/s.

kai\ o(/sai h)=san: i.e. those which were not present at the first engagement but had come up later. For the Corcyraeans, c. 25. 24, had 120 ships, and had engaged with only 110, c. 47. 3.—kai\ au)toi\ a)ntepe/pleon: this is the correct reading here and in c. 54. 18 (though Bekk. reads a)nte/pleon with the best Mss.), after e)pe/pleon. kai\ au)toi/ is not necessary, since a)nti- denotes only on their part and not ‘against’; but it gives additional force. Cf. c. 105. 28; iv.124.17; v.6.9; viii.104.4. See Ullrich, Beitr. z. Krit. I. p. 9.

peirw=sin: the act. peira=n (ii.72.21; 77. 5; iv.9.16; 102. 4; 128. 4) and the mid. peira=sqai (c. 25. 5; 31. 11; 71. 27; 78. 14; 81. 5; 143. 3; ii.35.19; 58. 6; iii.38.13; iv.15.10, etc.) are used with the inf., apparently without important difference of meaning. Perhaps the act. presents rather the notion of risk, and the mid. of effort.

h)/dh de\ h)=n...kai\ oi( *kori/nqioi : parataxis, as c. 26. 17; 29. 13. Soph. Phil. 355. Kühn. 518, 8. St. rightly prefers e)pepaia/nisto to the form with w(paiwn-). Schol., du/o paia=nas h)=|don oi( *(/ellhnes, pro\ me\n tou= pole/mou tw=| *)/arei, meta\ de\ to\n po/lemon tw=| *)apo/llw-
ni.
pru/mnan e)krou/onto : backed water: withdrew without turning the vessels. Schol., to\ kat' o)li/gon a)naxwrei=n mh\ stre/yanta to\ ploi=on. Cf. c. 51. 5; 54. 16; iii.78.12.

a(\s u(/steron kte(.: now these the Athenians had sent out later. Cf. the same use of the rel. pron., c. 35. 15; and for the aor.=our plpf. in rel. sentence, cf. c. 99. 9; ii.92.9; 98. 6; iii.86.8; Plat. Phaed. 59 d. Kühn. 386, 15.

o)li/gai a)mu/nein: cf. Hdt. vi.109.3; vii.207.9. “Not precisely our ‘too few to aid,’ which would be e)la/ssones h)\ a)mu/nein. The latter expresses disbelief, the former, misgiving.” Sh. Cf. tapeinh\ e)gkarterei=n, ii.61.12; fu/seis xalepai\ a)/rcai, vii.14.6; braxe/a perigi/gnesqai, v.111.8. GMT. 93, 1; H. 952.
The Corcyraeans return to the harbour of Leucimme, into which the Attic ships also sail.
proi+do/ntes: when they saw them from afar. Cf. iii.22.6; iv. 34, 22; vii.25.32; 44. 10; and so pro/oyis, v.8.11.
ou)x o(/sas: not so few as; explained by a)lla\ plei/ous.

e)pe/pleon ga\r kte(.: see on c. 31. 7. The close connexion of the parenthesis with the main sentence is seen in the reference of the dat. toi=s *kerkurai/ois to the adverbial e)k tou= a)fanou=s. (cf. c. 34. 10; 35. 17; 39. 2), ‘less visibly for them.’ But the dat. may be taken as of the agent interested, with e(wrw=nto. G. 188, 3; H. 769; Kühn. 423, 25 c. Cf. Plat. Legg. 715 b, le/getai h(mi=n; Virg. Aen. i. 440, neque cernitur ulli.
kai\ e)qau/mazon: as if oi( *kerkurai=oi ou)x e(w/rwn au)ta/s had preceded.

pri/n: until, with indic. Cf. c. 118. 14; 132.28; iii.29.5; 101. 13; 104. 42; v.61.6; vii.39.5; 71. 26; viii.105.9. In all these instances the principal clause is actually or virtually negative; as here, “they could not make out what they were about, till—.” See Gildersleeve, Am. J. of Ph. II. 469.—o(/ti nh=es e)kei=nai e)piple/ousi: almost a direct exclamation: “yonder are ships sailing up.” Cf. c. 27. 2.
kai\ au)toi/: as well as the Corinthians, c. 50. 21.

kai\ oi( *kori/nqioi kte(.: continues the narrative from c. 50. 21. a)potra-
po/menoi, opp. to pru/mnan e)krou/onto, implies the actual turning of the ships, and th\n dia/lusin e)poih/santo (see on c. 50. 8) the breaking up of regular order, in order to reach the harbour, where they are found, c. 52. 3.

h( a)pallagh\ e)ge/neto: periphrasis of a)phlla/ghsan, “they separated.”— 9. e)teleu/ta e)s nu/kta: lasted till night, continued to night, and then ended. Cf. iii.78.15; 108. 18; me/xri tou=de w(ri/sqw, c. 71. 15; e)s to\ . . . e)/xon o(ri/zontes, iii.82.62.

toi=s de\ *kerkurai/ois kte(.: the dat. depends on proskomisqei=sai, having made their way to join. Cl. interprets stratopedeuome/nois as if it were pf. partic., and then finds it necessary to assume a change of subj. (as in iii.5.17) in 16, supplying ai( a)po\ tw=n *)aqhnw=n nh=es for w(rmi/santo. This seems unnecessary. The impf. partic. stratopedeuome/nois implies that at that time the Corcyraeans were engaged in the process of taking their station at their encampment. It must be assumed that, while the character of the strange ships was doubtful, the operation of bringing the ships to their station was suspended, since it might prove necessary to resist an attack. When, however, the Corcyraeans had ascertained the nationality of the new-comers, they then brought their ships to a stand, w(rmi/santo. See Müller-Strübing, Jahrb. 127, 589. In ai( ei)/kosi nh=es a)po\ tw=n *)aqhnw=n note the absence of the art. before a)po/. Cf. vi.55.5; vii.41.6.
*)andoki/dhs: this cannot be the orator, who was born about B.C. 440. It might possibly have been his grandfather of the same name. See App.
The Corinthians decide to withdraw without further fighting.
a)nagago/menai: see on c. 29. 18.
to\n e)n *subo/tois lime/na: cf. ii.25.22; iv.25.22.

boulo/menoi ei)de/nai: bracketed by Kr., occurs in v.21.13; vi.44.24; 62. 4. The synesis boulo/menoi after ai( nh=es is not more surprising than th\n u(phresi/an plei/ous kai\ a)mei/nous, c. 143. 7; th\n h(liki/an w(=n, iii.67.11, etc. See App.

ta\s me\n nau=s...a)/rxein : corresponds to 10, tou= de\ oi)/kade plou= . . . diesko/poun. Their preparations seemed to show an intention of renewing the fight; but in fact they were thinking rather of returning home. a)/rantes, of putting to sea, only here with acc. obj. It is freq. abs., ii.25.15; 56. 16; 103. 1; iii.32.1; 91. 8; iv.11.4; 45. 1; v.3.26; vi.94.2; 104. 15; vii.26.2; 69. 27; viii.28.2; 32. 5; 88. 10; or with a dat., c. 29. 4; ii.23.9; iii.95.9; iv.129.11; vi.43.2; 51. 12; viii.60.10; 79. 4; 99. 14. Once, in viii.39.4, we find ai( nh=es a)/rasai e)/pleon. In the same way, since metew/rous, in the open sea, must have nau=s supplied, parataca/menoi here only is used with acc.; abs. in c. 29. 18; iv.73.3; v.59.9; vii.3.3.

a)kraifnei=s: see on c. 19. 8.—polla\ ta\ a)/pora cumbebhko/ta: = ta\ a)/pora a(\ cunebebh/kei polla\ u)/nta; and these difficulties are explained by the clauses ai)xmalw/twn peri\ fulakh=s and e)piskeuh\n . . . e)rh/mw|, which again depends on o(rw=ntes. With the former of these cf. seismw=n pe/ri, c. 23. 12. peri/ so used almost means ‘that is to say,’ ‘for example.’ Cf. Plat. Rep. 425 c; 479 c.
e)piskeuh/n: opportunity for repairs.—ou)k ou)=san: see on c. 2. 5.

tou= oi)/kade plou=: this gen. is placed proleptically before the dependent sentence, o(/ph| komisqh/sontai, which, as containing an inquiry as to the manner of carrying out their design, stands to tou= plou= as a part to the whole. Cf. c. 68. 7. Kühn. 417, note 9. So Cl. “The gen. at the head of a sentence is often used without strict dependence. Here tou= plou==to\ tou= plou=.” B. L. G. Cobet reads to\n plou=n.
ta\s sponda/s : ta\s triakontou/teis, c. 23. 19; 35. 1; 40. 11, 15. —ou)k e)w=si: see on c. 28. 9.
The Athenians do not interfere with their departure.
e)/docen ou)=n: the result of diesko/poun, c. 52. 11.—e)sbiba/santas: acc. though following au)toi=s. See on c. 31. 10.

khrukei/ou: a herald's staff, caduceus. Schol. cu/lon o)rqo\n e)/xon e(kate/rwqen du/o o)/feis peripeplegme/nous kai\ a)ntiprosw/pous pro\s a)llh/lous keime/nous. To bear such a staff would have been a recognition of a state of war. Cf. ii.1.3.—pei=ran poih/sasqai: to test their intentions.
pe/myante/s te e)/legon: and accordingly they sent and said (by the mouth of messengers). Cf. ii.71.6, etc.—a)dikei=te: cf. c. 37. 3.
pole/mou...sponda/s : without art., the reproach being generalized, “being beginners of war and truce-breakers.” Below, 8, ta\s sponda/s, in reference to the actually existing truce.
polemi/ous tou\s h(mete/rous: cf. c. 1. 5.—e)mpodw\n i(/stasqe: see on c. 40. 13.
u(mi=n gnw/mh e)sti/: only here; elsewhere gnw/mhn e)/xein. Cf. ii.86.17; iii.92.11; iv.125.20; vii.72.18; viii.44.2.
kwlu/ein te: should strictly be followed by kai\ lu/ein, which Cobet reads; but in the second clause the purpose is vividly expressed as a fact.
h(ma=s tou/sde: obj. of labo/ntes, and then to be supplied in thought in the dat. for xrh/sasqe.
prw=ton : referring to the whole sentence, “first of all commit this wrong.” Cf. vi.3.5.

tw=n de\ *kerkurai/wn to\ me\n strato/pedon: the me/n points to an unmentioned antithesis: the leaders kept silent, while the excited multitude called for the death of the messengers. So Cl.; but see App.

e)ph/kousen: here and in ii.36.20 of hearing from a distance.—a)nebo/hsen: takes the inf., as containing an e)ke/leuse.— 16. ei)...pleusei=sqe : minatory form of cond. See on c. 36. 17.—e)s tw=n...xwri/wn : see on c. 45. 8.
kata\ to\ dunato/n: pro viribus. Cf. ii.89.39; v.23.5; vii.36.23.
The Corinthians as well as the Corcyraeans erect a trophy.

pareskeua/zonto: impf. of the time which elapsed before their de
parture, c. 55. 1, during which tropai=on e)/sthsan aor.
toi=s e)n th=| h)pei/rw|: cf. c. 50. 15; toi=s e)n th=| nh/sw|, 8. See on c. 47. 5.

ta/ te naua/gia kai\ nekrou/s: here and in 15 taken together with the art. ta/ as constituting one notion (see on c. 6. 1 and c. 143. 23), as also the following ta\ e)cenexqe/nta refers to both. The clauses ta/ te naua/gia kte(. and 7, kai\ tropai=on a)nte/sthsan kte(. are parallel to the two preceding about the Corinthians, and this is enforced by a)nte/sthsan.
