See on c. 50. 18.—a)nei/lonto: the collection of the corpses (not u(pospo/ndous, i.e. without applying to the enemy for permission) was understood as a sign that the field was still maintained, and therefore of victory, which at sea under particular circumstances, as here, might be claimed by both parties.

u(po\ tou= r(ou= kai\ a)ne/mou: one article for both nouns, which is the less felt because the gender as well as the direction and activity of both is the same. —geno/menos: often used of the phenomena of nature, u(/dwr, brontai\ kai\ a)strapai/, seismo/s. Cf. c. 101. 5; ii.5.5; 77. 23; iii.87.9; iv.75.17; vi.70.2; viii.41.10. So also h(me/ra and nu/c.
gnw/mh| toia=|de: the adj. gains force from position. See on c. 1. 6.
me/xri nukto/s: cf. c. 50. 20.— 11. proskomi/sasqai: mid. conveyed to their side, without further designation of place. But c. 50. 13, proskomi/sai pro\s ta\ *su/bota.

ou)k e)la/ssous : = o)li/gw| plei/ous, as is seen in c. 55. § 1. Cf. ii.31.10; iii.68.14; 75. 22; 87. 7; vi.25.7; vii.75.27; 87. 19. The number given states the limit which may be exceeded but must be reached: at least.

ma/lista: see on c. 13. 11.—kai\ e)peidh\ *)aqhnai=oi h)lqon: this clause, as also the corresponding one in 18, separates sharply between the two aspects of the occurrences of the two days: (a) favourable for the Corcyreans, (1) the destruction of 30 ships on the Corinthian right wing, c. 49. § 5; (2) the recovery of their dead, c. 54. § 1. (b) unfavourable for the Corinthians, (1) their retreat on the evening of the first day when they had got sight of (i)do/ntes) the Athenian ships, c. 51. § 1; (2) their refusal to renew the engagement after the
Athenians had joined the Corcyraeans, c. 52. § 2, 3. See App.
th=| proterai/a|: see on c. 44. 2.
a)ntepe/pleon: for the form, see on c. 50. 19; for the fact, see c. 52. § 2, 3.
ou(/tw: corresponds to gnw/mh| toia=|de of 9.
nika=n: inf. of the impf. e)ni/kwn. See on c. 13. 32. For this use of nika=n, be victorious, cf. iii.8.5; vii.34.24. Kr. Spr. 53, 1, 3.
The Corinthians and the Athenians return home.
*)anakto/rion: a little to the south of Actium, c. 29. 10.

a)pa/th|: opposed to bi/a|, which is joined with it in iv.86.5.—h)=n de\ koino\n kte(.: it was therefore a compensation for their lost interest in Epidamnus. The gen. is possessive, and koino/n a secondary pred.
dou=loi: these were no doubt the e)re/tai, whereas the 250 were e)piba/tai.

dh/santes e)fu/lasson : as the Corcyraeans held the captive Corinthians, c. 29. 23; 30. 4.—e)n qerapei/a| ei)=xon: a periphrastic expression to denote an enduring relation. Cf. e)n fulakh=|, iv.14.26; e)n h(donh=|, iii.9.4; e)n o)rrwdi/a|, ii.89.3; e)n o)rgh=|, ii.21.22.
prospoih/seian: causative to prosxwrei=n. Cf. ii.2.16; and iii.70.5, where the carrying out of this plan of the Corinthians leads to the bloody feud at Corcyra.

e)tu/gxanon: as h)=san, h)=n in c. 25. 23; 49. 5, placed at the beginning to confirm the preceding remark: “and it actually was the case that the greater part of them belonged to the most influential families of the city.” duna/mei, of political importance, as in c. 77. 9.

perigi/gnetai: maintained itself. In this sense elsewhere abs. Cf. c. 32. 22; 69. 30; 141. 20 (e)k tw=n kindu/nwn); ii.49.36 (e)k tw=n megi/stwn); iii.
11. 23; 37. 12; 98. 18; iv.10.5; 27. 8; v.60.31; 111. 8; vi.78.12; probably here only with the gen. (tw=n *korinqi/wn, against the Corinthians), with which it has commonly the meaning of ‘overcome.’ Cf. ii.65.61; iii.82.59; vii.56.17; viii.53.6; 76. 25. (B. gives the word this meaning here, comparing ii.65.61. v. H. brackets tw=n *korinqi/wn: “quippe perigi/gnetai hic est salva fuit.”) It is true that the Corcyraeans have the advantage of the Corinthians in having secured Epidamnus; but of this there is no thought here. For tw=| pole/mw|, in the war, cf. ii.13.59.—kai\ ai( nh=es kte(.: added in parataxis as the consequence of the former clause.
ai)ti/a au(/th prw/th: on the order and construction, see on c. 1. 8. Cf. c. 50. 9. Cobet omits tou= pole/mou, giving ai)ti/a the meaning of e)/gklhma.
e)s tou\s *)aqhnai/ous : see on c. 38. 1. Cf. c. 66. 2; 79. 2.

sfi/sin: refers to *korinqi/ois, which is virtually the subject of the main sentence.—e)n spondai=s: in time of peace, during the continuance of the truce. Cf. ii.5.20; iii.56.4; 65. 2; vii.18.13. See on ii.54.3.—e)nauma/xoun: impf., “they persisted in fighting, notwithstanding the spondai/.” B. L. G.
THE HOSTILITIES BETWEEN THE CORINTHIANS AND THE ATHENIANS ON ACCOUNT OF POTIDAEA. Chaps. 56-66.
The Athenians take measures to prevent the intended revolt of Potidaea, and to counteract the hostile designs of Perdiccas.

dia/fora: pred. to ta/de, cune/bh kai\ ta/de gene/sqai dia/fora e)s to\ polemei=n, it came to pass that the following events also proved points of difference tending to war. The article would otherwise be indispensable. dia/fora as in c. 67. 14; 78. 12; v.45.2. See on c. 68. 8.
o(/pws timwrh/sontai: see on c. 19. 3. Here pra/ssein=contrive, manœuvre. Cf. iii.4.21; vi.88.19; iii.70.6, where also the future a)posth/sousi is to be preferred to the aor. subjv.

u(potoph/santes: see on c. 20. 9.—*poteidaia/tas: this form rather than *potidaia/tas is confirmed by the constant usage in inscriptions, particularly the metrical one referred to on c. 63. 20 (Wecklein, Cur. epigr. p. 52). We should expect the art. here; but the use or omission of it by Thuc. with ethnic names seems quite arbitrary.

*korinqi/wn a)poi/kous: the time of this settlement cannot be accurately fixed. It was certainly before
the Persian war. See O. Müller, Die Dorier, I. 6, 8.—fo/rou u(potelei=s: cf. c. 19. 6.

to\ e)s *pallh/nhn tei=xos kaqelei=n: by this means the town would be open on the seaside, and always accessible to the Athenians. The Spartans, on the contrary, desired towns to be open on the land side: see viii.16.12. For the verb, cf. c. 58. 17; 90. 25; iii.3.17; v.33.13.

e)pidhmiourgou/s: probably officers of supervision, sent yearly to the colony. As dhmiourgoi/ was a not uncommon title of town magistrates in Doric states (cf. v.47.54), so e)pidhmiourgo/s seems to mean ‘the chief demiurgus.’ See Müller, Dor. II. 8, 5. Cf. e)pistra/thgos, Böckh, Inscr. II. 2285.—e)kpe/mpein: inf. pres., following the aor., acc. to the common usage of this verb. See on c. 26. 2.

tou\s a)/llous e)pi\ *qra/|khs cumma/xous: without a second art., as c. 44. 15. e)pi\ *qra/|khs, the usual designation of the Thracian coast, so far as it was occupied by Hellenic colonies, from the mouth of the Hebrus on the east to the Thermaic gulf on the west; particularly Chalcidice as far as Amphipolis: chiefly in the phrases ta\ e)pi\ *qra/|khs and oi( e)pi\ *qra/|khs cu/mmaxoi. Cf. v.34.1.
cunaposth/swsi: refers to the intr. a)postw=si, but indicates not a common activity (as the compound in c. 37. 16; 39. 9), but a similar result.
The Athenians send 30 triremes to secure their possessions in Thrace.
tau=ta de/ kte(.: connected epexegetically with the preceding (as in 6, e)polemw/qh de/) to define more precisely the time.

eu)qu\s meta\ th\n e)n *kerku/ra| naumaxi/an: the stress of the sentence lies on this: “the Athenians began to take these precautions immediately after the sea-fight, before the Corinthians could hinder them.” This moment is emphasized by h)/dh, 3; and the two motives for the activity of the Athenians, the open enmity of the Corinthians and the hostile attitude of Perdiccas, are joined on the same level by te te. Cf. c. 8. 14; 26. 8. What in c. 56. 7 ff. appears merely as a direction given to the Potidaeans, is in this chap., 19 ff., laid as a command on the generals of the expedition.

e)pepole/mwto: this verb is pass. also in c. 36. 10; had been made an enemy. In v.98.6 it is used trans. in the mid., ‘to excite to hostility,’ and
so iii.3.4, prospolemw/sasqai. Alexander, the father of Perdiccas and Philip, had been friendly to the Greeks in the Persian war. See Hdt. v. 19 ff.; viii. 136 ff.; ix. 44 ff. Perdiccas, who originally possessed only lower Macedonia, had deprived Philip of upper Macedonia, which had been his portion. See ii.100.10.

*de/rda|: Schol., *de/rdas *)aridai/ou pai=s, a)neyio\s *perdi/kka kai\ *fili/ppou. In c. 59. 8 the brothers of this Derdas are mentioned among the opponents of Perdiccas, and the Pausanias of c. 61. 17 was probably one of them.— 7. pro\s au)to/n: unusual const. for au)tw=| (so polemei=n has both consts.), probably to avoid the repetition of dats. in different relations.
dediw/s te: the inferential te, as in c. 4. 5; 49. 5.—e)/prassen: cf. c. 56. 3.
o(/pws ge/nhtai: subjv. after a verb of striving. See GMT. 45; H. 885 b.
kai\...prosepoiei=to : as if the preceding clause had been e)/s te th\n *lakedai/mona e)/prasse pe/mpwn. Cf., for a like change to a finite verb, c. 53. 8; iii.87.3.
e(/neka: for the position, see on c. 5. 6; to bring about the revolt of Potidaea. The impf. tenses express the effort without regard to the result.
prose/fere lo/gous: with dat. also in ii.70.7; iii.4.8; 109. 6; viii.32.12, but only here with following inf. See on c. 53. 11.

*xalkideu=si: a collective name for the Greek settlers on the Thracian coast, because the most and oldest of them had issued from Chalcis in Euboea.—*bottiai/ois: originally settled in eastern Macedonia near Pella,—a district which retained the name Bottiaeis,— they had under pressure of the Macedonians removed to the northwest part of the Chalcidian peninsula, which was called *bottikh/. Cf. c. 65. 14.
tau=ta: the obj. of e)/xoi, conforming in gender to the attrib., o(/mora o)/nta xwri/a, though referring to *xalkideu=si kai\ *bottiai/ois.
to\n po/lemon poiei=sqai: see on c. 6. 3; 34. 11.—w(=n: the gen. of the thing with ai)sqa/nesqai in c. 72. 3; iv.108.31. Cf. iii.102.11; v.83.2. G. 171, 2; H. 742.
prokatalamba/nein: to prevent; here and v.30.5, with acc. of thing; with acc. of person, c. 33. 21; 36. 19; without obj., iii.2.15; 46. 25; vi.18.13.

e)/tu-
xon ga/r: see on c. 31. 7.
met' a)/llwn du/o: see App.
o(mh/rous...kaqelei=n : the compliance, therefore, of the Potidaeans (c. 56. 7) was not to be waited for.
Potidaea, in concert with the Chalcidians and Bottiaeans, breaks off from Athenian control.

kai/: and kai/ in 3 combine into one whole the two acts which are contrasted by me/n, de/. Cf. the double kai/ in comparative sentences. Kühn. 524, 2.—ei)/ pws pei/seian: so ii.67.5. The apod. is not formulated but implied, and ei)/ pws has nearly the effect of o(/pws in 3. GMT. 53, N. 2; H. 907. Cf. Kühn. Lat. Gr. II. 219, 2.
newteri/zein: applied to any innovation in established order, specially to harsh and violent changes. Cf. ii.3.6; iv.51.3.
[e)/prasson]: see App.
h)\n de/h|: after opt. GMT. 77, 2, N.; H. 933.—e)k pollou=: temporal. Cf. c. 68. 17; ii.85.8; iv.67.12.
hu(/ronto: see on c. 31. 11.—e)pith/deion: in neut. almost a subst., as in vi.41.12; vii.20.11. Cf. c. 29. 16, a)ph/ggeilan ou)de\n ei)rhnai=on.
ai( nh=es : see App.

o(moi/ws: used not only with pa/ntes to denote ‘without exception,’ but with other antithetical expressions, stress being laid on the word to which o(moi/ws is annexed. Cf. c. 39. 4; 70. 25; iii.47.13 (in which places it stands with the former word); c. 141. 4. The ships were sailing against them as well as against Macedonia.—ta\ te/lh: see on c. 10. 30.— 8. h)\n i)/wsin: subjv. after a past tense. GMT. 74, 1; H. 933.
to/te dh/: see on c. 49. 30.

kata\ to\n kairo\n tou=ton: at such a favourable moment, when the Athenians were threatened on several sides. This expression is not, therefore, as Cobet says, a mere gloss of to/te dh/. Cf. ii.84.21.
a)noiki/sasqai: cf. c. 7. 9.—tau/thn: obj., with mi/an po/lin i)sxura/n pred. Cf. c. 10. 11, and ii.15.14, h)na/gkase mia=| po/lei tau/th| xrh=sqai.

toi=s e)klipou=si : a repetition of the preceding e)klipo/ntas, after the execution of the scheme, and therefore without obj.—th=s...gh=s : part. gen. depending on the limitation implied in peri\ th\n *bo/lbhn li/mnhn.
*mugdoni/as : the eastern portion of Macedonia above Therma, separated by the Axius from Emathia. See ii.99.14.
The 30 Attic ships proceed first to the Macedonian coast.

ta\ e)pi\ *qra/|khs: see on c. 56. 11. —th\n *potei/daian: the best Mss. have no te here; so that, though the close connexion of the events would have justified te kai/ (which B. has restored; see on c. 49. 22), they are here simply placed side by side with kai/. In 4, 5, the particles correctly indicate two united objects of hostility.

a)festhko/ta: katalamba/nein in the sense of meet with, find, takes regularly the partic. pres. or pf., never aor., since only existing states can be in question. Cf. c. 61. 7; ii.56.20; iii.69.8; iv.129.2; vi.53.2; 94. 17; vii.2.6; 30. 2; 33. 25; viii.55.4; 65. 5. G. 279, 2; H. 982.
a)du/nata ei)=nai: see on c. 7. 2. But Cobet reads a)du/natoi, comparing c. 32. 21; 105. 15; 117. 12.
ta\ cunafestw=ta xwri/a: connected loosely with *perdi/kkan, for he e)polemw/qh (c. 57. 6), not a)pe/sth.
e)f) o(/per : refers to the sentence as a whole. See App. on c. 33. 16.
katasta/ntes: see on c. 49. 10.—meta\ *fili/ppou kte(.: see on c. 57. 6.

a)/nwqen: from the upper country of the interior. Cf. ii.99.16; 102. 14; iii.115.3.—e)sbeblhko/twn: the pf. partic. implies that the invasion was independent of any previous concert with the Athenians.
The Corinthians send Aristeus with 2000 men to the help of the Potidaeans.

kai\ e)n tou/tw|: and then, not
of time, but emphasizing the importance of the occasion, which decides the action of the Corinthians; the circumstances are expressed in th=s *poteidai/as . . . ou)sw=n, where the pf. and pres. partics. are quite proper.
peri\ tw=| xwri/w|: Thuc. uses peri/, for, with dat. nearly always after verbs of fear. The gen., ‘about,’ occurs iii.102.11; viii.93.17.
e(cakosi/ous...tetrakosi/ous : the whole number (tou\s pa/ntas, in all, c. 100. 6; viii.21.4) to which the Corinthians, e)qelontai/, and the allies, misqw=| peisqe/ntes, contribute.
*)adeima/ntou: see Hdt. viii. 59, 61. Schol., tou=ton i)/smen e)n toi=s *mhdikoi=s pro\s to\n *qemistokle/a stasia/zonta.

h)=n ga\r...e)pith/deios : gives the reason only of e)strath/gei *)aristeu/s, the clause kata\ fili/an te ... cune/sponto being inserted parenthetically, and te introducing this subordinate matter, as in c. 12. 15; 93. 24; ii.10.3; 19. 2.
a)ei/ pote: see on c. 13. 16; 47. 9.

tessarakosth=|...u(/steron : dat. of time, on the fortieth day after. Cf. viii.24.5. Unusual, but not less correct logically than tessara/konta h(me/rais, which would, however, be the dat. of measure or difference after a comparative.—e)pi\ *qra/|khs: see on c. 56. 11. Here the expression is construed with a verb.—h(=|...a)pe/sth : so the best Mss. for h)/. The complete expression would be h)\ h(=|, which v. H. reads here, as in Plat. Crit. 44 a in all Mss., and in Symp. 173 a in most Mss. But Buttmann, commenting on Dem. XXI. 119 (th=| proterai/a| o(/te tau=t' e)/legen), shows that the comparative particle h)/ might in such carelessly condensed expressions be easily omitted, but hardly the rel. pron. In Antiphon, VI. 37, the Mss. have eu)qu\s th=| u(sterai/a| h(=| o( pai=s e)qa/pteto.
Thereupon the Athenians send 40 additional ships and 2000 hoplites to Macedonia and Thrace.

h)=lqe...h( a)ggeli/a...kai\ pe/m-
pousin: parataxis as in c. 26. 16; 48. 3; and therefore a comma, not a colon or period, after a)festa=si.

toi=s *)aqhnai/ois : see on c. 13. 12.—tw=n po/lewn o(/ti a)festa=si: as we could have h)gge/lqhsan ai( po/leis o(/ti a)festa=si, this prolepsis is retained when the verb passes into the noun a)ggeli/a, which then takes the gen. Cf. viii.15.1, a)ggeli/a th=s *xi/ou. Similarly, c. 97. 13; 138. 7; ii.42.15. Kühn. 600, 5.— 3. e)pipario/ntas: see App.

pe/mpton au)to/n: Gilbert, Innere Geschichte Athens, p. 42, gives strong reasons for thinking that by such combinations of au)to/s with a numeral Thuc. means to indicate that the general named had the supremacy over his colleagues at the time. So in c. 62. 14 Callias is mentioned alone as strathgo/s.
prw=ton: with a)fiko/menoi, first, before going to Potidaea and ta\ a)festw=ta, their main object.—katalamba/nousi: see on c. 59. 2. The following words continue the narrative of that section.
*qe/rmhn: restored to Perdiccas, ii.29.28.
e)polio/rkhsan: to this and the following finite verbs the united force of 3000 men (c. 57. 17; 61. 3) is subj., not the latest comers only. See on c. 18. 21.

a)nagkai/an: made under stress, the ground of which is given in w(s . . . parelhluqw/s. This alliance was not felt as binding by either party; for the Athenians immediately resume hostilities, and Perdiccas a)pe/sth eu)qu/s, c. 62. 6.
kai\ a)fiko/menoi kte(.: on this march, see App.
e)pi\ *stre/yan: the emendation of Pluygers (Cobet, N. L. p. 382) for the unintelligible e)pistre/yantes. Strepsa was in Mygdonia, north of Therma.—peira/santes: with gen., as iv.70.18; vii.12.7.

e)poreu/onto kata\ gh=n: Cl. thinks that these words with a(/ma de\ nh=es kte(., 17, imply that they started from Therma, to which they must have returned after their failure at Strepsa. But see App. It took them three
short marches (tritai=oi, see on c. 12. 3) to reach Gigonus.
xwri/s: here abs., besides. Cf. ii.13.29; 31. 11; iii.17.6; vi.31.39.
tw=n cumma/xwn: i.e. of those who remained faithful.
*fili/ppou: the brother of Perdiccas, c. 57. 6. Schol., *pausani/as kata\ me/n tinas ui(o\s tou= *de/rdou (see on c. 57. 7), kata\ de\ a)/llous a)delfo/s.
nh=es e(bdomh/konta : 30 in c. 57. 16; 59. 1; to which 40 are added in c. 61. 4.
An engagement takes place between the two armies before Potidaea, not far from Olynthus.

e)stratopedeu/onto: Cobet reads e)stratope/deunto, since the meaning must be habere (not ponere) castra. Cf. iv.54.7; 129. 16.—pro\s *)olu/nqw|: in the neighbourhood of Olynthus on the isthmus. Aristeus marched to meet the advancing Athenians as far as the neighbourhood of Olynthus (60 stadia from Potidaea, c. 63. 9). While he himself with his main force occupied the approach to the isthmus (the road to Potidaea), and drew upon himself the chief attack, he had pushed forward the Chalcidian troops and the Macedonian cavalry to Olynthus itself, that they might assail in the rear the Athenians when engaged. But this flank attack was prevented by a detachment dispatched by the Athenians; the battle took place between the two main bodies on the road between Olynthus and Potidaea, at a considerable distance from the latter. See App.
e)pepoi/hnto: cf. h( a)gora\ pareskeua/sqh, vii.40.2; they had arranged that provisions should be for sale outside of Potidaea, to prevent the soldiers from dispersing. Cf. vii.39.10.

strathgo\n me/n: though me/n belongs strictly to pezou=, opp. to th=s de\ i(/ppou, it is attracted by the principal word, which belongs to the second clause also. “Often me/n and de/ attack different members of the antithesis with chiastic effect.” B.L.G. on Pind. Ol. XI. 8.
a)pe/sth: as plpf. of a)fe/sthka.

a)/rxonta : i.e. as administrator of Macedonia. But Grote, V. c. 47, p. 335, understands that
Iolaus was the captain of the 200 horse, which seems implied by the words th\n para\ (not meta\)*perdi/kkou in 11.

tou= *)ariste/ws...e)/xonti : a rare change of case at so short an interval, caused by the equivalence of h)=n h( gnw/mh to e)/doce. (Cobet says: postulat Graecitatis ratio e)/xonta.) Cf. Hom. K 187; *c 141; Eur. Med. 58; I. A. 491. See Classen, Beobb. üb. d. hom. Sprachgebr. p. 156. ff. Further on, when the subject changes, h)=n de\ h( gnw/mh takes acc. with inf., *xalkide/as . . . me/nein kai\ . . . e)n me/sw| poiei=n au(tw=n tou\s polemi/ous, in which the pron. au(tw=n contains a reference to Aristeus and his troops. See App.— 11. tou\s e)/cw i)sqmou=: Cl. explains ‘stationed outside the Isthmus’; but it is rather from beyond the Isthmus.—diakosi/an i(/ppon: fem. collective = cavalry; cf. i(/ppos muri/h, Hdt. i.27.8; a)spi\s . . . muri/a kai\ tetrakosi/a, Xen. An. i.7.10.

e)pi\ sfa=s: i.e. against Aristeus and his army. Note sfa=s used as a refl. of the 2d degree, referring to the principal subj., not that of its own clause (cf. c. 91. 14), while in the next line au(tw=n is refl. of 1st degree, referring to Aristeus and the two divisions of his army.
poiei=n: in pregnant sense, ‘to bring into a position.’ So e)pi\ tou= chrou=, c. 109. 16; v.2.13; vii.5.14.
*kalli/as: his advance from Gigonus (c. 61. 19) must have taken place meanwhile. — 15. tou\s *makedo/nas i(ppe/as: the 600 of c. 61. 16.
tou\s e)kei=qen: proleptic, as in c. 8. 9; 63. 8.—e)pibohqei=n: simple inf. after verb of hindrance. GMT. 95, 2 a; H. 963.
a)nasth/santes: cf. iv.90.2; 93. 2; v.58.10.
a)ntikaqi/stanto kai\ au)toi/: see on c. 50. 18. The impfs. here indicate the preparations for the decisive action. Cf. c. 46. 1; 48. 2.

e)/treyan to/: several Mss.
have e)tre/yanto, which might suggest the correction e)tre/yanto to/. But Thuc. uses the act. 30 times and the mid. only 6 times in this sense.— 24. e)pi\ polu/: (of time, c. 6. 12; ii.16.1; 64. 26, and frequently) here of space, as ii.75.8; v.73.25; vi.37.18; 70. 12; viii.10.9.

to\ tei=xos: i.e. of Potidaea. This engagement near Potidaea, which acc. to ii. 2, 7 must be placed in Sept., 432, was the one in which Socrates saved the life of the young Alcibiades. Cf. Plat. Symp. 220 d, e.
Aristeus forces his way through to Potidaea.
h(sshme/non: see on c. 30. 5.

diakinduneu/sai: the opt. of the Vat. Ms., instead of diakinduneu/sh| (Bekk., P., Kr., St.) or -sei (Sh.) of the other Mss., in deliberative sense, as in c. 25. 4. GMT. 71; H. 933. But c. 107. 25; ii.52.11; iii.112.22; v.65.21 show that the subjv. may be retained after a past tense. This verb generally = ‘to risk a decisive battle,’ here to force one's way through, as in iv.29.8; vii.1.7; 47. 11. xwrh/sas is to be joined with o(pote/rwse. See App.
d' ou)=n: with P. for gou=n of the Mss. See on c. 3. 19; 10. 33.

w(s e)s e)la/xiston: a prep. regularly stands after o(/ti, w(s thus used with a sup. See on c. 35. 10. Cf. ii.34.24; iii.46.4; and for a similar use in Latin, see Madvig on Cic. de Fin. v.9.26.—bia/sasqai e)s: cf. vii.69.29.

kai\ parh=lqe: this position of the verb indicates the instant carrying out of his decision; the aor. its successful result.—xhlh/n: a farprojecting mole or quay for the protection of the harbour and harbourwall. Cf. c. vii.53.5; viii.90.23. Schol. xhlh\ kalei=tai oi( e)/mprosqen tou= pro\s qa/lassan tei/xous probeblhme/noi li/qoi dia\ th\n tw=n kuma/twn bi/an, mh\ to\ tei=xos bla/ptoito.
ballo/meno/s te kai\ xalepw=s : combination of unlike elements in the same relation. Cf. c. 39. 2; 65. 2; 67. 2. Kr. Spr. 59, 2, 3. He may probably have been exposed to missiles from the Attic ships.

toi=s *poteidaia/tais: constructed with the noun bohqoi/, as it would be with the verb bohqei=n. Cf. c. 73. 1,
Kühn. 424; Kr. Spr. 48, 12, 4.— a)pei=xe: i.e. Olynthus from Potidaea. The ‘geographical impf.’ (Bekk., Sh. have a)pe/xei with inferior Mss.), the local circumstances being referred to the time of the narrative.—kai\ e)/sti katafane/s: the change of tense and the position of the verb implies the result of personal observation: “and the fact is there is a clear sight all the way.” For a similar omission of subj., cf. vi.101.15; vii.84.16.— 11. ta\ shmei=a h)/rqh: see on c. 49. 2. These signals were not for battle but for the movement of the distant troops; and as soon as it was seen that the purpose could not be accomplished, katespa/sqh.

pa/lin e)panexw/roun e)s to\ tei=xos: this is alluded to in the following lines of the sepulchral inscription presently referred to: e)xqrw=n oi( me\n e)/xousi ta/fou me/ros, oi( [de\ fugo/ntes] tei=xos pistota/thn e)lpi/d) e)/qento [bi/ou].
parege/nonto : i.e. took no part in the engagement just described.

tou\s nekrou\s...*poteidaia/tais : this was an acknowledgment of defeat on the part of the Potidaeans. Those who thus recovered their dead were said komi/zesqai tou\s nekrou/s, ii.79.29; 82. 4; iii.7.17. In ii.22.15, the words a)nei/lonto tou\s nekrou\s a)spo/ndous show that the defeat was not decisive.

*)aqhnai/wn au)tw=n: for some of the allies and the Macedonian horse (c. 62. 16) had not been engaged. The monument erected to the slain Athenians in the Ceramicus is still extant with the greater part of the inscription, and is now in the British Museum. See Kirchhoff, C. I. A. 442; Hicks, Inscr. no. 42.
The Athenians shut in Potidaea on all sides.

to\ d' e)k tou= i)sqmou=: the narrative is continued from c. 63. 18; and so de/ is used here, though we have a de/ in next line, which might seem to require a previous me/n. In this expression the prep. e)k is used to designate the north wall, which, to the Athenians regarding it from the north, would meet their eyes from the Isthmus, such being the Greek manner of
indicating observed positions. Cf. ii.76.13; iii.51.13. Kühn. 430, p. 398; Kr. Spr. 68, 17, 3. But the wall on the south side, from the same point of view, must for clearness be spoken of as in 2, to\ d' e)s th\n *pallh/nhn. On the other hand, the south wall as regarded by Athenians approaching from Aphytis is again correctly described, 13, as to\ e)k *pallh/nhs. On the bracketing of tei=xos, see App.— 2. a)poteixi/santes: as a)polamba/nein in c. 7. 4, implies the complete prevention of access. Cf. iii.51.13; 94. 12; iv.130.32; vi.101.9; 103. 6; vii.4.4. — 3. a)tei/xiston h)=n: here = ou)k a)petetei/xisto, as also in 5 teixi/zein =a)poteixi/zein. See Herbst, Schl. b. d. Argin., 8, note 11.
diaba/ntes: i.e. by ship; for the isthmus was completely closed by the town. Cf. iv.120.16.

genome/nois di/xa: this, though in only few Mss., is to be preferred to gignome/nois; for the meaning is that the Athenians feared an attack if they should have divided their forces, not at the moment of separation. For gi/gnesqai with adv. phrase, see on c. 37. 13.
punqano/menoi: impf. partic. (cf. iii.18.12; viii.83.1), of reports frequently arriving. Cf. c. 95. 10; 132. 21; ii.57.5.
th\n *pallh/nhn: = to\ e)s th\n *pallh/nhn.
*formi/wna : he took the command in place of Callias who had been killed, and distinguished himself highly in the first years of the war. See ii.29.30; 68; 80 ff.

*)afu/tios: Ionic gen. in a proper name, as *goa/cios, iv.107.11; *kni/dios, v.51.8. Aphytis was on the east side of Pallene, on the gulf of Torone. e)c *)afu/tios o(rmw/menos, making his base at Aphytis.
kata\ braxu/: cf. c. 61. 18, kat) o)li/gon.
kei/rwn : only here in Thuc. instead of te/mnwn. Frequent in Hdt., as vi.75.20; vii.131.2; viii.32.13; 65. 3.

kata\ kra/tos: applied to any energetic use of force, with poliorkei=n, polemei=n, ai(rei=n, lamba/nein. Cf. c. 118. 21; ii.54.14; iii.18.20; 103. 3; iv.23.10; 131. 4; v.116.10; vi.91.39; vii.41.1; viii.1.20; 64. 15; 70. 9.
Aristeus secretly leaves Potidaea, in order to procure aid from without.

a)poteixisqei/shs au)th=s kai\ e)/xwn: see on c. 63. 7, a similar coupling of unlike elements. Cf. also c. 67. 2; iv.28.2, 4; 29. § 1; 100. § 1; and for Latin examples see Nipperdey on Tac. Ann. iii.11.5.

a)/llo: ti must be repeated, something else.—para\ lo/gon: since Thuc. often uses the subst. o( para/logos (cf. c. 78. 3; ii.61.14; 85. 6; iii.16.10; vii.28.17; 55. 4; 61. 12; viii.24.29), and para\ lo/gon is unquestionable in ii.64.8; iv.26.11; 55. 17; 65. 18; vi.33.31, it is probable that where some Mss. give a neut. adj. para/logon (here, c. 140. 11; ii.91.15; vii.71.42), which is used by Arist., Polyb., Plut., etc., we should write para\ lo/gon divisim, corresponding to kata\ lo/gon in ii.89.25; iii.39.24. See Kr. on Dion. p. 267.
plh\n pentakosi/wn: belongs to toi=s a)/llois.

a)nti/sxh| : hold out, suffice, in either good or bad sense. Cf. c. 7. 6; ii.64.26; vi.69.9; vii.71.26. On the mood, see on c. 58. 7.—h)/qele: in pregnant meaning, expressed his willingness. Cf. c. 28. 6.—tw=n meno/ntwn: part. gen. with verb. Cf. viii.76.7.
ta\ e)pi\ tou/tois: what was expedient under these circumstances. Cf. vi.45.3; vii.62.14.—o(/pws...e(/cei : also dependent on paraskeua/zein in the sense of e)pimelei=sqai.
ta\ e)/cwqen : proleptic, as c. 62. 17; vi.25.13. See on c. 8. 9.
ta\ a)/lla: for this semi-adv. use see on c. 38. 6. Supply with the verb toi=s *xalkideu=si.

*sermuliw=n : depends on pollou/s, but to be understood also with pro\s th=| po/lei, which belongs grammatically to loxh/sas: having lain in wait near the city. Sermylia was in the peninsula of Sithonia, acc. to Hdt. vii.122.9, between Galepsus and Mecyberna.
e)s th\n *pelopo/nnhson e)/prassen: or with pro/s, of secret negotiations. This notion is more fully expressed in c. 57. 8. Cf. c. 131. 7; 132. 21.

th=s *po-
teidai/as th\n a)potei/xisin: for the order, cf. c. 32. 8.

*bottikh/n: see on c. 57. 12. While Phormio with his force was seeking to subdue the places which had revolted, the main army of 3,000 men, c. 61. 15, continued the siege of Potidaea. Its further course and result (in the winter of 430-429) are told in ii. 58 and 70. For the cost of this long siege, see iii. 17. § 3.
Review of the quarrel on account of Potidaea.

ai)ti/ai: as the following exposition shows, the pl. refers only to the affair of Potidaea in its two aspects, as affecting the Athenians and the Peloponnesians; and prosegege/nhnto of the best Mss. is to be preferred to proegege/nhnto, as this clause stands in close connexion with c. 55. § 2, where, after the narration of the affair of Corcyra, we read, ai)ti/a au(/th (the sing., because one only relation is regarded) prw/th e)ge/neto toi=s *korinqi/ois e)s tou\s *)aqhnai/ous, to which this passage adds a second ai)ti/a. Ullrich, Beitr. zur Krit., I. p. 27 ff. As Aristeus had brought other Peloponnesians with him (c. 60. 5; 62. 2) to the support of Potidaea, the hostile feeling extended itself beyond the Corinthians, who were first affected by it. This accounts for the mention of *peloponnhsi/ois in 1; and the expression ai)ti/ai has the general meaning of ground of complaint (in c. 146. 1, connected with diaforai/), and without the addition of tou= pole/mou, as in c. 55. 13. So ai)ti/ai me/n is opposed to ou) me/ntoi kte(. in 8, i.e. to the actual outbreak of the war.
a)po\ tou= profanou=s: see on c. 34. 10.
cunerrw/gei: from currhgnu/nai, here only in Attic writers, but often used by Appian., Dio Cass., Plut. In viii.96.7, we have the related fut. curra/cousi(r(a/ssw).
i)di/a|: on their own account, without the instigation of others. Here e)/pracan must be rendered as plpf.; cf. c. 128. 16, 17.
NEGOTIATIONS AND RESOLUTIONS IN THE LACEDAEMONIAN POPULAR ASSEMBLY. Chaps. 67-87.

p.hi: The Corinthians, in concert with other allies, go to Sparta with complaints against the Athenians.

div2.p: a)ndrwn...dedio/tes : see on c. 63. 7.

te: inferential, see on c. 4. 5. —tou\s cumma/xous: who belonged to the Peloponnesian alliance (Ullrich, Beitr. z. Krit. I. p. 29, explains the word of the Corinthian allies in the affairs of Corcyra and Potidaea). Though the formal summons to attend their diet belonged to the Lacedaemonians (c. 87. 11), friendly invitations to counsel could be made by other states (v.30.12).

katebo/wn: with gen. Cf. c. 115. 8; v.45.18. So the noun kataboh/ in c. 73. 3.—e)lqo/ntes: this word implies a zealous purpose, they came and. Similarly, c. 115. 8; ii.72.19; 79. 5; iii.65.5; iv.61.28; 92. 4; v.32.15; 81. 7; vi.79.16; viii.67.1. Cf. i)w/n in Soph. Aj. 304. Kühn. 486, note 10.

a)dikoi=en: the constant use of a)dikei=n = to be in the wrong (GMT. 10, 1, N. 4; H. 827) makes this verb parallel in sense to leluko/tes ei)=en: “had put themselves in the wrong in regard to the Peloponnesians.”

*ai)ginh=tai/ te: since these did not belong to the cu/mmaxoi, but had been in dependence on Athens since Ol. 81, 1, B.C. 456 (c. 105; 108. § 4), te is used, as in c. 2. 6; 33. 6, and besides. They ventured therefore only presbeu/esqai kru/fa (this is the established form in Thuc. for the more usual krufh=| or krufh=. Kühn. 336, note 7).

kata\ ta\s sponda/s: this, like para\ ta\s sponda/s in 16, probably refers to the thirty years' truce of B.C. 445, Ol. 83. 4, in which there may have been a general formula such as e)a=n au)tono/mous ta\s po/leis, as Kr. conjectures (Stud. I. p. 194). Some suppose that the general peace after the battle of Plataea is meant. Cf. ii. 72. § 1. Grote, V. c. 48, p. 342, thinks that the Aeginetans “may have taken advantage of both.”

prosparakale/santes kte(.: refers to 3, pareka/loun tou\s cumma/xous of the Corinthians. The Lacedaemonians also called upon any of the allies who had any other complaint to make to come forward: ti a)/llo, i.e. beside those of the Corinthians and Aeginetans. See App.

cu/llogon sfw=n au)tw=n to\n...ei)wqo/ta : on the order, see on c. 1. 6: the Spartan popular assembly, which all Spartans of 30 years of age were entitled to attend (Schömann, Ant. of Gr. I. p. 234). poiei=n, to summon, not ‘to hold’; cf. c. 139. 17; ii.22.4; 59. 11; iv.114.11;
vi.8.5; 72. 3; viii.76.4.
le/gein e)ke/leuon: addressed to all those present.

paoio/ntes - e)poiou=nto : impf. of the succession of complainants; 16, parelqo/ntes—e)pei=pon of the Corinthians alone. parie/nai is the constant expression for appearing before an assembly. Cf. c. 72. 4, 15; 73. 4; 79. 7; 85. 13, etc.
w(s e(/kastoi: one by one. Cf. c. 3. 19; 48. 11.

dia/fora: see on c. 56. 2.—lime/nwn te ei)/rgesqai: the first mention of the yh/fisma peri\ *megare/wn (c. 139. 6; 144. 7), which was perhaps adopted at the same time with the resolution against Potidaea. Ullrich, Das Megarische Psephisma, p. 34 ff.
para\ ta\s sponda/s: this Pericles expressly denies, c. 144. 10.
kai\ e)a/santes kte(.: to be connected with teleutai=oi. Both expressions are predicative to parelqo/ntes, the later of the two circumstances being placed first. Cf. c. 37. 10; 70. 25.
e)pei=pon: i.e. they made the following speech in confirmation of what was urged by the other allies.
SPEECH OF THE CORINTHIAN ENVOYS IN THE SPARTAN ASSEMBLY. Chaps. 68-71.
You have too long disregarded our warnings as to the hostile purposes of the Athenians. They can now be seen clearly manifested in their dealings with Corcyra and Potidaea.

to\ pisto/n: (see on c. 36. 3, for use of neut. adj. as abstract noun) a contrast is evidently intended between this and a)pistote/rous, though the meaning is not quite the same: to\ pisto/n, meaning honesty, integrity, which can be trusted (pass.), and a)pistote/rous, implying incredulity (act.).—u(ma=s: note the emphasis of the position. Cf. c. 70. 5; and of other prons., v.82.23; vii.78.26.— 2. politei/as kai\ o(mili/as: behaviour in public life and in social intercourse. —e)s tou\s a)/llous h)/n ti le/gwmen: in this punctuation Cl. now follows P. and St. ‘if we bring any complaint against others.’ For le/gein e)s in this sense (usually ‘to speak before’), cf. vi.41.4; Hdt. i.86.30; and for the position of the conj., cf. c. 19. 3; 120. 9. But it seems better, chiefly on account of the generic art., with most editors to connect e)s tou\s a)/llous with a)pistote/rous. The meaning will then be, either indisposed to believe anything against (see on c. 38. 1) others (here, the Athenians) if we say anything to their discredit; or (tou\s a)/llous=h(ma=s) ‘distrustful of us the rest, if we allege
any complaint.’

kaqi/sthsi: with an adj.=an emphatic tiqe/nai, renders. Cf. ii.42.4; iii.46.3; viii.66.25.— a)p' au)tou=: refers to the whole preceding description, as in 9. See on c. 2. 11.—swfrosu/nhn: sobriety, moderation, leaning here rather to the side of indifference, which in ii.40.7 is described as a)/pragmon and a)xrei=on.— 4. ple/oni :=mei/zoni, i.e. than it would be under different circumstances.

proagoreuo/ntwn: partic. impf.: here, announced beforehand; elsewhere, ‘proclaim aloud’; see on c. 29. 3.— 7. ma/qhsin e)poiei=sqe: “you would not take knowledge of what we were trying to show you.” See on c. 6. 3.— tw=n lego/ntwn...le/gousi : the const. is similar to vii.73.2, u(ponoh/sas au)tw=n th\n dia/noian, except that here a sentence, w(s . . . le/gousi, stands in place of the subst. Cf. Xen. Cyr. v.2.18, e)neno/hsen au)tw=n w(s e)phrw/twn a)llh/lous. See on c. 52. 10. “Against the speakers, rather, you directed your suspicion that they were influenced by selfinterest.”

e(/neka: see App.—diafo/rwn: here, interests (from the act. diafe/rein), as me/testi pro\s ta\ i)/dia dia/fora pa=si to\ i)/son, ii.37.5; iv.86.23; v.115.8; elsewhere, ‘points in dispute’ (from the mid. diafe/resqai), as in c. 56. 2; 67. 14; 78. 12; ii.27.9; iv.79.10; v.45.2.
ou) pri\n pa/sxein: see on c. 39. 5.—e)n tw=| e)/rgw|:=e)n au)tw=| tw=| pa/sxein, but also having reference to the common use of e)n tw=| e)/rgw| of action in war: when we are actually engaged.

e)n oi(=s: Cl. connects with the sup. ou)x h(/kista, ‘among whom we have the best right to speak’; and compares c. 6. 6, e)n toi=s. But it is better with P. and Kr. to interpret before whom, as c. 85. 15, e)n toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois.
o(/sw| : ‘in what degree,’ in so far as; without a comp., also in ii.47.14; iii.45.27; v.90.6; 108. 3; vi.78.5; viii.84.3.
u(brizo/menoi, a)melou/menoi: partics. impf., including a considerable time up to the present.

w(s ou)k ei)do/si: sc. u(mi=n, depending on prose/dei, “you would need additional information on the ground of your ignorance.”—nu=n de/: i.e. e)n fanerw=| ou)/shs th=s a)diki/as au)tw=n.—
15. makrhgorei=n: cf. ii.36.14; iv.59.6, in both places with e)n ei)do/sin, which has here been anticipated. We must supply h(ma=s as subj., extended now to include the other allies, and serving as the antecedent of w(=n. When the rel. is thus used rhetorically to introduce important aspects of the case, a certain freedom of const. is common. Cf. c. 74. 11; vi.68.2, pollh=| paraine/sei ti/ dei= xrh=sqai, oi(\ pa/resmen e)pi\ to\n a)gw=na ; So, often in poets: Soph. O. C. 263, 427; Aj. 457; Ar. Nub. 1226, 1377; Ran. 1058.—tou\s me/n: e.g. the Aeginetans.
toi=s de/: e.g. the Megarians.—toi=s...cumma/xois : i.e. the Potidaeans, as special dependants of the Corinthians.

propareskeuasme/nous: in the second member of the rel. clause o(ra=te has taken a new obj., au)tou/s, with an act. partic.; to this obj. a third partic. member is here attached which has no longer any connexion with the rel. w(=n; “and you see that they have long ago prepared themselves, in case they shall by and by be involved in war.”

polemh/sontai: fut. mid. as pass. Cf. viii.43.13. G. 199, N. 4; H. 496. Here the apod. is merely implied. See on c. 58. 2.—ou) ga\r a)/n: “for otherwise (see on c. 11. 5) they would not have so openly resorted to violent measures at Corcyra and Potidaea.” Cf. Eur. I. T. 666.—u(polabo/ntes: of crafty appropriation at the expense of another. Cf. c. 121. 9; 143. 3; vi.58.7; viii.105.15.
bi/a| h(mw=n: see on c. 43. 8.—ei)=xon: after the aor. partic., as c. 29. 23; 30. 4; 38. 15.
to\ me/n...h( de/ : chiasmus: to\ me/n (Potidaea) conformed in gender to the pred. xwri/on.

a)poxrh=sqai : to make use of. Cf. vi.17.5; vii.42.27. The inf. is epexegetic of e)pikairo/taton, “excellently situated for profitable use of it (sc. tw=| xwri/w|) in relation to the Thracian coast.”— 21. toi=s: before *peloponnhsi/ois is from the Vat. Ms.
§ 1-6. You have yourselves encouraged their encroachments by looking quietly on as they increased their power, and you will have to bear the consequences.
th\n po/lin...kratu=nai : see c. 90-93. kratu=nai, a poetic word; act., iii.18.7; mid., iii.82.40; iv.52.13; 114. 10. In tragedy=kratei=n.

ta\ makra\ tei/xh : see c. 107. § 1.—sth=
sai: to raise; probably only here of walls; but with sth/las, v.18.54; 23. 22; and often with tropai=on, c. 30. 2; 54. 3; 105. 30; ii.22.16.—e)s to/de te: the postscript te connects an important third particular. Cf. c. 2. 6; 50. 4; 56. 8. e)s to/de = me/xri tou=de (Schol.) is rare. Cf. Hdt. iv.10.17, e)/ti kai\ e)s to/de; and e)s tou=to, v.26.6.— a)posterou=ntes: expresses not so much the act of depriving, as the continued withholding of what is due. See on c. 40. 7.
tou\s...dedoulwme/nous : an invidious expression for the Attic cu/mmaxoi, to which is opposed tou\s u(mete/rous cumma/xous with the emphasizing h)/dh, now even.

au)to\ dra=|: i.e. doulou=tai. See on c. 5. 11.—th\n a)ci/wsin th=s a)reth=s: reputation for magnanimity. a)reth/, particularly of generous dealing with the weak. Cf. c. 37. 21; iii.58.2; iv.19.12. See Introd. p. 36.
w(s e)leuqerw=n kte(.: this claim of Sparta often occurs. See ii.8.15; 71. § 2; iii.32.5; 59. 30; 63. 16; iv.108.12. fe/resqai, properly of bearing off a prize; and so to gain, enjoy. Cf. ii.11.36.
nu=n ge: so Stephanus for nu=n te of the Mss., rightly adopted by the recent editors (not by Sh., who renders ‘now too’).

e)pi\ faneroi=s: e)pi/ with dat. of conditioning circumstances, as c. 13. 4; 65. 7; 70. 10; iv.22.13; upon a basis of openly expressed purpose, from which alone a sure decision can be reached.—xrh=n ga\r kte(.: “by this time we ought to have been considering not whether we are wronged but how we are to be revenged.” J. On the formation of xrh=n=xrh\ h)=n, Kühn. 298, 6. For kaq' o(/ ti, how, cf. vi.8.16; and see on c. 35. 16.

oi( ga\r drw=ntes...e)pe/rxontai : Cl., considering that we need in this clause a special designation of the Athenians, renders oi( ga/r, for they (cf. vi.36.6), though this use of the art. for dem. pron. with ga/r is extremely doubtful in prose (Kühn. 458, 3; 459; Kr. Dial. 50, 1, 2). It seems better to regard this as a general proposition of which the application to the Athenians is found in 12, kai\ e)pista/meqa kte(. The previous clause xrh=n ga\r . . . a)munou/meqa implies the dilatory, indecisive behaviour of the Lacedaemonians; and it is proper that this should be contrasted first with the resolute practice of energetic natures in general, and then with actual policy of the Athenians. The commas, therefore, are to be removed and h)/dh to be connected with ou) me/llontes. “For men who act (men of energy and action, actuosi), with plans fully formed, advance at once and without hesitation against men who have not yet made up their minds.” This does not necessarily imply impetuous action;
and therefore the words involve nothing inconsistent with the slow and steady aggression attributed to the Athenians. See App.

kai\ e)pista/meqa kte(.: observe that a verb (e)pece/rxontai or xwrou=si) must be supplied for oi(/a| o(dw=|, unless, with Cobet, kai\ o(/ti is bracketed. For o(/ti can hardly be taken as=kaq' o(/ ti of 10.—kat' o)li/gon: by little and little. Cf. c. 61. 18.—tou\s pe/las: see on c. 32. 3.

kai\ lanqa/nein...qarsou=si : while they think themselves unobserved merely because your perceptions are dull, they are not so wholly (h(=sson) free from fear. On to\ a)nai/sqhton, see on c. 36. 3. Cf. c. 82. 1; vi.86.17.

gno/ntes de\...e)gkei/sontai : but when they have come to the conclusion that you know their doings and yet do not interfere, they will press on with vigour. e)gkei=sqai often of actual fighting. Cf. c. 49. 29; ii.79.24; iii.98.6; iv.22.5; v.73.17; viii.85.18.

ou) th=| duna/mei...a)muno/menoi : defending yourselves not by using your power but by looking as if you were going to use it. For the sing. tina, cf. c. 95. 16; 141. 29; ii.37.2; iii.46.20; iv.85.19.
diplasioume/nhn: the usual form of the verb is diplasia/zein. Some concrete notion like du/namin must be supplied as obj. from au)/chsin.

kai/toi: and yet, introduces an objection adduced by the speaker to his own disparaging account. “If you were disinclined to move, at least people said you were secure against dangers from without.” Kr.'s interpretation ‘cautious’ is not justified by the usage of Thuc.

w(=n: refers to the antecedent u(mei=s implied in e)le/gesqe (cf. c. 68. 15), and has an adversative meaning, as in c. 35. 15. w(=n is objective gen. to lo/gos in the sense of repute. Cf. ii.42.7; Eur. El. 937, ta)ndro\s me\n ou)dei\s tw=n de\ qhleiw=n lo/gos; I. T. 517; Plat. Apol. 26 b.— a)/ra: chiefly with the impf. (cf. c. 35. 20) emphasizes the revelation of a fact not before realized: “but it turns out that your reputation was greater than the facts warranted.” Kr. Spr. 53, 2, 6; Kühn. 509, 4.

i)/smen...e)lqo/nta : Thuc. never uses ei)de/nai with the inf., but with either o(/ti, w(s, or a partic. Cf. c. 76. 5; 122. 14; 127. 3; 140. 3; ii.40.22, etc. GMT. 73, 2; H. 982.—e)k pera/twn gh=s: proverbial. Cf. Alcae. frg. 8; Xen. Ages. 9. 4. Often imitated by later writers. —pro/teron h)/: like pri/n with inf., ii.
40. 11; vi.58.3; viii.45.29; u(/steron h)/, vi.4.12. Sturm, *p*r*i*n, p. 97.—e)pi\ th\n *pelopo/nnhson: even to the confines of Peloponnesus, in hostile sense.
ta\ par' u(mw=n: your defensive forces. Cf. vi.22.14; 46. 9.—a)ci/ws: sc. th=s u(mete/ras duna/mews.
proapanth=sai : went forth to withstand him. Cf. iv.92.28.
e)kei=non: assimilated to tou\s *)aqhnai/ous. Kr. Spr. 62, 4, 3; Kühn. 581, 3. Cf. v.99.4; vi.68.9; Dem. IV. 21.

e)ggu\s o)/ntas: not to be construed with periora=te, which is here used without a partic., as in 6, but pred. to tou\s *)aqhnai/ous, although they are not far off but close at hand. —a)nti\ tou= e)pelqei=n: cf. vii.75.40.— e)pelqei=n au)toi/: ultro adoriri, with reference to the following e)pio/ntas.— 25. e)s tu/xas katasth=nai : used specially of the uncertainties of war. Cf. c. 78. 5; vi.11.22.
e)pista/menoi: though you know.
au)to\n peri\ au(tw=|: by his own fault. Cf. vi.33.29; Hdt. ix.101.13, mh\ peri\ *mardoni/w| ptai/sh| h( *(ella/s. “Propr. circa se tanquam scopulum, i.e. sua culpa.” P.—ta\ plei/w: see on c. 13. 17.
h(ma=s: not the Corinthians alone, but the other allies also who depended on Sparta.
perigegenhme/nous: see on c. 55. 11.—ai( u(me/terai e)lpi/des: the hopes which rested on you. See on c. 33. 18.

h)/dh tina\s...e)/fqeiran : have already ruined some, who remained unprepared just because they trusted you; alluding perhaps to the Thasians, c. 101, and the Euboeans, c. 114. The aor. is empiric, drawing a general inference from special occurrences. GMT. 30, 1; H. 840; Kühn. 386, 7. For h)/dh, cf. c. 120. 6; ii.77.15; iv.62.13; vi.86.14; vii.77.2, 16.

to\ ple/on h)/: after a neg. See on c. 9. 21.—e)p) e)/xqra|...ai)ti/a| : see on c. 37. 8. Here, as there, e)pi/ indicates the end; but the two nouns do not exactly correspond, e)/xqra referring to a sentiment, and ai)ti/a, expostulation, to an action: “not to lay bare our hostile feelings, but to make a well-grounded complaint.” Accordingly in the following explanation, in which ai)ti/a stands
first chiastically, instead of an elucidation of e)/xqra we have kathgori/a, the real opposite of ai)ti/a. The genitives fi/lwn a)ndrw=n and e)xqrw=n are objective. The course of thought is this: our reproaches are not kathgori/a but ai)ti/a, for we regard you as fi/loi a)marta/nontes, not as e)xqroi\ a)dikh/santes.
The Athenians, by their activity and decision, have great advantage over you with your sluggish and dilatory policy.

kai\ a(/ma kte(.: “besides the good intentions of which we are conscious, we have as good a right as any to find fault with you.” What follows, however, relates rather to the character of the Lacedaemonians than to the justification of the Corinthians.— ei)/per tine\s kai\ a)/lloi: cf. c. 142. 24; iv.55.12; Hdt. ix.27.26; Plat. Phaed. 58 e; 63 c; 67 b; Xen. Cyr. iii.3.42. On the kai/ in such formulae, see Kühn. 524, 2, 3; Kr. Spr. 69, 32, 13.
toi=s pe/las: see on c. 32. 16; here specially of the Lacedaemonians.

tw=n diafero/ntwn: the points of difference, i.e. between you and the Athenians, to be presently stated; so ii.43.27. But P. and Kr. interpret, ‘the interests at stake,’ as in vi.92.23, like ta\ dia/fora in c. 68. 8. The former sense is confirmed by 4, pro\s oi(/ous . . . e)/stai. Bonitz, Beiträge zur Erklärung des Thukydides, p. 7.— ai)sqa/nesqai - e)klogi/sasqai : have for obj. the following dependent interr. clause pro\s oi(/ous kte(. The use of pw/pote shows that e)klogi/sasqai represents a real past tense, to have calculated.

pro\s oi(/ous kai\ o(/son diafe/rontas: i.e. oi(=oi kai\ o(/son . . . diafe/rontes oi( *)aqhnai=oi/ ei)sin, pro\s ou(\s o( a)gw\n e)/stai. Cf. c. 73. 18. For examples of similar blending of a question and a dependent sentence, see Kühn. 587, 6.
u(mi=n: depends on e)/stai. On its emphatic position, see on c. 68. 1.— o(/son kai\ w(s pa=n: how far, I should say how utterly. Sh.
oi( me/n ge: see on c. 40. 15. The opposition is thus strongly marked. —newteropoioi/: the adj. only here in Thuc.; the abstract noun in c. 102. 11.

e)pinoh=sai kte(.: in the following delineation, 10 aor. infs. alternate with 7 pres. infs. (aor. e)pinoh=sai, e)pitele/sai, e)pignw=nai, e)cike/sqai, pra=cai, pisteu=sai, e)pelqei=n, bla/yai, tuxei=n pra/cantes, pra=cai; pres., sw/|zein, oi)/esqai, kta=sqai, pra/ssein, th\n e)pixei/rhsin poiei=sqai, kta=sqai, h(gei=sqai). The latter designate enduring conditions or continued activities; the former, activities with a definite direction or ends attained. It will be observed, too, how the inf. with a neg. (or with a neg. notion, as e)ndea=, 12, o)li/ga, 22) is regularly in the aor. (complexive), unless resistance or refusal is implied, as in 13 (“you refuse to believe that you will ever”).— e)pinoh=sai: to form plans. Cf. 21;
ii.11.11; v.13.7; Ar. Eccl. 247.— o)cei=s: quick, defined by the dependent infs. But as applied to the Lacedaemonians, it must be taken ironically, or by zeugma implying the general sense u(mei=s oi(=oi/ e)ste.
a(\ a)\n gnw=sin : whatever they have decided. So usually in aor. See App.
e)pignw=nai: to adopt further measures. Cf. ii.65.48; iii.57.6. In c. 132. 35 it means ‘find out.’

ou)de/: the two preceding clauses (sw/|zein and e)pignw=nai, connected by te kai/) give the positive and neg. sides of the Laconian conservatism, and are in the same const. as e)pinoh=sai; but the neg. ou)de/ shows that this last clause is conceived independently of the former, as if Thuc. had said ou) me/ntoi o)cei=s e)ste ou)de\ ta)nagkai=a e)cike/sqai. This last verb is usually intr., as in Pl. Prot. 311 d; Xen. Mem. i.4.17; ii.3.19, but is here, carry out, attain. So in 21, e)celqei=n has a neut. pl. obj. Cf. iii.108.9; Soph. Tr. 506, e)ch=lqon a)/eql' a)gw/nwn.

tolmhtai/...kinduneutai/ : Thuc. seems to have coined several verbal substs. of this form: mellhth/s, a)podhmhth/s, 14; ei)kasth/s, c. 138. 15; diallakth/s, iv.60.4,—all expressing bent, habituation to a course, like Latin nouns in -tor. Here para\ du/namin (beyond the measure of one's strength, implying rashness) and para\ gnw/mhn (beyond the limits which prudence would set, implying recklessness) are opposed to the clauses which state the defects of the Lacedaemonians, th=s duna/mews e)ndea= pra=cai and th=s gnw/mhs mhde\ toi=s bebai/ois pisteu=sai.
e)pi\ toi=s deinoi=s : in the face of dangers, propositis periculis. Cf. c. 143. 8; v.90.6; vi.20.3; Dem. IV. 20, e)pi\ tw=| pra/ttein ou)de\ ta\ mikra\ poiei=te.
kai\ mh\n kai/: introducing forcibly a further statement, iam vero. Cf. c. 142. 1, kai\ mh\n ou)de/.
a)/oknoi : not here ‘indefatigable in endurance,’ but resolute for action, as in c. 74. 5.

th=| a)pousi/a|: by their absence from home.—a)/n ti kta=sqai: the pres. inf. with the pregnant ti, as in 29, a)ei\ kta=sqai, implies a never-satisfied eagerness to press forward; while ta\ e(toi=ma, 16, a strengthened u(pa/rxonta, means possessions lying ready for use, the loss of which is feared. Cf. iv.61.2; vi.9.16.

e)pelqei=n: whether abs. or with a dat. has in Thuc. so generally the meaning of hostile advance (cf. c. 2. 8; 18. 18; 62. 10; 69. 12, 24; 123. 14; 124. 18; ii.36.14; 39. 12; 89. 22; iii.84.7, etc.) that it expresses the aggressive spirit,
which the Lacedaemonians are said to dread, more distinctly than e)celqei=n, proposed by Ullrich and approved by St. (Jahrb. 1863, p. 413). In 22, e)pelqo/ntes is used of the Athenians in the same sense of agression.

kratou=nte/s te: from this point, when the inferential te marks the passage from the general to its application in particulars, the delineation confines itself to the Athenians, and is calculated to make a lively impression on the Lacedaemonians.

e)p' e)la/xiston a)napi/ptousin: clearly opp. to e)pi\ plei=ston e)ce/rxontai (they pursue their victory to the furthest extent, cf. Plat. Prot. 361 c) and to be taken in the pass. sense of pi/ptein =ba/llesqai, they allow themselves to be forced back, they fall back, the least. Cf. Bonitz, ibid. p. 8 ff.—e)/ti de/: this bravery, always pressing forward, never frightened back, does not merely lead the Athenians to evernew results; still more effective is the clear consciousness with which they put all powers of body and mind at the service of their country.

th=| gnw/mh|: the mind and all its powers, opp. to sw/mata. Cf. ii.38.2, “A somewhat forced antithesis between a)llotriwta/tois and oi)keiota/th| is the veil of a noble sentiment. Their bodies they throw away, as freely as though they did not belong to them, in the service of their country; their minds they jealously preserve as the thing dearest to them, that they may use them on her behalf.” Jowett.

kai/...me/n...de/...de/ : this unlimited devotion of the Athenians exhibits itself in three aspects, as regards (1) aims not completely carried out (a(\ me
 a)
 . . . h(gou=ntai); (2) aims perfectly attained (a(\ d' a)
 . . . pra/cantes); (3) aims which have not succeeded (h)
 d' a)/ra...th
 xrei/an). There must not therefore be a full point before h)
 d' a)/ra. See St. Jahrb. 1863, p. 473-4.

e)ce/lqwsin: (so the best Mss. for e)pece/lqwsin) here and iii.108.9 with a neut. obj. of undefined extent (a(\—a)/n, to\ polu/) has a trans. meaning, bring to an issue. See on 9.— oi)kei=a ste/resqai h(gou=ntai: the acc. with ste/resqai does not occur elsewhere, but may be tolerated as inner obj. from a neut. adj. See on c. 32. 4. Kr. Spr. 47, 13, 10. ste/resqai seems to be=e)sterh=sqai, but “verbs of privation connote feeling.” Gildersleeve on Pind. Py. VII. 22. “In failing to attain an object, they consider that they have lost what was really their own.”

o)li/ga pro\s ta\ me/llonta: cf. c. 6. 15; 10. 8, 33; “only little in comparison with what remains to be done.” So tuxei=n pra/cantes instead of pra=cai (GMT. 24, N. 1; H. 984) points to the unsatisfying character of the result: “that they have indeed succeeded this time.”

h)\n d' a)/ra: and if after
all it turn out that.—tou: belongs to sfalw=sin rather than to pei/ra|. Cf. ii.43.12. The best Mss. have kai/ tou and not tou kai/. For the force of kai/, see on c. 15. 7.

a)ntelpi/santes: occurs here only, forming new hopes in compensation for failure.—e)plh/rwsan: empiric aor. See on c. 69. 31.— xrei/an: want, lack. Cf. iii.59.9.— 25. e)/xousi...kai\ e)lpi/zousin : an inversion of the natural order for greater effectiveness; “possession and hope in this case coincide.”—o(moi/ws: see on c. 58. 7.
w(=n: the gen. assimilated to the obj. of e)pixei/rhsin. Cf. vii.43.12.
meta\ po/nwn: with, i.e. not without, constant toil.
ai)w=nos moxqou=si: ai)w/n (in Thuc. here only) and moxqei=n (once more in ii.39.23), unusual expressions chosen to enforce the close of the delineation.

mh/te e(orth\n a)/llo ti h(gei=sqai: the hyperbole usual in proverbial expressions, the only thing they deem a festival. Cf. iii.30.12; vii.77.25. The Schol. makes this an allusion to the refusal of the Spartans to set forth during festivals.

ou)x h(=sson...h)/ : this combination emphasizes the former member so much that the latter is often practically denied. Cf. ou) tosou=ton— o(/son, and ou) ma=llon(to\ plei=on)h)/. See on c. 9. 2, 21. Here it is represented that a)sxoli/a e)pi/ponos is certainly not regarded by the Athenians as a misfortune, while h(suxi/a a)pra/gmwn is so regarded.

e)pi\ tw=|...e)a=n : the infs. with e)pi\ tw=| after pefuke/nai represent the constant object of their whole existence. The inf. alone would indicate only adaptation in the special case, as in ii.64.17; iii.45.8; iv.61.20.
e)a=n: with this e)/xein h(suxi/an must be supplied, as must a corresponding partic. with o(ra=n, c. 78. 10; 80. 2.
You have now an excellent opportunity for changing your policy. Nothing short of an invasion of Attica will help us and keep us in your alliance.

tau/ths toiau/ths po/lews: although this state with such characteristics stands facing you. It is better to make tau/ths, with appos. toiau/ths po/lews (sc. ou)/shs) subj. of a)ntikaqesthkui/as, than, with Kr. and B., to make tau/ths alone
the subj., and toiau/ths po/lews pred. with the partic. The elaborate delineation of the last chap. requires to be resumed here with something more than the simple tau/ths. Cf. ii.60.16, e)moi\ toiou/tw| a)ndri/. But in c. 74. 1, toiou/tou cumba/ntos tou/tou, tou/tou alone is the subj.

a)rkei=n: from the meaning ‘suffice’ comes naturally that of hold out, last.—oi(\ a)\n kte(.: the condition under which quiet behaviour can maintain adequate security for a considerable time is expressed in the first member by a description of the persons in question, “who, in the use they make of their own warlike preparation, do only what is just, but show also a decided purpose not to submit to wrong.” The neg. mh/ is used because in a generic rel. sentence. Kr. Spr. 67, 9. For e)pitre/pein, cf. c. 82. 4; 95. 5; ii.72.20; vi.40.9; viii.27.6.

a)ll) e)pi\ tw=| mh\ kte(.: in these words the sentence is continued as if the former portion had begun with ou)k oi)/esqe tou/tois (instead of oi)/esqe ou) tou/tois). The sense is: “but on the principle of doing no offence to others, and of receiving no damage yourselves in being compelled to resist injuries, you maintain what you consider to be an impartial attitude”; whereas this is really a course which is wholly in favour of the aggressive Athenians. But Cl. explains to\ i)/son ne/mein ‘attach equal importance,’ comparing iii.3.6; 48. 2; vi.88.10; Plat. Prot. 337 a; in which passages, however, the phrase is followed by the dat. and not by e)pi/ with dat. Others explain, ‘you form your notions of right,’ ‘your conception of political justice is founded’; but Cl. rightly objects that no instances can be quoted of the words used in this sense.
mo/lis d) a)\n kte(.: but you could hardly carry out such a policy successfully, if you had a city just like yourselves for your neighbour.
nu=n de/: introduces the real state of the case, ou)x o(moi/a| po/lei paroikei=te.

a)rxaio/tropa : old-fashioned; not elsewhere in Attic.—e)pithdeu/mata: see on c. 32. 10.—pro/s: see on c. 6. 15. pro\s au)tou/s = pro\s ta\ e)pithdeu/mata au)tw=n, comparatio compendiaria. Cf. 14; c. 77. 24; 143. 14; Hom. P 51, ko/mai *xari/tessin o(moi=ai. Kühn. 543, 3; Kr. Spr. 48, 13, 9.

te/xnhs: not ‘art’ in the higher sense, but any competence resting on exercise and experience; especially in matters of war and seamanship. Cf. c.
49. 6; 142. 24; 87. 19; vii.36.22; 70. 21; of medicine, ii.47.15. Elsewhere of artifice, v.8.8; 18. 16; 47. 9. The gen. depends on ta\ e)pigigno/mena. Cf. c. 52. 11; 68. 7; iii.30.4. As in the case of any technical dexterity.—ta\ e)pigigno/mena: what is new (cf. c. 70. 9), whether of inventions (as with te/xnh), or of new views and plans in politics.—kratei=n: sc. tw=n a)rxaiotro/pwn.
no/mima : like e)pithdeu/mata, principles, habits.
pro\s polla\ i)e/nai: = polloi=s e)pixeirei=n, as viii.27.18, pro\s au)qaire/tous kindu/nous i)e/nai.
e)pitexnh/sews : here only in Attic; chosen in reference to te/xnh: progressive improvement. e)pi- as in e)piskeua/zein. The emphatic repetition of pollh=s makes kai/ take the second place.
a)po/: in consequence of, through the influence of. Cf. c. 12. 5; 23. 27; 24. 10.
e)pi\ ple/on: cf. c. 9. 20.
me/xri tou=de w(ri/sqw: cf. c. 51. 9; iii.82.62.—u(mw=n: for position, see on c. 30. 14.
w(/sper u(pede/casqe: see c. 58. 8.
a)/ndras te: correlated with kai\ h(ma=s, 19.
pro\s...cummaxi/an : a similar threat made by the Corcyraeans, c. 28. § 3. If we must suppose a definite plan, the Argives are probably thought of, as enemies to the Lacedaemonians.
drw=|men a)/n: sc. ei) pro\s e(te/ran cummaxi/an trapoi/meqa.

pro\s qew=n : in the face of, and so, ‘in the judgment of.’ Cf. ii.71.22; iii.58.1, qew=n tw=n cummaxikw=n. Hom. A 339. For the position of the epithets, see on c. 1. 6.— ai)sqanome/nwn: abs., who have judgment, insight. Cf. v.26.23.
e)rhmi/an: abandonment, isolation. Cf. iii.67.10, 18.—a)/llois prosio/ntes: cf. c. 40. 23; 75. 6.

boulome/nwn...ei)=nai : this presumption, for the fulfilment of which the whole speech presses, is the condition of each of the following
clauses, “for then should we—.” For the gen. proqu/mwn, see G. 138, N. 8; H. 941; Kühn. 475.
pro\s ta/de: in view of this; therefore. Also pro\s tau=ta, at the close of longer speeches; Lat. proinde. Freq. in Soph. Cf. Aj. 971, 1313; El. 383, 820; O. R. 426; O. C. 956; Ant. 658.

e)chgei=sqai: Cl. refers to vi.85.7 for another instance of the acc. with this verb. But there he now reads, with the best Mss., toi=s cumma/xois, notwithstanding the following acc. in appos. So St. The dat. occurs also iii.55.14, along with an acc. of the inner obj. The verb must be regarded here as trans. Kühn. 420, note 6.—mh\ e)la/ssw: expresses the result of e)chgei=sqai, proleptic pred. Kühn. 405, 3.
Ambassadors of the Athenians, who were accidentally at Sparta, seek to withhold the Lacedaemonians from an over-hasty decision.

tw=n de\ *)aqhnai/wn...e)/tuxe ga/r : the inclination of the earlier usage to place causal sentences in parataxis with the principal clause (see on c. 31. 7) leads sometimes to an involved structure whereby strict grammatical sequence is interrupted. In c. 37. 7; 57. 16; iii.70.11; 107. 16; etc., the grammatical connexion is not violated; but in iv.132.7 the de/ interferes with it. In this passage and c. 115. 15; Hdt. ii.101.1; iv.200.5 the structure is impaired by the gen., which depends on the inserted clause: as by the dat. in viii.30.2; Hdt. i.24.17; ix.109.7. In all these passages there is a clear anacoluthon. kai/, 3, is bracketed by v. H. and Kr.
tw=n lo/gwn: see on c. 57. 14.
parithte/a: for the pl., see on c. 7. 2; 59. 4; for the form, Kr. Spr. 38, 3, 6; for the meaning, see on c. 67. 12, and cf. 15.
a)pologhsome/nous: following au)toi=s. See on c. 31. 10.

dhlw=sai de/: though opp. to mhde\n a)pologhsome/nous, the inf. is controlled by e)/dqce, whereby it is more energetic. So also peri\ tou= panto/s points to the importance of the question. Cf. c. 126. 26; 132. 23; v.30.6; viii.79.12.

w(s...ei)/h : bouleute/on is from either bouleu/ein or bouleu/esqai (see on c. 85. 5): that they ought to come to no over-hasty decision.—e)n plei/oni: temporal, as dia\ plei/onos, c. 124. 13; e)k plei/onos, iv.42.15; 103. 13; v.82.9;
viii.91.1.
th\n po/lin: proleptic. See on c. 23. 23; 26. 6.—ebou/lonto: needlessly rejected by Cobet, ad Hyper. p. 67, who did not see that nomi/zontes in 11 requires it.

kai\ u(po/mnhsin...h)=san : te is used with toi=s presbute/rois as if for toi=s newte/rois another noun, e)ch/ghsin, were not required. Cf. iv.52.5; Xen. An. i.2.21. But Cobet places toi=s te presbute/rois before u(po/mnhsin.
e)k tw=n lo/gwn : under the influence of their arguments: stronger than a)po\ tw=n lo/gwn, vi.19.6.
toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois: i.e. toi=s e)n te/lei tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn, i.e. the Ephors.—e)s to\ plh=qos ei)pei=n: cf. iv.58.9; v.45.3; vi.41.13; 89. 1.

ei)/ ti mh/: unusual order for ei) mh/ ti, which Cobet would read.—a)pokwlu/h|: see App. But most editors read the indic. Cf. Xen. An. iv.8.4, ei) mh/ ti kwlu/ei, e)qe/lw dialexqh=nai.— 15. e)pie/nai : (e)pe/rxesqai) here, as in c. 90. 29; 91. 16; 119. 9; iii.52.24, of appearing before an assembly or magistrate, particularly of foreigners: parie/nai, specifically of coming forward to speak.—e)/legon: on the tense, see GMT. § 11, N. 5; H. 831. But “the impf. has only to do with the vision of the narrator.” B. L. G., Am. J. of Ph. IV. 160.

div2.head: Speech of the Athenian envoys. Chaps. 73-78.
div2.p: That you may rightly judge of the complaints made against us, we must remind you of the services of Athens in the first and second Persian wars.

h( pre/sbeusis h(mw=n e)ge/neto: the pass. expression of the act. periphrasis, th\n pre/sbeusin e)poihsa/meqa. See on c. 50. 8. Cf. c. 75. 14; 87. 18; 96. 10; ii.11.18; 14. 7; iv.74.17; etc. pre/sbeusis not found elsewhere in Attic.— toi=s cumma/xois: dependent on a)ntilogi/an. See on 63. 9.

kataboh/n: cf. viii.85.10; 87. 19. Not elsewhere in Attic. But kataboa=n in c. 67. 4.— 4. tw=n pole/wn: see c. 67. § 1, 2.— 5. ou) ga\r...a)\n gi/gnointo : the stress of the thought lies mainly on para\ dikastai=s u(mi=n, “our taking part in these proceedings does not imply that we recognize you as our judges.” h(mw=n
and tou/twn depend on lo/goi.

a)ll' o(/pws...a)ci/a lo/gou e)sti/n : the positive purpose of the speech is expressed, (1) by the conj. o(/pws kte(., and (2) by the partic. boulo/menoi kte(. (going back in constr. to a)nterou=ntes); and the second of these includes two points: (a) w(s ou)/te . . . kekth/meqa, and (b) h(/ te po/lis . . . e)sti/n. But in carrying out this scheme, the order is changed chiastically, and the speaker treats (b) in c. 73 to 74. § 2; (a) in c. 75 to 77; and (1) in c. 78.

peri\ tou= panto\s...kaqestw=tos : not about the complaints just now brought forward by the Corinthians,—the partic. pf. could not mean this,—but on the whole judgment which our enemies have this long while formed about us.
ou)/te a)peiko/tws: cf. ii.8.2; vi.55.11; viii.68.25, always with neg., and by litotes = dikaio/tata.

kai\...me\n...de/ : transition to consideration of details. Cf. c. 69. 14.—ta\ pa/nu palaia/: Schol., ta\ kata\ *)amazo/nas kai\ *qra=|kas kai\ *(hraklei/das; favourite themes among the panegyrists of Athens at all times. These are put aside with an ironical oxymoron, w(=n . . . a)kousome/nwn, for a)koai\ lo/gwn are in no proper sense ma/rtures. a)koai/, pl. on account of the pl. object, as in c. 20. 3; while o)/yis with the pl. subjective gen. is to be preferred to o)/yeis of the inferior Mss. which Kr., St., and v. H. adopt (in c. 10. 17, ta\s o)/yeis is connected with the objective tw=n po/lewn).
w(=n depends on ma/rtures. With ma=llon . . . h)/, as with ou)x h(=sson . . . h)/, c. 70. 31, the second member is practically denied.

cu/niste: i.e. of your own knowledge. Cf. ii.35.10; iii.56.2.—di) o)/xlou e)/stai: = e)noxlh/sei. See on c. 40. 16.—ma=llon...a)ei/ : express reciprocal proportion; “the more annoying, the more often they are brought forward.” Herbst, Philol. 16, p. 351.—proballo/mena: see App.
o(/te e)drw=men: when we were engaged in the war. Cf. c. 69. 11.—e)p' w)feli/a|: to gain a common good, a modestly vague expression for e)pi\ swthri/a| th=s *(ella/dos.

e)kinduneu/eto : impers. pass.; see on c. 46. 1.—h(=s: see on c. 10. 20; 35. 15. The gen. depends both on e)/rgou and on lo/gou, the former of the practical gains, the latter of the result in fame. me/ros, which is usually not expressed with mete/xein, is here necessary as opp. to tou= lo/gou panto/s, where panto/s is made more forcible by its pred.
position.

ei)/ ti w)felei=: “if you have received your share in the practical results, we should not miss all our share of the credit, if there is any advantage in that,” as there would be if it led now to a just appreciation of the present case.
r(hqh/setai: this form of the fut. also viii.66.5. ei)rh/setai, vi.34.18; the latter is the only form in Tragedy and in Hom.
ou) ma=llon - h)/: not so much—as, the former member being completely excluded. Cf. c. 70. 31.—paraith/sews: here only in Thuc. = tou= ai)tei=n cuggnw/mhn, “not to excuse ourselves.”

pro\s oi(/an: see on c. 70. 4.—o( a)gw\n katasth/setai: a significant and solemn expression for o( po/lemos e)/stai, in reference to the momentous character of the war, if it should actually break out.
*maraqw=ni: on this as a locative form, without e)n, see Kühn. 426, 1; and App. on c. 18. 13. In ii.34.14 the Mss. have e)n.

mo/noi : no doubt the Plataeans were counted as Athenians. See Hdt. vi. 108; 111.—prokinduneu=sai: from the frequent use of ki/ndunos for ma/xh, the verb here has the sense and even the const. of ma/xesqai. pro-, before all others, i.e. before they appeared on the ground. Cf. vii.56.21.
cunnaumaxh=sai: i.e. koinh=| meq' u(mw=n, opp. to the former mo/noi.

e)/sxe : prevented; with mh/ and inf. also in Hdt. *)aristo/dikos o( *(hrakleidew . . . e)/sxe mh\ poih=sai tau=ta *kumai/ous, i.158.8; ix.12.5; with to\ mh/, Hdt. v.101.1; with acc., vii.62.13; Hdt. vii.171.12; viii.110.15; Soph. El. 375. GMT. 95, 2 c; H. 1029.— 24. a)duna/twn a)\n o)/ntwn: i.e. e)n w(=|(ei) kata\ po/leis e)pe/plei)a)du/natoi a)\n h)=san. Cf. iii.82.6. GMT. 41, 1; H. 987. The gen. tw=n *peloponnhsi/wn must be supplied. See on c. 2. 9; 3. 9.
tekmh/rion e)poi/hse: cf. iii.67.28, para/deigma.
o(moi/as : paris, i.e. a)ntipa/lou, a)cioma/xou: in this sense in ii.89.4; ou) ga\r w)=n e)do/keon o(/moioi ei)=nai, Hdt. ix.96.9; very seldom elsewhere. In c. 80. 8 paro/moios in same sense.
tw=| ple/oni: i.e. except what was left with Mardonius, Hdt. viii. 113.
We supplied the largest number of ships, the ablest commander, and the most disinterested zeal.

toiou/tou: pred. to tou/tou cumba/ntos. Different from c. 71. 1.—dhlwqe/ntos: one of the rare instances where an abs. impers. partic. is in the gen., not the acc.; like the Lat. comperto, nuntiato, etc. So a)ei\ kaqestw=tos, c. 76. 11; a)ggelqe/ntos, vi.58.1. So the neut. pl. e)saggelqe/ntwn, c. 116. 15; ploi+mwte/rwn o)/ntwn, c. 7. 2; o)/ntwn a)kri/twn, iv.20.5. GMT. 110, 1. N. 3; H. 973 a; Kühn. 486, note 2.
e)n: dependent on.—ta\ pra/gmata: the political existence, salus, summa rerum. Cf. c. 110. 1; ii.65.43; iii.93.13; vii.27.14; 49. 4.

e)ge/neto: aor. of ei)=nai: “that the salvation of the Greeks depended on their ships.”—e)s au)to/: refers to what precedes. Cf. c. 68. 3, 9.—paresxo/meqa: “the mid. is used regularly in reference to the supply of good, not evil; exceptions chiefly in Plat.” B. L. G.
a)/ndra strathgo/n: the generic and the specific term united, as often.
a)oknota/thn: see on c. 70. 14.— me/n ge: me/n begins the enumeration, ge emphasizes nau=s, though always placed after the other particle. See on c. 40. 15. Cf. 70. 6.

tetrakosi/as: probably a round number instead of 378 as given by Hdt. viii. 48. But Aesch. Pers. 339 gives 310, and Dem. XVIII. 238 gives 300 (in XIV. 29, 200 acc. to Ms. *s) as the whole number. Of this total the Athenian 200 (180 + 20 lent to Chalcidians, Hdt. viii. 1; 44) could be spoken of as plei/ous tw=n h(mi/sewn, or with slight exaggeration as o)li/gw| e)la/ssous tw=n du/o moirw=n. The art. is wanting in the best Mss. but seems indispensable to the fraction 2/3. Cf. c. 10. 9; 104. 9; ii.10.6. See App.
naumaxh=sai: inf. without art. after ai)/tios here only in Thuc. Cf. Soph. Ant. 1173. GMT. 92, 1, N. 2; H. 952; Kühn. 473, 3. For the fact, see Hdt. viii. 60.

kai\ au)to\n dia\ tou=to kte(.: the importance of Themistocles is enforced by the position of au)to/n, in which the relative sentence is continued as usual (see on c. 42. 2); and a)/ndra ce/non, = kai/per a)/ndra ce/non o)/nta, has its full force as pred.— 9. e)timh/sate: see Hdt. viii. 124; Plut. Them. 17. 3.

kai\ polu/: emphasizes the sup. strongly. Cf. c. 25. 20; vi.22.6; 24.
7; vii.34.35; 41. 14. Cf. also viii.68.21; 89. 25.
oi(/ ge: forcibly taking up the subj. of e)dei/camen. See on c. 68. 15.
me/xri h(mw=n: properly of place, ‘up to our borders’; then numerically, except ourselves.— h)ciw/samen: see on c. 42. 2.
diafqei/rantes: = proe/menoi. Schol., diafqarh=nai e)a/santes.
prolipei=n : an emphatic deserere, as ii.87.31.
mh\ o)rgisqh=nai: as c. 32. 7, not to take offence. For mh/, see on c. 43. 4.
au)toi/: we on our side. The other side of the case is expressed by h)\ tuxei=n tou/tou, to avoid the ambiguity of h)\ u(ma=s w)felh=sai h(ma=s.
tou/tou : i.e. th=s a)f) u(mw=n w)feli/as.
oi)koume/nwn : impf. partic. emphasized by its pred. position, while they were still undisturbed. a)po/ kte(., of the starting-point; e)pi\ kte(., of the purpose.
ne/mesqai: to possess, to occupy. See on c. 2. 6.
kai\ ou)x h(mw=n to\ ple/on: ironical, for u(pe\r u(mw=n to\ ple/on (=ma=llon)h)\ u(pe\r h(mw=n. The proof is given in o(/te gou=n . . . parege/nesqe.

th=s ou)k ou)/shs...e)lpi/di ou)/shs : cf. Hdt. viii.57.7, peri\ ou)demih=s e)/ti patri/dos naumaxh/seis; the same thought in the famous answer of Themistocles, Hdt. viii.61.8, w(s ei)/h kai\ po/lis kai\ gh= me/zwn h)/per kei/noisi, e)/st' a)\n dihko/siai ne/es sfi e)/wsi peplhrwme/nai. The state had then only an ideal existence, in the ships and their crews; and so ou)k ou)/shs opp. to oi)koume/nwn, as th=s e)n braxei/a| e)lpi/di ou)/shs, “whose continuance rests only on a feeble hope,” is to to\ loipo\n ne/mesqai.

o(rmw/menoi : cf. c. 144. 22; ii.65.5; iv.8.36; vii.49.17.— 23. to\ me/ros: referring to h(mei=s in cunesw/samen, pro virili parte, as far as we could. Cf. c. 127. 7; ii.67.17. G. 160, 2; H. 719. Kühn. 410, note 15.

w(/sper kai\ a)/lloi: just as others did: contemptuous omission of the names, e.g. of the Thebans. kai/, though as usual inserted in the rel. clause,
really emphasizes h(mei=s.
w(s diefqarme/noi : because we looked upon ourselves as already ruined.

ou)de
 a)
 e)/dei: “e)xrh=n ei)=nai, oportebat esse, at non sunt; e)xrh=n a)
 ei)=nai, oporteret esse, at non oportet.” Franke. GMT. 49, 2, Rem. 1; H. 897; Kühn. 392 b, note 2. Ironical: you would have had no more need to fight, because you could not.
proexw/rhse: cf. c. 111. 7; 127. 4; ii.5.2; etc.
h(=| e)bou/leto: assimilated to the mood of the unreal apodosis. G. 235, 2; H. 919; Kühn. 399, 6 a.
No one should regard us with disfarour on account of our hegemony. Circumstances compelled us to assume it, and strong measures are necessary to maintain it.

th=s to/te: belongs also to cune/sews, on which gnw/mhs depends, in reference to the battle of Salamis, gnw/mh being here decision (cf. c. 32. 17; 77. 9; 122. 12), not ‘intelligence.’—a)rxh=s: depends upon e)pifqo/nws diakei=sqai = fqonei=sqai. Kühn. 419, 1 e. This periphrasis means “to be in a position exposed to envy,” like u(po/ptws diakei=sqai, viii.68.8.
mh\ ou(/tws a)/gan: = h(=sson. The question, as with ou)k ou)=n, implies a forcible assertion: “verily, we do not deserve to be regarded with so much jealousy.”
e)la/bomen: not e)kthsa/meqa. We took it, when you gave it up, tanquam in medio positam.

paramei=nai: to continue on the spot. Cf. iii.10.9; vi.61.26; vii.15.9; Xen. An. ii.6.2.—ta\ u(po/loipa: what yet remained, with the implication that it was not much. The reference is to the garrisons still maintained by the Persians on the Hellespont, etc.—tou= barba/rou: collective, = tw=n barba/rwn or th=s duna/mews tw=n barba/rwn. Cf. iii.10.9, pro\s ta\ u(po/loipa tw=n e)/rgwn.
proselqo/ntwn : see on c. 39. 11; 40. 23. For the fact, see c. 95.

proagagei=n kte(.: to raise it to its present height. Cf. c. 144. 25; vi.18.32. This growing advance of the Athenian hegemony is sharply op
posed to its beginning, as a consequence of the free offer of the allies; and therefore there should be a full stop after katasth=nai. This progress has its two stages marked by to\ prw=ton and kai\ ou)k a)sfale/s in 10. The position of things itself (e)c au)tou= tou= e)/rgou) forced them to advance (e)c causal as in c. 2. 17; 72. 11). Three motives are indicated: (1) fear, of untrustworthy allies as well as of rivals; (2) honour, when the offer of the hegemony had once been accepted; (3) selfinterest, since the hegemony furnished the means of aggrandizement. The three gens. are governed by u(po/. See on c. 6. 20.
kai\ ou)k a)sfale\s kte(.: this is the second point; after the first step had been taken, our own security forbade us to go back.

a)phxqhme/nous...katestramme/nwn : pf. partics., with the full meaning of “when it had once come to this, that etc.”; whereas the aor. a)posta/ntwn, as giving the occasion, is subord. to katestramme/nwn, to which also kai\ h)/dh belongs: after we had once incurred the hatred of most, and several of our allies who had revolted had been by that time (h)/dh) forcibly reduced.
u(mw=n te: see on c. 2. 6.

u(po/ptwn: suspicious, as in iv.103.11; v.25.9. But in c. 131. 12; viii.45.4, ‘suspected.’ —a)ne/ntas: here abs., remiss, relaxing our hold. Cf. vi.18.16; 86. 14; and the free use of a)neime/nos, c. 6. 7; ii.39.8; v.9.19.
kai\ ga\r a)\n: sc. ei) a)nei=men, indic. aor. See on c. 11. 5.
e)gi/gnonto: see on c. 73. 1.

ta\ cumfe/ronta : what is for their interest, here, for guarding against these dangers. With this eu)= ti/qesqai, to make a good disposition of, is quite proper. See on c. 25. 2. Cf. Hdt. vii.236.17.—tw=n megi/stwn pe/ri kindu/nwn: when it is a question of the greatest dangers. Thuc. uses pe/ri, not peri/, (1) with the rel. pron., as c. 95. 10; (2) to emphasize the preceding word, as c. 72. 5; (3) when the clause is abs. or has only a loose connexion with its sentence, as here and c. 10. 25; 23. 12. Herbst, Philol. 16, p. 278. These dangers are sufficiently indicated by kinduneu/ein, 13, with its parenthetical exposition kai\ ga\r a)\n kte(.
You would find yourselves as unpopular as we are if you were in our position.

gou=n: adduces a proof for a particular case;
            see on c. 2. 18. “You Lacedaemonians, for example, act in 
 the
            same way, look after your own interest just as much.”
e)pi\ to\...katasthsa/menoi : cf. c. 19. 3, sfi/sin au)toi=s mo/non e)pithdei/ws o(/pws politeu/sousi qerapeu/ontes.
e)chgei=sqe : exercise your supremacy, here abs., as in c. 95. 26; ii.65.17; and h(gei=sqai c. 19. 3.—to/te: e)n toi=s *mhdikoi=s.

dia\ panto/s : temporal, to the end. See on c. 38. 2.—ei) to/te...toi=s cumma/xois : the protasis and apodosis are not tautological. “If you had by the continuance of your rule come to be detested, you would have found yourselves obliged to resort to as stringent measures of repression as we.”

mh\ a)\n...genome/nous : partic. in indir. disc. after i)/smen. GMT. 113; H. 982. If the image of the dir. disc. is vividly present, its ou) is usually retained. GMT. 69, 5. But verbs of will, including the notions of making, promising, hoping, believing, have a strong preference for mh/. Cf. c. 139. 6; ii.17.15; vi.102.19; vii.29.14; Soph. El. 908; Xen. Mem. i.2.41. Cases where ou) is used are: c. 25. 1; 140. 2; ii.36.18; v.4.24; vi.64.5. See Am. J. of Ph. 1, 48.
a)po/: see on c. 7. 6.

a)rxh/n ge: Cl. reads ge here, for te of the Mss. (which all the recent editors have retained), on the ground that no opposition exists between a)rxh/n and tau/thn. But te kai/ would here unite as a whole the two sentences, which are properly complements of each other: “we acted only like men, both in accepting the command when it was offered to us, and in not giving it up afterwards.”—ei)...e)deca/meqa : the influence of qaumasto/n causes the fact to be expressed in hypothetical form. Cf. c. 33. 8.—didome/nhn: cf. c. 33. 25; iv.21.3.

anei=men: aor. indic.; here with definite obj., different from c. 75. 13.—u(po\ tw=n megi/stwn: H. Weil (Rev. de Philol., 1878, p. 92) conjectures u(po\ triw=n tw=n megi/stwn, referring to c. 74. 3 and iii.40.6. But since only the same three motives are meant as were specified in c. 75. 9, there is no need of emphasis on the number here.—nikhqe/ntes: metaphorical, as in ii.47.17; 51. 23; 60. 22; 87. 9.

u(pa/rcantes: having been the originators; with and without a gen. Cf. ii.67.29; 74. 17.—kaqestw=tos: the subj. is in the following inf. (see on c. 74. 1), it being an estab-
lished rule. Cf. iii.43.5.
a)/cioi/ te: te introduces the third reason, as c. 67. 6; 69. 3.

u(mi=n dokou=ntes: sc. a)/cioi ei)=nai.
