See c. 95. 25.—me/xri ou(=...nu=n xrh=sqe : “till it suits you to talk about justice, while your real calculations are those of expediency.” Since dokou=ntes is a partic. impf. = e)dokou=men, me/xri ou(= (H. 999) should be followed by a past indic. (GMT. 66; H. 922); and so for xrh=sqe we should expect the aor.; but the pres. is suggested by nu=n.

o(/n : introduces the real state of the case (cf. c. 10. 20; 33. 13); “whereas no one, when he had the opportunity of gaining something by force, ever gave justice the preference (Schol., prokri/nas) and turned aside from his advantage.” Cf. iii.39.20, i)sxu\n tou= dikai/ou proqei=nai; iii.84.14; Hdt. iii.53.16.—paratuxo/n: see on c. 2. 8; 22. 9.—mh/: pleonastic after a verb of negative meaning. GMT. 95, 2 d; H. 1029.

e)painei=sqai/ te: te inferential, and so. Cf. c. 4. 5; 67. 3.—oi(/tines...gege/nhntai : the speaker leaves it to the hearers to apply this general statement to the case of the Athenians.— 17. dikaio/teroi...gege/nhntai : have allowed more weight to considerations of right than they might have done, considering their power. Kühn. 543, 8; Kr. Spr. 49, 4.
a)\n - a)\n : see on c. 36. 14. The former of the two separates gou=n, at any rate, into its component parts.
tou= e)pieikou=s: fairness, equity, the temper which results in metria/zein.
The forbearance we have shown in our dealings with our allies has so spoiled them, that they break out into complaints if they are thwarted in any way.

kai\ e)lassou/menoi kte(.: we have here the proof of the concluding words of c. 76. St.'s is probably the correct interpretation of this passage, adopted in the main by Cl. It depends on these particulars: (1) The former kai/ = kai/per and brings out the concessive force of the two partics. (2) tai=s . . . di/kais refers to what are commonly called di/kai a)po\ cumbo/lwn, i.e. commercial treaties originally made between independent states, in accordance with which disputes in matters of trade
(ex contractu) were decided upon certain fixed rules in the courts of the defendant's city. As Athens had no doubt such treaties with many of her allies before their subjection to tribute, there is no reason to suppose they were abrogated after that change in their political status. (3) ta\s kri/seis refers to the compulsory jurisdiction which Athens enforced upon her allies in her own courts in suits arising ex delicto between Athenians and citizens of subject states, and also between citizens of subject states by way of appeal, when the sentence in the local court was either death, exile, or disfranchisement. Probably it soon came to pass that the more important of such cases were brought to Athenian courts in the first instance. (4) au)toi=s does not agree with h(mi=n but means for them, i.e. for the allies. The passage may be thus paraphrased: “For even though we exact less than our power would justify in cases decided under commercial treaties made with our allies, and though we have established for them trials in our own courts on the basis of impartial laws for us and them, we are thought to be litigious.” Cf. Dem. LVI. 14, h(gou/menoi dei=n e)lattou=sqai ti kai\ sugxwrei=n w(/ste mh\ dokei=n filo/dikoi ei)=nai. See Am. J. of Ph. V. p. 298 ff., and I. p. 4 ff.
au)tw=n: i.e. tw=n cumma/xwn.
toi=s kai\...metri/ois ou)=si : placed for emphasis before the interr. dio/ti, why. Cf. c. 19. 3 (o(/pws); 120. 9 (h)/n); 10. 5 (ei)). Kühn. 606, 6; Kr. Spr. 54, 17, 7.

bia/zesqai ga/r: this gives the reason of some suppressed thought, like ei)ko/tws. See Ullrich, Beitr. z. Erkl. note 119. The assonance of bia/zsqai, dika/zesqai gives a kind of proverbial character to the sentence.
a)po\ tou= i)/sou: on a basis of equality; with o(milei=n again, iii.11.3. Cf. c. 99.. 7; 136. 15; 140. 31; 143. 14; ii.89.5; iii.84.7; iv.19.11; v.101.2. Also a)po\ th=s i)/shs.

para\ to\ mh\ oi)/esqai xrh=nai : the neg. which properly belongs to xrh=nai is attracted to oi)/esqai, after the analogy of ou)/ fhmi, ou) nomi/zw, ou)k e)w=, against their conviction that it ought not so to be. Since with xrh=nai is to be supplied from what follows, e)lasswqh=nai au)tou/s, the neg. mh/ is not pleonastic (Bonitz) nor to be bracketed (Kr.).

h)\ gnw/mh|...th\n a)rxh/n : whether by a decree or by some exercise of power required by the interests of our empire.—kai\ o(pwsou=n: even in any degree whatever, ever so little. Cf. vii.60.20; viii.90.16; 91. 21; with ou)de/, vii.49.7.— 10. ou) tou= ple/onos kte(.: to\ ple/on is the advantage of an equal standing in the courts of law, which is of far greater moment, on the whole, than
the occasional acts of interference rendered necessary by the interests of the leading state. This indispensable subordination is called here to\ e)ndee/s, what is lacking, “the trifling restrictions they have to submit to.” It is better to govern tou= e)ndeou=s by sterisko/menoi repeated, than with Cl., B., Kr. to make it depend on xalepw/teron fe/rontes. They refer to ii.62.18. But there au)tw=n is bracketed by Dobree and changed to au)tw=| by Madvig. The const. here preferred is adopted by Sh., St., and Madvig, Adv. I. 311, who says, to\ e)ndee/s est quod deest ad spem explendam; hoc qui non accipit, eo privari videtur.

a)po\ prw/ths: from the first, with no definite ellipsis. See on c. 14. 15. With art., vii.43.35.—to\n no/mon: legality, pretence of law: a rare use, yet similar to that in ii.53.13; iii.45.8; 56. 5.— 13. e)kei/nws de/: i.e. ei) fanerw=s e)pleonektou=men: the thought, not the statement, being regarded as remote. Cf. iii.46.8; vi.11.10. de/ is epexegetic, not adversative.—w(s ou): after verbs of neg. meaning, ‘doubt,’ ‘deny,’ etc., ou) sometimes follows w(s(o(/ti) introducing a finite verb, thus continuing the neg. idea of the governing verb. Cf. mh/ with inf., c. 76. 15. H. 1029 a; Kühn. 516, 3 b. a)nte/legon here = contest, deny (not ‘rejoin,’ as in c. 28. 16). Cf. c. 86. 3; viii.24.27.
te: inferential, as c. 67. 3; 76. 16. a)dikou/menoi as opposed to biazo/menoi implies stealth or overreaching.

a)po\ tou= i)/sou: Cl. regards this and tou= ktei/ssonos, with Herbst, as masc. But they are probably neut. Sh. explains: “for the one (a)di/khma) is thought to be, when the start is made from a position of equality, an act of overreaching; the other, when it is made from one of superiority, an act of compulsion.”— 18. pa/sxontes h)nei/xonto: cf. ii.74.3; v.69.8; vi.16.20. G. 279; H. 983.

ei)ko/tws: advs. are often thus placed with emphasis at the end of sentences, but should not be separated by punctuation from what precedes.—to\ paro\n ga\r kte(.: here the argument passes to the general consideration that superior power is always felt as a grievance by those who have to submit to it.

u(mei=s g' a)\n ou)=n: cf. c. 76. 18. Kühn. 508, 2 a.—kaqelo/ntes: having overthrown; with acc. of person, iii.
13. 33; iv.85.7; of thing (du/namin, a)rxh/n), v.14.14; vi.11.13; of both, c. 16. 4; Hdt. i.71.3.—a)/rcaite: you should attain power. See on c. 3. 8.— 21. ta/xa: generally in Attic expresses probability, and except viii.94.8 constantly in Thuc. with a)/n; but here it includes also its primary temporal meaning. So also when it is combined with i)/sws: vi.10.14; 34. 9; 78. 16.—to\ h(me/teron de/os: see on c. 33. 19; 69. 30.
metaba/loite: short for th=| tw=n pragma/twn metabolh=| a)poba/loite.
di) o)li/gou h(ghsa/menoi : after you had only for a short time held the hegemony. di) o)li/gou, of time. Cf. ii.85.9; iii.43.14.
u(pedei/cate: showed a glimpse of. Cf. iv.86.19.— o(moi=a gnw/sesqe: you shall adopt such principles: so often with neut. pl., iii.57.3; v.36.10.

a)/mikta toi=s a)/llois: i.e. toi=s tw=n a)/llwn (c. 71. 9), incompatible with (not corresponding to) the habits of others, and therefore not conducive to frank intercourse.—ta/ te kaq' u(ma=s: te belongs by hyperbaton not to the noun but to the whole sentence; e)/xete and xrh=tai are opposed.

ei(=s e(/kastos: the reference is mainly to Pausanias.—e)ciw/n: when he goes abroad in command. Cf. c. 95. 23; iv.5.3; v.34.2; vi.37.18.— 26. oi(=s...nomi/zei : dat. as with xrh=sqai. Cf. ii.38.3; iii.82.65; Hdt. ii.50.14. Kühn. 425, 5.
Deliberate well, therefore, before you engage in war at the instigation of others. We are still ready for a friendly arrangement, but shall know how to repel any attack.

w(s ou) peri\ braxe/wn: for w(s peri\ ou) braxe/wn, from the reluctance to separate the prep. from its case. So w(s e)s e)la/xiston, in c. 63. 5; w(s e)pi\ plei=ston, c. 82. 20. See on c. 35. 10. The litotes also is thus enhanced. See on c. 5. 5. ou) here, as applying to a single word, even after the imv. Cf. c. 82. 18; 140. 9; 141. 27. Kr. Spr. 67, 9, 2; Kühn. 513, 4.
prosqh=sqe: burden yourselves with. Cf. c. 144. 3; ii.37.13; iv.98.16.

to\n para/logon kte(.: see on c. 72. 8. On the subst., miscalculation, mistake in judgment, see on c. 65. 3; “how greatly one can deceive one's self.”— 4. prodia/gnwte: occurs again in v.38.19; probably also c. 91. 20; elsewhere only in later writers.

filei=: is wont; in Thuc. in this sense
only. Cf. c. 141. 28; ii.62.22; iii.42.5; 81. 23; iv.28.12; 125. 7; v.70.6; vi.63.10; vii.79.10; 80. 12; viii.1.30. So also Hdt. exceptin v.5.5. Cf. Lat. amare, Hor. Car. iii.16.10, etc.—tu/xas: chances, which do not depend on human operation.—ta\ polla/: adv. See on c. 13. 3.—perii/stasqai: see on c. 76. 21.—w(=n...kinduneu/etai : w(=n rel. to tu/xas. Though only the first clause depends grammatically on w(=n, the second also stands in a like relation to the antecedent sentence. See on c. 68. 15. a)pe/xomen, sc. e(ka/teroi. e)/stai = genh/setai, without definite subj., “how things will turn out, whether well or ill”; and this clause is subj. of e)n a)dh/lw| kinduneu/etai, which phrase is itself a combination of e)n a)dh/lw| e)sti/ and kinduneu/etai (see on c. 46. 1). Cf. ii.35.7.
i)o/ntes te kte(.: “so it comes to pass that if men embark in war.” i)e/nai is freq. in this connexion: c. 40. 6; 41. 12; 58. 9; 71. 12; 82. 14; 143. 15; v.65.30; vi.63.3.

e)/xontai: cf. c. 49. 30; Hdt. iii.72.28.—o(/: appears necessary in place of a(/ of the Mss., since a(/ would suggest a false reference to e)/rgwn, and dra=n would lose its characteristic meaning (see on c. 5. 12). The sing. is required by the manifest reference to the whole tw=n e)/rgwn e)/xesqai (c. 49. 30). Stahl, Jahrb. 1863, p. 411, thinks differently, but Cobet reads o(/. See App. on c. 70. 7.
h)/dh: belongs to kakopaqou=ntes.

ou)/t' au)toi/: the marked opposition requires the combination ou)/te— ou)/te; otherwise ou)/q' u(ma=s o(rw=ntes would have been joined directly to o)/ntes. After o(rw=ntes supply e)n a(marti/a| o)/ntas. Cf. c. 80. 2; v.80.11.—le/gomen: = keleu/omen. Cf. c. 131. 10; ii.5.21; 6. 7; 71. 23; iii.3.16.

sponda/s: without art. Cf. c. 53. 4; 67. 5; 71. 22. Sh. renders “not to be covenantbreakers.” So the art. is omitted with other nouns which with verbs make established formulae; e.g. gnw/mhn poiei=sqai, ‘propose,’ c. 128, 27; gnw/mhn e)/xein, ‘intend,’ ii.86.17; di/aitan e)/xein, ‘live,’ c. 135. 8; tafa\s poiei=sqai, ‘bury,’ ii.34.2.—ta\ dia/fora: cf. c. 56. 2; 67. 14.

lu/esqai: = dialu/esqai, the mid. of reciprocal action. Cf. c. 140. 17; 145. 6; v.80.2.—kata\ th\n cunqh/khn: see c. 140. 14; vii.18.14. —ei) de\ mh/: so the best Mss. for h)/ of the others. Both expressions are nearly alike in meaning and use (cf. Soph. Phil. 1341; Lys. XXV 14; Dem. 11. 8), but the fuller form seems better suited to the close of the speech. —qeou\s tou\s o(rki/ous: see on c. 1. 6.
a)/rxontas: u(ma=s seems here purposely avoided, to maintain as long as possible the attitude of generality. Only in u(fhgh=sqe the present case is referred to.
In the Lacedaemonian assembly the majority is inclined to war. Archidamus comes forward in opposition.
ta\ e)s tou\s *)aqhnai/ous: cf. c. 38. 1; 66. 2; vi.105.15.

kai\ tw=n *)aqhnai/wn a(\ e)/lecan: the same order as in the former clause. For gen., see G. 171, 2; H. 742.—metasthsa/menoi: causing to withdraw. Cf. v.111.9; Hdt. i.89.1; viii.101.7. Aeschin. 111. 125, metasthsa/menos tou\s i)diw/tas. The corresponding intr. metasth=nai, in v.111.25; Soph. Aj. 750.
pa/ntas: i.e. all the envoys of the allies and the Athenians.—kata\ sfa=s au)tou/s: so iv.65.2. kaq' e(autou/s, iv.38.18; vi.13.12.
e)pi\ to\ au)to\ e)/feron: a metaphor from a road (iii.24.2). Cf. Hdt. i.120.12; vii.6.22; Soph. O. C. 1424.
a)dikei=n...h)/dh : that they were already in the wrong. Cf. v.30.8. See on c. 67. 5.—polemhte/a: see on c. 72. 4.

e)n ta/xei: with all possible speed. Cf. c. 86. 13; 90. 31; ii.86.22, etc.—*)arxi/damos; son of Zeuxidamus, succeeded his grandfather Leotychides in Ol. 77. 4 (B.C. 469); led the early invasions into Attica; and died Ol. 88. 2 (B.C. 427).

div2.head: Speech of King Archidamus. Chaps. 80-85.
div2.p: Do not fancy that a war with the Athenians will be without danger; for in ships and money they are superior to you.
o(rw=: sc. o(moi/ws e)mpei/rous o)/ntas. See on c. 78. 10.

a)peiri/a|...nomi/santa : for the change, see on c. 39. 2; 63. 7; 107. 26; iv.69.16.—e)piqumh=sai: the aor. with the neg. and in reference to the immediate case, “so that no one of you from inexperience covets the war.” Still mh/t' a)\n kte(. would have been more natural, ‘will be likely to covet.’—e)/rgou: often of war and battle, as in c. 105. 24; ii.89.42; iv.14.15. a)gaqo\n kai\
a)sfale/s neut. after e)/rgou, though to/nde in 5 goes back to po/lemon.
polloi/ : to desire war from inexperience belongs not so much to the mass of men as to the young. Therefore polloi/ with the Vat. Ms. rather than oi( polloi/.
ou)k a)\n...geno/menon : i.e. o(/ti ou)k a)\n . . . ge/noito. For partic., cf. ii.6.14.
swfro/nws: without passion, impartially.

pro\s...a)stugei/tonas : these two nouns do not stand in the relation of whole to part, nor are they both parts of a whole; but they describe the characteristics of the enemies with whom the Lacedaemonians have had hitherto to contend; of course, however, in contrast to the Athenians; “against Peloponnesians and against near neighbours, i.e. against states without naval power, and against whom distant expeditions were not needed.” The repeated art., therefore, which all good Mss. have, needs no defence. Sh. renders: “for though against the Peloponnesians, in other words, our borderers.” He regards kai/ as epexegetic, and compares Dem. XXI. 196, tou= dh/mou kathgorh/sei kai\ th=s e)kklhsi/as. So Plat. Gorg. 472 b, e)k th=s ou)si/as kai\ tou=a)lhqou=s. Dem. XVIII. 156. See Munro on Lucr. iii. 993.

paro/moios: not ‘nearly like,’ but ‘like when placed side by side and compared.’ Bonitz, ibid. p. 28. So c. 132. 20. See on c. 73. 26.—a)lkh/: in a material sense, as in iii.30.7; not, as in ii.87.21, in a moral sense.—dia\ taxe/wn: cf. iii.13.14; iv.8.18; 96. 4; vi.66.10; viii.101.4.—e)f' e(/kasta e)lqei=n: since the enemy is not at a distance, and can be reached by land.

pro\s a)/ndras oi(\ kte(.: the antecedent is repeated in tou/tous, 14, the attributes being accumulated before it. The same rhetorical turn in iii. 39. § 2. —e(ka\s e)/xousi: probably refers to the taunt of the Corinthians, c. 69. 23, but also to indicate the narrow range of the Lacedaemonian policy.
qala/sshs: often without art. unless a special sea is meant. Kr. Spr. 50, 2, 15.

o)/xlw|: a population (cf. vi.17.8), the complement of the three preceding nouns, which only by help of this can be employed in war. o(/pla includes the equipment of forces of all kinds as well as of ships.
e(ni/ ge xwri/w|; so viii.40.8, mia=| ge po/lei. Cf. vi.20.8, w(s e)n mia=| nh/sw|.

pw=s xrh\
. . . e)peixqh=nai: this form of rhetorical question occurs again in Thuc. only in vi.38.27. See Blass, Att. Bered. I. 215.—r(a|di/ws: lightly, without serious consideration, temere. Cf. c. 73. 6.

e)peixqh=nai: intr., as in c. 85. 3; iii.3.14. In c. 82. 22 it is a true pass. of e)pei/gein. The impf. mid. tenses are trans. in iii.2.14; iv.5.9; vi.100.5; viii.9.2; intr. in c. 93. 8; iv.3.4; vi.32.14.

a)lla\ toi=s xrh/masin kte(.: notice a)lla/ introducing both question and answer. Cf. vi. 38. § 5; Lys. XXIV 24.—tou/tou e)llei/pomen: tou/tou is collective for tw=n xrhma/twn, which must be understood also in acc. with e)/xomen and fe/romen. For e)llei/pein, cf. ii.61.20; Plat. Phaedr. 269 d. See App.

e)n koinw=|: in aerario. Cf. c. 141. 11; with art., vi.6.29.—e(toi/mws: easily, not ‘willingly.’ Pericles in c. 141. § 3 repeats this statement about the Peloponnesians. See Stahl, Jahrb. 1863, p. 459.
fe/romen: regularly used of taxes. Cf. c. 19. 6; 83. 3.
And the means we have are not adapted for successful operations against them.

ta/x) a)/n tis kte(.: this objection is merely a new turn in the supposed dialogue, and therefore without conj. —toi=s o(/plois...plh/qei : these words together denote a well-appointed military force. There is no special reference to the superiority of Spartan warfare. plh=qos refers to the number of the Spartan allies, and does not, therefore, contradict c. 80. 12.— 2. u(perfe/romen: with gen. = diafe/romen, in Thuc. only here. Cf. Hdt. ix.96.14; Soph. O. T. 381; Ar. Eq. 584.—e)pifoitw=ntes: by repeated invasions.
e)pa/contai: of ordinary importation e)sa/gesqai is used; but this verb denotes also the supply of need. Cf. vi.99.21; and si=tos e)pakto/s, vi.20.20.
kai\ tou/tois: as the Athenians themselves could be effectually harmed only by sea.

to\ ple/on: 
 cf. c. 49. 6,
              12.—ti/s: = poi=os. Cf. Soph. Tr. 307;
            Dem. XXXVII. 54.
a)fairh/somen: cf. c. 134. 11; iii.31.8; v.23.25; 29. 15; vii.13.3. Cobet prefers u(fairei=n, per occasionem socios ad defectionem impellere. Cf. iii.13.33; 82. 17.

ka)n tou/tw|: and if things have turned out so. The phrase (cf. c. 37. 15) is not temporal, but designates the position of things, corresponding to e)n w(=|. See on c. 39. 11; 42. 5; ii.35.9; vi.55.18.—katalu/esqai: to settle differences. See on c. 78. 13: more rarely katalu/ein (v.23.8; viii.58.28). Cf. iv.18.17; v.15.8; 17. 20; vi.13.15. So katalu/ein to\n po/lemon, c. 24. 19; ii.29.25; 95. 12; iv.108.39; v.47.18.—kalo/n: consistent with honour.
a)/rcai ma=llon: sc. h)\ a)mu/nasqai. But Kr. understands ‘rather than the Athenians.’
e)kei/nh| th=| e)lpi/di: this was, however, the prevailing impression at Sparta. See v. 14. § 3.

te/mwmen: St. has rightly restored this for ta/mwmen of the Mss., as the only Attic prose form. See Cobet, Mnem. 11, 376; Kr. Spr. 31, 13, 3.—de/doika de\ kte(.: Herbst thinks that this could have been regarded as one of ta\ de/onta (c. 22. 5) only if it was written after the close of the whole war. See Philol. 38, 583.

ei)ko/s: takes regularly the inf. aor. (never the fut.) where the probability of the occurrence of a fut. action is to be expressed. Cf. c. 121. 4; ii.11.33; 73. 6; iii.10.22; 40. 26; iv.60.15; 85. 28; v.109.7; vi.11.10; 36. 16. In iii.13.19 the pres. e)/xein is required by the notion of duration. Herbst, gegen Cobet, p. 16. GMT. 23, 2, N. 2; Madv. Synt. § 172, Rem. 1; Adv. I. p. 156-177.— 14. fronh/mati: in Thuc. always selfconfidence, spirit. Cf. ii.43.28; 61. 13; 62. 27; iii.45.17; iv.80.15; v.40.16; 43. 7; vi.18.22. In Hdt. only ‘sentiment,’ ‘disposition.’
We should employ some years on our preparations, and then make war upon them, if they do not listen to our reasonable demands.

ou) mh\n ou)de/: see on c. 3. 17.— a)naisqh/tws: with indifference. Cf. c. 69. 14. This belongs both to e)u=n and
to mh\ katafwra=n, and au)tou/s stands at the beginning as obj. of both. The two clauses are joined as a whole by te kai/, expressing together the two aspects of the watchfulness recommended. See on c. 49. 22.
mh\ katafwra=n: to shut your eyes to, = a strong periora=n, and, like e)a=n, dependent on ou)de\ keleu/w.
ai)tia=sqai : abs., make complaints. Cf. c. 140. 18; vii.14.19.—dhlou=ntas: with po/lemon, threatening; with w(s e)pitre/yomen (c. 71. 5), letting them know.

ka)n tou/tw|: here temporal, interim; not as in c. 81. 9.—kai\ ta\ h(me/tera au)tw=n kte(.: i.e. our whole power, including the aid of allies and other resources; here cumma/xwn te prosagwgh=| answers to kai\ ta\ au)tw=n e)kporizw/meqa in 10; where au)tw=n = tw=n cumma/xwn (so St., B.) is to be preferred to au(tw=n, since Thuc. has nowhere else used au(tou= for the refl. of first pers., and ta\ h(me/tera au)tw=n has already been spoken of. See Hünnekes, Quaestiones Thucydideae, p. 5. After the parenthesis we have by a slight anacoluthon the independent subjv. e)kporizw/meqa for an inf. depending on keleu/w.
a)nepi/fqonon : see on c. 75. 15.

e)pibouleuo/meqa: constructed with h(mei=s, where we should expect e)pibouleu/ontai with o(/soi (so iii.67.33; Dem. IV. 12; Xen. Cyr. iv.1.3), and h(ma=s is to be supplied with proslabo/ntas diaswqh=nai in 10, the chief stress lying on the partic., which alone could be e)pi/fqonon. Cf. c. 23. 25; ii.61.3.
e)kporizw/meqa: take pains to gain and use. Cf. c. 125. 6; vi.83.9.

e)sakou/swsi: give ear, comply. Cf. c. 126. 3; iii.4.3; iv.110.1; v.17.10; 45. 18; 50. 1; viii.31.10; with gen. of pers. in v.22.6 only. The aor. subjv., answering to the Lat. fut. exact., is the reading of most Mss. and to be preferred to the pres. Even in c. 126. 3, to which St. refers, Vat. reads the aor.

dielqo/ntwn...triw=n : the former kai/ = even; the latter gives a choice, where we use or. Like this passage is Plat. Phaed. 63 e, kai\ di\s kai\ tri\s pi/nein; 69 b, kai\ prosgignome/nwn kai\ a)pogignome/nwn. In Xen. Re. Eq. 4. 4 we have the second only, a(ma/cas tetta/ras kai\ pe/nte. Cf. An. iv.7.10. In v.10.44, kai\ di\s h)\ tri\s prosbalo/nta.

kai\ i)/sws: significantly introduces the probable consequences of the action of the Lacedaemonians.— h(mw=n: for the force of the pron. thus placed, see on c. 30. 14; 71. 15.— 15. tou\s lo/gous...u(poshmai/nontas : opp. to 4, mh\ po/lemon a)/gan dhlou=ntas. When due preparation has been made, there will be no reason for holding back. u(poshmai/nein again in vi.32.3, hardly distinguishable in meaning from the simple verb. au)th=| o(moi=a, in harmony therewith. Cf. ii.72.2, h)\n poih=te o(moi=a toi=s lo/gois; vii.61.8.

mh\ ga\r...e)/xein : Cl. considers e)/xein here to have a fut. reference, comparing c. 93. 13; 127. 4 (where v. H. and Cobet insert a)/n); ii.84.8; iv.127.4 (where v. H. and Cobet read the fut.). But it is better to consider with St. Qu. Gr. p. 8, that e)/xein is used because the Attic country might be regarded before occupation as a pledge for their good behaviour.—o(/mhron: (Schol., e)ne/xuron to\ u(pe\r ei)rh/nhs parexo/menon) probably here neut. subst., as often in later Greek. Cf. Polyb. iii.52.5. But not so in Plat. Theaet. 202 e, w(/sper o(mh/rous e)/xomen tou= lo/gou ta\ paradei/gmata.
ou)x h(=sson : (see on c. 8. 1) = tosou/tw| ma=llon. For ou) after imv., see on c. 78. 1.
h(=s: but this; position and force as in c. 35. 15; 74. 11.— w(s e)pi\ plei=ston: see on c. 63. 5. Here in temporal sense, as long as possible. Cf. c. 2. 19; 18. 5.
e)s a)po/noian katasth/santes: cf. vii.67.22.
a)lhptote/rous: cf. c. 37. 20.

o(/pws mh\ kte(.: see on c. 19. 4. Kr. and B. take pra/comen act., and render ‘that we may not bring about a more disgraceful and difficult state of things for Peloponnesus.’ But the use of Thuc. (vi.13.17; 75. 17; vii.67.26; 71. 5; viii.95.28) requires here also the intr. meaning, “that it turn not out for us as regards Peloponnesus in a more disgraceful and difficult fashion”; a)porw/teron, for not, like the Athenians, e)k qala/sshs w(=n deh/sei e)paco/meqa (c. 81. 3). Kr. is probably right in understanding ‘than for the Athenians as regards Attica’; but Bonitz, ibid. (p. 29), supplies ‘than now,’ which would require e)/ti with the comp. See Herbst, Philol. 16, p. 322.

po/lemon de\...tw=n i)di/wn : “when the whole confederacy begins a war, not for common but for individual interests,” i.e. for the Megarians and Corinthians. Cf. Dem. v. 19, fobou=mai mh\ pa/ntes peri\ tw=n i)di/wn e(/kastos o)rgizo/menos koino\n e)f) h(ma=s a)ga/gwsi to\n po/lemon.
o(\n...xwrh/sei : prolepsis. Cf. c. 61. 2; 67. 4; 72. 8; 78. 3. The act. form of the simple fut. only here and Hdt. v.89.13; viii.68.20; of compounds freq.
qe/sqai: answers to e)gklh/mata katalu=sai, 24, bring the war to an end with honour. Cf. c. 31. 15; viii.84.19. See on c. 25. 2.
But most of all should we take thought for ways and means.
taxu/: used as adv. ten times by Thuc., who has taxe/ws only once (c. 72. 6), but more often periphrases like dia\ taxe/wn, dia\ ta/xous, e)n ta/xei, kata\ ta/xos.

xrh/mata fe/rontes: from its position = kai\ tau=ta xrh/mata fe/rontes. This Sparta could not claim. —ou)x o(/plwn...dapa/nhs : gens. dependent on e)/stin in pregnant sense, not so much a matter of arms as of money. Cf. c. 142. 24.

a)lla/: has the same effect as h)/ (see on c. 9. 21), for the expression ou) to\ ple/on has really lost its comp. force. Cf. ii.43.16.—di) h(/n: in virtue of which only arms are of service. Cf. iii.13.26; 39. 43; vii.68.18; Dem. 1. 12, to
 tro/pon di) o(
 me/gas ge/gonen. But Dem. VIII. 10, to
 tro/pon di) ou(= ta\ pra/gmata a)polw/leken. Cf. Dem. v. 22; VI. 6; Hom. A 72.—a)/llws te kai/: seldom with a noun without a partic. Cf. Plat. Crit. 50 b; Symp. 173 c. The dat. h)peirw/tais is related loosely to e)/stin, for a land power.
au)th/n: i.e. th\n dapa/nhn.

e)pairw/meqa : pass., be pushed on, impelled. Cf. c. 42. 7; 81. 11; 84. 9; 120. 20; iii.38.12; 45. 3; iv.108.16; 121. 1; vii.13.12. But used also intr.: ‘be proud,’ c. 25. 20; iv.18.17; vi.11.23.—oi(/per de\ kai\ kte(.: kai/ is taken, as often, into the rel. sentence, though really belonging to the demonstrative. See on c. 74. 25. Here it is repeated with ou(=toi. tw=n a)pobaino/ntwn depends on th=s ai)ti/as, responsibility, and this on to\ ple/on. On the order, see on c. 25. 21.

e)p' a)mfo/tera: with tw=n a)pobaino/ntwn, for good or for evil. Cf.
ii.11.37; iv.17.16.—ou(=toi: emphatic resumption of the rel. clause though in first pers., and we who are sure to have . . . let us . . . See on c. 33. 8. Sh. compares Dem. XIX. 69, and in Lat. Plaut. Ep. iii. 1, 9; Rud. 1195, 1292. Kr. Spr. 63, 1, 2.
ti au)tw=n: sc. tw=n a)pobaino/ntwn: a litotes in which the ti, apparently insignificant (see on c. 34. 8), implies something considerable.
The circumspection with which we are reproached has so far been useful to us; we should adhere to it still, and not underrate our opponents.
to\ bradu\ kai\ me/llon: see on c. 36. 3.—me/mfontai: see c. 69. § 4; 70. § 2.

h(mw=n: possessive gen. with o(/, which they find fault with in us. Kühn. 417, note 9; Kr. Spr. 47, 10, 2. —speu/donte/s te ga\r...nemo/meqa : we have here two reasons, united as complements by te kai/, why the Lacedaemonians need not be ashamed of to\ bradu/: (1) because the opposite behaviour (speu/dontes) is sure to lead to entanglements of which the issue cannot be seen; (2) because they owe to it their uninterrupted (dia\ panto/s) freedom and renown. To this is added in § 2 the new remark, that this despised slowness is at bottom nothing else than considerate discretion (swfrosu/nh), which shows itself (1) in the absence of elation at success and of despair at failure; (2) in the fact that neither praise nor blame moves them to act in a way that their judgment does not approve.

kai\ du/natai kte(.: Cl. explains du/nasqai here ‘to have the same meaning,’ valere, whether in words or facts, comparing c. 141. 6; iii.46.10; iv.95.2; vi.36.9; 40. 16. But in all these there is no ei)=nai; and vii.58.13, where ei)=nai occurs, is now bracketed by Cl. himself and St. It is probable that in connexion with ma/lista, ‘approximately’ (c. 13. 11), it means it may turn out to be: “the policy which they condemn may well be the truest good sense and discretion.” J.—e)/mfrwn: truly rational; in Thuc. only here; mostly poetic; cf. Aesch. Prom. 848; Soph. Aj. 306; Pind. Ol. IX. 80.— 6. di) au)to/: i.e. dia\ to\ braxu\ kai\ me/llon; for the four following manifestations of swfrosu/nh all imply full consideration.

h(=sson e(te/rwn: = h(/kista. Cf. vi.9.6. So ma=llon e(te/rwn or e(te/rou = ma/lista. Cf. c. 85. 5. 138. 10; ii.15.1; 60. 24; iv.3.17; vi.16.1; vii.29.29. For e(/teroi includes all others.—tw=n e)cotruno/ntwn: depends on h(donh=|; i.e. by weakly allowing ourselves to be misled by the
pleasure of hearing ourselves praised. Cf. ii.37.12; iii.38.31; 40. 7.
para\ to\ dokou=n h(mi=n: against our own judgment. Cf. iii.38.11.

kai\ h)/n tis ara: and if any one should actually, etc., referring to c. 69 and c. 71. § 3; and because of this distinct reference we have the empiric aor. a)nepei/sqhmen, which includes all similar cases. See on c. 69. 31.—cu\n kathgori/a|: cf. c. 69. 34.

ou)de\n ma=llon a)xqesqe/ntes: opp. to h(donh=|; i.e. we are just as little influenced by anger at their reproaches. a)napei/qein is stronger than the simple verb, implying an almost violent conversion from previous policy. Cf. c. 126. 12; ii.14.1; iii.70.23; viii.52.2.

te kai/: not correlative, but te is inferential, and so. polemikoi/ and eu)/bouloi imply the just-mentioned qualities in action. These are referred to to\ eu)/kosmon (like e)/mfrwn, a word specially chosen for this specific behaviour), i.e. swfrosu/nh, which is based on deliberateness.—to\ me/n: answers to polemikoi/. The filiation is traced in reverse order: from swfrosu/nh comes ai)dw/s, and from ai)dw/s comes eu)yuxi/a, which is the basis of to\ polemiko/n. swfrosu/nh is identified with to\ eu)/kosmon, and ai)sxu/nh (properly the shame which follows a wrong action) only in this place with ai)dw/s (properly the shame which prevents a wrong action). For eu)yuxi/a, cf. c. 121. 16; ii.87.19; vi.72.22; and to\ eu)/yuxon, ii.39.7; iv.126.38; Aesch. Pers. 326; Eur. Med. 403; Plat. Legg. 795 d; Tim. 25 b.

eu)/bouloi: implies consideration and reasonable decision. This is traced to its source in swfrosu/nh by the partic. paideuo/menoi with its triple result: (a) a)maqe/steron . . . u(peroyi/as; (b) swfrone/steron . . . a)nhkoustei=n; (c) kai\ mh\ . . . nomi/zein de\ kte(. It is swfrosu/nh which fosters the habit of subordination even in severe trials, and of vigorous action rather than of idle talk.— a)maqe/steron...u(peroyi/as : for the order, see on c. 32. 8; = h)\ w(/ste u(perora=n tou\s no/mous. This is the theoretical side: “not so highly trained that we fancy ourselves wiser than the law.” Cf. Eur. Or. 417. Arist. Rhet. i.15.12, to\ tw=n no/mwn sofw/teron zhtei=n ei)=nai, tou=t' e)/stin o(\ e)n toi=s e)painoume/nois no/mois a)pagoreu/etai. In a)maqe/steron is an ironical admission of the charge of a)maqi/a in c. 68. 4.

cu\n xalepo/thti: belongs to paideuo/menoi repeated, in strict discipline.—swfrone/steron...a)nhkoustei=n : this is the practical side; “not so presumptuous as to refuse obedience to the law.” For const., see H. 954; Kr. Spr. 49, 4. Cf. viii.46.34.

kai\ mh\...e)pecie/nai, nomi/zein de\ kte(.: and so trained “that we do not, through over-sagac
ity in unprofitable accomplishments, disparage in clever speeches our enemy's resources, and then when it comes to action make our advance with no corresponding vigour, but are convinced, etc.” See Grote's analysis of this speech, V. c. 48, p. 351. ta\ a)xrei=a, chiefly of rhetorical artifices. cunetoi\ o)/ntes, subord. to memfo/menoi, expressing the means. Cf. c. 31. 5; 67. 6; 75. 11. e)pecie/nai, abs., used with e)/rgw| also in c. 120. 28; v.9.41.
ta\s dianoi/as: pl. as c. 144. 5; iii.82.22; vi.11.23; Lys. XXIV 16: designs, projects, the results of dia/noia, c. 138. 2; vi.15.15.

paraplhsi/ous: only here of two terminations; sc. tai=s h(mete/rais, therefore not to be disparaged. —kai\ ta\s...diaireta/s : referring to c. 69. 25, bou/lesqe . . . katasth=nai. We have learned “that the chances which may occur do not admit of distinct definition by argument,” i.e. before they occur. With this is naturally connected what follows, § 4, “let us always assume prudent counsels on the part of our enemies, and prepare ourselves actively to meet them, not building our hopes on their mistakes; for this would be to make definite assumptions about accidental circumstances.” See App.

w(s pro\s eu)=...e)nanti/ous : Kr. Spr. 68, 8, states the rule: when a prep. phrase (a) is attended by an illustration (b) with w(s, w(/sper, the prep. is used with both (a) and (b) when (b) follows (as in c. 85. 9), but only with (b) when (b) stands first, as here, iv.41.6, and vi.50.20. For other instances of a prep. not repeated, cf. c. 21. 5; 28. 6; 69. 32; 91. 20.

paraskeuazw/meqa: the subjv., which the best Mss. have, suitably follows up the declaration of Spartan principles with an exhortation (but Arn., Kr., Sh. read the indic. on account of a)ei/). The same connexion of thought is shown also by the repeated dei=.
pronooume/nwn : usually mid. in Attic; but act., iii.38.28; 58. 11.
polu/ te diafe/rein kte(.: here the marked difference of national traits, insisted on by the Corinthians in c. 69, is denied.

e)n toi=s a)nagkaiota/tois: in the severest school. J. The words tau/tas . . . mele/tas of c. 85. 1 show that this expression refers to the peculiar Spartan training, especially to its suppression of the individual will; (cf. 14) “the man who is trained under the strictest discipline,” so that no choice is left to his own will. Cf.
ii.64.9, fe/rein xrh\ ta\ daimo/nia a)nagkai/ws: i.e. with submission to the inevitable. Cf. c. 70, 71. See App.
Try, therefore, first to gain redress of grievances from the Athenians by peaceful means; but let us not neglect meanwhile to prepare for war.
tau/tas...mele/tas : the rel. clause interposed renders the art. unnecessary. Cf. Xen. An. i.5.16. Kühn. 465, note 6 a.
e)peixqe/ntes: too hastily. See on c. 80. 16.
swma/twn: lices; opp. to xrh/mata, as c. 141. 18; ii.53.7.

bouleu/swmen: Thuc. uses the act. and mid. for the most part in the same sense: in pres., ‘deliberate’; in aor., ‘decide.’ Cf. c. 97. 2; 132. 28; ii.6.9; iii.28.5; iv.15.3; 41. 1; v.87.3; vi.39.5; viii.53.24. Probably only in iii.42.25 it means ‘give advice.’

e(te/rwn: see on c. 84. 7; here for h)\ e(te/rois, as ii.15.1; vi.16.1. H. 643 b; Kühn. 543, 2 c. See on c. 71. 9.—pe/mpete: the imv. pres. when the aor. would be expected, acc. to the usage noted on c. 26. 1. For the epanaphora, cf. c. 28. 8; 30. 17; 126. 40.
au)tw=n: of themselves. Cf. iv.60.14.
ou) pro/teron: sc. pri\n a)\n ai( di/kai dikasqw=sin.
i)e/nai : in pregnant sense. See on c. 78. 7. Contrast the advice of the Corinthians, c. 71. 17.
kra/tista kai\ foberw/tata: properly pred. to tau=ta, but in effect adv. See on c. 43. 10.
*sqenelai+/das: the ephor who now comes forward represents the jealous and encroaching attitude of that magistracy towards the conservatism of the kings.

e)n toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois: i.e. in the assembly. Cf. Dem. VIII. 27, 74 (e)n u(mi=n); Plat. Legg. 886 e (e)n a)sebe/sin a)nqrw/pois). Kr. and v. H. bracket the words. On the character and connexion of the speech of Archidamus, see App.

div2.head: Speech of the ephor Sthenelaidas. Chap. 86.
div2.p: In view of the evident wrong of the Athenians, further discussion would be out of place, and war should immediately be decided on.

ou) gignw/skw: I cannot understand. Cf. c. 126. 21; ii.40.7; iv.50.9, an affectation of simplicity. The position of tou\s pollou/s indicates the speaker's sense of weariness.— 2. a)ntei=pon: followed by neg. See on c. 77. 13.
a)dikou=si: see on c. 67. 5.

kai/toi: and yet, quamquam; introduces a confident refutation.—ei)...e)ge/nonto : referring to what is a fact. Cf. c. 33. 8; 76. 8.— 7. kai\ to/te...e)smen : by a sort of zeugma h)=men is to be supplied with to/te. Cf. iii.40.5; vi.60.13.—kai\ tou\s cumma/xous: this noun by its position is made so prominent (see on c. 32. 17) that it is not repeated in the dat. (with timwrei=n) in the second clause.—h)\n swfronw=men: see on c. 40. 8.

oi( d)...pa/sxein : sc. su/mmaxoi; connected with the preceding in parataxis: ‘nor will we postpone helping them, since they have no longer postponement of ill-treatment.” me/llein, in sense of ‘postpone,’ regularly has the pres. inf. The conjecture of Hünnekes, oi(/ g), in close connection with timwrei=n, is not improbable.
a)/llois me\n kte(.: refers chiefly to c. 80. § 3, 4, of the speech of Archidamus.
paradote/a: and the following pl. verbals, as in c. 72. 4; 79. 6; 88. 2. GMT. 114, 2; H. 635 a.

ou)de\ diakrite/a: the verbal is from diakri/nesqai, dispute. Cf. v.79.15.—mh/ lo/gw|...blaptome/nous : mh/, not ou), since the neg. is determined by the imv. force of the verbal diakrite/a. As to the acc. au)tou/s, sc. h(ma=s with the verbal, which = dei= diakri/nesqai, see G. 281, 2; H. 991; Kühn. 427, note 2; Kr. Spr. 56, 18, 3. Cf. viii.65.14.

kai\ w(s h(ma=s kte(.: in answer to
c. 85. § 1, 2.
e)pi/wmen pro/s: see on c. 83. 2. But Cobet reads e)pi/.
The Lacedaemonian assembly votes against the Athenians. The decree of the allies is adjourned to a later meeting.

e)peyh/fizen: applied to the putting of a question to vote at Sparta as well as at Athens. Cf. ii.24.6; vi.14.3; viii.15.7. The impf. inchoative (he proceeded to—), as c. 26. 23; 27. 2; 46. 2. The addition e)s th\n e)kklhsi/an only here, but perhaps confirmed by Lucian's imitation, Tim. 44, th=| e)kklhsi/a| e)peyh/fise. The words are bracketed by St. and v. H. after Kr., who quotes Plat. Gorg: 474 a, e)piyhfi/zein tou\s paro/ntas, for the usual Attic expression.

o( de\ kte(.: this is the fullest notice we have of the process at Sparta. See Schömann, Ant. I. p. 236. The use of o( de/ here without change of subj., assumes the occurrence of the first voting by boh/, so that after e)peyh/fize kte(. we must supply kai\ oi( me\n e)peyhfi/zonto.
kri/nousi ga/r kte(.: similar parenthesis in c. 104. 5; iii.3.1; 52. 14.
mei/zwn: louder, as from more voices. e)sti/ or ei)/h must be supplied. For a similar omission of finite verb in indir. question, cf. iv.40.8; viii.92.58.
o(rmh=sai: trans., as c. 127. 11; ii.20.13. The obj. is au)tou/s; he desired to encourage the war party by the sense of their majority, and to show the others how much they were outnumbered.
lelu/sqai...a)dikei=n : as the Corinthians had asserted, c. 67. 5.
a)nasth/tw e)s: i.e. a)nasth/tw kai\ i)/tw e)s. Cf. c. 101. 7; vii.49.10; viii.45.1. G. 191, N. 6; H. 788.

dei/cas...au)toi=s : parenthetical insertion in the narrative. Cf. c. 136. 18; 137. 27; Hdt. viii.137.22; Isocr. XII. 215; Isae. 11. 12; Dem. XXI. 116; Aeschin.
11. 43; Cic. de Fin. v.3.7.
die/sthsan: in literal sense; the figurative in c. 15. 16; 18. 28.
proskale/sante/s te: and so (c. 67. 3; 76. 16; 78. 7) calling in, since, c. 79. 3, metesth/santo pa/ntas.
ei)=pon : with o(/ti dokoi=en and bou/lesqai. Cf. ii.80.6, 10; iii.2.12, 15; 3. 12, 14; iv.46.18, 20; v.61.9, 11. Kühn. 550, note 3.

tou\s pa/ntas...e)pagagei=n : implies a general convocation of the allies, since the invitation of the Corinthians (c. 67. 3) and of the Lacedaemonians (c. 67. 9) had been addressed only to particular states. This purpose is carried out, c. 119. § 1, with the formal expression yh=fon e)pa/gein (with dat., c. 125. 3). Cf. iv.74.15, yh=fon dienegkei=n of the act of voting; pass., Xen. An. vii.7.57, ou)/pw yh=fos au)tw=| e)ph=kto peri\ fugh=s.— 14. koinh=| : belongs both to bouleusa/menoi and to to\n po/lemon poiw=ntai.
e)f' a(/per h)=lqon: cf. c. 72. 3. Thuc. avoids digressions which would not elucidate his main subject, perhaps in intentional divergence from the practice of Hdt.

xrhmati/santes: of public affairs, v.5.2; 61. 6; vi.62.18. The mid. is used mostly of mercantile business. Cf. vii.13.13. The narrative in § 5 is continued at c. 118. § 3, au)toi=s me\n ou)=n *lakedaimoni/ois kte(., being here interrupted by the detailed account of what is called, c. 23. 23, a)lhqesta/th me\n lo/gw| de\ a)fanesta/th pro/fasis tou= pole/mou.
diagnw/mh : used only by Thuc. of Attic writers. Cf. iii.42.1; 67. 33 (c. 118. 18, die/gnwsto).

tou= ta\s sponda\s lelu/sqai: this explanatory clause is quite in place, considering the importance of the subject, and is not to be bracketed with Kr., St., and v. H. It is rather confirmed than rendered doubtful by the repetition in c. 88. 1. For the gen. inf. as appos., see Kühn. 402 d.—e)n tw=|...deka/tw| : these words are grammatically connected with tw=n . . . prokexwrhkuiw=n, the pf. expressing with e)n, instead of the expected e)s, the period reached, = e)s to\ e)/tos prokexwrhkuiw=n kai\ e)n tw=| e)/tei ou)sw=n. See Kr. Spr. 68, 12, 2 for instances of the pf. thus used with e)n. P. prefers to connect e)n e)/tei with e)ge/neto (with which, as Cl. admits, its position shows that it was intended
to be connected in sense) understanding e)s tou=to to\ e)/tos with the partic.
triakontouti/dwn: for the form, see on c. 23. 19.
ai(\ e)ge/nonto kte(.: see c. 23. 20; 115. § 1.
The real reason of the war was the fear the Lacedaemonians felt of the growing power of the Athenians.
e)yhfi/santo de/: a resumption of what precedes with de/ epexegetic, the verb pointing on to the reason following (ou) tosou=ton kte(.), as the chief contents of the chapter.
ou) tosou=ton - o(/son: = “less—than.” See on c. 9. 2; 11. 1.

fobou/menoi...mh/ : see on c. 72. 8; 78. 3; 82. 26.— 4. dunhqw=sin: the aor. stands to du/nasqai as i)sxu=sai (c. 3. 8) to i)sxu/ein; and so e)pi\ mei=zon. Cf. c. 10. 20; 21. 3; iv.117.12; viii.24.22; 74. 12. Thuc. very rarely, if ever, uses the opt. with mh/ after verbs of fear. We have thus again stated the a)lhqesta/th pro/fasis a)fanesta/th de\ lo/gw| of c. 23. § 6, which also speaks of the Athenians as fo/bon pare/xontas toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois.
HISTORY OF THE GROWING POWER OF THE ATHENIANS FROM THE BATTLE OF MYCALE TO THE BEGINNING OF THE PELOPONNESIAN WAR, B.C. 479-431. Chaps. 89118.
This period is called by the Greek grammarians h( penthkontaeti/a or h( penthkontaethri/s.
Capture of Sestos. The rebuilding of Athens begun.
oi( ga\r *)aqhnai=oi kte(.: these words introduce the events between the retirement of the Persians and the transfer of the hegemony to the Athenians, B.C. 476, c. 89-96.

h)=lqon e)pi\ ta\ pra/gmata: i.e. not of set purpose but by the course of events they found themselves in such circumstances that they had to take the hegemony. Cf. ii.36.15; 56. 12; iii.49.3. Antiphon, VI. 20. To the history of this au)ca/nesqai Thuc. passes in c. 97. 3 with the words tosa/de e)ph=lqon, which introduce the subsequent political and military enterprises deliberately carried out by the Athenians to the beginning of the war. See on ii.36.16, and Herbst, Philol. 24, p. 725 ff.—e)peidh\ *mh=doi kte(.: following toiw=|de without conj. Cf. c. 128. 7; ii.34.3; 75. 24; iii.20.13; 21. 2; 52. 4; 92. 3; 97. 2; 104. 5; iv.46.16; 67. 11; 90. 6; 100. 8; v.45.6; 71. 2; vi.46.12; 64. 14; 88. 2; viii.50.5; 69. 5; 104. 1. With ga/r only in ii.20.3; v.68.9; viii.73.3; 84. 2. tro/pw| toiw=|de is resumed in c. 96. 1 with tou/tw|tw=| tro/pw|.

kai\ nausi\ kai\
pezw=|: i.e. at Salamis and Plataea.— 5. diefqa/rhsan: see Hdt. ix. 100-105.
tw=n e)n *muka/lh|: cf. ii.34.14; iii.113.10.
a)pexw/rhsan: see Hdt. ix.114.6.

kai\ oi(...cu/mmaxoi : these were the Greeks of the Asiatic coast, who, on the appearance of the Hellenic fleet, had declared themselves independent and had become de facto allies of the Athenians. “Considering the reserved attitude of the Lacedaemonian, and the relatively private character of the Athenian, undertaking, we cannot think here of any formal reception into the Hellenic alliance.” Kirchhoff, Der delische Bund. Hermes, 11, p. 9. See App.— 9. h)/dh a)festhko/tes: at and after the battle of Mycale. Hdt. ix. 103 ff. The attrib. partic. placed after its subst., as c. 11. 19.

u(pomei/nantes: opp. to a)pexw/rhsan, 7, keeping their ground. Cf. c. 76. 3.—e)polio/rkoun: impf.; cf. c. 26. 23; 87. 1. See Hdt. ix. 114-118.—*mh/dwn e)xo/ntwn: the standing expression. Cf. c. 94. 6; 98. 1; 103. 10.

e)pixeima/santes: so the capture of the town took place in the spring of 478. See Ullrich, Die hellen. Kriege, p. 41.—au)th/n: th\n *shsto/n. Schol., *shsto\s h( po/lis le/getai kai\ a)rsenikw=s kai\ qhlukw=s. Masc., Xen. Hell. iv.8.5, 6; Dem. XXIII. 158.
w(s e(/kastoi: see on c. 3. 19.

*)aqhnai/wn de\ kte(.: the rebuilding of the city and walls now mentioned took place in the winter months of 479-8, during the siege of Sestos. See on c. 90. 22.—to\ koino/n: the whole community without designation of any particular magistracy, and without distinction of boulh/ and dh=mos. So c. 90. 29; 92. 3; iii.11.22. For the pl. verb following, see on c. 24. 9; 34. 5.—au)toi=s: ethical dat., used in good as well as in bad sense. Cf. c. 101. 6; 106. 8; v.3.21.

e)k th=s xw/ras: i.e. out of Attica, opp. to e)k th=s *eu)rw/phs, 3. See Ullrich, Hell. Kr. p. 41.—o(/qen: = e)nteu=qen oi(=: a rare attraction, transferred from the pron. use to the adv. Cf. Soph. Tr. 701, e)k de\ gh=s, o(/qen prou/keit' , a)naze/ousi qrombw/deis a)froi/. Hor. Od. i.38.3, rosa quo locorum sera more
tur. The reference is to the neighbouring islands and the Argolic Acte. —u(pece/qento: had carried for safety; u(pekkei=sqai is the pf. pass., c. 137. 19; viii.31.15. The same verbs are used of the same fact by Hdt. viii.41.7; 60. 24; and by Plut. Them. 10. 4. Cf. also Soph. El. 297.
pai=das kai\ gunai=kas: without art. Kühn. 462 e; Kr. Spr. 50, 3, 8.—kataskeuh/n: household goods in general. See on c. 2. 12. Cf. ii.5.13; 14. 3.
peribo/lou...oi)ki/ai : in chiastic order to po/lin . . . tei/xh.
braxe/a : small portions. See on c. 14. 11.—oi)ki/ai: placed before its limitations. See on c. 1. 6. Cf. iii.13.18. Cobet reads ai( oi)ki/ai.
peptw/kesan : St., v. H., B. read e)peptw/kesan. G. 101, 4, N.; H. 358 c. Kühn., 199, 11, would write )peptw/kesan.— 20. e)skh/nhsan : the mid. in same sense, c. 133. 5; ii.52.9.
90, 91. In spite of the resistance of the Lacedaemonians, the rebuilding of the walls of Athens is completed through the address of Themistocles.

h)=lqon presbei/a|: = e)presbeu/santo. The dat. like nausi\ kai\ pezw=|, but with no exact parallel. Cf. au)tomoli/a| xwrei=n, viii.40.11.—ta\ me
...to\ de\ ple/on : the pl. more comprehensive, the sing. more emphatic. Cf. viii.47.9, 15. In c. 18. 30, with ta\ me/n . . . ta\ de/, equal weight is laid on both —kai\ au)toi\...e)/xonta : the partic. o(rw=ntes and the following gen. abs. are causal, representing clauses with o(/ti, e.g. o(/ti h(/dion a)
 e(w/rwn ei) mh/t' e)kei/nous mh/t) a)/llon mhde/na tei=xos e)/xonta e(w/rwn, or perhaps mh/ may be due to the feeling that h(/dion a)
 o(rw=ntes really expresses a wish, = ma=llon a)
 boulo/menoi.
e)cotruno/ntwn : this partic., expressing the effect, is placed co-ord. before foboume/nwn, the cause, as in c. 1. 3.
genome/nhn: on the position, see on c. 11. 19.

te: cf. c. 67. 3; 77. 14; 87. 11.— 8. o(/sois ei)sth/kei: the best Mss. have cuneisth/kei, which is hard to explain, but may have arisen by dittography from the following word. It is retained by Sh. and Kr., with Arnold's explanation, ‘stand or hold together,’ the peri/bolos being continuous, in contrast with c. 89. 18. The subj. is
tei/xh, from teixi/zein. Cf. c. 91. 3.— 9. to\ boulo/menon kai\ u(/popton: see on c. 36. 3; to\ boulo/menon, like to\ dedio/s, to\ qarsou=n, properly ‘that which wills’ in us, and so ‘the will’ in concrete sense. Cf. Eur. I. A. 1270, ou)d) e)pi\ to\ kei/nou boulo/menon e)lh/luqa; 386, to\ lelogisme/non parei/s.

dhlou=ntes : letting be seen. Cf. c. 82. 4; 102. 14; iv.68.29; v.30.14.—e)s tou\s *)aqhnai/ous: Cl. compares c. 72. 13, e)s to\ plh=qos ei)pei=n. But it is better, with Kr., Sh., to connect this with u(/popton. Kr. compares vi.60.3; 61. 18; 103. 21.—w(s de\ tou= barba/rou...e)/xontos : i.e. le/gontes de\ w(s, ei) mh\ teixi/zoien a)lla\ kai\ cugkaqe/loien tou\s peribo/lous, o( ba/rbaros ou)k a)\n e)/xoi kte(. Kühn. 398, 4; Kr. Spr. 69, 63, 3; 54, 6, 6.

e)xurou= poqen: from some stronghold, poqen being = the gen. of tis. Cf. Plat. Phaedr. 268 c, e)k bibli/ou poqe\n a)kou/sas; Rep. 544 d, h)\ oi)/ei e)k druo/s poqen h)\ e)k pe/tras ta\s politei/as gi/gnesqai.

nu=n : in the sense of nu=n dh/ or nundh/ (Cobet, V. L. p. 233) = o)li/gon e)/mprosqen, a)rti/ws, modo. So Dem. XIX. 65, o(/te ga\r nu=n e)poreuo/meqa ei)s *delfou/s. Eur. I. T. 327.— th/n te: te is postscript. See on c. 33. 2.
a)naxw/rhsin kte(.: to be taken locally, place of retreat as well as of advance.
gnw/mh|: by the advice. Cf. c. 93. 16; iii.50.3; vi.50.2.

tou\s me\n *lakedaimoni/ous kte(.: it would be more natural that in 17 we should find au)to\n d' a)pe/steilan; but by the variation it is suggested that it was not till the departure of the Lacedaemonians that the second part of the advice was given.
a)ph/llacan: gotrid of; the word implies that their presence was a burden. Cf. viii.46.26.
me/xri tosou/tou e(/ws: cf. Dem. XVIII. 48, me/xri tou/tou fi/los w)noma/zeto, e(/ws prou/dwken. Plat. Rep. 471 b, me/xri tou/tou poih/sontai th\n diafora/n, me/xri ou(= a)\n kte(.

i(kano/n : pred., containing the effect of the verb. Cf. c. 37. 21; 71. 27; ii.75.22; vi.92.26.—a)/rwsin: for ai)/rwsin of the Mss. The two forms could hardly be distinguished when the aor. was written with i subscript. An end to be reached, and not, as in c. 58. 16, an enduring process, is
spoken of. See App.
a)poma/xesqai: = ma/xesqai a)p' au)tou=, as Plat. Phaedr. 260 b, a)popolemei=n te xrh/simon. Xen. Cyr. iii.1.1. Cf. ii.20.9, o( xw=ros e)pith/deios e)fai/neto e)nstratopedeu=sai.

e)k tou= a)nagkaiota/tou u(/yous : from the height indispensable for defence. The sense might have been expressed by e(/ws a)\n to\ tei=xos e)s to\ pro\s to\ a)poma/xesqai a)nagkaio/taton u(/yos a)/rwsi.

tou\s e)n th=| po/lei : opp. to those before Sestos, c. 89. 10. Ullrich, Hell. Kr. p. 43 ff.— 24. o(/qen...e)/stai : fut. indic. in dependent sentence with potential sense. Cf. c. 107. 19. Kr. Spr. 53, 7, 8; Kühn. 387, 4 d.

kai\ o( me/n: answers to oi( de/ in c. 91. 1, and both together describe the execution of the preceding resolution.—u(peipw/n: see on c. 35. 18.— 26. ta)=lla: (placed for emphasis before the conj.; see on c. 77. 4) as for the rest, loosely connected with what follows, ta)kei= alone being obj. pra/coi. Cf. ii.100.6; with e)s, vi.15.5. —pra/coi: fut. opt. in indir. disc. Cf. ii.2.18; 80. 10; iv.83.15; viii.61.5. GMT. 70, 2; H. 932, 2.
prosh/|ei pro/s: would not go near, of physical approach. So Aeschin. 1. 165; usually with dat. of the interview merely. Cf. c. 72. 13; iv.36.2; v.59.23; vii.72.8.—ta\s a)rxa/s: cf. v.84.20.
dih=ge: abs., let time pass on, as vii.39.5.— 29. o(/ ti: the question would be ti/ ou)k e)pe/rxei; and in indir. disc., o(/ ti.
e)pe/rxetai : see on c. 72. 15.—e)pi\ to\ koino/n: before the community, i.e. in the public assembly. Cf. ii.12.5; iv.84.8; 97. 9; v.37.4.

qauma/zein w(s: Cobet and v. H. read pw=s, as in Xen. Cyr. ii.4.9. Usually const. with ei) = o(/ti. But with o(/pws in Dem. XVIII. 159; “Isocr. III. 3; Xen. Apol. 25. w(s is perhaps exclamatory.” B. L. G.

fili/an: of favour in public relations. Cf. c. 60. 7; 137. 31; ii.100.13; iii.95.7; v.95.2. For the fact, see c. 74. 9.—tw=n de\...kathgorou/ntwn : the partic. a)fiknou/menoi (in iv.27.16 also a)figme/noi), being constantly
used of persons who came from abroad, acquired an almost subst. meaning. Cf. c. 95. 11; iii.93.13; v.16.24; Hdt. i.105.16; Plat. Prot. 313 b; Gorg. 459 e; Isocr. VII. 66; Dem. XVIII. 82, 201. Here, therefore, tw=n a)/llwn a)fiknoume/nwn are to be taken closely together, the others who came from Athens; and kai/ with safw=s is intensive, quite positively, as in viii.87.20 (probably also in viii.1.3, where kai\ safw=s a)gge/llousi is pred. to what precedes). v. H. in Hermes, 4, p. 423, approves this explanation. (In his own edition v. H. brackets a)/llwn and kai/. Van der Mey, Mnem. 11, 327, omits kai/ and reads a)ei/ for a)/llwn.)
lamba/nei: sc. to\ tei=xos. See on c. 90. 8. So e)/xein in iv.13.4. Cf. Hdt. ix.7.5, to\ tei=xos e)pa/lcis e)la/mbane.

o(/pws xrh\ a)pisth=sai : depending on ou)k ei)=xon (= h)/|desan), they did not know how they could help believing them; usually the deliberative subjv. occurs, as in ii.52.11; iv.28.15; v.65.21; probably also vii.14.6. In iii.11.18, e)xo/ntwn . . . pro\s o(/ ti xrh\ sth=nai, though without neg. Kr. Spr. 54, 7, 2; Kühn. 394, note 3.
mh\ ma=llon...h)/ : see on c. 73. 17.

xrhstoi/: sc. ei)si, which is sometimes omitted after rel. Cf. c. 16. 4; 35. 25; ii.97.25. But Cobet brackets xrhstoi\ kai/. The fut. a)naggelou=si has a final meaning. Cf. iii.16.15; iv.22.3. See on c. 90. 24. See App.

kai\ peri\ au)tw=n: for similar parataxis, cf. c. 26. 17; 61. 2; ii.12.8.— 10. h)/dh ga\r kte(.: explains the pl. au)toi/, and shows that the suggestion of c. 90. 19 had been acted upon.— 11. au)tw=|: see on c. 13. 12; 61. 1.— *(abrw(nixos: see Hdt. viii.21.6.
e)fobei=to ga/r: gives the reason of keleu/wn, 9.

sfa=s : indir. refl. Cf. iii.93.7; iv.41.12; 55. 6; pl. as referring to the three envoys.—o(po/te a)kou/seian: = o(po/tan a)kou/swsi of dir. disc. Cf. the opt., c. 25. 4; 63. 3. GMT. 77, 2, N.; H. 932, 2.

e)pesta/lh: see on c. 46. 1.—
16. e)pelqw\n kte(.: as in c. 90. 29, e)pi\ to\ koino/n.
e)ntau=qa dh/ : of the decisive moment. Cf. c. 49. 30, to/te dh/.

ei) de/ ti bou/lontai kte(.: “if the Lacedaemonians or their allies wished anything, envoys must hereafter be sent (inf.=imv. after ei)=pen) to them with the understanding that they could for themselves recognize and decide what was for their own and the general interest.” The prep. para/ to be taken with prodiagignw/skontas as well as with sfa=s. See on c. 84. 19; 92. 3; vi.50.20. This compound is found also in c. 78. 4; v.38.19. Its pro- implies here “before the Lacedaemonians take the trouble to advise them.” The pres. inf. and partic. imply an ironical assumption as to the whole future. See App.
koina/: the position of te shows that this is opp. to sfi/sin au)toi=s, and that therefore su/mfora belongs to both.

a)/neu e)kei/nwn: i.e. a)/neu gnw/mhs e)kei/nwn. Cf. c. 128. 12; ii.72.17; vi.78.19; v.28.6; viii.5.14.— e)/fasan: bracketed by Kr., since e)/fh comes again in 30, and e)/fasan was probably supplied by a scribe, who thought a pl. verb was needed with gno/ntes. Cf. vi.25.15; 64. 22; vii.48.7. But Cl. thinks it may stand after ei)=pen, 17, without offence, since the completion of the embassy has been mentioned. Here, as in c. 28. 10, the repetition of the verb is due to the importance of the statement.

bouleu/esqai: inf. in rel. sentence in indir. disc. Cf. ii.13.34; 24. 11; 102. 28; iv.98.13; v.45.9; 46. 18; 63. 16; vi.24.14. GMT. 92, 2, N. 3; H. 947; Kühn. 594, 5; Kr. Spr. 55, 4, 9; 53, 2, 9.—gnw/mh|: like gno/ntes, 23, implies both discernment and decision, referring to prodiagignw/skontas above.
kai\ nu=n a)/meinon ei)=nai: repeated from 22, with a proud sense of selfdetermination.

kai\ i)di/a| kte(.: i.e. w)felimw/teron toi=s poli/tais kai\ i)di/a| kai\ e)s tou\s cumma/xous: the fortification of the city would be of more advantage to its inhabitants (toi=s poli/tais, not the colorless sfi/sin), in regard as well to the security of the city itself (i)di/a|) as to its influence over the confederacy. Thuc. very often
separates two parallel clauses by an expression common to both (here toi=s poli/tais). Cf. c. 69. 1, 13, 17; 70. 27; 93. 20. See App.

mh\...paraskeuh=s : = a)po\ paraskeuh=s mh\ a)ntipa/lou ou)/shs. “A position of equal independence is indispensable if the views proposed are to receive equal consideration.” For the effect of a neg. before a prep. to reverse the meaning of the following noun or adj., see Kr. Spr. 67, 9; 10, 4; Kühn. 514, 4. Cf. c. 141. 24; iii.62.16. For a)po/, cf. c. 74. 18; ii.77.3; vi.19.6; vii.29.6; for o(moi=o/n ti h)\ i)/son, see on c. 27. 4.
ta/de: “what has now happened.”
The Lacedaemonians are secretly displeased but make no open protest.
o)rgh\n...e)poiou=nto : see on c. 50. 7. The adj. fanera/n has here the same force as an adv. with o)rgi/zesqai. Cf. 6, a)dh/lws h)/xqonto.
kwlu/mh| : used only by Thuc. of Attic writers. Cf. iv.27.14; 63. 4.

gnw/mhs paraine/sei: governed still by the prep. e)pi/. See on c. 6. 20.—dh=qen: as they said, expresses ironically disbelief in the truth of the statement. Cf. c. 127. 2; iv.99.7.—tw=| koinw=|: cf. c. 89. 14; 90. 29; ii.12.5. The dat. depends on paraine/sei (cf. c. 63. 9; 73. 1), as iii.37.28, tw=| u(mete/rw| plh/qei parainei=n.
ta\ ma/lista : (cf. iv.74.16; 76. 14; v.16.7; 25. 13) belongs to prosfilei=s; “they were then most of all on a good footing with the Athenians”; which does not imply any hearty good-will.
a(marta/nontes: when they saw that they were failing, were bound to fail, not of the permanent consequences, as Cl. says. See Gildersleeve, Am. J. of Ph. IV. 160.—te: and so. Cf. c. 87. 11; 90. 7.

a)nepiklh/tws: since the appearance of a good understanding was maintained, they refrained from mutual recrimination. Cf. the use of e)pikalei=n, c. 139. 10; ii.27.3; iii.36.8; iv.23.8; 133. 2; v.56.4; 59. 25; 83. 15.
After the hasty completion of the city walls, at the instance of Themistocles the fortifications of the Piraeus also were built.

e)tei/xisan: complexive aor., summing up the narrative from c. 89. § 3. Ullrich, Hell. Kr. p. 49, calculates that the interval cannot have exceeded
three months.
kai\ dh/lh...e)ge/neto : proleptic and personal const., on the principle of c. 40. 13.
oi( ga\r qeme/lioi kte(.: = oi( qeme/lioi oi(\ u(po/keintai pantoi/wn li/qwn ei)si/n. u(po/keintai, pf. pass. of u(potiqe/nai, with li/qwn, gen. of material.
ou) cuneirgasme/nwn: not worked for the purpose of junction.—e)/stin h(=|: in several places. G. 152, N. 2; H. 998.

li/qoi ei)rgasme/noi: stones already wrought for other purposes.—e)gkatele/ghsan: Schol. e)gkatw|kodomh/qhsan. There is probably an allusion to the use of loga/dhn, as in iv.4.6.—mei/zwn: with e)ch/xqh (cf. c. 90. 21), i.e. than they were before, inclosing now the whole range of the Museum and the neighbouring heights. Curtius, Hist. of Gr. II. p. 363; Sieben Karten, 3.

pa/nta o(moi/ws: all without distinction. Cf. c. 121. 5; 124. 16; 130. 12; ii.49.41; iii.39.33; 111. 10; iv.112.10; v.68.13; vi.24.8; vii.28.4.—kinou=ntes: often used of interference due to necessity, as with temple-treasures, c. 143. 2; ii.24.7; with sacred water, iv.98.15. Here, no doubt, of the sth=lai a)po\ shma/twn, etc.

e)/peise de\ kte(.: this second greater design was projected but not completed by Themistocles. This is implied by the verbs e)/peise . . . kai\ cunkateskeu/aze, 15, which should not be separated by punctuation. The first parenthesis explains ta\ loipa/, the second, nautikou\s gegenhme/nous, while the partic. nomi/zwn with its two infs. gives the reason of e)/peise . . . oi)kodomei=n.— 9. u(ph=rkto de/ : now a beginning had been made. Cf. c. 6. 20; ii.13.29; vii.75.38; and see on c. 48. 1.
kat' e)niauto/n: = kat' e)niauto\n ou)/shs = e)niausi/as, vi.54.27.

*)aqhnai/ois: with h)=rce. Cf. ii.2.6; vi.54.27; Hdt. viii.51.5. G. 184, 3; H. 767; Kr. Spr. 47, 20, 2.—h)=rce: Böckh (Abh. d. Akad. 1827, p. 131) followed by Curtius, II. p. 242, dates this in Ol. 71. 4, B.C. 4932; Kr. Stud. I. p. 23 ff., in Ol. 74. 3, B.C. 482-1.

lime/nas...au)tofuei=s : the Piraeus, here in widest sense, is “the peninsula the heart of which is formed by the steep height of Munychia, from which the rocky land stretches to the sea like an indented leaf and forms three natural basins with narrow entrances.” Curtius, Hist. of Gr. II. p. 611. In a narrower sense the largest of these basins was called
*peiraieu/s, the others being Zea and Munychia. Curtius, Sieb. Kart. p. 30; 60, 61.—au)tou/s: the Athenians themselves, opp. to to\ xwri/on.

profe/rein : here as in c. 123. 6; ii.89.11, intr., = diafe/rein. Cl. takes the pres. inf. here in a fut. sense after nomi/zein. See on c. 82. 18. But it is better, with St., Qu. Gr. p. 8, to explain it as pres.: putans eos nauticos factos multum proficere ad potentiam sibi comparandam.
a)nqekte/a: see on c. 7. 2; 72. 4; from the mid. a)nte/xesqai. Cf. c. 13. 6.

th\n a)rxh\n kte(.: the impf., as in c. 26. 23; 27. 2, he proceeded to make a beginning of the work, with the implication that it was not finished before his banishment, cir. B.C. 471. eu)qu/s, Schol., a(/ma tw=| cumbouleu=sai. Arnold thinks this was immediately after the retreat of the Persians. Grote, V. c. 45, p. 149, connects it with e)to/lmhsen ei)pei=n, and refers to the time when Them. first suggested that the Athenians should make themselves a naval power.

kai\ w)|kodo/mhsan: complexive aor. including the whole operation; and as obj., not tei=xos with its description, but directly to\ pa/xos tou= tei/xous, whereas in 21 to\ u(/yos follows in a different const.
o(/per: the antec. is pa/xos.

du/o ga\r a(/macai...e)ph=gon : Grote, V. c. 44, p. 105, explains that “two carts, meeting one another, brought stones, which were laid together right and left on the outer side of each”; Cl., that carts brought stones from opposite sides, and after unloading passed down on the other side. But he does not show how this was possible while the walls were in process of construction. Kr. and Herbst, Philol. 38, p. 551, regard the words as a gloss, perhaps introduced by way of comparison with the Birdcity (Ar. Av. 1127) or Babylon (Strab. xvi.1.5; Curt. v.1.25).

e)nto\s de\...h)=n : if the previous words are omitted, these words continue the description of the walls and not of their construction; and thus h)=n proves that when these words were written the walls were no longer standing. (Otherwise the pres. would be used, as in c. 126. 44. Herbst, ibid. p. 552.) Cl. explains xa/lic and ph=los of mortar, ‘neither lime nor clay’; but the words more probably mean rubble, loose stones or clay, opp. to the mega/loi li/qoi and not to the means of joining them. These stones, cut with square angles, were fastened together, not by cement between them, but iron clamps on the outside (ta\ e)/cwqen, see on c. 2. 2) made secure by melted lead in the drilled holes.—
21. ma/lista: see on c. 13. 11. Curtius, Hist. of Gr. II. p. 363, conjectures that a height of 60 feet was intended.
tw=| mege/qei=u(/yei.
a)fista/nai :=a)potre/pein, repel; very unusual. Cf., however, v.45.10.
tw=n a)xreiota/twn: used chiefly of unfitness for military service. Cf. ii.6.17; 44. 20.
prose/keito: implies the resolute carrying out of the plan which prw=tos e)to/lmhsen ei)pei=n, 14. Cf. vii.18.6; viii.52.15; the const. as in vi.89.13; vii.50.31; viii.89.22.
to/n te: and accordingly. See on c. 87. 11.
th=s a)/nw po/lews: Athens as opp. to the harbour. Cf. ii.48.8.
h)\n a)/ra: cf. c. 84. 9.
kataba/ntas: acc., though the dat. precedes. Cf. c. 31. 10; 53. 1; 72. 5.

e)teixi/sqhsan: refers to 1,= th\n po/lin e)tei/xisan, while ta)=lla kateskeua/zonto (impf.) implies the gradual repair and equipment of their houses, during which the following occurrences took place. This relation is expressed by *)aqhnai=oi me\n ou)=n . . . *pausani/as de\ kte(.
Pausanias carries on the war against the Persians.

*pausani/as: as guardian of his first cousin Plistarchus, son of Leonidas, administered the government along with the Proclid (Eurypontid) king, Leotychides. The following table gives the genealogy of the Eurysthenid (Agid) house, so far as we are concerned with it in the history of Thuc.
The narrative is continued from c. 89. § 2.
*)aqhnai=oi: two of the commanders were Aristides and Cimon. Plut. Arist. 23.
*ku/pron: as a chief source of the Persian naval power, Cyprus was naturally attacked by the Greeks.
e)s *buza/ntion: depends on e)stra/teusan without regard to the paratactic intervening clause.—*mh/dwn e)xo/ntwn: see on c. 89. 10.

e)n th=|de th=| h(gemoni/a|: i.e. while Pausanias still held the command; so in c. 128. 17 the capture of Byzantium is ascribed to him immediately after the Cyprian expedition. In vii.15.11 e)n temporal is used with the same noun. See App.
The Lacedaemonians recall Pausanias, and soon cease to take part in the war against the Persians.
biai/ou: arbitrary and arrogant. Cf. iii.36.26.
ou)x h(/kista: see on c. 3. 2.

a)po\ basile/ws: the same const. with e)leuqerou=n in ii.71.10; viii.46.21.—newsti/: see on c. 89. 8. Kirchhoff, Hermes, 11, 11.— 5. kata\ to\ cuggene/s: on the traditional colonization of Ionia from Athens, see c. 2. 26; Hdt. i. 146, 147. Cf. vi.82.17.—e)pitre/pein: see on c. 71. 4.

prosei=xon th\n gnw/mhn: showed great zeal. Cf. vii.15.15. w(s with fut. partic., determining that they would—. The impf. includes the whole conduct of the Athenians during the down
ward course of the career of Pausanias.
au)toi=s: for them, i.e. the Athenians. See for a similar ambiguity, which the use of sfi/si would have removed, c. 116. 16, and cf. v.32.23; vi.35.5; vii.17.16.
metepe/mponto: impf., of the first step taken. Cf. c. 48. 2; 62. 21.— 10. e)punqa/nonto: for the tense, see on c. 64. 6.

kathgorei=to: on the pass. const., see G. 197; H. 819.— tw=n a)fiknoume/nwn: see on c. 91. 3. Cf. C. I. A. I. 45, eu)= poiei= *)aqhnai/ous kai\ i)di/a| kai\ dhmosi/a| to\n a)fiknou/menon. Tac. Hist. ii. 74, venientium a Vitellio militum.

e)fai/neto: the subj. is ‘his behaviour,’ suggested by the context. Cf. ii.65.39; and for a similar comparison of opposed expressions, iii.39.10; iv.95.3; vi.31.33. These show that h)/ before strathgi/a need not be changed into h(.

cune/bh te kte(.: and so it came to pass at the same time. Cf. v.37.21; vi.70.2; with me\n de/, viii.82.15. au)tw=|, which depends on cune/bh, is lost sight of in the second clause. Cf. v. 72. § 1. The position of te shows that au)tw=| kalei=sqai are to be read closely together. For metata/casqai we have in c. 130. 13 the more usual metasth=nai.
stratiwtw=n : almost a partic. Cf. c. 60. 9; iv.28.21.

i)di/a|: with the verbal noun a)dikhma/twn, as in c. 141. 34 with do/casma. “Advs. of time, place, degree are used attrib. with substs. of any kind; but others only with verbal substs. Cf. vi.80.25; viii.64.23.” B. Kühn. 461, 6. —pro/s tina: against this or that man. See App.—hu)qu/nqh: was corrected; here only in this sense. Cf. the noun in Ar. Vesp. 571; Plat. Prot. 326 d.— 17. ta\ me/gista: i.e. offences against the state.—mh\ a)dikei=n: cf. c. 128. 10; G. 263; H. 1029; Kr. Spr. 67, 12, 3. —kathgorei=to de/: i.e. in the general opinion, not in formal action. The subj. of e)do/kei is ‘this charge.’ The further story of Pausanias is in c. 128 ff.—19 *do/rkin: not elsewhere named.

oi(=s: but to these, with adversative force. Cf. 35. 15; 69. 20.—e)fi/esan: permittebant; only here in Thuc. Cf. Soph. El. 631; Xen. Hell. vii.4.7.—ai)sqo/menoi: without expressed obj. Cf. c. 118. 9; 126. 22; 131. 1; ii.25.8; iii.22.22; iv.67.8, etc.

oi( *lakedaimo/nioi: this probably has reference to the Ephors, and the following words, mh\ sfi/sin . . . gi/gnwntai, imply a jealous fear of any attempt at independent action on the part of king or general abroad.

e)chgei=sqai: abs., as c. 76. 3.—e)n tw=| to/te paro/nti: unusual for the common e)n tw=| to/te or e)n tw=| paro/nti. Kr. brackets paro/nti; but the expression is sufficiently defended by later imitation and the corresponding e)n tw=| nu=n paro/nti.
e)pithdei/ous := prosfilei=s, c. 92. 4.
The Athenians accept the hegemony, and arrange the contributions of their allies in money and ships.
e(ko/ntwn tw=n cumma/xwn: here and in vi.76.13, without o)/ntwn, plainly from the partic. origin of e(kw/n.
e)/tacan kte(.: the carrying out of c. 95. 8, ta)=lla/ te...au)toi=s.

a(/s te kte(.: this can refer only to the determination of the character of the contribution, whether money or ships, to be made by the several cities, and not, as Kirchhoff, Hermes, 11, 33, supposes, to the amount of the contributions.

pro\s to\n ba/rbaron: to meet the barbarian, kata\ tou= barba/rou. Schol.— nau=s: i.e. manned ships of war, as supplied at first by all the more important allies.—pro/sxhma: here like pro/fasis, the expressed reason; then, from the frequent misuse of this, the pretended reason. Cf. iii.82.27; v.30.16.—a)mu/nasqai: the aor. in reference to the special purpose. The gen. of the thing requited, as in vi.38.19; with u(pe/r, v.69.10.

For reasons for thinking that this section is interpolated, see App.— 6. *(ellhnotami/ai: with a)rxh/ in appos., as iv.53.8, *kuqhrodi/khs a)rxh/; Xen. Vect. 2. 7, ei) metoikofu/lakas a)rxh\n kaqistai=men. It is common in Greek thus to unite in one expression nouns of a
general and a specific meaning; see on c. 74. 4. Cf. cunoi/kia e(orth/, ii.15.16; mani/h nou=sos, Hdt. vi.75.5; perhaps also qa/naton zhmi/an, ii.24.9. The verb kate/sth agrees with a)rxh/. But Cobet, ad Hyper. p. 63, reads kate/sthsan, bracketing a)rxh/; and so v. H. On this office, which was filled only by Athenians, and on the whole arrangement, which in its first equitable form was ascribed to Aristides (Plut. Arist. 24; Dem. XXIII. 209; Pausan. viii. 52), see Böckh, Publ. Econ. p. 240 ff., 513; on the date Böckh, p. 514, agrees with Krüger, Stud. I. p. 35, in assuming B.C. 476 as the year in which the arrangements were carried into execution.

to\n fo/ron: this term, properly the tribute paid by foreigners, was applied to this general contribution. The name having become odious through the oppression of later years, after the Peloponnesian war the term sunta/ceis was introduced. Böckh. ibid. p. 541; Schömann, Gr. Alt. II. 99.
taxqei/s: though belonging to prw=tos, placed after the subst. See on c. 11. 19.

*dh=los: as being the national sanctuary of all Hellenes. About Ol. 80. 1, B.C. 460, the treasury was transferred to the Acropolis at Athens.—ai( cu/nodoi e)gi/gnonto:=ta\s cuno/dous e)poiou=nto=cunh/|esan (see on c. 73. 1), and so the const. e)s to\ i(eron, as in iii.104.15.
Reasons why the following brief narrative of exents between the Persian and Peloponnesian wars is inserted.
au)tono/mwn: pred.=e)f) w(=|te au)tou\s au)tono/mous ei)=nai.
to\ prw=ton : belongs to au)tono/mwn.

a)po/ : cf. c. 91. 28.—bouleuo/ntwn: see on c. 85. 5.— 3. tosa/de e)ph=lqon: with these words Thuc. passes from the beginning of the Athenian hegemony, narrated in c. 89-96, to the history of its development, during the so-called penthkontaeti/a, c. 98-117. This he presents in three aspects: (1) pro\s to\n ba/rbaron, (2) pro\s tou\s sfete/rous cumma/xous newteri/zontas, (3) pro\s tou\s a)ei\ prostugxa/nontas *peloponnhsi/wn.

e)ph=lqon : implies a systematic progress; they undertook the following (tosa/de) series of enterprises.—diaxeiri/sei: more forcible than dioikh/sei; it appears not to occur again till the later rhetoricians, Aristides, Libanius, etc. It implies civil administration of all kinds, especially of finance, as Harpocr. describes the *(ellhnotami/ai as those oi(\ diexei/rizon ta\ xrh/mata. Ullrich, Hell. Kr. p. 12.

pragma/twn: includes all political measures,
            external and internal, which exalted the power of Athens.—metacu\
             kte(.: with inversion of the order of time; see 
 on c. 118. 6. So in relations of place, ii.77.10; iii.29.6; v.66.5; vi.72.2; viii.88.10; 108. 3.
a(\ e)ge/neto au)toi=s: refers to tosa/de,=a(\ u(p) au)tw=n e)pra/xqh.
e)n e(ka/stw| : neut.,=e)n e(ka/stw| pra/gmati o(\ e)ge/neto, referring to the various attempts of the allies to regain independence, of which examples are found in c. 114 ff.
e)/graya kte(.: on the aor., see on c. I. 1. The second expression is a more precise extension of the first.—au)ta/: see on c. I. 10; 22. 15; 26. 16.
e)kbolh/n:=the later die/codos, pare/kbasis: excessus, egressio; Quint. iii.9.4; probably not used elsewhere by Attic writers, but recurring in Arrian, Dio C., and Plut. So e)klipe/s in 9.
xwri/on: locus, pars narrationis. Cf. Lycurg. 31.
cuneti/qesan: see on c. 21. 4.

tou/twn: refers to au)ta/, 7, and this is also subj. of e)/xei in 13.—o(/sper kai\ h(/yato: see on c. 15. 7. Cf. c. 105. 17; ii.51.5; iv.98.9; vi.87.15.—th=| *)attikh=| cuggrafh=|: called in the citations of grammarians *)atqi/s and *)atqi/des. With the oldest legends it included historical notices reaching down to the end of the Peloponnesian war. See C. Müller, Frag. Hist. Graec. I. p. xxiv. ff., who gives his dates B.C. 482-397.
ama de\ kai/: refers to dia\ to/de, 8.

a)po/deicin e)/xei : sc. au)ta/, 7. “These events disclose the way in which the power of Athens was established.” e)/xei=pare/xei. Cf. c. 140. 27; ii.61.9; 87. 3; iii.53.12; iv.95.3; 126. 17, 23. For a)po/deicin, cf. Hdt. i. 11.— th=s a)rxh=s...e)n oi(/w| tro/pw| kate/sth : see on c. 23. 27. For e)n, cf. c. 77. 2; 130. 5; vii.67.15.
Expeditions of the Athenians against Eïon, Scyros, Carystus, and Naxos, which was the first of the allies to lose its independence.
On the chronology of this period, see App.

*)hio/na: which commands the mouth of the Strymon, became the Athenian base for further operations in Thrace.—*mh/dwn e)xo/ntwn: see on c. 89. 10. On the gallant resistance of the Persian governor Boges, see Hdt. vii. 107.
h)ndrapo/disan: properly of the inhabitants. The mid. form occurs once, in iv.48.21; elsewhere the act.

kai\ w)/|kisan au)toi/: to be referred to both the preceding places, since Eïon undoubtedly was occupied by Athenian cleruchs. For such a new settlement w)/|kisan is the proper term. Cf. vi.3.12; and see on c. 4. 3.

*karusti/ous: on the southern coast of Euboea; the only place of the island which had not yet joined the league. Kirchhoff, Herm. 11, p. 20.— 6. kai\ xro/nw| cune/bhsan: change of subj. in parataxis. Cf. c. 26. 16; 61. 1. From this time Euboea seems to have remained quietly in the Athenian alliance till 445, c. 114. MüllerStrübing, p. 85.
e)pole/mhsan: at the time that Themistocles made his way to Asia, c. 137. § 2.

paresth/santo: see on c. 29. 22.—prw/th te au(/th po/lis cummaxi/s: see on c. I. 8; but here and in vii.85.17, the sup. stands first. The subj. is au(/th alone, and po/lis cummaxi/s stands in a pred. relation, which approximates to a gen. pl. For te, cf. c. 4. 5; 5. 19; 92. 7.

to\ kaqesthko/s: the established arrangement as described in c. 96; here abs. as in vii.67.10. Cf. c. 76. 11; iv.97.10.— e)doulw/qh: as doulei/a, c. 8. 15, of political subjection. See on this relation, Böckh, Publ. Econ. p. 530.
w(s e(ka/sth| cune/bh: indicates the varying circumstances under which the same fate befell different places.
In consequence of these encroachments, the hegemony of the Athenians became more and more disliked.
e)/kdeiai: arrears. Suidas explains, e)/kdeia/ e)sti to\ me/ros katabalei=n w(=n o)fei/lei tis, e)/ndeia de\ to\ mhde\n o(/lws katabalei=n. Cf. Dem. XXXII. 30.

lipostra/tion: in such words lip- is to be preferred to leip-. See Dind. in Thesaurus s.v. leipandre/w, and Cobet, N. L. p. 78. The point is decided not by Mss. but by the poets. Plut., Cim. 11, says, a)/ndras kai\ nau=s w(s e)ta/xqhsan ou) parei=xon. In vi.76.15, the fem. lipostrati/a is applied to a course of such conduct, the neut. here to failure in particular cases. It could apply only to those allies who had to furnish independent contingents, and was therefore rare; accordingly, ei)/ tw| e)ge/neto. The a)posta/seis were induced mainly by the knowledge that such short-comings would be severely visited by the Athenians; and this leads to the following, oi( ga\r *)aqhnai=oi a)kribw=s e)/prasson, which probably has the general sense of “exercising the
hegemony in a strict manner” (cf. iii.66.1; iv.114.23); for pra/ssein without an express object, like xrh/mata (viii.5.18), could hardly mean ‘exacted’ payment, etc.; which latter sense too would not well agree with lipostra/tion . . . e)ge/neto. The consequence of this strictness is expressed in luphroi\ h)=san (c. 76. 5; vi.18.6), and its exercise in ou)k ei)wqo/sin . . . a)na/gkas. Here the better Mss. read prosagago/ntes, but the pres. only is suitable to express systematic dealing.

a)na/gkas: severe measures of compulsion, joined with prosa/gein like mhxana/s. Cf. ii.76.17; iv.100.7; vii.25.23.—h)=san a)/rxontes: and in fact they exercised their authority. On the periphrasis, see App. on c. I. 1, and Am. J. of Ph. IV. p. 302.
o(moi/ws: Schol., w(s e)n a)rxh=| meta\ to\n *pausani/an.
e)n h(donh=| : with satisfaction to the allies. Cf. iii.9.4, e)n h(donh=| e)/xein.

ou)/te...i)/sou : supply a)ll' w(s kratou=ntes. custrateu/ein is applied to the leading state also in v.81.6; it seems impossible to suppose that cu/mmaxoi is subj. here, between the two clauses relating to the Athenians. As in c. 140. 31; iii.10.12, a)po\ tou= i)/sou implies the recognition of mutual rights.
prosa/gesqai: = parasth/sasqai. Cf. vi.94.14; viii.107.7.— 9. ai)/tioi e)ge/nonto: had been to blame. See on c. 50. 23.
a)p' oi)/kou: far from home. Cf. c. 7. 6; 76. 7; Eur. I. T. 481.

e)ta/canto: got themselves rated. ta/casqai is used with acc. of sum to be paid, c. 108. 14; with inf. c. 117. 16; without either, iii.70.19; with both, c. 101. 14; iii.50.10. So here the essential change in the relation is expressed by xrh/mata e)ta/canto, and the more definite statement by a)nti\ tw=n new=n . . . fe/rein.
i(knou/menon : proper, suitable (commonly, to\ e)piba/llon, to\ gigno/menon); the simple verb in Attic prose only in this form and sense.

kai\ toi=s me\n kte(.: and consequently, etc. Cf. c. 50. 21; 51. 16. This explains r(a/|dion prosa/gesqai h)=n au)toi=s of 7, for which the allies were themselves in fault.— 13. cumfe/roien: iterative opt., of what occurred every year. Cf. c. 50. 2. GMT. 62; H. 914 B.
Battle on the Eurymedon; conflicts with the Thasians; serious defeat of the Athenians in Thrace.
e)p' *eu)rume/donti: Diod. xi. 60; Plut. Cim. 12. Cf. the epigram of Simonides (but see Bergk, Poetae Lyrici Graeci, III^{4}, p. 489 ff.), Anth. Pal. vii. 296, which probably refers to this battle.
e)ni/kwn: were victorious. Cf. c. 13. 32; 49. 24.
a)mfo/tera: see on c. 13. 23.
ei(=lon...kai\ die/fqeiran : on the order see on c. 91. 26.

ta\s pa/sas: in all. Cf. c. 60. 6.—e)s diakosi/as: Diod. xi.60.7, and Lycurg. c. Leocr. 72, speak of 100 ships, probably following line 6 of the epigram. Good Mss. have e)s ta\s diakosi/as. But the pleonastic use of the art. with numerals, except in the case of divisions, as in c. 116. 2, 8, seems foreign to Thuc. Kr. on Dion. Hist. p. 303, note 69. Kr. Spr. 50, 2, 8, 9.
xro/nw| de/: here de/ of few Mss. is to be preferred to the better attested te in view of the transition to a disconnected topic.
peri\ tw=n...meta/llou : see Hdt. vi. 46, 47. The sing. also in c. 101. 15; Hdt. iv.185.5; v.17.8. Kr. Spr. 44, 1, 1; Kühn. 347, 1.
e)ne/monto: see on c. 2. 6.
a)pe/bhsan: the narrative is resumed in c. 101. 1.
e)pi\ de\ *strumo/na: this occurred (iv. 102. § 3) 29 years before the successful settlement of the Athenians at Amphipolis, which took place in Ol. 85. 4; B.C. 437.
*)amfi/polin: so called from its position, described in iv. 102. § 4.

au)toi/: opp. to the previous possessors, the Edonians. If the order had been a(\s ei)=xon *)hdwnoi/, au)toi\ e)kra/thsan, the use of the pron. would not have been surprising. Cf. c. 98. 4; 114. 16; iii.23.4.—e)kra/thsan, diefqa/rhsan: inaccurately connected with pe/myantes; but the collective name oi( *)aqhnai=oi, which is implied, permits a reference both to the commanding whole
and the executing part. Cf. c. 90. 1.

th=s *qra/|khs: the gen. of the country placed before the designated portion. So especially when the country has been previously named.—*drabhskw=|: this accentuation (for *drabh/skw|) is confirmed by Herodian, i. p. 153.

u(po\ tw=n *qra|kw=n cumpa/ntwn: defined by the following rel. sentence. See App.—oi(=s...ktizo/menon : for whom this point if occupied by the Athenians was a constant menace of war. Cf. iv.8.34; and v.52.16, oi(=s h)=n e)n bla/bh| teixisqe\n [to\ *(ri/on]. For this const. of the partic. (cf. the Latin ademptus Hector, Hor. Car. ii.4.10: Kühn. L. G. II. § 136, 5), see Kr.
