Spr. 50, 11, 3. Cf. Pind. Ol. VIII. 65; Pyth. XI. 22; Aesch. Pers. 727; Thuc. i.6.5; 23. 24; ii.49.16; vi.3.11; Dem. XVIII. 32, 57; Lys. III 13. The addition, ai( *)enne/a o(doi/, already twice named, is rightly rejected as a gloss by Cobet.
The Thasians reduced by the Athenians; the Lacedaemonians prevented from helping them by the revolt of the Messenians.
e)pekalou=nto: cf. c. 33. 15; 102. 2; iii.65.9; vi.18.9.—e)ke/leuon: see on c. 26. 1.
kru/fa tw=n *)aqhnai/wn: cf. c. 128. 21; 138. 29; ii.80.34; viii.7.4.
e)/mellon: sc. e)sbalei=n.
seismou= : see Plut. Cim. 16. 6.

au)toi=s: see on c. 89. 14.—perioi/kwn: i.e. the old inhabitants, chiefly of Achaean stock, who had been reduced to a condition of dependence (not slavery) by the Dorians. Müller, Dor. Bk. III. 16 ff.

e)s *)iqw/mhn a)pe/sthsan: see on c. 87. 7; iii.54.18. On the position of Ithome, “the natural fortress of all Messenia,” see Curtius, Pelop. II. p. 137 ff.; on Thuria, ibid. p. 161. Aethaea, acc. to Steph. Byz., *ai)qai/a, to\ e)qniko\n *ai)qaieu/s (more correct than *ai)qeei=s of our Mss.), po/lis *lakwnikh=s, mi/a tw=n e(kato/n. *qoukudi/dhs prw/th|. Müller, Dor. II. 2, p. 18.—plei=stoi: pred. The descendants of the Messenians of old times, who had in the first war been enslaved, formed the largest part of the Helot-class, and so they were called collectively (oi( pa/ntes) Messenians, though there were some who were sprung from Achaean inhabitants of Laconia, reduced after repeated risings.

to/te: refers to the mythical time of the first Messenian war, implied in palaiw=n. Cf. iii.69.2; iv.46.5; v.4.14; vii. 31.
12; viii.20.2; 73. 4.
doulwqe/ntwn: for the position of the attrib. partic., cf. c. 11. 19; 96. 8.

w(molo/ghsan: agreed to surrender. Cf. c. 108. 13; v.4.8; iv.69.19, cune/bhsan. The conditions of the submission here, c. 108. 13; 115. 3; 117. 14, are expressed by aor. partics., no doubt in the view that the o(mologi/a, the complete agreement, was perfected only when these points were performed. So Madvig (Bemerkungen zur Syntax, p. 47) explains the unusual partic. GMT. 24, N. 3.

xrh/mata/ te: the te here and that in 14 are not correlative with the following kai/, but add respectively the third and fourth member of the conditions. See on c. 76. 12. a)poo=ou=nai (aor., of the single case) depends on e)/dei, and fe/rein (of the established relation) depends on taca/menoi, with xrh/mata placed first as obj. of both taca/menoi and fe/rein. See on c. 99. 11.
th/n te h)/peiron kte(.: see c. 100. § 2.
The Athenians are summoned by the Lacedaemonians to their aid, but are soon mistrusted and dismissed. In displeasure they make an alliance with the Argives and Thessalians.
a)/llous: the Aeginetans, ii.27.9; Plataeans, iii.54.17; Mantinaeans, Xen. Hell. v.2.3.

*ki/mwnos: see Plut. Cim. 16. 6; Ar. Lys. 1143, e)lqw
 de\ su
 o(pli/taisi tetrakisxili/ois *ki/mwn o(/lhn e)/swse th
 *lakedai/mona.
e)pekale/santo: for the repetition, cf. c. 88. 1.—teixomaxei=n: cf. Hdt. ix.70.8, tw=n *lakedaimoni/wn ou)k e)pistame/nwn teixomaxe/ein.

toi=s de\...e)fai/neto : th=s de/, which is read by P. and v. H., has not sufficient Ms. authority. Cl. thinks the reference is to the Athenians, whose reputation was not sustained by success in this case, toi=s de/ not being in opp. to au)tou/s, but placing the second clause in contrast with the first. For this, he compares c. 81. 3; 86. 9; iv.73.22; 76. 27. But it is better, with Kr. and Sh., to refer toi=s de/ to the Lacedaemonians (in opp. to the subj. of e)do/koun), “who found out by the length of the siege their own incompetence; for had they had any skill in that
way, they would have taken the place by force.” Cf. c. 11. 5. Thus this section gives the reason for the invitation to the Athenians on both sides. For the dat., cf. c. 48. 9; 89. 14; iv.26.24; and for the pl. e)ndea=, see on c. 7. 2; ii.56.4; iii.88.4; v.8.6. tou/tou=tou= teixomaxei=n.

bi/a| : with ai(rei=n, or the pass. a(li/skesqai in 10, is opp. to o(mologi/a| parasth/sasqai or prosxwrei=n (cf. v.17.14), and implies violent capture, whether by storm or otherwise. See on c. 11. 9.
diafora\...fanera\ e)ge/neto : in contrast with c. 92. 6, a)dh/lws h)/xqonto. 10. to\ tolmhro/n : cf. ii.87.22, and see on c. 36. 3.
kai\ a(/ma: see on c. 2. 8, “particularly when they took into consideration that they were of a different stock.” After this, mh/ ti also depends on dei/santes.
h)=n paramei/nwsin : implies that their stay was not long. Cf. Paus. iv.24.6, u(po\ th=s u(poyi/as a)pope/myasqai met) ou) polu\ e)c *)iqw/mhs.
newteri/swsi : see on c. 58. 3; here, that they might join the insurgents against the Lacedaemonians.
ou) dhlou=ntes: cf. c. 82. 4; 90. 10.

e)/gnwsan a)popempo/menoi: for partic. after verb of knowing, see G. 280; H. 982.—ou)k e)pi\ tw=| belti/oni lo/gw|: not on the more creditable ground, just assigned, viz. o(/ti ou)de\n . . . e)/ti. e)pi/ with dat. of the motive of an action. Cf. c. 69. 32; Hdt. viii.5.16.
u(po/ptou: neut. Cf. c. 90. 10, =u(poyi/as tino/s taken in the concrete.

deino\n poihsa/menoi: being provoked; very frequent in Hdt.; e.g. i.13.3; 127. 2; ii.133.4; 161. 15; iii.155.8; iv.33.20; v.33.9; 42. 7; 87. 10. In Thuc. only here and vi.60.21. But in v.42.15, deina\ poiei=n, as Hdt. ii.121.2; iii.14.22; v.41.9.— ou)k a)ciw/santes: after the analogy of ou) fa/nai, ou)k e)a=n, either in reference to the subj., ‘regarding as unworthy,’ being indignant at: so here and iii.61.12; iv.86.7; or in regard to another, ‘not to expect from one.’ Cf. c. 136. 12; ii.89.2; iii.44.12; iv.40.3; viii.73.20. See on c. 22. 9.

e)pi\ tw=| *mh/dw|: rare for the acc. So iii. 63.
3. Cf. c. 40. 24.—pro\s au)tou/s: sc. tou\s *lakedaimoni/ous, placed at the end. Cf. iv.107.6; vii.70.11.
a)mfote/rois: i.e. the Athenians and the Argives.

kate/sth: sing., construed with the nearer noun. Cf. v.22.14. A further consequence of the displeasure of the Athenians was the banishment of Cimon (Plut. Cim. 17. 5) and the increased influence of Pericles and Ephialtes.
The Messenians allowed to depart from Ithome, and placed by the Athenians in Naupactus. Megara joins the Athenians to the indignation of the Corinthians.
deka/tw| e)/tei: so all Mss.; but Cl. follows Kr., Stud. I. p. 156-161, in reading teta/rtw|. See App. on c. 98. 1.

e)f' w(=| te: on condition that; in c. 113. 13; 126. 35; iv.30.19, e)f' w(=|, always with fut. indic. The form e)f' w(=| te is defended by passages in Plat., Hdt., and Xen. The orators and Plat. have only the inf., pres. or aor. (fut. only in Aeschin. III. 114); Hdt. and Xen. have fut. indic. and pres. or aor. inf. GMT. 65, 2; H. 999 a; Kühn. 584, note 3; Madvig, Synt. 103, R. 3. Another mode of expressing the conditions of a contract is seen in c. 101. 12.

ei)=nai: depends remotely on cune/bhsan. Cf. c. 117. 17. But the inf. is regular in indir. disc., for the imv. dou=lon is added to threaten the returning Messenians with a harder fate than they had endured as Perioeci.— 6. pro\ tou=: belongs to h)=n. They had had this oracle long ago.—*)iqwmh/ta: Thuc. has this Doric ending of gen. also in v.25.3; vi.4.17; viii.58.2.
a)fie/nai: depending on the command implied in xrhsth/rion.
kat' e)/xqos h)/dh: in consequence of the enmity already existing (c. 102. § 4). See on c. 30. 20.

e)s *nau/pakton katw/|kisan: cf. vi.7.6; 50. 18; with e)n, v.35.33. This settlement at the entrance of the Corinthian gulf was subsequently very important. See ii. 69; 91; iii. 102; iv. 41.—h(|rhko/tes newsti/: this fact is not further mentioned by Thuc., but attributed by Diod. xi.84.7, to the expedition of
Tolmidas. Kr. Stud. I. p. 201, note.

e)xo/ntwn: see on c. 94. 6; 98. 1. Curtius, Hermes, 10, p. 239, remarks correctly that Thuc. by this phrase always indicates an occupation connected with military operations. He refers this passage, therefore, with great probability to the Locrian Synoecismus in Naupactus, of which we are informed in an inscription (published 1869 by Oeconomides, and by W. Vischer, Rhein. Mus., 1871, p. 39 ff.; Hicks, No. 63). The fact that the Ozolian Locrians only are here mentioned, and not the Opuntian also, is explained by the predominant position of the former in their own district.
kai\ *megarh=s: i.e. as well as the Argives and Thessalians.

peri\ gh=s o(/rwn: without art., the statement being general. So c. 122. 9; iv.92.21. Cf. c. 78. 12.—pole/mw| katei=xon: oppressed with war. This unusual expression probably refers rather to a constant threat of war than to continuous hostilities.

kai\ e)/sxon: got possession of, ingressive; see on c. 12. 11. The Athenians placed there a garrison (e)frou/roun au)toi/: cf. c. 111. 11, ei)=xon de\ au)toi\ ta\s *phga/s), which was destroyed, c. 114. 5. Pegae was the Megarian harbour on the Corinthian gulf; Nisaea, a nearer one, on the Saronic.
ou)x h(/kista: see on c. 3. 2.—h)/rcato prw=ton: so often joined to emphasize the moment of beginning. Cf. ii.36.1; 47. 8; 68. 5; iii.86.7; vi.46.6.
The Athenians support the revolt of the Egyptians against the Persians with 200 ships.

*)ina/rws: acc. to Hdt. vii.7.6, Inaros began his insurrection with the assassination of the Persian governor, Achaemenes, the brother of Xerxes, who had been sent there after the suppression of the revolt of B.C. 486. Psammitichus is probably the basileu\s th=s *libu/hs mentioned as friendly to the Athenians by the Schol. on Ar. Vesp. 718.

*marei/as: Marea, on the southern bank of Lake Mareotis. Pharus, the island off the Canopic mouth of the Nile, afterwards united by a mole with Alexandria, and famous for its lighthouse. Thuc. uses this well-known place to define the position of Marea.—u(pe/r: with gen., above, further inland. Cf. c. 112. 9; 137. 16.

*)artace/rcou: (some
Mss. have *)artoce/rcou here; c. 137. 21; iv.50.14) succeeded Xerxes B.C. 465. See on c. 137. 21.
e)phga/geto: see on c. 3. 9. Cf. c. 114. 7; iii.34.8; 82. 5.
oi( de\...ga/r : see on c. 31. 7.— strateuo/menoi: probably, after the reduction of a large portion of the island (c. 94. 5), an Athenian force had been stationed there.
a)napleu/santes: i.e. up stream. Cf. Hdt. ii.4.19, a)na/ploos a)po\ qala/sshs a)na\ to\n potamo/n.
tw=n du/o merw=n : i.e. of three. See on c. 74. 6.
oi( mh\ cunaposta/ntes: i.e. ei)/ tines mh\ cunape/sthsan.
. Battles of the Athenians with the Corinthians and the Aeginetans.

*(alia=s: *(alih=s, -e/wn, -eu=si, -a=s, the correct form of the name, acc. to Hdt. vii.137.12; Xen. Hell. vi.2.3; and Böckh, Inscr. I. No. 165. It lay on the southern coast of the Argive peninsula (Curtius, Pelop. II. 461, 579). The district is called h( *(alia/s in ii.56.14.
*kekrufalei/a|: an island in the Saronic gulf, between Aegina and Epidaurus.

*peloponnhsi/wn: i.e. the Corinthians and Epidaurians, perhaps with the Halians and other inhabitants of the Acte.—kai\ e)ni/kwn *)aqhnai=oi: and this time the Athenians were victorious, retaliation being indicated by the repetition of the same words.

*lewkra/tous: acc. to Plut. Arist.
20. 1, he was a general also at Plataea.
pro/teron...e)pikou/rous : i.e. in the battle of § 1; an auxiliary contingent sent by the authorities of the league.
ta\ a)/kra th=s *geranei/as: they thus controlled the passage of the Isthmus. Curtius, Pel. I. 8; II. 551.

h)\n de\ kai/: kai/, actually, suggests a doubt as to the occurrence; see on c. 15. 7.—a)nasth/sesqai: cf. vii.49.10; 50. 22; viii.27.28; applied to the removal of a force from a post occupied for some considerable time.
pro\s *ai)gi/nh|: i.e. before the city of Aegina, which they were besieging, 9.
tw=n de\ e)k th=s po/lews: proleptic, as c. 8. 9; 18. 1; 63. 8; due to the influence of a)fiknou=ntai (G. 191, N. 6; H. 788; Kühn. 448), but peculiar in the addition of u(poloi/pwn.
oi(/ te...new/tatoi : these performed military service only in extraordinary cases; the former were between 50 and 60, the latter below 20 years of age. Gilbert, Griech. Alt. I. p. 301.
*murwni/dou: a great name among the leaders of the older generation. See c. 108. 7; iv.95.12; Ar. Eccl. 302; Lys. 801; Plut. Per. 16. 3.
i)sorro/pou: of indecisive engagements. Cf. vii.71.2.
au)toi/: placed for emphasis before e(ka/teroi.
ou)k e)/lasson e)/xein : cf. ii.22.12; iii.5.7; iv.25.20; vii.5.16; 36. 16; viii.61.17.—e)n tw=| e)/rgw|: in the action. Cf. c. 107. 28; ii.89.42; iv.32.24; viii.42.12.
e)kra/thsan: the position implies “in fact they had got the better.” 26. kakizo/menoi: cf. ii.21.23.

paraskeuasa/menoi...e)lqo/ntes : when after about twelve days' preparation they
again marched out: the acc. h(me/ras with paraskeuasa/menoi, and this subordinate to e)lqo/ntes. St. and B. follow Madvig in reading h(me/rais; but this would isolate paraskeuasa/menoi too much.

a)nqi/stasan...diafqei/rousi : the two sentences in parataxis (cf. c. 26. 16; 61. 1), in the same temporal relation as c. 48. 2, 3, the thing attempted being expressed by the impf., and its interruption by the pres. For kai\ au)toi/, see on c. 50. 18.
e)kbohqh/santes: only here in Thuc., and in Hdt. only in ix.26.11; frequent in later writers.
toi=s a)/llois: i.e. those who meanwhile had come to aid their friends.
The Athenians cut off a detachment of the Corinthians.
nikw/menoi: partic. pres. corresponding to e)ni/kwn (c. 13. 31; 49. 24; iii.8.5); so c. 70. 17; ii.47.17; 51. 23; 60. 22; v.73.12; vii.23.13. It is here pred. to u(pexw/roun.

e)/s tou xwri/on i)diw/tou : for the order, cf. c. 45. 8; 53. 17.—w(=|: refers to xwri/w|, and is probably governed directly by e)/tuxen, sc. o)/n (see on c. 32. 9; and cf. Lys. XXIV 5; and Thompson on Plat. Phaedr. 263 c) with periei=rgon as additional pred. Herbst, Philol. 1866, p. 651, makes au)tw=n me/ros ou)k o)li/gon, 2, antec. to w(=|, taken as dat. of interest to e)/tuxe (= ‘met’) and ou)k h)=n e)/codos. But this is very unlikely, in view of vii.81.22, a)neilhqe/ntes e)/s ti xwri/on, w(=| ku/klw| me\n teixi/on perih=n.
kai\ ou)k h)=n e)/codos : stands as a second member of the relative sentence, as if kai\ e)c ou(=. See on c. 42. 2; 68. 15; ii.4.25.
ei)=rgon: Schol., e)kw/luon e)celqei=n.
toi=s o(pli/tais : cf. c. 48. 12; 49. 18. kata\ pro/swpon and peristh/santes ku/klw| are opposed.
kate/leusan: i.e. with such stones as were at hand, with or without slings.
to\ plh=qos: the main body; opp. to the me/ros ou)k o)li/gon.

au)toi=s : cf. c. 102. 1. Böckh, Inscr. I. No. 165, p. 292; C. I.
A. I. 433; Hicks, No. 191, for a remarkable record of the events recorded in the three last chapters, naming the citizens of the tribe Erechtheis who fell in these campaigns: *)erexqhi/dos oi(/de e)n tw=| pole/mw| a)pe/qanon e)n *ku/prw|, e)n *ai)gu/ptw|, e)n *foini/kh|, e)n *(alieu=sin, e)n *ai)gi/nh|, *megaroi= tou= au)tou= e)niautou=. Thuc. does not notice the Phoenician affair, nor the Inscr. the action off Cecryphaleia. Böckh assumes for these events the civil year, Ol. 80. 3, B.C. 458-7; Kr. Stud. I. p. 162, B.C. 460, from spring to autumn; Ol. 79. 4-80. 1.
The long walls at Athens begun; the Lacedaemonians, who had gone to support the Dorians, hindered on their return by the Athenians.

h)/rcanto: the completion is mentioned in c. 108. 12. In this connexion of city and harbour, which identified the power of Athens with the sea, the democracy recognized the surest guarantee of its stability.

to\ *falhro/nde: of 35 stades; to\ e)s *peiraia=: of 40 stades. See ii. 13. § 7. The latter afterwards consisted of a double wall (to\ bo/reion kai\ to\ no/tion). But at first only the northern line was constructed; the southern one (to\ dia\ me/sou tei=xos) was added about B.C. 440, by the advice of Pericles. Plat. Gorg. 455 e, and Curtius, Zu den Sieben Karten, p. 33.
*dwria=s: applied both to district and inhabitants; and so the appos. th\n mhtro/polin, as in iii.92.9. Cf. Hdt. viii.31.7 (who, c. 43. 8, mentions a fourth town, Pindus); Strab. x.4.6.
*nikomh/dous: see on c. 94. 1.
basile/ws: appos. to *pleistoa/naktos.
a)pexw/roun : they began their return march. See on c. 87. 1.

dia\ tou= *krisai/ou ko/lpou: they may have intended to take ship at Cirrha, as Cl. suggests; but Thuc. always uses this name for the Corinthian gulf. See ii.69.4; 83. 2; 92. 22; 93. 1; iv.76.10. For the order of words, see on c. 77. 4.

e)/mellon kwlu/sein: it was to be expected that they would hinder. Thuc. uses the fut. inf. after me/llein (regarded
as a verb of thinking) in preference to the pres. (as after a verb of will). Cf. c. 10. 31; 22. 2; 114. 4; 130. 10; 132. 30; 134. 3; etc. Pres. and fut. together, vi.42.3. The Mss. vary as usual.
*me/gara kai\ *phga/s: see c. 103. 13.—poreu/esqai: in c. 26. 5 with pezh=|, of a march by land. badi/zein is usually opp. to plei=n.
du/sodos : occurs here only. Curtius, Pelop. II. 552.
kai\ to/te: in addition to the natural difficulties of that route, active opposition on the part of the Athenians was threatened.—kai\ tau/th|: i.e. as well as kata\ qi/lassan, 11.
o(/tw| tro/pw|: with fut. indic., for the more usual o(/pws. So iv.128.23; vi.11.25; 44. 23; viii.43.12; 48. 23; 63. 20.

to\ de/ ti kai/: (in 25 kai/ ti kai/) adds a collateral reason; and besides. Cf. c. 118. 12; vii.48.7.—a)/ndres tw=n *)aqhnai/wn: i.e. of the aristocratical party. For the use of a)/ndres for tines, see on vi.10.5.— 20. e)ph=gon: were seeking to introduce. So the act. in ii.85.21; viii.46.9; though usually the mid.—dh=mon: the democratic constitution; oftener with katalu/ein, kata/lusis: see iii.81.20; v.76.6; 81. 8; vi.27.11; 28. 10; viii.49.5; 54. 17; 64. 9; 65. 2; 68. 2, 27; 86. 8, 47. katapau/ein also of political changes, v.26.3; viii.97.5. The long walls would greatly strengthen the democracy.

e)boh/qhsan: (a) bohqei=n e)pi/ tinas=‘to carry force against’ them; (b) e)pi\(e)s)to/pon, ‘to carry aid to’ it. Arn. Cf. (a) iii.110.8; iv.25.32; 108. 28; (b) iii.97.14; iv.8.3; 42. 15; 72. 2; vi.65.20; vii.18.4; viii.60.15.—pandhmei/: includes either the whole population, as c. 73. 22; 90. 22; v.82.26; or the whole military force, as here, ii.31.2; v.64.6. In this case it appears that even the force in possession of Geraneia was withdrawn.
w(s e(/kastoi: cf. c. 67. 13.
o(/ph| die/lqwsin: deliberative subjv., as ii.4.29; 52. 11; iii.112.22.

tou= dh/mou: Kr. conjectures pou dh/mou, because dh=mos is often used
in this sense without the art., and here katalu/sews is without it. But dh=mos, the democratical constitution (besides the places cited by Kr. and P.), has the art. in v.76.5; viii.54.17; 68. 3, 14; and Thuc. often omits the art. with a governing subst. when a gen. precedes. Cf. c. 3. 1; 11. 2; 36. 11.—u(poyi/a|: after nomi/santes; see on c. 80. 3, where the order is reversed.

toi=s *)aqhnai/ois: see on c. 13. 12.—kata\ to\ cummaxiko/n: see c. 102. 21; ii.22.17. The word is rare, except in Thuc. Cf. ii.101.15; iii.3.19; 91. 7; iv.61.15; v.6.6; etc.—oi(\ mete/sthsan: rel. clause with adversative force; but these passed over. See on c. 35. 15.
The Athenians are defeated by the Lacedaemonians at Tanagra; as two months later the Boeotians are by the Athenians at Oenophyta.

*tana/gra|: on the Asopus, near the Attic border.—e)ni/kwn: this positive assertion must outweigh the opposing statements of later writers (Plat. Menex. 242 b; Diod. xi.81.6; Justin. iii. 6), who represent the result differently. A favourable consequence of this defeat was the recall of Cimon (see on c. 102. 22) on the motion of Pericles. Plut. Cim. 17. 10; Per. 10. 3.
dendrotomh/santes: not to be changed with v. H. into -koph/santes, though hardly occurring elsewhere. Metaphorical in Ar. Pax, 747. The reference is specially to the destruction of vines and olives.
deute/ra|...h(me/ra| : by this precise date and the condensed brevity of the account, Thuc. indicates the surprising character of these successes.
*oi)nofu/tois: Schol., xwri/on th=s *boiwti/as, of uncertain position. Kiepert marks it on the Asopus, a few miles east of Tanagra.

e)kra/thsan: not so much by further victories as by the support given to the democratical faction in the various towns, whose preponderance lasted till the battle of Coronea, B.C. 446, c. 113. —th=s xw/ras th=s *boiwti/as: i.e. the country except Thebes, but Grote, Hist. of Gr., V. c. 45, p. 187, includes Thebes; on p. 202 he quotes Arist. Pol. v.3.5 (1302 b, 29) as implying that a democracy was established there also at this time.

periei=lon: for the usual kaqei=lon; again in
14 and iv.51.1; 133. 2.

o(mh/rous: Curtius, Herm. 10, p. 239, considers that this was a punishment for the participation of these Locrians in the undertaking directed against Athenian interests, referred to on c. 103. § 3.—tou\s plousiwta/tous: for the position, cf. in 12 ta\ makra/, added as a supplementary explanation.— 12. ta/ te tei/xh: the last member of the enumeration. Cf. c. 67. 6; 69. 3; 76. 12; 90. 7; and so in 14, fo/ron te.
w(molo/ghsan: see on c. 101. 12. This was after a siege of nearly three years; see c. 105. 9. P. follows Diod. XI. 78. 5, who makes it last nine months only.
*tolmi/dou: son of Tolmaeus. On names from similar stems, see on c. 29. 7.
to\ new/rion: Gythium, see Paus. i.27.5; at the northwest corner of the Laconian gulf, now Marathonisi, Curtius, Pel. II. 270.

*xalki/da: no doubt the place mentioned in ii.83.18 near the mouth of the Evenus in Aetolia, which was then in the hands of the Corinthians. The Schol. wrongly places it in Acarnania.—a)poba/sei th=s gh=s: cf. para/plous th=s *)itali/as, c. 36. 11; gh=s patrw/|as no/stos, Eur. I. T. 1066; in adpulsu litoris, Tac. Hist. ii. 59. Kühn. 414, 4.

ma/xh| e)kra/thsan: Thuc. joins kratei=n with the acc. when it is used with ma/xh| or maxo/menos (ii.39.14; iv.67.29), or, more rarely, when the connexion clearly implies this (ii.39.18; iii.99.3); otherwise always with the gen.; for in viii.25.23, e)n th=| ma/xh| belongs to cune/bh; and in viii.62.7 the gen. is to be regarded rather as abs.
Final defeat of the Athenians in Egypt.
e)pe/menon, kai\...kate/sthsan : parataxis; = while they waited in Egypt (since B.C. 460, see c. 104, § 2) occurred, etc. kate/sthsan, complexive aor. summing up a series; see on c. 6. 3.

i)de/ai: used in vi.4.31 in its literal sense of ‘figure.’ Thuc., who is fond of the word, uses it elsewhere for ‘manner, mode’; and only here in pl., of vicissitudes in war (belli modos, Hor. Car. ii.1.2); often with pa=sa. Cf. ii.19.2; iii. 81.
22; 83. 1; 98. 15; 112. 23; vii.29.26.
e)kra/toun...kai\...pe/mpei : see on c. 61. 1.
e)s th\n *)attikh\n...a)p) *ai)gu/ptou : the position shows strong contrast.
a)paga/goi: cf. iii.36.4; vi.73.9.

prouxw/rei: here impers. as in ii.56.12; iii.4.19; 18. 4; iv.59.16. Elsewhere with a subj., h( ai(/resis (ii.58.7), to\ e)/rgon (viii.68.25), or a neut. of general meaning (c. 74. 28; 111. 7; 127. 4; ii.5.2; iv.18.21; 73. 20; 101. 11; v.37.9; 54. 7; 83. 7; vi.18.27; 74. 11; 90. 7; 103. 11).—a)/llws: = ma/thn. Cf. iv.36.2; vii.42.35; 47. 17; viii.78.9. ii.18.8, which Cl. gives here as another instance, is correctly explained by him there in a different sense. —a)nhlou=to: Wecklein, Cur. epigr. p. 34, has shown that a)nalou=n, a)nali/skein should have the aug. h. Cf. ii.13.29; 64. 14; 70. 11; iii.81.16; vi.31.38; vii.48.35; viii.31.17; 45. 30; 65. 12.
o( me\n *mega/bazos kte(.: the use of the common pred. e)komi/sqh has a sarcastic tone.
*mega/buzon: mentioned in Hdt. vii.82.8 and iii.160.12, where he is said to be the son of that Zopyrus, who gained Babylon for Darius.
meta\ stratia=s pollh=s: Diod. gives him (xi. 75) with Artabazus 300,000 men and (xi. 77) 300 ships.

*proswpi/tida: this island is mentioned in Hdt. ii. 41. It lay between the Sebennytic and Canopic mouths of the Nile, which must have been joined on the north by a channel, probably artificial. This Megabyzus rendered dry by diverting the water flowing into it (Diod. xi.77.2, to
 perirre/onta potamo
 diw/ruci dialabo/ntes h)/peiron e)poi/hsan th
 nh=son).

chra/nas...paratre/yas : the result stated before the means; see on c. I. 3.— 16. e)pi\ tou= chrou= e)poi/hse: cf. e)n me/sw| au(tw=n poiei=n, c. 62. 14; e)nto\s poih=sai, v.2.13; e)nto\s li/an tw=n teixw=n poih/sas, vii.5.14.
kai/: introduces the result of what precedes; and so. Cf. c. 99. 12.
An auxiliary force sent later by the Athenians is almost annihilated, and Egypt comes again under the dominion of the Persian King.

ta\ tw=n *(ellh/nwn pra/gmata: refers chiefly to the persons engaged; the Greeks and their undertaking. Cf. Hdt. vii. 9. g 4. Accordingly we have polemh/santa instead of the more usual polemhsa/ntwn, which Cobet and v. H. read. Sh. compares ii.36.13, *(/ellhna po/lemon e)pio/nta.

o)li/goi a)po\ pollw=n : this use of a)po/ strengthens the impression of loss, as in iii.112.30; vii.87.26. Cf. iv.9.3. Diod. xi. 77 represents the Athenians as retiring by capitulation, concluding with e)sw/qhsan parado/cws e)s th\n patri/da. He no doubt follows the later encomiastic writers. Grote, V. c. 45, p. 188.

u(po\ basile/a: so the best Mss., the inferior having basilei=. In iii.59.14 and vii.64.7 we have gi/gnesqai u(po/ with dat., vi.86.17, ei)=nai u(po/ with acc. Herbst, Gegen Cobet, p. 27, cites all the passages without drawing a distinction between them.

*)amurtai/ou: cf. Hdt. ii.140.7; iii.15.14.— toi=s e(/lesi: the lower parts of the Nile Delta. Cf. Hdt. ii.137.6; 151. 18.— 6. kai\ a(/ma...ei)si : a direct statement for a causal one. Cf. v.61.18; vii.47.7.
o(\s ta\ pa/nta e)/prace: who had been the originator of the whole movement. Cf. viii.82.10.

*)aqhnw=n: so Bekk. for *)aqhnai/wn of the Mss., which e)k will hardly allow.—th=s a)/llhs cummaxi/dos: here the members, not the territory, of the alliance, as in ii.80.5; v.36.4. On a)/llhs, besides, see G. 202, N. 3; H. 705. Kühn. 405, note 1; Kr. Spr. 50, 4, 11.
dia/doxoi: elsewhere (iii.115.7; vii.15.9; viii.85.3) only of persons; but here, too, the men are mainly thought of, and so in 12, ei)do/tes.

e)/sxon : put in, usually with e)s or a dat. But kata/, to designate the point of the coast, also iv.129.12; vi.97.3.—to\ *mendh/sion ke/ras: between the Pelusiac and Sebennytic mouths, named from the city Mendes. Hdt. ii.17.25; 42. 6; Strab. xvii.1.18. ke/ras of one of the Nile mouths (usually sto/ma) is
found in Pind. frg. 201, Bergk.

e)s *ai)/gupton: belongs to stratei/an, though placed after the subst. without repetition of the art. Cf. c. 11. 19; 18. 12.—e)teleu/thsen: of a series of events; cf. c. 138. 33; iii.68.32; v.26.21; viii.2.21.
Fruitless expedition of the Athenians into Thessaly to restore Orestes; attempts on the coast of Peloponnesus and Acarnania.

tou= *qessalw=n basile/ws: the generality of this expression is surprising, but the title basileu/s is applied to the chiefs of particular parts of Thessaly in Hdt. v.63.16; vii.6.8. As the family of Echecratidas and Orestes belonged to Pharsalus (Gilbert, Griech. Alt. II. p. 7), we perhaps should read *farsali/wn. Cf. ii. 22. § 3; iv. 78. § 2. Perhaps tago/s is here meant. Anacreon, Anthol. Pal. vi. 142, speaks of Echecratidas as *qessali/as a)rxo/s.

kata/gein : see on c. 26. 15. —paralabo/ntes: applied specially to the call of allied troops to active service. Cf. 14; v.52.12; vi.101.30; vii.20.16; 26. 5; 31. 7; 57. 41; viii.92.40.—o)/ntas cumma/xous: see c. 108. 9.
th=s *qessali/as: see on c. 100. 15.

o(/sa mh/: also o(/son or o(/ ti,= tosau/ths mo/non o(/shs kratei=n e)du/nanto mh\ proio/ntes. Kühn. 512, 4 b. An elliptical expression to limit a preceding assertion; so far as was possible without. Cf. iv.16.12; Soph. O. R. 347; Trach. 1214.
tw=n o(/plwn: i.e. the place of arms. Cf. iii.1.7; vi.64.20; Xen. Hell. ii.4.6; with ti/qesqai, ii.2.22; iv.44.6; vii.3.3; viii.25.22.
a)/praktoi: with a)poxwrei=n again, viii.43.24; with a)naxwrei=n, iv.22.14; with a)pie/nai, iii.113.20; iv.61.28; 99. 10; v.38.21; 56. 19; vi.85.15; 86. 23; the adv., vi.48.3.

e)pi\ ta\s nau=s e)piba/ntes: cf. ii.25.20; vii.69.26; the same as e)sbai/nein e)s, i.18.19. In vii.70.32, tai=s
nausi/, of boarding. But in iv.116.8, e)pibai/nein tou= tei/xous.

au)toi/ : see c. 103. 13.—pare/pleusan: sailed along the coast, the circumnavigation of Peloponnesus not being intended. Cf. ii.25.15, 26; 84. 30; iii.7.5; etc. Pericles is here first mentioned, with the distinction which is always given by the addition of a father's name. In his case this is repeated on each occasion that he is again prominently introduced. Cf. c. 127. 3; 139. 23; ii.13.3; 31. 3; 34. 22. In other places the father's name is omitted. Müller-Strübing, Aristophanes, p. 618 ff., whose further inferences are not to be accepted. See Introd. p. 2.

th=s *)akarnani/as: dependent on *oi)nia/das, as in 4. Oeniadae, at the mouth of the Achelous, used as name of the town (ii.102.15; iii.7.10; 114. 12) and of the inhabitants (iv.77.9). On this expedition of Pericles, see Plut. Per. 19. 2-4, who gives him 100 triremes.
Truce between Athens and Sparta; successful battles in Cyprus and on the coast; hostile action of Athens and Sparta about Delphi.

pentaetei=s: St. and v. H. read pente/teis here and deke/ths in v.25.3; 26. 16, without Mss., following the analogy of pentethri/s, iii.104.13, and the corresponding forms in Ar. Ach. 188, 191; Soph. Phil. 715; Eur. El. 1153. But the uncertainty of the orthography of triakontou/teis (c. 23. 19; 115. 3; ii.2.2) and of penthkontou/teis (v.27.1; 32. 19) indicates the absence of an established usage.
kai/: and accordingly; see on c. 109. 17.

*(ellhnikou= pole/mou: not a designation of a particular war, but expressing collectively all the military operations of the past ten years which were not against the Persians. Ullrich, Hell. Kr. p. 6 ff.—e)/sxon: Schol., e)pe/sxon, not = a)pe/sxonto, ‘they abstained from,’ but ceased, made a pause. So particularly the imv. sxe/s, Soph. O. C. 1169; Eur. Hec. 963; I. A. 1467. The gen. pole/mou is part., for in c. 113 the *(ellhniko\s po/lemos is continued. In viii.31.2, the compound e)pe/sxon is similarly
used. Cf. Plat. Lys. 210 e; Xen. Cyr. iv.2.12; An. iii.4.36; Dem. XIV. 5; Ar. Av. 1200.

a)p' au)tw=n: out of the number of 200. Cf. c. 110. 2; 116. 14.—*)amurtai/ou: see c. 110. § 2.—metape/mpontos: act. also in iv.30.12; vi.52.8; 71. 10; 88. 56; vii.8.7; 15. 6; 42. 20. Mid. in i.95.9; ii.29.4; iii.2.8; iv.100.1; v.47.38, 40; 82. 9; vii.31.8; 80. 23; viii.5.5; 37. 18; 57. 12. Each means substantially to summon to one by a message, with greater or less insistence upon employment for the purposes of the subj. See App.
*ki/tion: on the south coast of Cyprus, birthplace of Zeno the Stoic.
u(pe\r *salami=nos: off Salamis. Arn. compares the use of mete/wros, as in c. 48. 4, “from the apparent elevation of the horizon line of the sea above the shore.” Cf. c. 137. 16; viii.95.24.

e)nauma/xhsan: in Diod. xii.3.3, and Plut. Cim. 18. 7, this victory of the Attic fleet is erroneously ascribed to Cimon.— 11. a)mfo/tera: see on c. 13. 23; 100. 4. Diod. xii.4.4, represents the so-called Peace of Callias to have been made with Persia in consequence of these successes. On this, see on viii.56.18; Grote, V. c. 45, p. 190 ff.; Kr. Stud. I. p. 74 ff., who denies the conclusion of any such peace.
ai( e)c *ai)gu/ptou...met) au)tw=n : the attrib. partic. is placed as in c. 11. 19. met' au)tw=n is to be taken with a)pexw/rhsan. On the omission of ai(, see App.

po/lemon e)stra/teusan: like po/lemon polemei=n in viii.58.26. Here only in Thuc., but recurring in Diod. and Appian. Any war would be called i(ero/s which concerned the Delphian oracle or treasures. With the support of Athens (see c. 108. 9), the Phocians, who were always at variance with the Delphians, had possessed themselves of the temple and oracle. Now (B.C. 448) the Lacedaemonians had put it again in charge of the Delphians; but shortly afterwards (acc. to Philochorus, Schol. on Ar. Av. 556, u(/steron tri/tw| e)/tei tou= prote/rou pole/mou) the Athenians reinstated the Phocians, being, acc. to Plut. Per. 21. 2, under the command
of Pericles. See Grote, XI. c. 87, p. 49.
In the battle of Coronea the Bocotians and Locrians of the antidemocratic party defeat the Athenians, who lose their supremacy in Boeotia.

xro/nou e)ggenome/nou: cf. iv.111.4; Hdt. i.190.11; ii.124.13; Plat. Phaed. 86 e. See viii.9.6; and on c. 80. 17.—*boiwtw=n tw=n feugo/ntwn: (i.e. fuga/dwn) the order as in c. 1. 6; 5. 5; 15. 8; 17. 5. In 14 *boiwtw=n is part. gen. The party hostile to the Athenians had since the battle at Oenophyta (c. 108) maintained itself in northern Boeotia, and was strengthened by the disorders of Thebes, of which Arist. (see c. 108. 9) says, e)n *qh/bais meta\ th\n e)n *oi)nofu/tois ma/xhn kakw=s politeuome/nwn h( dhmokrati/a diefqa/rh. This expedition of Tolmides was undertaken, acc. to Plut. Per. 18. 2 against the advice of Pericles.

w(s e(ka/stois: with their respective quotas; opp. to e(autw=n xili/ois o(pli/tais. Cf. c. 107. 23. This phrase is elliptical, with a verb to be supplied from the principal sentence, which can be easily done when the relation is that of subj. (c. 3. 19; 67. 13; 89. 13) or obj. (vii.65.6; 74. 16). In Hdt. i.29.5 the verb is actually inserted, w(s e(/kastos au)tw=n a)pikne/oito. Cf. also vi.76.16. But in cases like the present no supplement can conveniently be made; and the expression is treated as practically a single word. Cf. Hdt. i.114.10; vi.31.5, etc., and the use of e)/stin ou(/s, etc.
pole/mia o)/nta: i.e. opposed to their policy. See on c. 100. 16. On the words bracketed, see App.
a)pexw/roun: began their return march. See on c. 107. 11.
*korwnei/a|: on the road from Chaeronea to Thebes.—th=s *)orxomenou=: masc. in iii.87.11; iv.76.11; v.61.13; fem. in Ap. Rh. iv. 257, acc. to the general rule for names of towns. Kühn. 96, II.
*lokroi/: in resistance to the oppression of the Athenians. Cf. c. 108. § 3; and see on c. 103. 10. In Euboea also the party was stirring which presently attempted an open revolt (c. 114. 1).

kai\ o(/soi...h)=san : a second definition of the Euboeans, parallel to fuga/des; “belonging to the same political party.” th=s au)th=s gnw/mhs again in iii.70.27; v.46.26. Cf. iv.56.17; viii.74.16. Kr. Spr. 47, 6, 10. There is no sufficient ground for the conjecture of Müller-Strübing, Arist. p. 291,
that there were among them aristocratical exiles from Athens.
tou\s me/n: among those slain was Tolmides himself, acc. to Diod. xii. 6; Plut. Per. 18; Ages. 19.
e)f' w(=|: see on c. 103. 2.

komiou=ntai: applied specially to the recovery of prisoners (tou\s a)/ndras, as in iv.15.5; 21. 17; 41. 15) and the corpses of the slain. Cf. ii.79.29; 82. 4; iii.7.17; iv.15.10; 21. 12; 41. 15; 108. 38; 117. 12; v.15.4; 17. 3; 39. 6; vi.103.4; vii.45.4.
katelqo/ntes: practically pass. of kata/gein. See on c. 26. 15. Cf. Ar. Ran. 1165, feu/gwn a)nh\r h(/kei te kai\ kate/rxetai.

kai\ oi( a)/lloi pa/ntes : i.e. who had come under Athenian control (c. 108. § 3), the rest of the Boeotians, the Opuntian Locrians, and the Phocians (so Arn., Grote, V. c. 45, p. 203, and B.); and it is chiefly in view of these that the pred. au)to/nomoi pa/lin e)ge/nonto is chosen. For oi( feu/gontes *boiwtw=n a more general one, as pa/lin e)poli/teuon, would be more appropriate.
Euboea and Megara fall away from Athens, and the Lacedaemonians at the same time invade Attica. Pericles makes vigorous resistance at all points.

diabebhko/tos h)/dh: partic. pf., not aor., since the relation is strictly temporal, not causal, after he had passed over; and this, too, renders the following au)tw=| less harsh than h(mi=n after sfale/ntwn in vi.10.6. On this irregularity, see GMT. 110, 1, N. 5; H. 972 d; Kr. Spr. 47, 4, 2; Spieker, Am. J. Ph. VI. p. 328 ff. For examples in Latin, see Kühn. L. G. II. 140, 9.— 4. a)fe/sthke...me/llousin...ei)si/n : repraesentatio, giving the tenses used by the messengers.
oi( frouroi\...*ni/saian : cf. c. 103. 15.
e)pagago/menoi de\...a)pe/sthsan : see on c. 88. 1; and on c. 3. 9.

*korinqi/ous kte(.: to them the control of the isthmus by the Athenians was most threatening. See c. 105. § 1;
111. § 2.

e)ko/mize: applied to the transport of troops only by sea. Cf. v.56.7; vi.7.19; 51. 11. The impf. after a)pe/sthsan implies that as soon as the news of the revolt reached him he began at once to convey back his troops. The following meta\ tou=to, however, refers to the completed fact a)pe/sthsan. See App.
*qriw=ze: (not *qri/wze; we must assume a nom. *qriw/) = e)s to\ *qria/sion pedi/on (ii.19.8; 20. 7), the most fertile district of Attica.

e)dh/|wsan: without expressed obj., as ii.11.28; 25. 27. Instead of the aor. (which is rare; cf. ii.66.6; iii.26.9; iv.45.4) the impf. (as Kr. has accidentally printed it in his note) would be more usual for a case like the present (cf. c. 81. 2; 96. 5; ii.12.20; 23. 3; etc.). If the word were omitted,—and it might easily have been introduced in imitation of similar passages,—we should lose nothing, and the correspondence with ii.21.5 would be closer.—*pleistoa/naktos: see on c. 94. 1; 107. 7. As his withdrawal was attributed to bribery (see Plut. Per. 22. 2), he was banished, and was not recalled to Sparta till B.C. 425. See ii.21.8; v.16.30.
to\ ple/on: only here as a local adv., further. For it, e)s to\ plei=on, ii.21.7; iv.128.10. Cf. braxu/ ti, o)li/gon proelqei=n. v. H. reads ka)s for kai/.

katesth/santo kte(: i.e. by formal agreements they arranged the constitutions of the towns to suit their own interests. Cf. c. 76. 2; iii.18.6; iv.107.1. See App. paresth/santo, which Cobet prefers, comparing c. 29. 22; 98. 8, would not be so suitable.

p.hi: truce between Athens and Sparta; revolt of Samos.

div2.p: a)podo/ntes: aor. partic., expressing the condition. See on c. 101. 12; 108. 13.—*troizh=na kai\ *)axai+/an: we have not been told of the occupation of either; though the expeditions of c. 105 and 111. § 2. 3, may have had such results. For *)axai+/an Cobet and Kr. needlessly propose *(alia/da or *(alia=s, where, in c. 105. 1, the Athenians are defeated. Achaea, however, can have been only partially in possession of the Athenians. Cf. c. 111. 14. The same places are named in iv.21.13 as ceded by this treaty. Curtius, Pel. I. 422.
*peloponnhsi/wn: cf. v.39.4, peri\ w(=n ei)=xon a)llh/lwn. Kr. Spr. 47, 10, 2.

peri\ *prih/nhs: neither in Diod. xii. 27, nor Plut. Per. 24, do we learn any details.—e)lassou/menoi: partic. pres., not of a single defeat, but implying continued disadvantage. Cf. c. 77. 1; viii.89.27.
katebo/wn: with gen., of indignant complaints. Cf. c. 67. 4; v.45.18.

cunepelamba/nonto: abs.; the object of the common effort is to be gathered from the context. So iii.74.3; viii.92.31.—i)diw=tai: non-official. This word, which Kr. brackets, is amply defended by the usage noted on c. 74. 4, and the analogy of other such combinations of a)nh/r in Thuc. So with strathgo/s and ce/nos, c. 74. 4, 9; ma/ntis, iii.20.9; dhmagwgo/s, iv.21.9; fuga/s, iv.76.7; vi.12.4; tu/rannos, vi.85.1; peri/oikos, viii.6.21; stratiw/ths, ii.89.1; vii.61.1; 77. 34.

newteri/sai: elsewhere used only abs. or with neut. pron. obj., as ti (c. 102. 13; iii.75.23; iv.51.3; 80. 8), ou)de/n, mhde/n (c. 58. 3; ii.3.6; 73. 14; iii.4.15; 11. 2). So here th\n politei/an is probably to be taken, not as direct obj., but as acc. of specification, for which in ii.73.14 we have peri\ th\n cummaxi/an; vii.87.6, e)s a)sqe/neian. The constitution of Samos was at this time aristocratic.
dhmokrati/an kate/sthsan: opp. to katalu/ein, viii.47.17; 63. 10. Plut., Per. 25. 4, makes Pericles conduct this first expedition.

i)/sous: after numbers, an equal number of. Cf. ii.97.6; iii.75.12; 113. 22; iv.1.2; v.20.12; 57. 12.—kate/qento: placed for safe keeping. Cf. iii.28.14; 35. 5; 72. 2; 102. 2; iv.57.19; viii. 3.
9.
e)gkatalipo/ntes: i.e. e)n th=| *sa/mw|.
tw=n de\ *sami/wn kte(.: on this involved const., see on c. 72. 1. The tines of the parenthetical sentence must be taken also with tw=n *sami/wn as the subj. of cunqe/menoi...die/bhsan.

ou)x u(pe/menon : would not remain in the island. So better than with the Schol. to supply th\n dhmokrati/an. Note the contrast of the neg. impf. and the aor.—e)s th\n h)/peiron: probably occupying Anaea; see iii.19.8; 32. 4. Cf. iv.75.7; viii.19.3.
toi=s dunatwta/tois: i.e. the heads of the aristocracy; see on c. 24. 13.
o(\s ei)=xe *sa/rdeis: as Satrap of Lydia. Cf. iii.31.9.
u(po\ nu/kta: at the approach of night. Cf. ii.92.22.
kle/yantes: Cobet with some Mss. reads e)kkle/yantes, as the proper word for the stealthy removal of persons. Cf. Hom. E 390.

tou\s a)/rxontas: also with *)aqhnai/wn. See on c. 91. 26. The addition oi(\ h)=san para\ sfi/sin (see on c. 20. 3) implies rather civil than military officers. Such under the name of e)pi/skopoi or fu/lakes (cf. iv.104.14, o(\s e)k tw=n *)aqhnai/wn parh=n au)toi=s fu/lac tou= xwri/ou) were established among the dependent allies. Böckh, Pub. Econ. p. 525. Stahl, De sociorum Atheniensium iudiciis, p. 4.
Pericles defeats the fleet of the Samians, and besieges their city.
w(s h)/|sqonto: see on c. 95. 21.
tai=s e(kkai/deka: the art. with numeralso designates them as parts of a whole; so in 8, ai( ei)/kosi. See on c. 74. 6.

e)/tuxon oi)xo/menai: had sailed away; belongs both to ai( me/n and ai(
de/, the purposes being expressed by e)s proskoph/n and periagge/llousai (see on c. 39. 2). Perhaps we should read periaggelou=sai. But see GMT. 109, 5. This word has the const. of keleu/ein. Cf. ii.10.2; 80. 13; iv.8.5; v.54.8; in vi.88.35 with keleu/ein.
proskoph/n : only here in Attic. —tw=n...new=n : the hostile fleet which was constantly looked for.
deka/tou au)tou=: among the nine was the poet Sophocles. Strabo, xiv.1.18. For the expression, see on c. 61. 5.

*tragi/a|: in Plut. Per. 25, *tragi/ai; in Strabo, xiv.1.7, ta\ peri\ ta\s *tragai/as nhsi/a, placed by the ancient authorities near the Ionic coast; by Ross, Inselreise, I. p. 40, note 10, identified with Makares between Naxos and Donussa. Kiepert marks Tragiae just south of Samos.
stratiw/tides: were properly transports (Böckh, P. Ec. p. 380). See vi.43.6; viii.62.6; called o(plitagwgoi/, vi.25.9; 31. 21; viii.25.5; 30. 10.
a)po\ *milh/tou: they had made use of their recovered independence first in an attempt on their hated rival. See c. 115. 24.

kratou=ntes: being superior; not by a battle; but the Samians withdrew behind their walls before superior numbers. — e)polio/rkoun: proceeded to besiege.—trisi\ tei/xesi: i.e. a wall or perhaps a fort on each of the three land sides.
a)po\ tw=n e)formousw=n: see on c. 112. 6.

e)pi\ *kau/nou kai\ *kari/as: kai/ joins part to whole. Cf. iii.51.6.—e)saggelqe/ntwn: see on c. 7. 2, and cf. Dem. L. 17; shmanqe/ntwn, Xen. Cyr. i.4.18. GMT. 110, 1, N. 3; H. 973 a; Kühn. 486, note 2; Kr. Spr. 47, 4, 5.

e)p' au)tou/s: against the Athenians; not as P. thinks, ‘to help the Samians.’ See on c. 95. 8. But in fact e)saggelqe/ntwn is equivalent to e)sh/ggeilan ga/r tines, which would require au)tou/s (not sfa=s) in reference to the Athenians.—w)/|xeto: cf. c. 28. 8 for this emphatic repetition.

*sthsago/ras: not else
where named.—e)pi\ ta\s *foini/ssas: to bring up, fetch, the Phoenician ships.
After a short suspension of the rigour of the blockade, Pericles brings the siege of Samos to an end.

tw=| stratope/dw|: the sequel shows that this means the ships of the blockading squadron, probably ranged on the shore of the harbour; a)fra/ktw| in pred. position, not being protected; they had not been sheltered by staurw/mata. Cf. vi.66.8; vii.25.19; 38. 12.—ta\s profulaki/das nau=s: i.e. ships moored afloat and ready manned, which lay off the camp as a sort of lookout or guard.
ta\s a)ntanagome/nas: which put out to resist them. See App. on c. 29. 18.
e)ni/khsan: aor., they won the victory. The three following aors. are complexive, and state summarily the events of the interval named.
e)lqo/ntos: = e)panelqo/ntos. Cf. c. 136. 11; iv.16.19; 65. 10.
pa/lin: belongs to kateklh/|sqhsan with the addition tai=s nausi/, because it was only e)k qala/sshs (c. 116. 13) that the blockade had been interrupted. So Herbst, Philol. 1866, p. 618 f.

tessara/konta me\n...*)antikle/ous : i.e. in two divisions in succession, as the preparations were completed. The repetition of ai( implies that both squadrons formed parts of a whole. The five commanders named must no doubt be regarded as strategi; and, as none of them occurs in the list of eight strategi given by the Schol. on Aristid. III. p. 485 for the first year of the Samian war, they must have been chosen for the second year. Cl. agrees with Curtius (Griech. Ges. II.^{4} p. 825, 61) that elections for the strathgi/a took place in the winter. But see K. F. Hermann, Gr. Staatsalt. § 152, 2; and Gilbert, Inn. Gesch. Ath. p. 12 ff., who gives strong grounds for thinking that the a)rxairesi/ai occurred in the ninth Prytany, i.e. toward the end of Munychion, = Apr. The strathgoi/ thus elected would enter their office at the beginning of the Attic year; and we need not, therefore, with Cl., place the arrival of these reinforcements so late as the beginning of 439; though the siege may have ended then. The Thucydides here named is probably the son of Melesias, who, though ostracized in 444, may have been recalled. For the reasons against this, see Th. Hoffmann, De Thuc. Mel. fil. Hamb. 1867, p. 39. Others suppose
the historian is meant. Certainty cannot be reached. Hermes, 12, p. 349, note 32; Grote, V. c. 47, p. 291. Hagnon (ii.58.1; 95. 16) and Phormio (ii.29.30; 68. 20; 80. 21; 84. 5; 90 ff.) are active in the Peloponnesian war. Tlepolemus and Anticles are not mentioned again.

braxei=an: insignificant. Cf. c. 14. 11; 74. 22; ii.22.9; iii.39.38.— 13. e)na/tw| mhni/: since the beginning of the siege, c. 116. 12, in summer of 440.—prosexw/rhsan o(mologi/a|: = w(molo/ghsan, c. 101. 12; 108. 12; and construed with the partic. aor. in the same way.

xrh/mata ta\ a)nalwqe/nta: position as in c. 1. 6. The cost of the war acc. to Isocr. xv. 111, was 1000 tal.; acc. to Nep. Timoth. 1., 1200; Diod. xii. 28, only 200. But here Kr. conjectures that xili/wn has fallen out. —kata\ xro/nous: by instalments. Kirchhoff, Gesch. d. Ath. Staatsschatzes, p. 43 (Abh. der Berl. Ak. 1876).—taca/menoi: see on c. 99. 11. This Samian war was always regarded as one of the most critical for Athens; see viii.76.15. As to the wish of some Peloponnesian states to aid Samos, see c. 40. 18; 41. 8.
w(/sper kai\ pro/teron: see on c. 74. 25.—ei)=nai: after cumbai/nein without w(/ste. Cf. ii.4.31; iv.54.10.
Connexion with the earlier narrative. The Lacedaemonians consult the Delphian oracle.
ou) polloi=s e)/tesin: only three years; for the first misunderstanding about Epidamnus occurred in 436. See c. 25.
ta/ te kte(.: Corcyra, c. 24-55; Potidaea, c. 56-65.
kai\ o(/sa kte(.: beside these affairs the transactions in the Spartan assembly, c. 67-88.—pro/fasis: not ‘pretext,’ but occasion, as in c. 23. 23.

tau=ta cu/mpanta: c. 24-117.— pro/s te a)llh/lous kai\ to\n ba/rbaron: the later events, as nearer to the speaker, placed first, as in c. 97. 4. But in 6 the chronological order is observed in consequence of the express designation of time. This period, from 480 to 431, embraces what may with sufficient accuracy (ma/lista, see on c. 13. 11) be said to have been 50 years, and so the old gramma
rians applied the term penthkontaeti/a or penthkontaethri/s to it.

e)n oi)=s: as in c. 89. 2, referring not merely to the period of penth/konta e)/th but to the events just summed up. —th\n a)rxh/n: their empire regarded externally.—e)gkratesteran: with a firmer hold; pred. to katesth/santo, as bebaio/tera in iii.18.7. Cf. c. 76. 6, a)/rxein e)gkratw=s. The process is described in c. 99.
au)toi/: at home, by the development of their internal resources.—e)pi\ me/ga duna/mews: see on c. 5. 10.

e)pi\ braxu/: to a trifling extent. See on c. 117. 11. The reference is to the invasion of Attica in 445 (c. 114. § 2) and to their opposition to the rebuilding of the walls, c. 90 ff.—mh\ taxei=s: the use of mh/ here seems so strange that Sh. writes ou) instead, supposing, as Arn. had suggested, that ou) was first lost because of the preceding tou=; and when it was missed was supplied by the copyist after the usage of his own time, perhaps influenced by c. 132. 26. But mh\ taxei=s may be defended by regarding it as = tw=n mh\ taxe/wn o)/ntes: A descriptive phrase such as oi( mh\ taxei=s o)/ntes when used as a pred. would lose its art. Cf. e)/coida, pai=, fu/sei se mh\ pefuko/ta, Soph. Phil. 79; o(\ xrh\ ga\r ou)dei\s mh\ xrew\n qh/sei pote/, Eur. H. F. 311; Antiphon, v. 82; e)pei\ e)/gnwn e)mauto\n mh\ i(kano/n kte(., Xen. Cyr. vii.2.22. See Gildersleeve, Justin Martyr, I. c. 9. 4.
i)e/nai: see on c. 78. 7.
a)nagka/zointo: opt. of repetition. Cf. c. 18. 28; 49. 14.—to\ de/ ti: see on c. 107. 19.—oi)kei/ois: see c. 101, 102. —e)ceirgo/menoi: sc. tou= tou\s *)aqhnai/ous kwlu/ein. Cf. ii.13.35.

pri\n dh/: until at last. Cf. c. 132. 28; iii.29.5; 104. 42; vii.39.5. h(su/xazon in 10 is in effect a negative verb, “they took no actual steps,” and so pri/n takes the finite verbs regularly; here in the impf., “began to exalt itself,” “undertook to lay hands upon.”

cummaxi/as: in concrete sense, “the members of their alliance.” Cf. c. 19. 8; 119. 4; ii.7.15; 9. 13, 21; v.40.4.—ou)ke/ti...e)poiou=nto : occurs again ii.21.11.— 15. e)pixeirhte/a: see on c. 7. 2; 79. 6; ii.3.10. e)do/kei is taken first impers. and then with subject h( i)sxu/s.

a)rame/nois : agreeing with an under
stood sfi/sin, agent to the verbal adjectives.

au)toi=s me\n ou)=n kte(.: resumption of the narrative broken off in c. 87. § 6. au)toi=s, dat. as in c. 46. 1; 48. 1; 50. 20. This refers to the Lacedaemonian assembly, without their allies, who are summoned to assist in c. 119, au)=qis de\ tou\s cumma/xous kte(.
e)phrw/twn : often used of the consulting of oracles. Cf. c. 25. 3; ii.54.13; iii.92.19 (aor. e)ph/ronto); Hdt. i.53.9; vii.169.4.

a)/meinon: the opposite possibility omitted. Cf. c. 73. 7; 102. 16; vi.9.4. So often in oracular utterances. Cf. ii.17.9; Hdt. i.187.8.—kata\ kra/tos: with all their might. Cf. c. 64. 14; ii.54.14 (referring to this passage); iv.23.10; v.116.10; viii.1.20.
au)to/s: goes with cullh/yesqai. Cf. ii.54.15; iii.27.9.

parakalou/menos kai\ a)/klhtos: in reverse order in vi.87.9, ou)k a)/klhtoi, paraklhqe/ntes de/. a)/klhtos is short for a)para/klhtos; cf. ii.98.12. Cf. also Hor. Car. ii.18.40, vocatus atque non vocatus audit.
LAST DEBATES AND NEGOTIATIONS AT SPARTA AND ATHENS BEFORE THE OUTBREAK OF THE WAR, Chaps. 119-146; WITH THE EPISODES OF THE END OF PAUSANIAS AND OF THEMISTOCLES, Chaps. 128-138.
Deliberation of the Peloponnesian allies at Sparta on the question of war.
au)=qis...parakale/santes : with reference to c. 67. 3, 9; 87. 11.
yh=fon e)pagagei=n: see on c. 87. 13.— 3. cummaxi/as: see on c. 118. 14.
a(\ e)bou/lonto: i.e. what they regarded as their interest, as in c. 67.
oi( plei/ous: appos. to oi( a)/lloi, though only a portion of the latter is meant. Cf. c. 2. 24; 18. 2.

e(ka/stwn: depends on dehqe/ntes, kata\ po/leis giving the principle of distribution; the separate allied states.—w(/ste: after dehqe/ntes is pleonastic, but serves to emphasize the object to be attained. See App. on c. 28. 18. Cf. iii.75.4; vi.88.47; vii.86.14; viii.79.2. Kühn. 473, note 6.

dedio/tes: subord. to dehqe/ntes as its motive. Cf. c. 31. 5; 67. 6; 75.
11.—mh\ prodiafqarh=|: see c. 65. § 3.

paro/ntes...to/te : opp. to dehqe/ntes . . . pro/teron, as they had before appealed to individual states, so now they came to the assembly to further their object. paro/ntes = parageno/menoi. Cf. iii.3.19; 69. 11; iv.107.13; 124. 26; vii.1.11; viii.17.14. Ullrich, Kr. Beitr. III. 5 ff., proposes pario/ntes, but the sense would rather require parelqo/ntes; cf. c. 67. 16; 139. 23. In vi.15.1; viii.68.7, pariw/n stands in definite relation to an impf. —teleutai=oi: so also c. 67. 16.— e)pelqo/ntes: see on c. 72. 15.

div2.head: Speech of the Corinthian envoys. Chaps. 120-124.
div2.p: After the example of the Lacedaemonians, we ought all to declare for war without further hesitation, free equally from cowardly desire of repose and from excessive assurance of victory.
tou\s me\n *lakedaimoni/ous: placed thus at the beginning to emphasize the change of sentiment, which no longer requires the rebukes of c. 68 ff., and in opp. to h(mw=n de/ of 6.

kai\ h(ma=s e)s tou=to cunh/gagon: this clause also depends on w(s ou), referring especially to the reproach of the Corinthians, c. 69. 8. To ou)de\ e)pi\ faneroi=s there is here opp. e)s tou=to, i.e. the distinct purpose tou= to\n po/lemon yhfi/sasqai. See Stahl, Jahrb. 1863, p. 477.—ga/r: introduces the reason for the commendation of the action just implied. Sh. renders it ‘of course.’

ta\ i)/dia: the special interests of particular members of the league (cf. c. 82. 26), including especially those of the Lacedaemonians themselves.— e)c i)/sou ne/montas: administering impartially, without claiming any preference. Cf. iii.12.12; iv.62.21; 117. 14; and for ne/mein, viii.70.9; Hdt. i.59.34; v.92.33; and see on c. 71. 6.

w(/sper...protimw=ntai : in contrast with proskopei=n. For the thought, cf. Xen. An. iii.1.37. “As on other occasions (meetings for counsel, conduct of war, etc.; cf. v.29.14) the foremost place is conceded to them by all.” For e)k = u(po/, mostly Ion. and poetic, see Kühn. 430, 2, 3 c. See on c. 20. 10; iii.69.3; vi.36.9.
h(mw=n: includes all the cu/mmaxoi, divided into o(/soi me\n . . . e)nhlla/ghsai and tou\s de\ . . . katw|khme/nous.

e)nhl. la/ghsan : not found elsewhere, though recognized by Thom. Mag. p. 80, 1, and by the Schol., who explains sune/mican kai\ w(mi/lhsan. Since this verb elsewhere always means ‘exchange,’ Madvig, Adv. I. p. 308, proposes e)n a)llagh=| h)=san, in commercio fuerunt. —h)/dh: often used of an appeal to experience. See on ii.77.15.—7
w(/ste: after didaxh=s, as in viii.45.20 after dida/skein. See on c. 119. 7.— 7. th\n meso/geian...katw|khme/nous : elsewhere katw|kh=sqai has only adverbial designations of place. Cf. ii.96.7; 99. 20; iii.34.2; v.83.13. The acc. would properly require an act. form as in viii.108.19. v. H. proposes to insert kata/.
e)n po/rw| : in the track of commerce, particularly on the coast. Cf. vi.48.8.

toi=s ka/tw: Schol. toi=s parali/ois: placed for emphasis before the conj. Cf. c. 19. 4; and see on c. 77. 6.—xalepwte/ran kte(.: a favorite turn of Thuc. for xalepwte/ra au)toi=s e)/stai, used often in expressions of change. Cf. c. 82. 18; ii.62.7; iii.11.16; 13. 36; 82. 16; iv.10.13; 62. 7; 92. 24; v.69.13; vii.63.10; 77. 18; viii.45.16.

th\n katakomidh/n: prop. of conveyance to the coast, implies also subsequent exportation; as also h( a)nti/lhyis does importation. Both being necessary parts of commercial exchange, are included, with their gens. and the adv. pa/lin (which belongs closely to a)nti/lhyin), under one art. Cf. c. 54. 4; ii.64.26; iii.2.6; 56. 7; v.5.1; Dem. II. 9.— tw=n w(rai/wn: the products of the land. Cf. iii.58.18.

mh\ kakou\s...ei)=nai : and not to be careless judges of the things now said as if they concerned them not. mh/ with proshko/ntwn from the imv. force of xrh/. Cf. vii.77.35; Ar. Ran. 128, w(s o)/ntos ge mh\ badistikou=. See Kühn. 515, 3.

pote: belongs to a)\n proelqei=n = o(/ti a)\n proe/lqoi, the prot. being ei) prooi=nto (cf. 17 and 22), the ideal form of the cond. sent. giving greater generalty to the supposition than the anticipatory (with h)/n) would do, which might seem more natural here. See on 16. —to\ deino/n: the danger. Cf. c. 70. 11; 84. 8; iii.22.26.

bouleu/esqai: does not depend, as Cl. says, on xrh/, but on a verb of thinking implied in prosde/xesqai. “They must understand that their own interests are at least as much involved in the present deliberation as those of others.”

metalamba/nein: to take in exchange. Cf. vi.18.19; 87. 25.— a)ndrw=n swfro/nwn: men of discretion. Cf. c. 40. 8. This term is not opp. to a)gaqw=n (‘courageous,’ ‘resolute’), but the latter is set forth as the higher quality. In the view of the Corinthians it is a)diki/a on the part of the Athenians to menace the interests of
the inland states.

ei) mh\ a)dikoi=nto: this opt., for which, as P. says, e)a/n with subj. would be more usual, occurs chiefly in dependence on an inf., and is to be regarded as a relic of the epic use of the mood. See examples with rel. in Kühn. 560, 4; Kr. Spr. 54, 14, 4. Cf. c. 121. 13; iii.10.5. In 13 ei) prooi=nto appears formally regular through the apod. ka)\n proelqei=n= o(/ti proe/lqoi a)/n, which is, however, merely an aoristic future.—a)dikoume/nous: not attracted to gen., the inf. not being that of a copulative verb. Kühn. 475, 2 a.—e)k me\n ei)rh/nhs: e)k used of immediate transition from state to state. Cf. Dem. XIX. 133, e)k pole/mou poiou/menos ei)rh/nhn.

parasxo/n : pare/sxen and parasxh/sei (in Hdt. also pare/xei, pare/cei, iii.73.2; 142. 10) impers. of an opportunity presenting itself. Cf. iv.85.8; vi.86.22; most freq. in abs. partic., v.14.11; 60. 25; 63. 3. GMT. 110, 2; H. 973.

tw=| h(suxi/w| kte(.: for neut. adj. as subst., see on c. 36. 3. h(su/xios (Hdt. i.107.13) expresses a constant and habitual tranquillity more than the commoner h(/suxos. h(do/menon is for h(dome/nous, as if tina had preceded; from the pleasure one takes in the tranquillity of peace to allow himself to be wronged. For this permissive use of the pass., see Kr. Spr. 52, 11, 3. Cf. iii.82.51.
o(/ te ga\r kte(.: the order of the clauses here is chiastic to the preceding.
ei) h(suxa/zoi: if he give himself up to inactivity, carrying out his character as o)knw=n.

pleona/zwn : presuming on; probably here only in this sense; different in ii.35.12.—e)ntequ/mhtai: with partic; cf. ii.62.5; vi.78.3. Usually with o(/ti, ii.43.9; v.111.4; vii.64.11. The pf. expresses the firm hold of a conviction. (Intensive pres. pf.; Curtius, Verbum, II. p. 156 ff.) Cf. Plat. Phaed. 86 b.—qra/sei a)pi/stw|: ill-grounded self-confidence.

tuxo/nta: so Cobet (ad Hyp. p. 46), for tuxo/ntwn of the best Mss., to which the preceding words might easily have led. “Many ill-contrived schemes have succeeded because by good luck they have had to deal with adversaries yet more ill-advised.” But Herbst, Philol. 1866, p. 651, and Stahl. Jahrb. 1863, p. 412, decidedly prefer tuxo/ntwn (with omitted o)/ntwn: see on c. 32. 9, and cf., for this omission even with gen. abs., Pind. Pyth.
IV. 5, ou)k a)poda/mou *)apo/llwnos tuxo/ntos). Herbst says that when tuxei=n in Thuc. means ‘hit,’ it implies previous aim; cf. iii.39.42; 42. 18, 26; 82. 31; iv.22.13.—katwrqw/qh: empiric aor.; cf. c. 69. 31; 70. 24. The mid. katorqou=sqai only with thing as subj., ii.65.28; iv.76.21; vi.13.7, while the act. is used in same sense of things (v.111.27; vi.33.26) and persons (c. 140. 8; ii.42.20; 89. 8; iii.14.5; 39. 39; 42. 28; vi.11.5; 12. 7; 17. 14; 38. 8; vii.42.34; 47. 4; 66. 7; 68. 9; viii.2.7; 109. 7).— kai\ e)/ti ple/w (e)sti\) a(/: Cobet wrongly omits a(/, connecting ple/w perie/sth directly. For thus ple/w and the opposition of kalw=s and ai)sxrw=s would be less prominent.
perie/sth: see on c. 32. 15; 76. 21.

e)nqumei=tai ga\r kte(.: this clause gives the reason of what immediately precedes. e)nqumei=sqai is here, as in ii.40.9; 60. 20; viii.68.6, form a plan (not, as usual, ‘deliberate,’ ‘consider’); and to this e)/rgw| e)pece/rxesqai is opposed (cf. c. 84. 17). To both verbs belongs o(moi/a| th=| pi/stei: “no one forms a plan and carries it out with unchanged confidence.” See App.
doca/zomen: takes the place of e)nqumei=sqai in an unfavourable sense, we form fallacious notions, just as e)n tw=| e)/rgw| e)llei/pomen repeats what precedes with greater distinctness.

h(mei=s de\ kte(.: the general statement of c. 120. 17 (a)gaqw=n de\ . . . cumbh=nai) is now shown to hold of the Peloponnesians. On de/ introducing a particular instance, see on c. 32. 7. The two partics., a)dikou/menoi and e)/xontes, together give the single reason for to\n po/lemon e)gei/romen, by which they are separated, as usual in Thuc. (see on c. 91. 26).—po/lemon e)gei/romen: also in Hdt. viii.142.8, imitates e)gei/romen o)cu\n *)/arha, which occurs five times in Hom. (B 440; *d 352; *q 531; *s 304; T 237).
a)munw/meqa: aor. subjv.
kataqhso/meqa au)to/n: will bring the war to an end. Cf. iv.20.7; Lys. XXXIII 6; Dem. XIX. 264; cf. the simple ti/qesqai in c. 82. 27; viii.84.19. —e)n kairw=|: answers to eu)= parasxo/n, c. 120. 18.
kata\ polla/: on many grounds; cf. c. 33. 2; 123. 8.
e)pikrath=sai: see on c. 81. 13.

e)mpeiri/a| polemikh=|: with the implied limitation e)n tw=| pezw=|, which is added by Phormio in ii.89.8, and is really involved in
the closely connected dat. plh/qei.
o(moi/ws pa/ntas : see on 93. 8; cf. ii.11.39, pollou\s o)/ntas e(ni\ ko/smw| xrwme/nous.

ta\ paraggello/mena : particularly used of military orders; cf. ii.11.39; 84. 18; 89. 40; iv.34.23; and again with i)e/nai e)s, iii.55.13. The expression well describes the ko/smos of the Dorian discipline.
nautiko/n te: the third reason; see on c. 33. 2. Therefore de/ of the Vat. is to be rejected.
e)cartuso/meqa: see on c. 13. 5. The confidence of the speaker in the result of his advice requires the fut. (as in 19, oi)/somen), though most Mss. have e)cartusw/meqa.
e)n *delfoi=s kai\ *)olumpi/a| : so in ii. 13. § 4 Pericles suggests a similar resource. We may perhaps infer from this that Delphi had again passed out of the hands of the Phocians. See c. 112. § 5.
u(polabei=n: see on c. 68. 18. Cf. the reply to this in c. 143. § 1.

ce/nous: only here a complete adj.; in c. 143. 3 it is tou\s ce/nous tw=n nautw=n. The sailors from the allied cities and islands serving in Attic ships are meant.—nauba/tas: a poetic word (Aesch. Pers. 375, 1011; Soph. Aj. 348; Phil. 270), occurs again vii.75.44; viii.44.3. Poll. i. 95 calls it tragikw/teron.
w)nhth/ : here, procured by money; so Soph. O. T. 1123; Eur. Hec. 365; usually ‘purchasable,’ as in iii.40.2.
tou=to: i.e. loss of men through the temptation of higher pay.
toi=s sw/masi i)sxu/ousa: accordingly oi)kei/a.

mia=| te...a(li/skontai : and by a single victory at sea it is likely that Athens is (i.e. will be) taken. See Herbst, Philol. 38, p. 582, who regards this as one indication that this book was written after the battle of Aegospotami. a(li/skontai is here in effect a fut. pf. Cf. vi.91.10, e)/xetai kai\ h( pa=sa *sikeli/a.
ei) d) a)nti/sxoien : and supposing they should still hold out. Cf. c. 7. 6; 65. 6; ii.64.26.
meleth/somen: expresses greater confidence than would the more regular meletw=|men a)/n; see on c. 120. 17. For the contradiction of this sanguine hope, see c. 142. § 6.
e)s to\ i)/son katasth/swmen: have placed on a par. Cf. c. 39. 4.

o(\ d)...prou/-
xousi: not properly trans., but o(/ is acc. of measure, like polu/, c. 25. 20, and plei=ston, iv.12.18. It is, however, practically what advantage they have.
kaqairete/on: we must master. Cf. Hdt. vii. 50, mega/la prh/gmata mega/loisi kindu/noisi e)qe/lei kataire/esqai. Eur. Sup. 749. The verb is a strengthened katalamba/nein. Stahl, Jahrb. 1863, p. 412.

e)s au)ta/: for this purpose, viz., the formation of a marine. Cf. c. 1. 10; 22. 15; 26. 16; 97. 7.—oi)/somen: of taxes. Cf. c. 19. 6; 80. 20; iv.57.21; vi.84.12.—deino
 a)
 ei)/h kte(.: see on c. 35. 4. Inconsistent thoughts may have their incongruity sufficiently indicated by simple juxtaposition with me/n—de/. Cf. Dem. XXXIV. 26-28. The neg. ou), which either might then take, may be retained as here, even when the pair (really the attempt to hold the two at the same time) forms the protasis of deino
(a)/topon)a)
 ei)/h (cf. Dem. 11. 24; XXVII. 28; XXXVIII. 18; Lys. XX 19; XXII. 13; XXX. 32; Hdt. vii.9.6); or ei) may make itself felt, and suggest mh/; and sometimes we have an opt. corresponding to a)
 ei)/h of the apod. (cf. Lys. XXIX 9, 11; XXX. 16; XXXI. 31; Dem. XVIII. 160; XXXIV. 47, 48; Isae. X. 23). The contrasted clauses, which Sh. calls ‘bimembered sentences,’ sometimes have the inf. (cf. Dem. XXXIV. 43).
doulei/a| th=| au(tw=n: see on c. 1. 6.

e)pi\ tw=| kte(.: the two objects to be gained are separated by ou)k a)/ra dapanh/somen. kai/ is to be connected with a(/ma; the chastisement of their enemies and their own security go hand in hand. The inferential a)/ra serves here an ironical purpose; a thing is treated as reasonable and as a natural consequence, the exact opposite of which ordinary good sense would assume. To be stingy with our money in the present case would be just as absurd as the inference: ‘because the Athenian allies are never tired of subscribing for their own enslavement, we need not contribute anything to maintain our freedom.’ Cf. Plat. Apol. 34 c; 37 d; Rep. 600 d; Lys. XII 36. So in vi.76.18, the clauses are in reverse order.— 23. au)ta/: and au)toi=s tou/tois refer to xrh/mata; “that our property may not be used to our own ruin.”
The war itself may suggest other methods of assailing them. Anyhow, shame should prevent us from ever yielding to them.
o(doi/: metaph. as in c. 69. 12. Cf. Tac. Ann. ii. 5, proeliorum vias.

a)po/stasis: revolt, from the intr. a)posth=nai, yet no doubt con
ceived as brought about by their enemies, and so parai/resis, ‘withdrawal’ (Plat. Rep. 573 e), stands as a strictly corresponding notion. A trans. meaning ‘seduction’ cannot be shown to belong to this or any other compound. Nearest is kata/stasis, viii.72.10. —ma/lista ou)=sa: showing its main effect in. Cf. iv.12.17.

e)piteixismo/s: or e)pitei/xisis, the occupation of a stronghold on the frontier or in the territory of an enemy; which was carried out in 413 at Decelea. See vi.91.25; 93. 6; vii.18.29; 28. 13.— th=|xw/ra|: governed by the verbal noun. Cf. c. 63. 9; 73. 1; 96. 10.
e)pi\ r(htoi=s: on predetermined conditions, according to fixed laws. Cf. c. 13. 4; 65. 7; 69. 9; 70. 10. The personification of o( po/lemos is continued in the following.
texna=tai: devises ways and means. Cf. iv.26.32.

pro\s to\ paratugxa/non: according to circumstances as they arise. para- has the effect of a)ei/, of what presents itself from time to time; therefore the sing. So the aor., iii.82.47; v.38.3.—e)n w(=|: wherein. See on c. 39. 11.—eu)orgh/tws kte(.: in these phrases the personification of war is maintained. Here o)rgh/ has the general meaning of passionate excitement, as in iii.82.19; viii.83.16. eu)o/rghtos, properly observing due measure in passion, is nearly =sw/frwn, ‘discreet,’ ‘sedate.’ It recurs only in late writers.

peri\ au)to/n: with o)rgisqei/s, as au)tw=| with prosomilh/sas: who allows himself to be moved by passion in regard to war. To read peri\ au(to/n in connexion with ptai/ei does not suit the sense, for mischances in war come from without; and we should have au(tw=|. Cf. c. 69. 27; vi.33.30; Hdt. ix.101.13.—ou)k e)la/ssw ptai/ei: cf. iv.18.15; vi.33.30; fails not less (i.e. “is surer to fail”), sc. ‘than another.’ Cf. vi.36.16; vii.28.15. The same thought in iv. 18. § 4.
a)ntipa/lous: nearly matched, opponents with whom we could cope. Cf. ii.89.20.—oi)sto/n: tolerable; classical only here and vii.75.46.

kai\ kata\ po/lin: with this pro\s h(ma=s is to be supplied from the former clause, te—kai/ uniting the two clauses as wholes.—e)/ti dunatw/teroi:=ma=llon e)/ti dunatoi/. Cf. c. 68. 2.—kai\ a)qro/oi: kai/ is intensive, vel universi; this is expanded in kai\ kata\ . . . a)/stu.— 12. a)/stu : probably to be taken as a part of e)/qnos (cf. ii.9.16; iii.92.22); each particular town in Laconia, Boeo
tia, etc.; or perhaps e)/qnos indicates the larger, and a)/stu the smaller independent states, answering to kai\ mei/zoni kai\ e)la/ssoni po/lei in c. 125. 3.
di/xa: cf. c. 64. 6; vi.100.4. On advs. so used, see Kühn. 353, note 2; Kr. Spr. 62, 2, 4.
ou)k a)/llo ti: the retention of ou) after the imv. is due to the fixity of the formula.

a)/ntikrus: to be connected closely with doulei/an, downright slavery. So li/qoi loga/dhn, iv.31.13; custado\n ma/xai, vii.81.25. In viii.64.23, we have h( a)/ntikrus e)leuqeri/a, with the art. in the usual way. Cf. Ar. Nub. 1120. Kühn. 462 m.

o(/: but that this (see on c. 10. 20; 33. 13; 35. 15). This forms the subj. of lo/gw| e)ndoiasqh=nai, “that it should be represented even in words as a possible occurrence.” e)ndoia/zein (from e)n doih=|, Hom. I 230, as dubitare from duo, zweifeln from zwei), to waver between two possibilities (cf. c. 36. 9; vi.91.20), and so to look upon as conceivable.
e)n w(=|: cf. 6, here=ei) d) o(/mws tou=to cumbai/h.

h)\ dikai/ws pa/sxein : either to suffer it deservedly, on account of some unexpressed guilt. This, as hardly probable, is placed first in order to lay stress on the second, the imputation of cowardice, which is then dwelt upon.—dokoi=men a)/n: men would say of us xei/rous fai/nesqai, that we showed ourselves worse. So there is no pleonasm in these verbs.

h(mei=s de/: is so directly opp. to oi(/, that the clauses should not, as usual, be separated by a colon. The thought of tw=n pate/rwn xei/rous is developed on both sides, the relation of which we should naturally express by rendering oi(/, for while they. Cf. c. 70. § 1; 74. § 1.

au)to/:=to\ e)leu/qeron ei)=nai or th\n e)leuqeri/an, from h)leuqe/rwsan. Cf. c. 68. 9.—tu/rannon po/lin: cf. a)ndri\ tura/nnw|, vi.85.1. The usual order in which the general term precedes the special (cf. c. 124. 16) is here, as in c. 96. 6, inverted, not to make tu/rannon a pred., but to lay greater stress on the opposition to au)to/ (=e)leuqeri/an); and allow a despotic state to establish itself in Hellas (cf. c. 124. 15). To this is opposed in parataxis tou\s de\ . . . katalu/ein, “while we consider it our business,” etc. Cf. c. 86. § 2. On the fact, see c. 18. 3. The Lacedaemonian policy is regarded as determining that of the whole confederacy.
mona/rxous: this poetic word chosen probably as a variation of tura/nnous. Cf. Aesch. Prom. 324; Ar. Eq. 1330; Plat. Rep. 575 a.

ta/de: such policy.—triw=n: as duoi=n in c. 33. 23, before a disjunctive enumeration leaves the choice open. It is different in iii.40.7 with conjunctive particles.—cumforw=n: in the unusual sense of faults to which men are liable.—a)ph/llaktai: can be clear of. Cf. c. 143. 14; iii.63.17; viii.2.21.

ou) ga\r dh\...kexwrh/kate : this sentence is not to be taken, as it usually is, as a serious assertion, “for it is not certainly an avoidance of these faults if you have betaken yourselves to contempt”; but just as ou) ga\r dh/ is used in v.111.3, it implies ironically under the appearance of disbelief a strong suspicion; “for it may be hoped that you have not, while avoiding these faults, fallen into the far worse one of despising your enemy.”
e)pi\ th\n...katafro/nhsin : cf. viii.64.23. For the paronomasia, cf. c. 33. 26; 37. 16.
to\ e)nanti/on o)/noma: for the accusative, with a pass. verb of naming, cf. ii.37.3; iv.64.12. Kühn. 411, note 7.
metwno/mastai: has had its name changed, i.e. by those who judge rightly of the matter.
Our confidence is naturally increased by the favourable answer of the oracle.
e)s o(/son:=e)s tosou=ton e)s o(/son. So o(/son alone, iii.11.10.

toi=s nu=n: neut., opposed to ta\ progegenhme/na and ta\ me/llonta. So in 3, toi=s parou=si. Cf. c. 132. 8.—e)/peita: in the future, as in iii.39.43; often e)s(to\)e)/peita in this sense. Cf. c. 130. 10; ii.64.27; iv.64.21.

toi=s parou=si bohqou=ntas: through the support of what exists. So with dat. of thing, 13; c. 140. 8; ii.63.2.—e)pitalaipwrei=n: to labour yet more. Cf. Plat. Rep. 540 b. The force of e)pi- as in e)pixrh=sqai, c. 41. 4; e)pite/xnhsis, c. 71. 12; e)pimanqa/nein, c. 138. 12; e)pikta=sqai, c. 144. 2; iv.61.2; e)pikrath=sai, c. 121. 4.

u(mi=n: in reference to the character of the Dorian race, and especially of the Lacedaemonians.—ta\s a)reta/s: the fruits of uirtue, whether in reputation, as in c. 33. 12, or in services to others, as in iii.53.20.
ei) a)/ra: even if it is really true that.

e)cousi/a|: such freedom of action as results from the possession of means. Cf. c. 38. 13;
iii.45.17.—profe/rete: see on c. 93. 13; sc. tw=n pate/rwn.

kata\ polla/: three reasons are given in tou= te qeou= kte(., kai\ th=s a)/llhs kte(., sponda/s te kte(. (cf. c. 33. § 1; 76. 12), though the last is in a changed construction.—xrh/santos: see c. 118. 21. Thuc. uses the verb in this sense only in aor. Cf. c. 134. 19; ii.102.30; v.16.23; 32. 6; in iii.96.3, the pass. xrhsqe/n.

th=s a)/llhs *(ella/dos: including what is still free, as well as the subject-allies of the Athenians. To the former belongs fo/bw|(i(/na mh\ doulwqh=|, Schol.); to the latter, w)feli/a|, i.e. of gaining their freedom. The dat. for e)p' w)feli/a| (i.73.14; cf. ke/rdei, vii.57.55) is due to analogy of fo/bw|.
sponda/s: without art. Cf. c. 53. 4.

parabeba/sqai: this and similar pass. forms of compounds of bai/nein, which are rare, or not found in other Attic writers, are freq. in Thuc. Cf. iii.45.13; 67. 25; iv.23.6; 30. 20; viii.98.13.—h)dikhme/nais: there is no example of a)dikei=n sponda/s, yet it is justified by the connexion=a)di/kws parabai/nein. It is really a personification of *spondai/; “you will vindicate its insulted majesty.” This clause is introduced parenthetically by way of encouragement, the following lu/ousi ga\r kte(. giving the reason of what precedes.
Everything, therefore, forces us to the resolution to break down the dangerous power of Athens in Greece, by courageously entering on the war.

koinh=|: contains the gist of the argument; in the interest of all (cf. ii.43.14), with reference to the proof in c. 120. § 1, 2, that every state of the league is imperiled by the predominance of Athens. The following parenthetical sentence, ei)/per . . . ei)=nai, is intended to place the thought of koinh=| in a clear light; but to do this it is necessary to read with Reiske tau)ta/ for tau=ta; for the speech has nowhere shown that the war (polemei=n=ta/de=tau=ta) will be of advantage to individuals as well as states, though identity of interests is of the greatest importance. But kai\ po/lesi kai\ i)diw/tais must be connected with bebaio/taton, not with cumfe/ronta, as Thuc. often separates words which in sense belong together; “if the surest
guarantee for states and individuals is identity of interests.” See App.— 4. me/llete: in this sense regularly takes pres. inf.—poiei=sqai timwri/an: =timwrei=n with dat., succour. But in Dem. XXI. 26,=timwrei=sqai/ tina, ‘inflict vengeance on.’
ou(=...tou)nanti/on : for the ascendency of Dorians over Ionians was generally recognized. Cf. v.9.3; vi.77.9; vii.5.18.
metelqei=n: to strive to win, here for others, as, in ii.39.8, for one's self.

w(s ou)ke/ti e)nde/xetai: impers., as in c. 140. 9; 142. 25; ii.87.11; iv.18.20; viii.27.15; since it is no longer admissible. On this an inf. like periora=n should depend with perime/nontas, which implies the subject h(ma=s, “we can no longer wait and quietly see that,” etc. But instead of this the new infs. bla/ptesqai and pa/sxein (arranged in parataxis, as in c. 28. 15) are introduced as if depending on e)nde/xetai, with which they have nothing to do. We have, therefore, here, as in c. 18. 21; 39. 15; 61. 9, a change of subject within the period; for perime/nontas with its subject h(ma=s has, in strictness, no relation to tou\s me/n (probably tou\s *poteidaia/tas) and tou\s de/(tou\s a)/llous cumma/xous).
ou) tolmw=ntes: the neg. retained, which would occur in the assumed thought of the Athenians, viz. cunh=lqon me/n, a)mu/nesqai de\ ou)k e)to/lmwn.
e)s a)na/gkhn a)fi=xqai: impers., as in vii.75.38, that things have now come to an extremity, i.e. that war is necessary.
a)/rista: adj., not adv. Cf. c. 145. 2.—mh\ fobhqe/ntes: mh/ from the imv.
a)p' au)tou=: i.e. tou= pole/mou, coveting the more enduring peace which will result from it (cf. th=s di) o)li/gou mele/ths, ii.85.9). Cf. c. 12. 5; 23. 27.
e)k pole/mou: denotes merely the transition from one state to the other. Cf. c. 120. 17; Hdt. i. 87, e)c ai)qri/hs te kai\ nhnemi/hs sundrame/ein ne/fea.

a)f) h(suxi/as : denotes the motive as well as the fact of change; polemh=sai, aor. ingressive; from love of repose to refuse to enter upon war.—ou)x o(moi/ws: i.e. as if peace were firmly established. Cf. c. 99. 6.

po/lin tu/rannon: see on c. 122. 20. tu/rannon is not a pred., but kaqesthkui=an and kaqesta/nai are purposely repeated in the pregnant sense of ‘establishing itself.’—e)pi\ pa=sin: with menace to all. Cf. c. 102. 19; iii.63.3.
dianoei=sqai: sc. a)/rxein. Cf. c. i. 7.

parasthsw/meqa: see on c. 29. 22.—te: after au)toi/, though only in inferior Mss., is necessary, since the two subjvs. oi)kw=men and e)leuqerw/swmen are closely connected as the result of parasthsw/meqa.
War is decided on, and the preparations are begun.

toiau=ta...ei)=pon : regularly me/n is used in this formula (cf. c. 36. 22; 72. 1), as de/ in summing up an opposing speech (cf. c. 44. 1; 79. 1). Here me/n is omitted by the best Mss. In ii.65.1; 72. 1; 75. 1; iv.11.1; 65. 1; 93. 1; 96. 1; 127. 1, which Cl. refers to as similar to the present case, the partic. const. forbids the use of me/n.

gnw/mhn : as yh=fon in c. 87. 13, in collective sense without art. Cf. c. 128. 28; ii.2.24; 86. 17; iii.92.11; iv.125.20; vii.72.8. With this a)f' a(pa/ntwn is to be more closely connected than with h)/kousan. Cf. iii.36.24; vi.76.3.—e)ph/gagon: see on c. 87. 13.
e)yhfi/santo: with subj., to\ plh=qos. Cf. c. 24. 9; 34. 5; 89. 14; vi.4.27.

dedogme/non: see on c. 2. 8. The pf. partic. of a resolution adopted without causal connexion with what follows; do/can, when such a relation exists (cf. v.65.10; viii.79.2; 93. 7); dokou=n, used of an existing conviction which leads to no resolution (iv.125.3).—a)du/nata: see on c. 7. 2.— 6. e)kpori/zesqai: cf. c. 82. 11; vi.83.9.—e(ka/stous: this is Nattmann's conjecture for e(ka/stois, adopted by Cl. because the resolution was taken by the collective body, which the particular states were to execute. But no other recent editor has adopted this conjecture.

pro/sfora: to the purpose. Cf. ii.46.2; 65. 47; vii.62.10; rare in Attic prose.—mh\ ei)=nai: cf. the pregnant use of ei)=nai with neg., c. 2. 5; 49. 11; delay must not be allowed.— o(/mws de\ kte(.: “in spite of the resolution not to delay there was spent by
them making needful preparations not indeed a full year, but somewhat less.” Cf. Hdt. vii. 39, th\n me\n a)ci/an ou) la/myeai, e)la/ssw de\ th=s a)ci/hs. If the twofold proceedings at Sparta (c. 67-87 and c. 118-125) are compressed as closely as possible after the battle at Potidaea (c. 62), in Sept. 432, the final resolution cannot be placed earlier than October; and since the invasion of Attica took place in June, 431 (see on ii.2.7; 19. 4), seven or eight months must have been spent in preparation. For kaqistame/nois=paraskeuazome/nois, cf. ii.6.3; 94. 11; iii.28.17; v.12.5.

to\n po/lemon...fanerw=s : in distinction from the partial breach of the truce by the Thebans in the attack on Plataea, which took place 80 days before (ii. 19. § 1). See Vömel, Frankf. Herbstpr. 1845, p. 8.
Meanwhile the Spartans demand the banishment of the descendants of those who had incurred pollution in the matter of Cylon's attempted usurpation. Narration of this event.
e)presbeu/onto: impf. as introducing the negotiations, which, with various digressions, occupy c. 126-138.
o(/ti megi/sth pro/fasis: the strongest possible excuse. Cf. c. 141. 4.
e)sakou/swsi: cf. c. 82. 11.
prw=ton me/n: the correl. to this is u(/steron de/ in c. 139. 3.
to\ a)/gos e)lau/nein: a formula. Cf. c. 127. 1; 128. 2; 135. 3; ii.13.9; Soph. O. T. 97, mi/asma e)lau/nein. to\ a)/gos=tou\s e)nagei=s, i.e. tou\s e)kgo/nous tw=n drasa/ntwn to\ a)/gos.
th=s qeou= : sc. th=s *)aqhna=s.

*ku/lwn h)=n : for the abrupt form of the commencement, see on c. 24. 1; for the fact, cf. Hdt. v. 71. The ancient rhetoricians, admiring the clearness of this narration, said of this writer, le/wn e)ge/lasen e)ntau=qa.
