Schol.—*)olumpioni/khs: probably Ol. 35, B.C. 640; his attempt on the Acropolis, Ol. 42, B.C. 612. a)nh/r may belong to either the preceding or following word (cf. Hdt. v. 71), but the latter is more likely since *)olumpioni/khs often stands abs. Cf. Plat. Rep. 465 d.
tw=n pa/lai: cf. ii.35.17.
*qeage/nous: on him, see Arist. Pol. viii.4.5 (1505 a, 24); Rhet. i.2.19; Grote, III. chap. 9, p. 43; Curtius, Hist. of Greece, I. p. 305. He was contemporary with Periander of Corinth.

xrwme/nw|: here only in Thuc. for
inquiring of an oracle, and rare in Attic (Aeschin. 111. 124), but freq. in Hdt.: i. 46; 47; 53; 85; iii. 57; iv. 150; 151; 157; vii. 141; 220. For this we have e)perwta=n in c. 25. 3; 118. 20.— 10. th=| megi/sth|: for the art., cf. c. 23. 16.

e)ph=lqon: the plur. with the name of the festival, perhaps as including a number of spectacles. So v.75.8, *karnei=a e)tu/gxanon o)/nta. But the sing. also occurs where merely a date is given, v.49.1; viii.9.3. Kühn. 365 b.—ta\ e)n *peloponnh/sw|: Schol., tou=to prose/qhken, e)peidh\ e)/stin *)olu/mpia kai\ e)n *makedoni/a| kai\ e)n *)aqh/nais.
w(s e)pi\ turanni/di : the personal end indicated by these words is expressed in Hdt. v. 71, e)pi\ turanni/di e)ko/mhse, in the verb.

e(autw=| ti prosh/kein: had some special reference to him. Cf. ii.29.10; v.66.18.—*)olu/mpia nenikhko/ti: cf. Arist. Rhet. i.2.13; a)nairei=n, Hdt. vi. 36; kratei=n kai\ e)ste/fqai, Lucian. de merc. cond. 13; Olympia coronari, Hor. Epist. i.1.50.
ei)/rhto: had been designated, was meant.
ou)/te...kateno/hse : for the tense, cf. c. 66. 9; he had not gone on and considered.—te...ou)k : for ou)/te because the neg. belongs closely to the verb, “would not make plain.” See on c. 5. 14.
*dia/sia: cf. Ar. Nub. 408, 864; celebrated in Anthesterion, Febr. A. Mommsen, Heortol. p. 19.

*meilixi/ou: mentioned by Arist. de Mund. 7, among the general epithets of Zeus. Xen. An. vii.8.4; Pausan. i.37.4.—pandhmei/: as a general festival of the people, not in all demes. C. Wachsmuth, Rhein. Mus. 23, p. 178, note 31.

qu/mata e)pixw/ria: Schol., tina\ pe/mmata ei)s zw/|wn morfa\s tetupwme/na. Kr. regards polloi\ . . . e)pixw/ria as a gloss. This is not unlikely; but the addition more probably begins at e)/cw th=s po/lews. See App.
e)p' au)tou/s: sc. tou\s a)mfi\ *ku/lwna.

e)pigignome/nou : being spent over the siege. Cf. iv.26.11, o( xro/nos
para\ lo/gon e)pigigno/menos.

truxo/menoi : in iv.60.13 and vii.28.23 we have the pf. partic. from stem truxo-; in iii.93.9 and vii.48.11 the fut. and aor. from e)ktruxo-: these are the only forms in Thuc. of this verb, which often occurs in Hom., the Attic poets (Soph. Aj. 604; O. T. 666; Trach. 110; Eur. Hipp. 147; Hel. 521; Ar. Pax, 989; Ach. 68), and in later writers. It is not used by Hdt., and is rare in Attic prose (Xen. Hell. v.2.4).—oi( polloi/: added for precision. Cf. c. 2. 24; 18. 2; 119. 5.
toi=s e)nne/a a)/rxousi: at their head was Megacles. Plut. Sol. 12.

au)tokra/torsi: with unlimited powers for this occasion; i.e. without consulting the people.— a)/rista: a pred. adj. to an understood ei)=nai with a general subj. supplied from what precedes, as is shown by vi.26.4. Cf. vi.8.15; viii.67.18.

to/te de/: i.e. before the legislation of Solon; from which time the administrative power of the Archons gradually decreased, and was restricted chiefly to judicial functions. Schömann, Antiq. of Greece, I. p. 389. Wecklein thinks that in these words we have a correction of the statement of Hdt. v. 71, that oi( pruta/nies tw=n naukra/rwn, oi(/per e)/nemon to/te ta\s *)aqh/nas, were charged with the repression of Cylon. Perhaps these officers may have been subordinate to the Archons, and have acted as the agents of the Archon Eponymus in this affair. So Wachsmuth, Hell. Alt. I. p. 437. Grote, III. chap. 10, p. 53.
flau/rws ei)=xon: only here in Thuc.; cf. Hdt. iii. 129. Thuc. does not use the adj. flau=ros, but fau=los, though not fau/lws.
kaqi/zousin i(ke/tai : see on c. 24. 19.—to\n bwmo/n: of Athena.

a)nasth/santes: the regular word for this action. Cf. c. 128. 3; 137. 1; iii.28.13; 75. 16, 24.—oi( tw=n *)aqhnai/wn...th\n fulakh/n : note the very unusual position of the part. gen. between art. and noun. See on c. 9. 4, and Kr. Spr. 47, 9, 11. The pass. subj. here from the dat. of person with act., the acc. of thing being retained. G. 197, N. 2; H. 819 b. But the acc. of thing is subj. in v.31.14.— 34. w(s e(w/rwn kte(.: when they saw them near death; the reason of to\ a)nasth=sai being that the temple might not be
polluted with corpses.
e)f' w(=|: see on c. 103. 2. This clause belongs to a)nasth/santes.
a)pagago/ntes : i.e. to execution. Cf. c. 128. 4; iii.68.12; Lat. ducere.

e)pi\ tw=n semnw=n qew=n: the sanctuary of the Eumenides, which lay between the Acropolis and the Areopagus. Cf. Ar. Eq. 1312, kaqh=sqai/ moi dokw= )pi\ tw=n semnw=n qew=n. Probably Dobree is right in rejecting e)n toi=s bwmoi=s as a gloss; they fled to, not sat on, the altars (Plut. Sol. 12, toi=s bwmoi=s prosfugo/ntes).

e)n th=| paro/dw|: to be connected with kaqezome/nous; some on the way to execution perceived what was to be their fate, and sought safety at the altars of the Eumenides.—diexrh/santo: cf. iii.36.15; vi.61.17; freq. in Hdt.
a)lith/rioi th=s qeou=: probably was the standing designation of those concerned in this crime. Cf. Ar. Eq. 445. The adj. expresses extreme outrage. Dem. XVIII. 159; Aeschin. III. 131.
to\ ge/nos: chiefly the Alcmaeonidae, from Megacles who was their head.

h)/lase: note the anaphora. Cf. c. 28. 8; 30. 17; 47. 7; ii.85.7.— *kleome/nhs kte(.: after the fall of the Pisistratidae, he supported Isagoras against Clisthenes, the head of the Alcmaeonidae, and compelled him for a short time to flee; B.C. 508, Ol. 68. 1. Hdt. v. 70; Curtius, Hist. of Greece, I. p. 412 ff. So the sta/sis here is that of the aristocratic faction.
tou/s te zw=ntas: te connects this with the preceding, and the following kai/= even. But Kr. after P. brackets e)ce/balon.
kath=lqon : see on c. 113. 14.—u(/steron: probably in the same year, B.C. 508, in consequence of the adherence of the boulh/ to the constitution. Hdt. v. 72; Grote, IV. chap. 31, p. 92.
This demand was specially directed against Pericles.
dh/: so ou)=n (c. 26. 1; 51. 1) and d' ou)=n (c. 3. 19; 10. 33; 63. 4), after a considerable digression; here referring to c. 126. 5.

dh=qen: as they pretended; see on c. 92. 3. Here and in iv.99.7 placed before the words
referred to; unusual, but cf. Soph. Tr. 382; Eur. Or. 1119.—prw=ton: enhancement of the irony; first of all, potissimum. Cf. Eur. Med. 377; Phoen. 886.—ei)do/tes de/: from the position this means, but in fact because they knew.

prosexo/menon au)tw=|: sc. tw=| a)/gei; an unusual expression, explained by Plut. Per. 33, to\ a)/gos, w(=| to\ mhtro/qen ge/nos tou= *perikle/ous e)/noxon h)=n. His mother was Agariste, the niece of the Alcmaeonid Clisthenes. Hdt. vi. 131.

proxwrei=n: inf. pres. in sense of fut. after nomi/zontes. See on c. 82. 18; 93. 13. But St. reads r(a=|on a)\n sfi/si, and so B., v. H. Sh. thinks the pres. inf. is retained from the dir. disc., comparing iv.24.12; viii.27.14.
ou) tosou=ton...o(/son : see on c. 88. 2.

paqei=n a)\n...oi)/sein : the former of the limited act of banishment, the latter of enduring disfavour. Cf. c. 140. 28; ii.64.21; iii.13.28; 38. 12. Herbst, Hamb. Progr., 1867, p. 14. Thuc. uses fe/rein in this sense only with a thing for subj. (cf. c. 5. 10; 33. 11; ii.37.18; iv.17.4; vi.16.5); so here tou=to to\ pra=gma must be supplied.
th\n po/lin:=tou\s poli/tas.
th\n e)kei/nou cumfora/n : the Lacedaemonians profess to regard his connexion with the Alcmaeonidae as a misfortune.—to\ me/ros: see on c. 74. 23.
e)/stai: emphatic by its position. See on c. 2. 5.
w)/n: always with emphasis when it precedes (cf. c. 21. 5; 124. 4; 130. 2; ii.2.11; vi.15.9); since he was undoubtedly the most influential man at that time in Athens.
a)/gwn: cf. ii.65.34.
Counter-demands of the Athenians. The plans and last fortunes of Pausanias. Chaps. 128-134.
, 6. a)nteke/leuon...e)ke/leuon : marked anaphora in reference to c. 127. 1. Cf. c. 30. 17.

to\ a)po\ *taina/rou a)/gos: i.e. the guilt which reached Sparta from thence. In 4, however, the expression is local, unless, indeed, it is repeated there by mistake. For the particulars, see Paus. iv.24.5, and on the chronology, Kr. Stud. I.
152 ff.
a)pagago/ntes: see on c. 126. 35.
di) o(\ dh/: referring to a well-known fact.—sfi/sin au)toi=s: the direct reflexive used for the indirect. Kr. Spr. 51, 2, 7. Cf. ii.21.19.— seismo/n: cf. c. 101. 5.
th=s *xalkioi/kou: sc. *)aqhna=s, from her temple in the citadel, of which Paus., iii.17.2, says, to/n te nao\n o(moi/ws kai\ to\ a)/galma e)poih/santo *)aqhna=s xalkou=n. Curtius, Pelop. II. 227 ff.
to\ prw=ton: for the facts, cf. c. 95. § 3-6.

a)/neu *lakedaimoni/wn: =ou) keleusa/ntwn au)tw=n, c. 131. 3.— 13. to\n *(ellhniko\n po/lemon: not as in c. 112. 3, but the war still waged by the Greeks against the Persians. The expression is used with reference to the character which Pausanias, the former general of the Hellenes, would wish to give to his movements. Ullrich, Die hell. Kr. p. 22-31.

pra/ssein: loosely connected with a)fiknei=tai to express purpose (cf. c. 50. 3; 57. 12), though a different form has intervened, as in c. 72. 6. The verb implies, as often, secret management; here of his negotiations with the Persian king.
th=s *(ellhnikh=s a)rxh=s: the control of all Greece.
eu)ergesi/an de\ kte(.: this is an explanation of e)nexei/rhse.
a)po\ tou=de : “from the following circumstance,” belongs to both the following members.

kate/qeto: see on c. 33. 6. The aors. kate/qeto and e)poih/sato, as in c. 66. 9, to be rendered with ‘had.’ To the phrase eu)ergesi/an kate/qeto corresponds, as its pass., kei=tai/ soi eu)ergesi/a in c. 129. 13. e)s basile/a belongs to eu)ergesi/an, as in c. 41. 8.
th=| prote/ra| parousi/a|: see c. 94. 7. The dat. of time, as in c. 44. 3; ii.20.3; iii.54.13. Kr. Spr. 48, 2, 9.

prosh/kontes: partic. as subst. with adnominal gen. GMT.
108, 2, N. 3.—oi(\...to/te : by placing to/te thus in connexion with what precedes, instead of joining it with tou/tous, as is usually done, the rel. clause gets its full force; “and these were at that time taken prisoners.” Bekk., Kr., and B. bracket oi(/ on the ground that Thuc. uses e)/xein in this sense with only a single subj. But the mention of prosh/kontes (connexions in general) and cuggenei=s (blood-relations) after *mh=doi is like that of the leaders with their troops.

tw=n a)/llwn cumma/xwn: a)/llos used as when it implies not identity of class with what precedes, but only extension of number. Cf. ii.14.3; 77. 12; iii.19.8; iv.100.12. Kr. Spr. 50, 4, 11:—tw=| lo/gw|: as he represented. Cf. ii.65.40.
au)to/n: so Hdt. ii. 182, a)pedi/drhskon tou\s *)ai)gu/ptou pai=das.
e)/prasse de/: cf. c. 88. 1.
w(=|per: with the Vat. Ms. for w(=|, is very suitable in reference to this important agent, the very man to whom. Cf. c. 89. 6.
kai\ e)pistolh/n: the order similar to c. 9. 6; 11. 10; v.7.20; Dem. III. 6.
a)neure/qh: here only in Thuc.; freq. in Hdt., as i. 67; 137; iv. 44; vii. 8. g 3; ix. 12.
tou/sde te: correlative to kai\ gnw/mhn poiou=mai.

a)pope/mpei : the easy conjecture of a)pope/mpw to correspond with poiou=mai is refuted by a similar change of person in Xen. Hell. v.1.31. Cf. also c. 129. § 3, and the treaty in iv. 118.—dori/: old and poetic form for do/rati; so in iv.98.27.

gnw/mhn poiou=mai: form the design. Cf. ii.2.24; vii.72.8.—th\n sh/n: for the order, see on c. i. 6.— 31. a)re/skei: here only in Thuc. with acc., but pass. in c. 129. 14 (but freq. in Plat., as Theaet. 172 d; 202 c; so Soph. Aj. 584); with dat., c. 38. 8; iv.113.3; 121. 3; v.37.13; vi.24.16; vii.49.18; viii.43.11; 48. 20.— 32. e)pi\ qa/lassan: an oriental designation of the coast of Asia Minor inhabited by the Greeks.
*)arta/bazon: the well-known general of Xerxes. Cf. Hdt. vii. 66; viii. 126 ff.

*daskuli=tin: this satrapy, so called from Dascylium in Bithynia (Xen. Hell. iv.1.15), comprehended the northern part of Asia Minor; that of Sardis, the southern.—a)palla/canta: relieving, superseding. Cf. c. 90. 17.

kai\...a)ntepeti/qei au)tw=| : and he charged him with a letter in reply (addressed) to Pausanias at Byzantium. As the following inf. depends on the sense of keleu/ein, the const. would have been more regular if a)ntepeti/qei had been expressed as partic. For a similar irregularity, see on c. 16. 2. para/ is used of the official address of Pausanias.
th\n sfragi=da: i.e. the impression of the royal seal on the letter. Cf. Xen. Hell. vii.1.39.
e(autou=: i.e. basile/ws: here an indirect reflexive (cf. c. 128. 5), ou(= being found only in Plato. Kr. Spr. 51, 2, 4 and 5.
w(=de le/gei kte(.: the same direct beginning, without a xai/rein in the letter of Amasis to Polycrates, Hdt. iii. 40. See Bernays, Die Heraclit. Briefe, p. 118.
tw=n a)ndrw=n: in regard to these men, depending loosely on eu)ergesi/a.

kei=tai/ soi eu)ergesi/a : pf. pass. of (kata)ti/qesqai, c. 128. 16, the service is laid up, preserved; the execution of this is expressed in a)na/graptos (accent as a)na/dotos, iii.52.9, and both in meaning of past partic.; Kühn. 147 c, B). Cf. Hdt. viii. 85, *fu/lakos eu)erge/ths basile/os a)negra/fh., Such benefactors o)rosa/ggai kale/ontai *persisti/.
e)s a)ei/ : cf. e)s e)/peita, c. 130. 10; e)s au)=qis, iv.63.8.—toi=s a)po\ sou=: see on c. 37. 5.

mh/te nu\c kte(.: in oriental style. Cf. Hdt. v. 23.—e)pisxe/tw: trans. hinder. Cf. iv.5.5. Prob. aor. Kühn. 397, 3. The pres indic. e)pi/sxei in iii.45.15.—a)nei=nai: become slack in: usually with acc. of subst. Cf. iv.27.8, fulakh/n. Xen. Mem. ii.1.33, meqia=si ta\ de/onta pra/ttein.—
16. u(pisxnei=: this form of the second sing. mid. is rightly preferred by St. to -nh=| of Mss. So also in vi.14.1, h(gei= should be written; the only instances in Thuc. of this person.
kekwlu/sqw: sc. tou=to, o(\ pra/ssein me/lleis, unless the verb is to be taken impers., let there be no impediment. Cf. iv.14.14, and see on c. 46. 1.
e)/pemya: the past from the point of view of the reader. Cf. c. 23. 21. GMT. 17, 2, N. 5; H. 838; Kr. Spr. 53, 10, 1.
ta\ gra/mmata:=th\n e)pistolh/n, which is used with it in vii.8.12, 15. Cf. also c. 133. 1; 137. 20.

u(po\ tw=n *(ellh/nwn : u(po/ with a)ci/wma in pass. sense. Cf. vi.15.10; and so with do/casma in c. 141. 34; with a)rxh/, ii.65.40; with fugh/ in viii.64.14. The partic. w)/n (see on c. 127. 8) here and vi.15.9, of the impf., being held as he was before in high consideration, heightens the following climax.—*plataia=sin: locative. G. 61, N. 2; H. 220.

h)=rto : ai)/resqai, rare in Attic in metaphorical sense,=e)pai/resqai (c. 120. 19; iv.18.17), is freq. later. Cf. Plut. Fab. 8; Aemil. 12; also the epigram in vi.59.16. There is no proper opposition here; for he grew not in the estimation of others, but in his own self-conceit: and ou)ke/ti e)du/nato refers to the moral feebleness of vanity.

e)n: within the limits of. —tw=| kaqesthko/ti tro/pw|: the style established and traditional among the Greeks. Cf. ta\ kaqestw=ta no/mima, c. 132. 9; iii.9.1; 56. 5.—skeua\s *mhdika/s: the rare pl. points to the various articles of Eastern costume (see on c. 2. 12), and the verb e)ndu/esqai probably to the a)nacuri/des (Xen. Cyr. viii.3.13) as well as to the ka/ndus.
e)dorufo/roun : with acc. Cf. Hdt. ii. 168; iii. 127; Plat. Rep. 575 b.
tra/peza/n te: the third member, not related to the following kai/.

pareti/qeto : had placed before him, the mid. with causative meaning. G. 199, N. 2; H. 815; Kühn. 374, 7.—kate/xein: cf. ii.65.33; iii.62.13; iv.130.27.—th\n dia/noian: his real purpose. Cf. c. 132. 20; ii.20.19; iv.52.10.

braxe/si: trifling.
Cf. c. 14. 11; 117. 11. Here these are innovations in his mode of life. —th=| gnw/mh|: belongs to e)/melle, what in his heart he purposed.

meizo/nws: so iv.19.16; vi.27.9. On a larger scale than was permitted by ordinary Hellenic relations. This is the only form of this adv., mei=zon being probably always adj. Cf. other similar advs., meio/nws, Soph.; beltio/nws, kallio/nws, e)lasso/nws, Plat.; kreisso/nws, Antiph.; e)xqio/nws, Xen. See Kühn. 158, note 1.—e)s e)/peita: see on c. 123. 2; usually e)s to\ e)/peita, ii.64.27; iv.18.22; 64. 21.
te: inferential, and so.—o)rgh=|: in the old, chiefly poetic, sense of temper. Cf. c. 140. 3; iii.82.19; viii.83.15.—xaleph=|: harsh, imperious.
du/nasqai: i.e. without disagreeable consequences. Kr. proposes to omit du/nasqai and bring prosie/nai from prosi/hmi, ‘to admit to his presence.’ But would not this rather be prosi/esqai?
h( cummaxi/a mete/sth : see c. 95. § 4, tou\s cumma/xous metata/casqai.
ai)sqo/menoi: see on c. 95. 21.—to/ te prw=ton: not only the first time; c. 95. 9.

a)neka/lesan: had they recalled him; though in parataxis, really a prot. to what follows. Cf. c. 126. 17; 128. 16. P. reads a)nekale/santo with some Mss., which is less common; not used elsewhere by Thuc. in this sense. We have metape/mpesqai in c. 95. 9; 128. 8.—th=| *(ermioni/di: the art., because known from c. 128. 11.
bi/a|...e)kpoliorkhqei/s : forcibly dislodged. He was forced to retire from Byzantium, where he had established himself, c. 128. 17. We must not think of a regular siege.

*kolwna/s: see Strab. xiii.1.19; Pausan. x.14.1: with the fem. noun ta\s *trw|a/das used as adj. (cf. *)ia/s, iv.61.10; *(ella/s, vi.62.9, and see Kühn. 405, 1), to distinguish it from places in Phocis and Thessaly.—i(druqei/s: often used of troops taking up a position (cf. iii.72.8; iv.42.9; 44. 11; 131. 2), and then mostly with e)pi/ with the gen. For e)s, see on c. 87. 7.—pra/sswn: and poiou/menos in pers. const. with the pass. e)shgge/lleto. Cf. iii.16.12; and see Kühn. 482, 4; 484, 17; Kr. Spr. 56, 7, 3.

pro/s: with, of negotiations. Cf. ii.5.32; iii.28.11; iv.68.14. As applied to a number of people, e)s
may also be used. Cf. c. 132. 21.— e)p' a)gaqw=|: cf. c. 34. 4; 126. 14.
ou(/tw dh/: see on c. 49. 30.—e)pe/sxon: intr., delay. Cf. c. 90. 20; iv.78.29. See on c. 129. 15.

skuta/lhn: Schol., cu/lon stroggu/lon e)cesme/non e)pi/mhkes, which by means of a strap wound around it and then written on, served the Spartans as a means of secret communication. Plut. Lys. 19; Nep. Paus. 3. 4; A. Gell. xvii.9.6. Pausanias was still in possession of the staff, probably as guardian of the young king Plistarchus.— ei)=pon:=first e)ke/leuon and then a)ph/ggeilan. Cf. proei=pon, c. 26. 20.—mh\ lei/pesqai, not to remain behind. More usual a)polei/pesqai.
ei) de\ mh/ : see on c. 28. 10.
dialu/sein: cf. iii.83.5; iv.118.36. dialu/esqai with pl. subject and reciprocal operation, c. 140. 17; 145. 6; v.80.2.
e)spi/ptei: pass. to e)sba/llein, after analogy of e)kpi/ptein, c. 2. 23; ii.27.7; iii.68.17. Cobet, Mnem. 12, p. 129 ff.
to\n basile/a: of course, therefore, the guardian of the king.

dra=sai: see on c. 5. 12. poiei=n is more common with a double acc.—e)/peita: the next step after to\ prw=ton; u(/steron, after some while.— diapraca/menos: the object to be supplied out of the result itself (e)ch=lqe). Cf. iii.82.66; v.89.7. Schol., diakrousa/menos th\n kathgori/an. Grote, V. chap. 44, p. 125, with the Schol., thinks by bribery.
e)ch=lqe kai\ kaqi/sthsin: on the change of tense, see Kühn. 386, 6.—toi=s boulome/nois: pl.; so in iv.118.9; usually sing. Cf. c. 26. 3, 20; ii.34.10; iii.66.2; iv.26.15.
peri\ au)to/n: as in c. 135. 6, tw=n peri\ *pausani/an e)le/gxwn.
o(/tw| a)\n kte(.: a)/n belongs to e)timwrou=nto (would have undertaken to punish), bebai/ws to pisteu/santes.
tou= basilei/ou : on the order, see on c. 1. 6.

a)neyio\s w)/n: see on c. 94. 1.—
e)petro/peuen: has the acc. in Attic writers (Ar. Eq. 212; Plat. Rep. 519 b), the gen. in Hdt. i. 65.—u(poyi/as: grounds for suspicion, opp. to fanero\n shmei=on. For pl. of abstracts, see Kühn. 348, 3 c; Kr. Spr. 44, 3, 4.— 7. paranomi/a|: violation rather of custom than of law. So vi.15.15; 28. 13, of Alcibiades.—zhlw/sei: united to paranomi/a| by the single art. (see on c. 120. 10) as defining it; though in strictness te after th=| demands a second art.—i)/sos ei)=nai toi=s parou=si: to acquiesce in things as they were, the established arrangements. Cf. vi.16.18; viii.89.24. parou=si is neut., as in c. 123. 3.

ta/ te a)/lla: te stands here as copulative conj. and also as correl. to the following kai/. But Ullrich, Beitr., 1862, p. 34, inserts kai/ before ta/. This, Stahl adopts, and B. approves. P. regards te as only the copula.— au)tou=: in him. Cf. c. 68. 7, tw=n lego/ntwn.
a)nesko/poun : of inquiry into the past. Cf. vii.42.24.

e)cededih/|thto: in pf. and plpf. the double aug. probably without exception (cf. vii.77.10; Dem. XXI. 85), but not so consistently in aor.; dih/|thsa and e)dih/|thsa, dih|th/qhn (vii.87.15) and e)dih|th/qhn.
tw=n nomi/mwn : gen. depending on e)c ededih/|thto, imitated by Dion. H. A. R. v. 74, mhde\n e)kdiaitw/menos tw=n patri/wn.

to\n tri/poda : cf. Hdt. ix. 81, o( tri/pous o( xru/seos, o( e)pi\ tou= trikarh/nou o)/fios tou= xalke/ou e)pestew/s. The gold tripod was carried off by the Phocians in the sacred war (Pausan. x.13.5), but the bronze pillar of three intertwined snakes was removed by Constantine to Byzantium, and placed in the hippodrome, the modern Atmeidan. Gibbon, chap. 17, note 48. This remarkable monument, completely brought to light in 1856, contains the names of all the Greek states which took part in the Persian war. The e)legei=on (acc. to Pausan. iii.8.1, composed by Simonides) was probably on the tripod itself, while the Lacedaemonians e)pe/grayan (16) on the pillar. O. Frick, N. Jahrbb. Spplbd. 3, Heft 4, 1859; Hicks, Inscr. p. 11.
a)po\ tw=n *mh/dwn: short for e)k tw=n *mhdikw=n lafu/rwn.

a)kroqi/nion : pl. in Hdt. i. 86; 90; viii. 121; 122; sing. in Eur. Phoen. 282; Plut. Mar. 23; the choice part of the booty.—h)ci/wsen e)pigra/yasqai: he presumed (an exaggeration of the meaning of c. 22. 9) to have inscribed; mid. as in c. 130. 8; 134. 23.
i)di/a|: without authority of the state, opp. to dhmosi/a|, as c. 128. 11; ii.65.6; iv.121.6.

e)ceko/layan: like the simple kola/ptein applied to erasure from
metal or from stone.
cugkaqelou=sai: Hdt. viii. 82, of the same fact says, e)n toi=si to\n ba/rbaron katelou=si.

tou= me/ntoi *pausani/ou : in opp. to his action; though the inscription could be erased, yet he was not himself free from guilt. The subj. of e)do/kei is the before-mentioned action, to\ e)pigra/yasqai i)di/a| kte(., to which a)di/khma ei)=nai is pred. We must therefore read kai\ to/t) for kai\ tou=t). See App.
e)n tou/tw|: Schol., e)n th=| kathgori/a| tou= *mhdismou=.
paro/moion : see on c. 80. 8.—praxqh=nai: with allusion to his secret intrigues.—dianoi/a|: as in c. 130. 8.
e)s...pra/ssein : see on c. 65. 12; 131. 7.

kai\ h)=n de\ ou(/tws: in this combination of particles (cf. ii.36.2; iv.24.5; vi.71.12; vii.56.10; viii.67.19) kai/ is not the copula, but even, here emphasizing the fact as opp. to conjecture, and de/, now, epexegetic.— 23. to\ pa=n: his whole plan. Cf. c. 72. 6; 126. 26; v.30.6.
ou)de\...pisteu/santes : explains ou)d' w(/s, since so far the source of their knowledge has not been named.— 25. new/tero/n ti poiei=n:=newteri/zein, c. 58. 3. Cf. ii.6.7; iv.51.3.
w(=|per ei)w/qasin: sc. xrh=sqai.
mh\ taxei=s ei)=nai : not to be over-hasty; with inf. as in c. 118. 11.

a)ndro\s *spartia/tou: of the Dorian stock.— 28. ti a)nh/keston: a euphemism for capital punishment. Cf. iii.39.40; iv.20.2.—pri/n ge dh/: more forcible than pri\n dh/, c. 118. 13, with which accords the pres. gi/gnetai. GMT. 67, 1; H. 924 a.
basilei=: dat. with e)pistola/s. Cf. c. 5. 6, toi=s a)sqene/si trofh=s.
e)pistola/s : of a single letter. Cf. viii.39.15.
*)argi/lios: from Argilos in Chalcidice.

pisto/tatos: i.e.
up to this time; fear for his own safety first changed him.—e)kei/nw|: after au)tou= on account of the change of case, to avoid the repetition of the same word. Cf. c. 138. 29; iv.29.17; v.30.22; vi.61.21; Plat. Prot. 310 d; Phaed. 60 d; 111 b.—mhnuth\s gi/gnetai: assumes the part of an informer, a stronger mhnu/ei. See on c. 35. 12. After this statement of the essential fact, the narrative returns in dei/sas . . . a)fi/keto to the motive of it; and since this suggested the mention of the immediate results, we have with a second finite verb (lu/ei ta\s e)pistola/s) a report of what was really antecedent in time. Cf. a similar violation of the order of time in c. 9. § 2.
kata\ e)nqu/mhsi/n tina: because he had observed with misgiving.
ti metagra/yai: to change something in the letter. But in iv.50.7 the mid. means ‘to translate.’

e)n ai(=s u(ponoh/sas ti kte(.: in which, as he had conjectured that some such special instruction was enjoined, he actually found himself set down for death. kai/ is to be referred rather to the whole following clause than to au(to/n alone, though this is accentuated by its position and by the reference to earlier messengers.
e)ggegramme/non: masc. in agreement with au(to/n, for ktei/nein= interficiendum. Cf. pare/xw e)mauto\n e)rwta=n, praebeo me interrogandum. Kühn. 473, 7; Kr. Spr. 55, 3, 14, 20.
to/te dh/: so with Vat. better than de/, pointing back to c. 132. 28, pri/n ge dh\ . . . gi/gnetai.
ma=llon me\n e)pi/steusan : cf. 132. 24, ou)de\ . . . e)pi/steusan.
*pausani/ou : governed by au)th/kooi, like a)kou/ein. Kühn. 417, note 6; Kr. Spr. 47, 26, 1.—a)po\ paraskeuh=s: by agreement, ex composito. Cf. iv.130.20, a)po\ proeirhme/nou tino/s.
i(ke/tou oi)xome/nou : to be taken in close connexion, as c. 24. 19, i(ke/tai kaqezo/menoi.

skhnhsame/nou : from skhnei=sqai (or skhna=sqai), elsewhere probably intr. (cf. ii.52.9; Plat. Rep. 621 a; Legg. 866 d; the word does not occur in Hdt., and only in active forms in Xen., An. iv.5.33; vii.3.15; Cyr. iv.2.11; Hell. iv.6.7, but always intr.), must here be taken trans., having prepared for temporary occupation. But the conjecture of Madvig (Adv. I. 309), skeuasame/no:, which Sh. also proposed, would be simpler and easier.—diplh=n diafra/gmati kalu/bhn: a hut divided in two
by an intervening partition.—tw=n [te] e)fo/rwn: the te though found in all Mss. should be rejected with St. and P.; so Kr. and v. H. The two participial clauses, boulhqe/ntes kte(. and *pausani/ou . . . e)lqo/ntos kte(. form a proper antecedent to h)/|sqonto kte(., which te only obscures.

e)nto/s: proleptically used with e)s h(\n . . . e)/kruye, the position which is the result of the action being anticipated. Cf. iv.129.16, e)cestratopedeume/noi e)/cw th=s po/lews, where, however, Cl. in his text omits e)c-.
pa/nta : as elucidated in the following participial clauses.— safw=s: placed at the end for emphasis, no more doubt remaining. Cf. c. 77. 19.—ai)tiwme/nou: with acc. Cf. c. 123. 2; v.30.5.

paraba/loito: like the Homeric parati/qesqai(b 237; g 74), to place at hazard—lit., on the table where dice are thrown—; in mid., at one's own cost or by one's own fault; so to bring into danger, compromise. Cf. ii.44.16; iii.14.5; 65. 12.—protimhqei/h: by its position strongly contrasts service with payment, with bitter irony; his preferment was to die just like the ruck of his servants.
au)ta\ tau=ta: the very fact. Bekk., seeing no reason for this emphasis, conjectured au)= tau=ta/ te; easier would be au)tw=| tau=ta, or with Tilmanns, au)tou= tau=ta.
ou)k e)w=ntos : urging him not. Cf. c. 127. 10; vi.72.7.

dido/ntos: offering, promising. Cf. c. 33. 25; iv.86.8.—th=s a)nasta/sews: (cf. c. 126. 33) depends on pi/stin, “an assurance of safety in his quitting,” and explained by e)k tou= i(erou=, which is so placed for emphasis. It was all-important to Pausanias to put an end to this strange i(ketei/a.— 15. ta\ prasso/mena : i.e. pro\s basile/a (c. 131. 6), not e)s tou\s *ei(/lwtas (c. 132. 21).
bebai/ws: i.e. with sure grounds of proof, which were wanting in c. 132. 1.

e)poiou=nto: impf., as in c. 26. 23; 48. 2; 107. 11;
113. 7; they made preparations for.— 5. w(s ei)=de: for this position of the conj., see on c. 77. 4.—e)f' w(=|: of purpose, as c. 3. 9; 34. 4; 126. 14; 131. 8; iii.63.3; vi.28.10.

a)fanei=: i.e. hardly perceptible to any one else.— dhlw/santos: cf. c. 82. 4; 90. 10; giving him to understand their purpose.— 7. th=s *xalkioi/kou: see on c. 128. 6. —prokatafugei=n: outran his pursuers and escaped. Lycurg. Leocr. 128, fqa/sai katafugo/nta.
oi)/khma : this must have been, as the subsequent treatment of it shows, a building subordinate to the temple, not a part of the temple itself. Cf. ii.4.24; iv.47.9.
u(pai/qrios: adv. meaning expressed by local, as often by temporal adj. See on c. 12. 3; 61. 18.
to\n o)/rofon: in iv.48.10, Thuc. uses th\n o)rofh/n.

e)/ndon o)/nta thrh/santes : cf. ii.83.8; vi.100.10; viii.108.22; he might leave the chamber whether, as Schol. says, e)ch/|ei ei)s to\ i(ero\n polla/kis, or for other purposes. —a)polabo/ntes ei)/sw: i.e. cutting him off after he had got within. But Cobet brackets these words, thinking that ei)/sw is used for e)/ndon, which “nunquam apud bonos scriptores legitur.”
a)pw|kodo/mhsan: cf. vii.73.8.—proskaqezo/menoi/ te: (the third particular) cf. c. 11. 14; 26. 19; 61. 8; 126. 23.—e)cepolio/rkhsan limw=|: they starved him out; different from c. 94. 6; 131. 5.
a)poyu/xein: to expire; rare in Attic prose. Hom. w 348; Soph. Aj. 1031 with bi/on.

w(/sper ei)=xen : just as he was; an expression indicating immediate action, generally with the implication that something more might have been expected. Cf. ii.4.28; iii.30.3; vi.57.10; viii.42.1; sometimes, as viii.41.16, strengthened by eu)qu/s.

ai)sqo/menoi : see on c. 95. 21. The particles te—kai/ distinguish markedly the last particulars; he was brought out still living, and died immediately after. See Herbst, Philol. 16, p. 306 ff.—e)/ti e)/mpnoun: cf. v.10.52.

*kaia/dan: a cleft in the mountains not far from the city, probably
near the modern Mistra, into which, in early times prisoners, in later, the corpses of criminals, were thrown. Strab. viii.5.7; Paus. iv.18.3; Curtius, Pelop. II. 252.—ou(=per tou\s kakou/rgous: e)mba/llousin is to be supplied. Some inferior Mss. read ei)w/qesan, but this is a gloss, as the three words probably are.
plhsi/on pou: sc. tou= *kaia/da.
e)/xrhse : see on c. 123. 8.
ou(=per:=e)kei=se ou(=per.

protemeni/smati : Schol., e)n tw=| propulai/w|, e)n tw=| pro\ tou= i(erou= proastei/w|. But the latter statement can hardly be correct, since the temple was in the middle of the town (Curtius, Pelop. II. p. 227) and Paus. iii.14.1 saw the tomb of Pausanias tou= qea/trou a)pantikru/. The proteme/nisma was “a sort of lodge or entrance to the sacred ground.” Arn.—o(/: refers to the previous statement, that he was buried in the space before the temple.—grafh=|: rare in this sense; in ii.43.19, sthlw=n e)pigrafh/; vi.59.12, e)pi/gramma.
w(s...to\ pepragme/non : contains the judgment of the god; for the acc. abs. (not here impers.) with w(s, cf. iv.5.3; vi.24.10; vii.31.19; viii.66.20. GMT. 110, N. 1; H. 974; Kühn. 488 d.
poihsa/menoi: hauing caused to be made. See on c. 130. 8.—a)ndria/ntas du/o: i.e. du/o ei)ko/nas *pausani/ou, as Pausanias, iii.17.7, saw them by the altar of Athena Chalcioecus.
The last fortunes of Themistocles. Chaps. 135-138.
oi( de\ *)aqhnai=oi kte(.: continued from c. 128. 1. a)ntepe/tacan answers to a)nteke/leuon there.
cuneph|tiw=nto: and h)ci/oun, 7, impf., as in c. 134. 3. But hu(/riskon of the gradual development of proof. Cf. Plut. Them. 23, e)pistolai/ tines a)neureqei=sai kai\ gra/mmata.
toi=s au)toi=s : i.e. qana/tw|. te is inferential.
e)/tuxe ga\r kte(.: see on c. 31. 7. This gives the reason of the following pe/mpousi.

e)/xwn di/aitan :=diaitw/me-
nos, living, abiding. Cf. ii.14.7; 52. 5.
ei)/rhto: cf. c. 129. 10; iii.52.6; v.58.20; vi.30.4.—a)/gein:= labo/ntas a)/gein, to which o(/pou kte(. is naturally joined. Cf. iv.39.12.

au)tw=n: sc. tw=n *kerkurai/wn. Cf. c. 24. 9; 34. 5.—eu)erge/ths: either because he took their part in a strife with Corinth (Plut. Them. 24), or (Schol.) excused their absence in the Persian war (Hdt. vii. 168). It is probable (Hermes, 14, 152) that a right of asylum had been decreed to him as eu)erge/ths.— 3. e)/xein au)to/n : to keep him with them; the object of fear in inf. Cf. iv.110.13; v.105.12. GMT. 46, N. 8.— w(/ste...a)pe/xqesqai : the result of e)/xein; by which they would become odious. a)pe/xqesqai here and a)ph/xqesqe, ii.63.6, are plainly aor. in sense; but by the evidence of Mss. the inf. (like kaqe/zesqai) seems to have kept the accent of the pres. Buttmann, Gram.II.^{2}p.141(1), 187; Kühn.I.p.827.
tw=n prostetagme/nwn: those appointed thereto. Cf. v.75.23; vi.31.31; vii.70.21; viii.8.13.

h(=| xwroi/h: depends on kata\ pu/stin, opt. of repetition: they were to pursue him in whatever direction their inquiries told them he had gone.—kata/ ti a)/poron: what this difficulty was is left unmentioned; a similar reticence in c. 72. 3. The conjecture to\ a)/poron is unnecessary.
katalu=sai: aor., ‘to take up one's quarters’ para/ tina: katalu/ein, ‘to dwell as a guest’ para/ tini. Cf. Plat. Prot. 311 a; Dem. XVIII. 82.
to\n pai=da sfw=n: she would say, to\n pai=da h(mw=n. Cf. v.71.14, dei/sas *)=agis mh\ sfw=n kuklwqh=| to\ eu)w/numon.

kaqe/zesqai : so we must write even against the Mss. for kaqi/zesqai. For Thuc., with Attic writers generally, uses only active forms of kaqi/zw. Cf. c. 126. 32; iii.28.13; 75. 15, 21. On the other hand, the mid. forms kaqezo/mhn, kaqezo/menos, kaqe/zwmai (c. 24. 20; vi.49.16; vii.67.13; 77. 22), and the inf. (see on 3), are always true aors, in sense.

o(/s e)sti: qui sit; the rule is to say oi)=da/ se o(\s ei)=, and ou)k oi)=da/ de o(stis ei)=, quis sis. But o(/stis is not seldom found after an affirmative (cf. c. 137. 11; Kühn. 562, 4), and o(/s sometimes after a negative. Kr. Dial. 61, 6, 1.

ou)k a)cioi=: like ou) fa/nai, ou)k e)a=n, with an appeal to the sense of honour:=ou)k a)/cion ei)=nai/ fhsi. Cf. c. 133. 13, and see on c. 102. 17.— ei)/ ti a)/ra: a)/ra implies the naturalness of the inference that former injury justifies revenge. See on c. 121. 22.
deome/nw|: the circumstances are not known. The Schol. merely conjectures peri\ cummaxi/as deh/sews.

kai\ ga\r a)\n...timwrei=sqai : gives the reason of what precedes, particularly of ou)k a)cioi=. All the better Mss. read a)sqeneste/rou; “he could in his present state be harmed by a far weaker man than Admetus; but a generous man will avenge himself only on persons who are on a par with him.” See App.
tou\s o(moi/ous: wrongly suspected by Cobet, is the object, and a)po\ tou= i)/sou denotes the position of the subject. See on c. 77. 8.

xrei/as tino/s: in the matter of some petition. Kr. Spr. 47, 21, 1; Kühn. 419 g. A similar gen. with e)nantiou=sqai, Xen. An. vii.6.5.—e)s to\ sw=ma sw/|zesqai: the art. belongs to the inf. sw=ma=life, as c. 85. 4, and requires no expressed art. Kr. Spr. 50, 2, 13.
ei)pw/n: inserted as dei/cas, c. 87. 8.—e)f' w(=|: see on c. 134. 5.— a)/n: repeated after the parenthesis. Cf. c. 36. 15; 76. 19.
a)ni/sthsi: see on c. 126. 33.
ui(e/os: see on c. 13. 26.—w(/sper kai\ e)/xwn: cf. c. 74. 25; 117. 17. kai/ emphasizes the identity of the present with the earlier situation.
me/giston: surest, most constraining. Cf. c. 126. 2.—ou) pollw=|: by Thuc. often placed after u(/steron. Cf. c. 18. 21; ii.27.6; 30. 10; viii.95.34.

e(te/-
ran: the Aegaean.

th\n *)aleca/ndrou: sc. po/lin, which is easily to be supplied here, though rarely omitted. He was then king of Macedonia, called o( file/llhn, son of Amyntas, and father of Perdiccas. Cf. c. 57. 4; Hdt. v. 19; viii. 121; 136; ix. 44.
a)nagome/nhs: see App. on c. 29. 18.
e)p' *)iwni/as: gen., as in c. 116. 3.
*na/con: the siege of c. 98. § 4, B.C. 466.—h)=n ga/r: see on c. 31. 7; 135. 8.
o(/stis...feu/gei : see on c. 136. 11. Cf. vi.34.40, o(po/soi t) e)sme\n kai\ e)n w(=| xwri/w|.

th\n a)sfa/leian : the indispensable means of safety. With such preds. the subj. inf. often omits the art. Cf. ii.45.9; iii.58.13. Kr. Spr. 50, 6, 5; Kühn. 473, 5.— 13. me/xri: with subjv. without a)/n, of a future event; as me/xri ou(= in iii.28.15; iv.16.16; 41. 2; 46. 12; e(/ws, Soph. Aj. 555; Trach. 148; Phil. 764; pri/n, vi.10.19; 29. 9; 38. 9; viii.9.3, 14; the rel. pron., iii.43.17; iv.17.6; 18. 13. Kühn. 398, note 2.— plou=s: opp. to a)/ploia; fair weather. Cf. iii.3.23; Hes. Op. 630.

xa/rin a)pomnh/sesqai: not elsewhere in prose. Hes. Theog. 504; Eur. Alc. 299. Kr. prefers a)pomemnh/sesqai, saying that mnh/sesqai is not Attic; and St. after L. Dindorf writes a)pomnhsqh/sesqai. But mnh/sei, fut. second sing., occurs in Eur. I. A. 667. So freq. in Hdt. See Veitch, Greek Verbs, p. 452.
a)posaleu/sas: cf. Dem. L. 22, a)nagkai=on h)=n e)p' a)gku/ras a)posaleu/ein th\n nu/kta metew/rous. Here it is probably simply “having ridden out the gale in the open sea.”
u(pe\r tou= stratope/dou: cf. c. 112. 9.
e)qera/peuse: applied to any kindly, generous dealing. Cf. c. 9. 16; iii.12.3; v.43.12; viii.52.14.
au)tw=|: see on c. 13. 12.
a(\ u(pece/keito: plpf. pass. of u(pektiqe/nai, c. 89. 15; what had been conveyed there for safety. Cf. viii.31.15.— ka/tw, a)/nw: referring as usual to the coast and the interior.

e)s basile/a: so the best Mss., not w(s or pro/s. The reference is to the king's palace, expressed also by ai( qu/rai basile/ws, Xen. An. i.9.3. Cf. e)s qeo/n,
Pind. Ol. VII. 32. So also Ar. Plut. 237, where Dind. now reads w(s, as Bekk., St., and v. H. do here.

newsti/: acc. to Kr., St. I. p. 31 and 52 ff., B.C. 473, against Diod. xi. 69. But see Curtius, Hist. of Greece, II. p. 399, note 45, p. 659, who assigns as the date B.C. 465. See on c. 104. 4, and Am. J. of Ph. VII. p. 325.
e)dh/lou: cf. c. 129. 1.
o(/ti: introducing oratio recta. Also in iv.38.16; v.10.20; viii.53.20. Kühn. 551, 4. Very rarely is w(s so used. Cf. Dem. XXI. 151; Dinarch. I. 12, 102.
e)pio/nta e)moi/: see on c. 83. 2. Themistocles speaks of himself as the representative of Hellas. Cf. iv.64.1.
e)n tw=|...e)moi/ : we must supply the pred. e)gi/gneto with a general subj., as the neut. pl. in c. 7. 2; 93. 14; 125. 5.

pa/lin: though before the art. in near relation to a)pokomioh/, as in iv.10.14 to a)naxwrh/sews. This connexion of pa/lin with a verbal subst. seems more natural when the art. precedes, as in vii.44.42, th=s a)po\ tw=n *)epipolw=n pa/lin kataba/sews, or where a noun of the contrary notion is opposed to it, c. 120. 10; v.5.1; vii.38.16. Herbst, Philol. 1866, p. 619 f.

kai/ moi kte(.: stands in relation to 30, kai\ nu=n e)/xwn kte(. He connects his services in the past with promises for the future.—gra/yas: inserted, as c. 87. 8; 136. 18, but more freely related to the introducing words, 21, e)dh/lou h( gr/afh/.

th\n proa/ggelsin th=s a)naxwrh/sews : the advice given to Xerxes (Hdt. viii. 110) to retreat before it was too late. Grote, IV. chap. 41, p. 474, refers this to the message (Hdt. viii. 75) that the Greeks were intending to flee from Salamis.—e)k *salami=nos: acc. to Hdt. viii. 108, the second message was sent from Andros. But the detail is unimportant, and the former designation was clearer for a Greek reader.

h(\n yeudw=s prosepoih/sato: Cobet, Mnem. 11, 375, wishes to erase these words. Most of the commentators find in them a contradiction of the statement of Hdt. But Hdt., viii. 108, says that Them. strongly urged the destruction of the bridge and was resisted by Eurybiades and the Peloponnesian commanders, and that only after this failure did he oppose (viii. 109) independent action on the part of the Athenians, a)poqh/khn me/llwn poih/sesqai e)s to\n *pe/rshn, i(/na . . . e)/xh| a)postrofh/n.

th\n . . .
to/te di) au(to\n ou) dia/lusin: note this free use of an adverbial qualification, “the non-destruction.” Cf. iii.95.12; v.35.6; 50. 17; vii.34.26. Kühn. 461, 6.
th\n sh\n fili/an: objective, on account of my friendship to you. Cf. c. 33. 19, 21; 69. 30; 77. 21.

au)tou=: see on c. 30. 14. —th
 dia/noian: power of mind directed to definite objects (cf. c. 130. 9; 132. 20; ii.20.19; iv.52.10), indications of which were in his letter. To these, and not merely to e)niauto
 e)pisxei=n, refer the words, poiei=n ou(/tws.— 3. o(
 e)pe/sxe : the rel. is here not assimilated (w(=|), in order not to obscure the expression of duration of time.

o(/sa e)du/nato: cf. the extravagant exaggeration of Nepos,
Them. 10, ut multo commodius dicatur apud regem verba fecisse quam hi poterant qui in Perside erant nati.
kateno/hse: learned; usually only of the apprehension of particular things. Cf. c. 126. 17; ii.3.7; iii.66.5.
a)fiko/menos: i.e. at the King's court.—meta\ to\n e)niauto/n: after the year agreed upon.
gi/gnetai me/gas: cf. Hdt. vi. 30.—*(ellh/nwn: Schol., *(istiai=os kai\ *(ippi/as kai\ *dhma/ratos kai\ a)/lloi.

kai\...e)lpi/da : the art. th/n is not as in c. 132. 7 to be repeated in thought, but is omitted because its place is supplied by h(\n u(peti/qei (see on c. 85. 1) as elsewhere by adj. and partic. with the art. Cf. c. 139. 12, a)ndrapo/dwn tw=n a)fistame/nwn. See on c. 1. 6.—tou= *(ellhnikou=: placed by prolepsis in gen. with e)lpi/da, though in sense it is obj. of doulw/sein. See on c. 61. 1. Kühn. 600, 5.
pei=ran didou/s: partic. impf.; by the repeated proofs which he gave of it.

h)=n ga/r: to be joined with a)/cios qauma/sai, of which bebaio/tata . . . dhlw/sas contains the justification; and so kai/ before diafero/ntws is intensive, as in c. 91. 3 before safw=s, in c. 3. 5 before pa/nu. For in fact (this is the force of the position of h)=n) Themistocles, having given the surest proofs of the strength of his native powers, was in the very highest degree worthy of admiration in that respect. To join h)=n with dhlw/sas (so St. and GMT. 108, N. 6) would be contrary to the usage of Thuc., who employs only pres. or pf. partics.
in periphrasis with ei)=nai. Cf. c. 38. 8; 99. 7; ii.12.6; 80. 15; iii.3.1.
e)s au)to/: cf. c. 68. 9; 74. 3; 84. 6; 122. 20.—ma=llon e(te/rou: see on c. 84. 7. —qauma/sai: so usually the act. inf. See Kühn. 473, note 14.

oi)kei/a| cune/sei: with an intelligence all his own, inborn as well as self-cultivated. This is enforced from the negative side, ou)/te promaqw/n, i.e. before his entrance into public life, ou)/te e)pimaqw/n, by which obligation to others is excluded. au)th/n is explained by the Schol. as =th\n i)sxu\n th=s fu/sews, but more probably=cu/nesin.

tw=n te paraxrh=ma : = tw=n paro/ntwn to be construed with gnw/mwn as the opposite tw=n mello/ntwn is with ei)kasth/s, so that di) e)laxi/sths boulh=s answers to e)pi\ plei=ston tou= genhsome/nou. v. H. inserts h)=n after gnw/mwn.
gnw/mwn: rare for krith/s. Cf. Aesch. Ag. 1130.
ei)kasth/s: only in Thuc. and late writers. See on these formations c. 70. 10. See App.—meta\ xei=ras: cf. Hdt. vii. 16; Aeschin. 1. 77. In Hom. x 10, meta\ xersi/n. From this, metaxeiri/zesqai.
e)/xoi...ei)/h : opt. as in c. 50. 2; 99. 14.—kai\ e)chgh/sasqai: also to set forth, lo/gois not e)/rgw|. Cf. v.26.31; vii.50.32; in ii.60.18, e(rmhneu=sai.

a)/peiros : not so much ‘without experience’ as ‘without being in direct contact with.’— 17. ou)k a)ph/llakto: litotes, he came not short of=ou)k a)du/natos h)=n, and so with inf. The pf. occurs again in c. 122. 22; 143. 14; iii.63.17.—to/ te a)/meinon: the third fact, in which tw=| a)fanei= e)/ti forms the new point.
e)/ti: to be joined with e)n tw=| a)fanei=. Cf. c. 30. 20; iii.13.5; iv.26.20; vii.84.10.—to\ cu/mpan ei)pei=n: cf. vii.49.18 The abs. inf. in parenthetical phrase. GMT. 100; H. 956.

fu/sews...braxu/thti : parallel structure of clauses, though each pair has a different relation; du/namis an essential quality, braxu/ths an accidental one.—20 ou(=tos: resumes the whole personality. Cf. c. 33. 10; ii.51.8; 64. 33.—au)tosxedia/zein kte(.: instantly to hit upon what was needed, in act as in word. The e(toi/mws le/gein of the Schol. is too narrow.

kai\ e(kou/sion: the particle connected with the fact instead of the notice of it (le/gousi/ tines).—
farma/kw|: for the various accounts, see Cic. Brut. 11. 43; Plut. Them. 31; Diod. xi. 58; Ar. Eq. 83.
th=| *)asianh=|: that on the Maeander (Diod. xi. 57), not that near Mt. Sipylus.— th=s xw/ras: the district belonging to the town.

do/ntos basile/ws: cf. Hdt. i. 92; vii. 135; ix. 107.—a)/rton...oi)=non...o)/yon : these preds. attached directly to the names answer to the Eastern mode of expression; though ei)s (inserted by Cobet) is found in Plut. Them. 29; Hdt. ii. 98; Xen. An. i.4.9. Athen. i. p. 29, adds, *perkw/thn kai\ th\n *palai/skhyin ei)s strwmnh\n kai\ i(matismo/n.
prose/fere : rare for the simple fe/rein, corresponding to prosie/nai (ii.13.23; vii.28.30) and pro/sodos.
poluoino/taton : neut. adj. with name of town also in <*> 1; iv.76.15. The district is <*>

fasi\...oi( prosh/kontes : Thuc. evidently doubts the truth of the statement. The words of Nepos,
Them. 10, ossa eius clam in Attica ab amicis sepulta, seem to rest on a misconception of our passage.
au)tou=: e)kei/nou. See on c. 132. 31.
ou) ga\r e)ch=n: cf. Xen. Hell. i.7.22.— w(s...feu/gontos : depending on ta\ o)sta=.
ta\ kata/ : with acc. of person or thing to express the connected occurrences. Cf. c. 110. 15; iii.68.7.
New demands of the Lacedaemonians on the Athenians, who call an assembly for final deliberation.
e)pi/: on the occasion of. Cf. ii.2.3; vi.34.59.
e)pe/tacan: c. 126. § 2; a)ntekeleu/sqhsan, c. 128. § 1.

th=s e)la/sews: governed by peri/. On the order, see c. 32. 8; 84. 13.—u(/steron de/: these discussions fall in the winter of
432-1; Ol. 87. 1.
*poteidai/as: cf. c. 64. § 3.—a)pani/stasqai: of raising a siege; so c. 140. 19.—*ai)/ginan: cf. c. 67. § 2.

prou/legon: pro- here and in proagoreu/ein (c. 140. 22; iv.97.18) not temporal ‘in advance,’ but of solemn, emphatic declaration, which accounts for the following mh/, as in c. 140. 25. Cf. c. 26. 20; ii.8.15; iii.66.2; iv.26.14; 80. 12; v.30.31.— to\ peri\ *megare/wn yh/fisma: in c. 140. 20, the simple gen. in same sense. For the facts, see c. 67. § 4. The date of this was probably the summer of 432, shortly after the battle near Sybota. Ullrich, Meg. Pseph. p. 34. —kaqelou=si...po/lemon : in direct speech, ei) kaqe/loite, ou)k a)\n ge/noito po/lemos.
au)tou/s : after verbs of ‘saying’ used for ‘commanding’ the dat. or acc. of the person is admitted as with paragge/llein. Kühn. 475, note 2; Kr. Spr. 55, 3, 13.
a)rxh=|: i.e. the whole Attic confederacy. Cf. c. 67. § 4.

e)pikalou=ntes: cf. ii.27.3; iii.36.8; iv.23.8; v.56.4.—e)pergasi/an: the extension of tillage beyond certain limits. Cf. Xen. Cyr. iii.2.23; Plat. Legg. 843 c; and see on c. 2. 5. Here the tillage of land partly dedicated to the Eleusinian goddesses, partly still in dispute, and therefore a)o/ristos, not yet marked by boundaries. The spurs of Cithaeron, called ke/rata (Strab. ix.1.11; Plut. Them. 13) formed the natural limit. Grote, V. chap. 48, p. 340.

a)ndrapo/dwn u(podoxh/n: such reception proved disastrous to the Athenians in the Decelean war, vii.27.22. Ar. Ach. 525 ff. after his manner distorts the facts. Yet his story of the theft of certain female slaves of Aspasia's has passed into later narratives. Plut. Per. 30; Athen. xiii. p. 570. How much truth there may be in this cannot be told. W. Vischer, Kl. Schr. I. 480 f.; Müller-Strübing, Arist. p. 48.
a)fistame/nwn: as of the Helots, c. 101. 7; iii.54.18.
a)/llo me\n ou)de\n w(=n : w(=n depends on ou)de/n, not on a)/llo, which is opp. to what follows. Cf. viii.67.9; Hdt. viii. 30. Kr. Spr. 50, 4, 10.

au)ta\ ta/de: only this. Cf. v.60.4; vi.37.9.—
o(/ti: see on c. 137. 22.
ei)=nai: so ii.75.5. Often in this sense with a neg.; see on c. 2. 5; 25. 2.
poih/santes: see on c. 67. 11.

gnw/mas prouti/qesan: cf. iii.36.21; 42. 1; vi.14.3; and in iii.38.2, le/gein protiqe/nai, properly to give every one free right of speech. Since here, instead of oi( e)n te/lei or o( pru/tanis, the collective oi( *)aqhnai=oi appears, we have sfi/sin au)toi=s instead of *)aqhnai/ois as in vi.14.4.—e)do/kei: the general opinion was; therefore the impf.; the conclusion follows in c. 145. 2 with the aor. e)yhfi/santo.

e)p' a)mfo/tera gigno/menoi: the use of gi/gnesqai explained on c. 37. 13, and like di/xa gi/gnesqai of c. 64. 6, expressing opposing opinions. The details are introduced by kai/—kai/ (not te—kai/), the clauses introduced by w(s being mutually exclusive. For a similar const., see on c. 27. 7.
xrh/: to be repeated with the following infs. The second w(s, which Kr. wishes to strike out, cannot be dispensed with, considering the opposition of the two clauses.
prw=tos *)aqhnai/wn: this decisive judgment is not added to, but only elucidated by the following words, which are therefore without conj.
parh/|nei: introduces a direct speech, also vi.8.23; 15. 21; 32. 22.

div2.head: Speech of Pericles. Chaps. 140-144.
div2.p: I am now, as always, against yielding to the Peloponnesians, and expect that those who vote with me will also share the responsibility for this policy. § 1. Instead of appealing to arbitration, the Lacedaemonians present demands, the concession of any of which would be an admission of fear. § 2-5.

th=s me\n gnw/mhs: his own conviction, placed thus in opp. to the advice to be given to others, 5, o(rw= de\ kai\ kte(., where the stress lies on cumbouleute/a. th=s au)th=s : cf. c. 127. 9.—e)/xomai: cf. c. 22. 6; iv.66.10; v.49.21; viii.81.2.
mh\ ei)/kein: that we should not yield; depending on gnw/mhs, and representing the imv.

th=| au)th=| o)rgh=|: with
              the same temper or zeal. See 
 on c. 130. 11;
              iii.45.18.

e)n tw=| e)/rgw|: when it comes to action. See on c. 120. 27.—pro\s ta\s cumfora/s: cf. iii.82.18; vi.34.47; Dem. I. 11. Here and in 9=eventus, whether in good or in bad sense. Cf. ii.64.32; Soph. O. T. 33.

trepome/nous: pass., as iv.106.12, gnw/mas being acc. of specification, as in ii.59.4; iv.106.2.—o(moi=a kai\ paraplh/sia: two adjs. for emphasis, without important difference of meaning. Cf. Dem. III. 27; and see on c. 27. 4.
dikaiw=: as appealing rather to duty than to honour; stronger than a)ciw=. Cf. iv.64.7.—toi=s koinh=| do/casin:=tou/tois a(\ a)\n koinh=| do/ch|.
h)\n a)/ra ti kai/ : if after all we do, etc.; each particle helps to reject the probability of failure.

bohqei=n: see on c. 123. 3.—h)\...metapoiei=sqai : or, in case of success, they must not claim a share either in the credit of good judgment. h)/=ei) de\ mh/. See on c. 78. 13; ii.63.3; v.63.11. With katorqou=ntas the subject is changed imperceptibly. See on c. 18. 21; 39. 15. On metapoiei=sqai, cf. ii.51.20.

e)nde/xetai ga/r: for it may happen, even if it is not likely, referring to h)\n . . . sfallw/meqa. See on c. 124. 7. Note that ou)x h(=sson follows e)nde/xetai here (not as in c. 142. 25) from the fixity of the formula.

a)maqw=s xwrh=sai: take an unforeseen course, one not reckoned upon; a)maqw=s here in the rare pass. meaning (not as in c. 84. 13). Grote, V. chap. 48, p. 371, understands a)maqw=s in connexion with dianoi/as in its usual active sense, ‘ignorant,’ ‘deficient in reason.’ There is probably no such play of meaning.— h)\ kai/: kai/ placed as in rel. sentences. See on c. 74. 25.—ta\s dianoi/as: purposes, plans. Cf. c. 84. 17; 144. 5; vi.11.23; 31. 6.—tou= a)nqrw/pou: of a man; art. generic; more usually in pl. Cf. Xen. An. ii.6.10.
o(/sa: in everything which.
*lakedaimo/nioi de/: transition from the general to the particular, as in c. 32. 7, but now, etc.
ei)rhme/non: acc. abs. See on c. 2. 8, and cf. vii.18.14. For the fact, see c. 78. 12.

tw=n diafo/rwn: not diaforw=n with P. and Kr. Cf. c. 56. 2; 78. 12.—
15. e)/xein a(\ e)/xomen: regular description of the status quo. Cf. iv.65.3; 118. 14.
dido/ntwn: cf. c. 33. 25; 35. 22.
dialu/esqai: see on c. 131. 12; here trans. with acc., but intr. in c. 145. 6.
a)pani/stasqai: cf. c. 139. 4.— 20. *megare/wn: short for peri\ *megare/wn, c. 139. 6. Cf. the gen. in c. 129. 12. Kr. Spr. 47, 7, 6.
teleutai=oi: adv. to h(/kontes. See on c. 12. 3; 61. 18.
proagoreu/ousin: see on c. 139. 6.

peri\ braxe/os: cf. c. 78. 1.— 24. o(/per: grammatically object of prou/xontai, taken by prolepsis from the subj. of kaqaireqei/h. Cf. c. 82. 26; 88. 3. Kr. makes o(/per nom. and subj. of kaqaireqei/h, saying that such prolepsis is not found before a conditional particle. But cf. Plat. Phaed. 95 b, tau)ta\ dh\ ou)k a)\n qauma/saimi kai\ to\n tou= *ka/dmou lo/gon ei) pa/qoi. For mh/, see on c. 139. 7.
to\ braxu/ ti tou=to: ti thus added to the repeated braxu/ adds to the notion of triviality.—e)/xei: contains. See on c. 97. 13.

oi(=s: on the rel. in this position, see on c. 68. 15; and cf. c. 35. 15; 69. 20; 95. 21. The forcible effect of o(/per ma/lista prou/xontai, 24, which controls all that follows, appears to permit the pron. oi(=s to refer to the subj. of prou/xontai, and the demand itself to be obj. of cugxwrh/sete. For a similar free ref. of the rel., cf. iv.26.12. The conjecture of J. Steup, o(\ i)/ste (for oi(=s) is, therefore, not necessary.

e)pitaxqh/sesqe: pass., from e)pita/ssein
tini/. See on c. 2. 18.
a)pisxurisa/menoi: short for i)sxurw=s(bebai/ws)a)pwsa/menoi.

safe\s a)\n katasth/saite : will make them understand clearly. Cf. c. 32. 6; vii.44.26. The inf. prosfe/resqai represents the dependent imv., as mh\ ei)/kein in 2. The aor. opt. with a)/n points more distinctly than the simple fut. to the effect now to be produced. See on c. 127. 6. Madvig, Adv. I. p. 309, proposes safe\s e)gkatasth/sete.
a)po\ tou= i)/sou : as equal to equal. Cf. c. 99. 7.—prosfe/resqai: with dat., v.111.23; with pro/s tina, v.105.17.

Therefore a quick decision should be taken. § 1. If war comes, as I hold it to be advisable, it will be found that we have the advantage of the Peloponnesians in means, in varied adaptation to events, and in unity of interest. § 2-7.

The first section gives the conclusion to be drawn from c. 140. § 2-5. With § 2 begins the discussion of points unfavourable to the Peloponnesians, which continues to c. 143. § 2. Then are mentioned the advantages on the side of the Athenians, to c. 144. § 1.
au)to/qen: temporal, as in vi.21.9; prop. ‘from the spot,’ and therefore like w(/sper ei)=xen, c. 134. 14, immediately, on the spot.
dianoh/qhte: see on c. 18. 18.
e)pi/: with dat. causal, as in c. 138. 31.

o(moi/ws: places the two notions on the same level, strengthening kai/ . . . kai/, used as in c. 139. 21. Cf. c. 39. 4.—ei)/contes...e(/contes : though the const. is changed, these partics., as above the inf. u(pakou/ein, denote the obj. of dianoh/qhte. A similar const. in vi.78.5, e)nqumhqh/tw maxou/menos. Sh. supplies polemei=n, which P. suggests. “The intercalated w(s causes the shift, as if w(s mh\ ei)/contes kte(.” B. L. G. P. thinks also that the partics. might depend on some appropriate verb implied in dianoh/qhte, comparing vii.68.3, nomi/swmen . . . ei)=nai . . . e)kgenhso/menon. Kühn. 484, note 4.
du/natai: valet, means, implies. Cf. iii.46.10; vi.36.9. But here only with a subst. as obj.

dou/lwsin (iii.10.15) . . . dikai/wsis (iv.86.21; v.17.11): Thucydidean nouns; the latter ‘a demand based on a claim of right’ (see on c. 140. 7); to which, therefore, the notion of indecent arrogance is given by a)po\ tw=n o(moi/wn e)pitassome/nh. The last words we must take with Kr. and Herbst (Gegen Cobet, p. 51) as masc. (so viii.89.27) though Bonitz, p. 24, and Sh. think neut. The pl. makes this case different from c. 77. 16.
pro\ di/khs: ‘before,’ i.e. really without proceeding by way of, arbitration.

ta\ de\...u(parxo/ntwn : placed at the beginning of the period as the theme of the following exposition as regards both sides. From this must the advantage of one side, ta\ h(mi=n u(pa/rxonta, be supplied as obj. to ou)x a)sqene/stera e(/comen. The following description of the position and warlike resources of the Peloponnesians is so plainly opposed to that of the Corinthians, c. 121, 122, that we can see plainly the literary use made by Thuc. of the thoughts of Pericles, which are no doubt truly stated. See the Introd. p. 44 ff.

au)tourgoi/ te ga\r kte(.: to appreciate the following reasoning we must observe that in § 3 three characteristics of the Peloponnesians of an unfavourable tendency are joined by te, kai/, e)/peita. In § 4, 5, these are illustrated by their necessary results in reverse (chiastic order). Thus: (1) 13, kai\ oi( toiou=toi kte(. expands e)/peita xroni/wn kte(.; (2) 17, ai( de\ periousi/ai kte(. enforces kai\ ou)/te i)di/a| kte(.; (3) 18, sw/masi/ te kte(. repeats au)tourgoi/ te ga\r kte(.

au)tourgoi/ : properly those who use their own hands, not those of slaves, in work; then, from the prevailing application of e)/rga to agriculture, those who till their own land,= gewrgoi/ of c. 142. 18.

diaponti/wn: here only in Thuc.; Xen. Hell. vi.2.16; freq. in Polyb., Dion., Plut. —braxe/ws: for a short time; in this sense only here; elsewhere ‘in brief,’ of speeches. Cf. c. 97. 12; iii.61.2; v.9.4.
e)pife/rein: sc. pole/mous or o(/pla, which occurs in iv.16.15; 78. 23; v.18.12; vii.18.15. If braxei=s (so v. H.) were read for braxe/ws, two unusual features would be removed.

plhrou=n: so v. H. and St.; which gives a simpler const. than plhrou=ntes of Mss. But the other editors, as Cl. formerly, make nau=s as well as stratia/s obj. of e)kpe/mpein, retaining plhrou=ntes (neither ships, manning them), which emphasizes the point wherein the Peloponnesians would naturally come short. This seems preferable.

a)po\ tw=n i)di/wn: away from. Cf. c. 7. 6; 76. 7; 99. 10.—a)po\ tw=n au(tw=n: with. Cf. c. 74. 18; 91. 28. Here only Thuc. uses ta\ au(tw=n for ta\ sfe/tera, ii.20.12; iii.95.14; 107. 12; iv.66.4. The Peloponnesian soldier had to maintain himself; a(/ma calls attention to the difficulty of doing this while farms were left without cultivation.

qala/sshs ei)rgo/menoi: (cf. ii.85.4; iii.86.15; 115. 10) by the superior skill
of their <*>

ai) periousi/ai: sc. xrht<*>atwn; cf. c. 7. 2; 8. 15, referring probably to the reserved fund of the Atherians. See ii.13.25.—bi/aioi e)sforai/: extraordinary taxes, imposed in times of necessity, as the Corinthians had advised, c. 121. 19. In vi. <*> 6 we have bi/aios doulei/a, while in iii.82.18 war is called bi/aios <*>a/s<*>os.

a)ne/xousi : Schol., basta<*>usi, <*>uca/nousi, keep up, support; probably without an exact parallel. Cf. Aristid. Panath. p. 182, pa/ntas a)nqrw/pous . . . th=| kalli/sth| tw=n eu)ergesu<*>n a)ne/xete.

sw/masi: with life and limb; often opp. to xrh/mata. Cf. c. 85. 4; 121. 12. Here to\ me/n refers to ta\ sw/mata, to\ de/ to ta\ xrh/mata, and both are objs. of e)/xontes. In the connected expressions pisto\n e/xontes, ou) be/baion(<*>xontes) the objective thought (to possess a thing) passes into the subjective, ‘to have a confident hope,’ ‘to have no assurance’; and then to\ me/n, to\ de/ are on the one hand to be construed as objs. of e)/xontes; on the other, to be connected closely with the infs. <*>n perigene/sqai and proanalw/sein, with the former as acc. of specification (since au)toi/ is to be supplied there), with the latter as obj. The sense is, “people who till their lands with their own hands are more inclined to risk their lives in war than their property; for, as to their lives, they have a good hope that they will pass safely through the dangers of war; but they feel no confidence that they will not use up their property before the war comes to an end.” Cf. the quite different inference from the same premises in c. 121. § 3, 4.
mh\ ou): instead of mh/ with inf. depending on a negatived verb. Cf. viii.60.5; 71. 5. GMT. 95, 2, N. 1 b; H. 1034. Kühn. 516, 5; Kr. Spr. 67, 12, 6.— 22. au)toi=s: see on c. 6. 8; 48. 9.

a)ntisxei=n: aor. in reference to ma/xh| mia=| (cf. c. 117. 12; vi.91.9); polemei=n, pres., of protracted war.— mh\ kte(.:=ou) du/nantai e)a\n mh\ pro\s o(moi/an a)ntiparaskeuh\n polemw=si, implying that the Athenians were furnished in a quite different fashion. See on c. 91. 28.

o(/tan: introduces a confident reason in form of an uncertain assumption, so long as, while. Cf. e(/ws a)/n, Plat. Phaed. 74 c.—bouleuthri/w| e(ni/: an indirect justification of the Athenian hegemony in opp. to the Spartan demand, tou\s cumma/xous
au)tono/mous a)fie/nai.

ou)x o(mo/fuloi : they are not all Dorians, but some Thebans, Achaeans, Areadians. ou) retained, though after o(/tan, as the regular neg. for contradicting a single notion. See on c. 78. 1.—to\ e)f' e(auto/n: we should expect (cf. c. 17. 2) e(autw=n or e(autou=. Cf., however, iv.28.5; viii.48.41; Soph. Ant. 88. — e(/kastos: after the pl. subj. makes the verb sing. Cf. ii.16.11.—speu/dh|: with acc. Cf. v.16.7; vi.10.15; 79. 14.

filei=: see on c. 78. 5. Here, like iv.125.7 and probably vii.80.12, to be taken impers. This will explain the neg. mhde/n, as in c. 142. 26, after e)nde/xetai. Kühn. 514, 2 b; Kr. Spr. 67, 7, 1.—e)pitele\s gi/gnesqai: only here in Thuc. Hdt., i. 124, who often uses e)pitele\s poiei=n, as iii. 141; iv. 4; v. 107.
tina: designating any object at pleasure, like oi( pe/las. Cf. c. 37. 12; 69. 17.

xro/nioi (c. 140. 21) cunio/ntes: and when at last they do come together for consultation. Cf. the complaint of the Corinthians, c. 69. 8.—e)n braxei= mori/w|: after xro/nioi the ellipse of xro/nou is easy. Cf. c. 85. 3. Also with tw=| ple/oni (on which the force of e)n is continued) xro/nw|, not mori/w|, is to be supplied. But Kr. supplies th=s cuno/dou with mori/w|. St., Jahrb. 1863, p. 478, explains the two expressions, ‘to a small degree,’ ‘mainly.’
para/: with acc., in consequence of; freq. in Dem., as in IV. 11; XVIII. 232, 239.
me/lein de/ tini kai\ a)/llw|: but that of course some one else is taking care.
u(po\ a(pa/ntwn i)di/a|: joined with doca/smati as with a pass. partic. See on c. 95. 16; 130. 3.
The attempt to establish themselves in our country will not help them; and at sea, in spite of all their efforts, they can never match us.

me/giston de/:=o(/per de\ me/gisto/n e)sti, regularly with the art. Cf. ii.65.9; iii.63.10; iv.70.18; 108. 28; viii.76.35; 92. 34: 96. 9; without art. c. 35. 19; vi.69.25. But me/giston may here agree with the inner object of kwlu/sontai; they will experience their greatest hindrance. Cf. Plat. Phaed. 60 a, u(/staton dh/ se proserou=si; and see Kühn. 410, note 5.

kwlu/sontai: fut. mid. with pass. meaning, as e)aso/menoi, 19. Kühn. 376, 4.— o(/tan: see on c. 141. 25.—sxolh=|:
opp. to taxu/, as iii.46.10.
ou) menetoi/: act.; apt to stay,=ou)x oi(=oi me/nein. Cf. Ar. Av. 1620; Dem. IV. 37, oi( tw=n pragma/twn ou) me/nousi kairoi\ th\n h(mete/ran braduth=ta kai\ ei)rwnei/an.
ou)d) h( e)pitei/xisis kte(.: refers to c. 122. 3.
fobhqh=nai: act. sense with a)/cion, as c. 138. 11, a)/cios qauma/sai.

th
 me
 ga/r : the acc. thus placed at the beginning, stands in no exact const. with the following words (see on c. 32. 18); it is neither subj. nor obj., but seems to introduce the matter in hand; as regards the first, viz. the e)pitei/xisis. The second point comes in at 15, to\ de\ th=s qala/sshs kte(. (With paraskeua/sasqai a general subject must be supplied.) Epiteichisis consisted either in the founding of a permanent settlement at a point dangerous to the enemy (as Heracleia, iii. 92), or in the establishment of a fort from which sallies might be made (as Deceleia, vii. 19). So po/lin and frou/rion are species to the genus th
 me
(e)pitei/xisin).
h)= pou dh/: of course therefore. Cf. vi.37.15.—polemi/a|: sc. gh=|. Cf. ii.11.20; iii.58.24; v.64.18.

ou)x h(=sson: the neg. belongs only to the adv. The inf. would take mh/. See on c. 141. 28.—h(mw=n a)ntepiteteixisme/nwn: it is best to understand this pf. not with Cl., of the assurance the speaker feels that the Athenians will be beforehand with the Spartans in adopting this measure, but with Sh. (and apparently St.), “much more in time of war when our city is a counter-e)pitei/xisma against their infant colony.” Athens itself is represented, and not, as Kr. and B. think, other existing fortresses as Oenoe. This allusion to the e)pitei/xisis is probably put into the mouth of Pericles as one of ta\ de/onta (c. 22. 5) by Thuc. writing at the end of the war, with the knowledge of the occupation of Pylos, Cythera (vii.26.10), and Deceleia. Herbst, Philol. 38, p. 581.
bla/ptoien a)/n: after fut. GMT. 54, 1 a; H. 901 a.
au)tomoli/ais: i.e. of slaves. Cf. vii. 27. § 5; viii.40.11.
e)piteixi/zein: depends on kwlu/ein. GMT. 95, 2 a; H. 963.

h(=|per i)sxu/omen: cf. ii.13.18.—a)mu/nesqai: to retaliate, not here ‘to defend ourselves.’ Cf. c. 42. 2; ii.67.28; iv.63.11. He refers to attacks by sea on the Peloponnesus, which also would be attended by katadromai/ and
au)tomoli/ai. Cf. vii. 26. § 2.

ple/on ga\r h(mei=s e)/xomen kte(.: ple/on e)/xomen means as usual (cf. c. 37. 18; 42. 15; 76. 15; iii.43.12; iv.59.7; 62. 16; vii.36.6; viii.99.12), we have the advantage, though here the comp. retains its full const. with h)\ e)kei=noi. The gen. tou= kata\ gh=n, as regards operations on land, is like c. 22. 14; 36. 11; Hdt. i. 32, metri/ws e)/xontes bi/ou: and e)k governs e)mpeiri/as with its obj. gen. placed before it, from our experience in naval matters, as in c. 32. 8; 84. 13; 107. 26; 139. 2, and its article is omitted, as in c. 3. 1; 11. 2; 23. 20; 36. 11; 107. 26.
to\ de\ th=s qala/sshs kte(.: refers to c. 121. 14.

e)cei/rgasqe/ pw: have as yet brought it to perfection. This remark answers so well to the thought of Pericles that the particle pw, though wanting in the best Mss., can hardly be dispensed with; it might easily drop out before the following pw=s.— 18. ou)de\...e)aso/menoi : expressed with the same confidence as 8 above: “we will leave them no time to practise.” The pass. sense is rare. Cf. Eur. I. A. 331; Dem. 11. 16, e)w/menoi diatri/bein; VIII. 59, a)/gein h(suxi/an e)a=sqai.— 19. e)formei=sqai : cf. viii.20.3; pass. of e)formei=n with dat. See on c. 2. 18; 140. 29.
diakinduneu/seian: force their way through. Cf. iv.29.8; v.46.11.
tw=| mh\ meletw=nti: see on c. 36. 3; the lack of practice.
di) au)to/: just for this reason. Cf. c. 68. 9; 74. 3.
te/xnhs: a matter of acquired skill. Cf. c. 83. 4.—w(/sper kai\ a)/llo ti: as much as anything else whatever. Cf. vi.18.38; Xen. An. i.3.15, w(/s tis kai\ a)/llos. Kr. Spr. 69, 32, 13.

o(/tan tu/xh|: at any chance time, without plan. So tuxei=n, pers. and impers., is used in various relative turns to express accidental circumstances of time, place, fact. No doubt a grammatical supplement is to be assumed as original, but is not present to the mind of the speaker. Cf. w(s, o(/pws e)/tuxe, iv.25.7; v.20.9; 56. 15; viii.95.21; o(po/qen tu/xoien, iv.26.20; with rel. pron., iii.43.18; viii.48.36.—e)k pare/rgou: and
e)n pare/rgw|, as a by-work, a holiday task. Cf. vi.69.27; vii.27.20.
mhde\n...gi/gnesqai : sc. dei= from e)nde/xetai. See on c. 141. 28.

Nor will they be able to seduce our sailors by moneg, for the best of them are Athenian citizens. § 1, 2. Our superiority at sea will enable us to endure for a time even the loss of our own country. § 3-5.
ei)/ te kai/: the third point (in reference to c. 121. § 3), after the e)pitei/xisis, c. 142. 6, and the nautiko/n, c. 142. 15.

kinh/santes: see on c. 93. 8. The obj. is the part. gen. tw=n xrhma/twn, like vi.70.20. See on c. 30. 8; 58. 15.—*delfoi=s: without e)n because under the influence of the locative *)olumpi/asin (see Kühn. 336, note). Conversely, in c. 121. 8, *)olumpi/a| is controlled by e)n.
u(polabei=n : see on c. 68. 18.

mh\ o)/ntwn h(mw=n kte(.: this gen. abs. makes the prot. to deino
 a)
 h)=n, being=ei) me
 mh\ a)nti/paloi h)=men. The second e)sba/ntwn . . . metoi/kwn is subord. to the former,=“supposing we ourselves (i.e. citizens of the two lower Solonian classes, see iii.16.6) and the metics went on board and served.”
nu=n de/: but as it is. Cf. c. 68. 14; 71. 8.—to/de u(pa/rxei:=a)nti/paloi/ e)smen.
kubernh/tas : pred., we have citizens for steersmen.
th\n a)/llhn u(phresi/an: the rest of our crews. Cf. vi.31.21. This noun being collective, the adjs. are pl. Cf. c. 24. 9; 136. 2.

kai\ e)pi\ tw=| kindu/nw| kte(.: kai/ belongs to ou)dei\s tw=n ce/nwn as opp. to citizens. e)pi\ tw=| kindu/nw|, in view of the danger. See on c. 70. 10. “Not only on our citizens may we reckon; even the strangers among us will not consent, for the offers our enemies can make them, to give up their own homes.” For, since these maritime places were dependent on Athens, such would be the result of Athenian success; no one who had taken part with the Peloponnesians being allowed to return to his native city. The inf. after de/xesqai, as in iii.53.4; v.94.3. Cf. Soph. El. 1304 with Wolff's note.

e(/neka: (as usual placed between the attendant gens; cf. c. 5. 6; 73. 17) belongs to do/sews, on which mega/lou misqou= depends, and o)li/gwn h(merw=n on both.
12. kai\ ta\ me\n kte(.: transition to the second part of the examination of ta\ tou= pole/mou kai\ tw=n e(kate/rois u(parxo/ntwn, c. 141. 8.—toiau=ta kai\ paraplh/sia: cf. c. 28. 17; vii.78.4.
w(=nper: assimilated from a(/per.

e)kei/nois : though = toi=s e)kei/nwn (cf. c. 71. 9, pro\s au)tou/s) is still pers. so as to justify the dat. with me/mfesqai, as in iv.61.18. Kr. Spr. 46, 7, 3.— a)phlla/xqai: to be free from. Cf. c. 122. 22; iii.63.17; viii.2.21.—ou)k a)po\ tou= i)/sou: more than a match. This enhances the force of mega/la, which, though not indispensable (v. H. omits it, following Cobet, V. L. p. 436), is added to balance w(=nper . . . e)memya/mhn.

h)/n te kte(.: the speaker's purpose was here to detail the mega/la just spoken of. But the first point touched upon, the proper conduct of the Athenians when invaded by land, is treated with so much fulness, that the second, to which the te points, is omitted altogether; and only in c. 144. 1 is the thread resumed with polla\ de\ kai\ a)/lla, to be again postponed to some other occasion, c. 144. 5. See App.

kai\ ou)ke/ti kte(.: ou)ke/ti implies the certain change of a former opinion; “they will not then find it the same thing” (but far worse). Cf. Plat. Gorg. 475 c, a)mfote/rois me\n ou)k a)\n e)/ti u(perba/lloi, ‘it cannot now excel in both.’ Pind Ol. 1. 5, 114. With e)k tou= o(moi/ou, cf. ii.3.18, e)k tou= i)/sou gi/gnesqai, and see on c. 34. 10.
a)ntilabei=n: receive in compensation. Cf. iii.40.13; 58. 7.
kat' h)/peiron: particularly on the Thracian coast.
ske/yasqe de/: introduces an explanatory addition; so iii.58.21; iii.46.4 with ga/r; c. 33. 7 with kai/.
a)lhpto/teroi : less assailable. Cf. c. 37. 20; 82. 21.

kai\ nu=n: used in partial, as nu=n de/ in complete opposition to a state of things previously described; “and though islanders we are not, yet now we must get as near as possible to the islanders' way of thinking.” For dianohqe/ntas, cf. vii.5.15, where ou(/tws answers to e)ggu/tata tou/tou; iii.40.32, geno/menoi o(/ti e)ggu/tata th=| gnw/mh| tou= pa/sxein.

th\n gh=n kai\ oi)ki/as : the land and houses thereon. One art. (as the following
th=s) covers both nouns (see on c. 120. 10), as in 30, 31, both together are denoted by the neut. prons. ta/de, tau=ta.
po/lews : denotes all inclosed by the walls, Athens as well as Piraeus.—fulakh\n e)/xein: a continued fula/ssein. Cf. c. 57. 20; ii.69.3; v.50.10; viii.11.11.
mh diama/xesqai: the neg. mh/ gains weight by its postponement, but does not affect the partic. o)rgisqe/ntas, as Cl. says; though enraged with them.
maxou/meqa: we shall have to fight.— 27. ta\ tw=n...i)sxu/omen : cf. iii.39.43, h( pro/sodos, di) h(\n i)sxu/omen.
ou) ga\r h(suxa/sousi : euphemistic for a)posth/sontai.
th/n te o)lo/fursin : third member, after me\n kte(., de\ kte(., 23.
oi)kiw=n kai\ gh=s : gen. depending on the subst. o)lo/fursin, as ii.51.22. In vi.78.16 the pass. aor. of the verb has the dat.
ktw=ntai: applied by zeugma to tou\s a)/ndras = genna=|, ti/ktei . The same thought in vii.77.39.
au)ta/: referring to gh=n kai\ oi)ki/as. See on 23.

We must not, however, undertake conquests while the war lasts. § 1. We should reject decisively all their demands, convinced that the war must come, and resolved to engage in it in a way worthy of our fathers. § 2-5.
polla\ de\ kai\ a)/lla kte(.: this is the continuance of what begins with h)/n te, c. 143. 15.—e)/xw:=e)/xw ei)pei=n, v.105.17. Cf. ii.46.1.
a)rxh\n mh\ e)pikta=sqai: in addition to what we have, with principal stress on a(/ma polemou=ntes. The same thought and reference to the Sicilian expedition in ii.65.24.

prosti/qesqai: see on c. 78. 3.—ma=llon ga\r...dianoi/as : gives parenthetically the reason of what precedes.—pefo/bhmai: emotional pres. pf. Cf. iv.114.24; vi.34.49. Curtius, Verb. II.^{2} p. 175.— 4. ta\s oi)kei/as h(mw=n: poss. gen. with corresponding adj. Kr. Spr. 47, 5, 1.

a)ll' e)kei=na: referring to polla\ kai\ a)/lla, 1.—e)n a)/llw| lo/gw|: in the speech given in outline in ii. 13, particularly from § 3. But probably this indication has reference to the arrangement of his material by the historian (see on c. 141. 8); particularly so the words e)n toi=s e)/rgois, i.e. “when the story of the events comes to be told.” So also dhlwqh/setai, not dhlw/sw, a)pofanw=, a)podei/cw, because it is the intention of Thuc. expressed in the words of Pericles. Herbst, Philol. 38, p. 564. Pericles could hardly in reality defer an important part of his advice to the time of actual war.

a)pokrina/menoi: the partic. contains the main gist of the sentence, governing all on to a)munou/meqa, 16. The chief points of the Lacedaemonian demands are indicated at the head of three clauses by *megare/as, 7, ta\s po/leis, 10, di/kas, 14. In the first two, the answer is connected with a condition; but as this will certainly not be granted, there is practically a refusal.

cenhlasi/as: usually in pl.; the expulsion of foreigners from Laconia, at the discretion of the Ephors. Schömann, Ant. of Greece, I. 278. Cf. ii.39.3; Ar. Av. 1013.— poiw=si: establish by law, not ‘carry out,’ which would be poiw=ntai. See on c. 77. 3.

ou)/te ga\r e)kei=no kte(.: e)kei=no, the Spartan xenelasy, to/de, the Megarian decree. kwlu/ei appears to be used as in Ar. Av. 463, lo/gos o(\n diama/ttein ou) kwlu/ei (= ou)de\n kwlu/ei). “In the terms of the truce there is as little prohibition of the one as of the other.”
ta/s te po/leis: though unusual for ta\s de/, not to be changed against the best Mss. Instances of this closer connexion of an emphatic word are found in ii.70.12; iii.46.9; iv.32.8 (Mss.).
ei) kai\...e)speisa/meqa : as was not the case (in the 30 years' truce, c. 115. 1).
kai\ o(/tan...bou/lontai : which they will, however, never allow. Both conditions represent with ironical confidence a decided rejection.
toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois: purposely added to prevent the possible reference of sfi/si to po/leis.

e)pithdei/ws : cf. c. 19. 3, where the indifferent politeu/ein follows, while here au)tonomei=sqai of itself neutralizes the sfi/sin e)pithdei/ws. So mh/ belongs in thought to the adv., though construed with the inf.

au)toi=s e(ka/stois: referring kata\ su/ne-
sin to po/leis, each for itself. Cf. ii.15.6; iv.108.18; v.29.22.

ou)k a)/rcomen: we will not begin, whatever they may do. The act., a)/rxein, opposes one beginner of an action to another; the mid., a)/rxesqai, opposes the beginning of an action to its subsequent stages; and so a)rxome/nous implies, “if they begin the war, they will not so easily find the end of it.” pole/mou a)/rxein, bellum movere; pole/mou a)/rxesqai, bellum incipere. H. 816; Kühn. 421, 3.
di/kaia kte(.: so ii.36.1.
h(=sson e)gkeisome/nous e(/comen: so c. 120. 9, with a formal comp. adj.; “the more courageously we accept war, the less eager will they be to attack us.”
perigi/gnontai: result at the end. Cf. perii/stasqai, c. 32. 15.—oi( gou=n pate/res: appeal to example; our fathers at any rate. See on c. 2. 18.

ou)k a)po\ tosw=nde o(rmw/menoi: a litotes, which expresses nearly the same as c. 74. 21, a)po\ th=s ou)k ou)/shs e)/ti o(rmw/menoi. tosw=nde refers to the manifest signs of the power and splendour of Athens.— 23. gnw/mh| kte(.: wise calculation opposed to blind chance, tu/xh|: resolute courage, to/lmh|, to material power, duna/mei.
e)s ta/de : like tosw=nde. Cf. vi.18.32, e)s ta/de h)=ran au)ta/. On au)ta/ here and in 27, see on c. 1. 10.— w(=n: see on c. 35. 15; 69. 20; 95. 21.
The assembly decides to answer in accordance with the advice of Pericles.
a)/rista: adj., not adv. Cf. c. 124. 11. Often with art. Cf. c. 43. 11; iv.74.10.—a(\ e)ke/leue: sc. yhfi/sasqai.

th=| e)kei/nou gnw/mh| : cf. c.
90. 14; 93. 16.

w(s e)/frase: belongs only to kaq' e(/kasta, since fra/zein always implies ‘to set forth details.’ On the other hand, to\ cu/mpan finds its exposition in ou)de\n keleuo/menoi poih/sein, “that they would do nothing upon dictation.”
dialu/esqai: only here with peri/ and gen. Usually with acc. Cf. c. 140. 17; v.80.2.— e)pi\ i)/sh| kai\ o(moi/a|: see on c. 27. 3.
War is not formally proclaimed, but is imminent.
ai)ti/ai de\ au(=tai kte(.: conclusion of the statement of the causes of the war announced in c. 23. § 5. au(=tai is subj. to the pred. substs. ai)ti/ai and diaforai/.
a)rca/menai a)po( : to designate the point of beginning. Cf. vi.99.15; 101. 7; 103. 6.

e)pemi/gnunto: see on c. 2. 5.—e)n au)tai=s: i.e. e)n w(=| ou(/tw diefe/ronto, while these recriminations were going on. Cf. c. 55. 14, e)n spondai=s. The partic. pres. (impf.), ta\ gigno/mena, expresses collectively these proceedings.

a)khru/ktws: (in ii.1.3, a)khruktei/) still without the formalities which are indispensable after war is declared.— 5. spondw=n cu/gxusis: an actual disruption of the truce, though war had not yet broken out. Cf. v.26.30.
